The most impressive thing about Terra
column2: Julian Lynch's third album
column3: is how much stylistic ground it covers while sounding like it barely gets off the collapsible camping chair. Taken as a whole
column4: it's folksy post-rock
column5: but broken down into parts
column6: there are elements of Pharaoh Sanders' meditative jazz; blossoming
column7: Eno-like song structures; George Harrison's Eastern flirtations; the monastic drones of mid-70s German music; and the hippyish optimism of a group like the Incredible String Band. (There's probably more
column8: too
column9: but I'll leave room for the geeks and trainspotters.) Lynch's talent as a writer-- and as a listener before that-- is to hear how all these sounds essentially exist on the same spectrum: They're earthy
column10: unhurried
column11: and occupied by a hypnotic kind of beauty.

column1: Lynch is a 26-year-old PhD student in ethnomusicology
column2: which I weigh more as a biographical curiosity than some kind of key as to why he's able to make good music. He's not particularly phenomenal or technically capable as an instrumentalist (or if he is
column3: he's not rubbing our noses in it)
column4: but he handles everything-- whether it's piano
column5: drums
column6: saxophone
column7: or synthesizer-- without a twitch or fumble. And despite the variety of the instruments
column8: everything on the album sounds like it's riding backseat. If anything sticks out
column9: it's his voice-- it's a little nasal and attention-getting
column10: though I can't imagine him letting someone else sing
column11: either.

column1: Lynch's music is essentially nice
column2: which Pitchforker Joe Colly hinted at when reviewing last year's Mare: ""For how druggy and narcotized it sounds
column3: it doesn't come across as sad or tuned-out."" I'd argue that it is tuned-out
column4: but I agree that it's not sad: Terra doesn't ever feel like it's staring down the void or opening a space for the listener's loneliness (whether it's the warm or the cold kind

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
). Most of the album stays just above resting pulse-- at its most agitated
column2: it's a hootenanny in slow motion. Lynch gets a lot of ""front""/""back porch"" in his reviews
column3: which I generally agree with
column4: but would choose to add: warm weather
column5: fading daylight
column6: bird twitter
column7: and your relaxant of choice.

column1: It's hard to know what to make of Lynch
column2: Matt Mondanile from Ducktails
column3: and other shorts-and-sandal bros that have gotten popular in the indiesphere during the last few years. Terra is almost relentlessly benign. It's not music of struggle
column4: or even music of depth. That's one thing that definitely makes it feel different from its antecedents: unlike
column5: say
column6: Pharaoh Sanders or the Incredible String Band or even Sung Tongs-era Animal Collective
column7: Lynch never stretches for transcendence or intensity. It's the musical equivalent of ""beer in the fridge if you want it
column8: dude."" That's not criticism
column9: just a mild skepticism. Terra's reclamation of a low-stakes domestic space is ultimately more comforting than it is naive-- a counterweight to the impulse to make something glossy
column10: agitated
column11: and
column12: well
column13: young. It makes me think of what one of my favorite composers
column14: David Behrman
column15: said when asked about the therapeutic qualities of his music: ""The world is filled with busy
column16: noisy music-- and noise in general-- and I'd rather contribute to the quieter end of the spectrum."" Terra doesn't just contribute to the quieter end of the spectrum
column17: it reminds me of the boundaries of that spectrum
column18:
and all the sounds murmuring inside them.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16447/homepage_large.fa00ae7d.jpg|Start and Complete|28299.0|About Group|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Domino']|2011-04-26 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:31:52.739943|"

This second record by the players of About Group is an attempt to form order from chaos
column2: to take the essence of their initial open-ended jam sessions and filter it into perceptible structure. Their first album together was simply recorded under the last names of the four musicians involved-- Charles Hayward of This Heat
column3: Alexis Taylor of Hot Chip
column4: John Coxon of Spiritualized/Spring Heel Jack
column5: and Derek Bailey associate Pat Thomas. That record was recorded in one day
column6: with no prior practice
column7: and released on the Treader label in 2009. The four lengthy improvisations were loose
column8: fun
column9: and occasionally whimsical. No one was surprised they returned to their day jobs once it was complete. Instead
column10: they've done some fine-tuning to their methodology
column11: adopted the About Group moniker
column12: and signed to indie behemoths Domino. Start and Complete was also recorded in one day
column13: at Studio 2 at Abbey Road
column14: but this time Taylor handed out demos for certain tracks so his fellow musicians had a vague idea what to expect.

column1: The result is that the rough edges have been shaved down and tamed. Many of the free-floating ideas have been constrained and refined into discipline
column2: all topped off by Taylor's earnest vocalizing
column3: which mines similar territory to his former collaborator Robert Wyatt. In truth
column4: Taylor has a more limited range than Wyatt. But he knows how to find that same buckle in his voice
column5: where it feels like he might slip out of tune at any minute but the weight of emotion he's conveying more than makes up for it. The singer talked about Tim Buckley's marrying of folk aesthetics with astral-jazz projections in a recent interview
column6: but that's only one of many touchstones to surface on Start and Complete. Krautrock
column7: Hammond organ-propelled soul
column8: country-ish guitar plucking
column9: and buckets of primal Brian Eno-eque electronics also play a large role in shaping the About Group sound.

column1: There are 14 tracks on this record
column2: but a handful of them are barely more than a minute or two long. The most impressive feat
column3: considering the limitation they were working under
column4: is how complete the longer songs sound. ""Don't Worry"" is a jaunty pop number that bears a verse-chorus-verse structure and a squelchy wah-wah guitar solo at its center; the following ""With Each New Day"" is a tender ballad punctured by gloops of analog synth that reflect Stevie Wonder's 70s peak on Innervisions. A cursory listen to either track would not reveal their improvised roots to the uninitiated. But sometimes the seams do show. ""A Perspective"" never finds direction beyond its basic piano and organ arrangement
column5: with Hayward's late-entry drums sounding like he's lost for something to do before the track sags to a close. Sometimes fragments of ideas are cut frustratingly short-- ""There's a Way to End This Run of Doubt"" sounds like it's about to flourish into a wonderful soft-pop track before being abruptly cut after just 45 seconds.

column1: But these are minor quibbles-- the bulk of Start and Complete feeds off a rich seam of melancholia that the four players intuitively tap into. The twin highlights are ""Lay Me Down"" and the cover of Harvey Averne/Terry Riley's ""You're No Good"". The former is a tale of troubled love that bridges the sad and the frivolous sides of the band
column2: with its dolorous keyboard textures and yearning vocal stylings set to playful bleeps and bloops. With ""You're No Good"" they return to the territory mapped out on that first record and bolt it to some of the ideas from this one
column3: allowing their blue-eyed soul crooning to filter into choppy grooves and organ soloing that sounds like Brian Auger jamming with Jaki Liebezeit. Occasionally the mid-tempo range that exerts a lockhold on the band can feel a little same-y
column4: and it's surprisingly trad at times considering the experimental background of the players involved. But Start and Complete ultimately achieves what it sets out to do
column5: which is to place a song-oriented frame around another off-the-cuff session by these four disparate talents
column6:
who will no doubt spin off in a completely different direction should About Group reconvene.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16459/homepage_large.47e3abf1.jpg|Music Sounds Better With You|252.0|Acid House Kings|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Labrador']|2011-04-26 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:31:52.908419|"

After a bit of time away
column2: Swedish indie-pop aesthetes the Radio Dept. returned last year with their third proper album
column3: the excellent Clinging to a Scheme. It was a profile-raising breakthrough release for both the band and the Labrador label. But the band didn't exactly sound joyful about the whole situation: The record sounded reluctant and distantly depressed
column4: and various interviews revealed their own distaste for the Internet and self-publicity in general.

column1: Sweden's Acid House Kings are another band on Labrador with an uneasy relationship to ambition
column2: but they sound happier about what they're doing. The band
column3: which features Labrador head Johan Angergård as a member
column4: is back with its first LP in six years
column5: Music Sounds Better With You. Like the Radio Dept. last year
column6: AHK have returned after a layoff with their strongest-sounding record and a newfound vitality. The band's previous releases were low-key and shy-sounding-- when vocalist Julia Lannerheim first appeared on 1997's Advantage Acid House Kings
column7: she sounded reserved and afraid to speak up. There's no stage fright here: the production is bright
column8: the arrangements propulsive and peppy
column9: and Lannerheim and co-vocalist Niklas Angergård sound confident in their newly strong voices.

column1: Considering how long the band's been doing this (20 years and counting)
column2: such an outgoing attitude is a little surprising. ""Maturity"" in popular music is sometimes associated with mellowing and settling down. Very little on this record scans a ""old
column3: but the concept of growing up-- and how those shifts affect the way you live and love-- is a recurring theme. Lannerheim bemoans the 9-to-5 grind and wonders whether it's making her insane in ""(I'm In) A Chorus Line""
column4: while on ""I Just Called to Say Jag Ålskar Dig""-- ""I love you"" in Swedish
column5: of course-- Niklas sends a dispatch to his dearest from a business trip
column6: wondering ""is it really me in the conference room?"" On the charmingly upbeat highlight ""Are We Lovers or Are We Friends?""
column7: he caps a slow dance by admitting that ""I know I've held my hopes so high/ I almost forget that we're gonna die.""

column1: So one way to settle into adulthood is to fall in love-- with love itself
column2: and with your record collection
column3: too. Music Sounds Better With You is a mash note to a wide range of indie-pop-- alternately buzzy
column4: peppy
column5: shy
column6: melodramatic
column7: and grandly sweeping. Each approach is rendered with heart and never feels rote. That album title
column8: it turns out
column9: isn't a reference to the beloved Stardust song; it's about the joy that comes from creating music with others. Acid House Kings might be addressing the sentiment to each other and they might be addressing it to us
column10: but either way
column11:
it rings true.

column3: an essayist
column4: and the frontman for D.C. punk
column5: hardcore
column6: and mod/soul groups Nation of Ulysses
column7: the Make-Up
column8: and Weird War. Add to that résumé a stint earlier this year as the honorary activities director and keynote speaker for a weekend-long
column9: garage rock ""Bruise Cruise"" to the Bahamas. In a Washington City Paper essay about the cruise-- titled ""A Supposedly Punk Thing I'll Never Do Again""-- Svenonius also acted as a sort of self-aware narrative interlocutor
column10: peeking over the fourth wall to ask
column11: ""How's the story going? What's it going to say?""

column1: On Chain and the Gang's debut
column2: Down With Liberty... Up With Chains!
column3: Svenonius played a similar split role
column4: as both performer and critical interrogator of what he might call the entertainment-industrial complex. Songs like ""Interview With the Chain Gang"" and ""Trash Talk"" spoofed music criticism
column5: while other numbers toyed with broader issues of rock'n'roll and late-stage capitalism.

column1: So a follow-up titled Music's Not For Everyone suggests a few possible theses: Do Chain and the Gang long for a bygone era of elitism and cultural gatekeeping? Is it an ironic pronouncement on par with their debut's condemnation of liberty? The band plays it typically close to the vest on the title track. Over a distant
column2: dubby low hum and tambourine
column3: Calvin Johnson intones the titular motto
column4: while Svenonius delivers an archly anti-populist spoken-word sermon: ""Everyone likes to switch on the radio/ But they don't get it... I know you wanna share
column5: but don't."" Other guests include guitarist/organist Brian Weber (Dub Narcotic Sound System)
column6: and Tara Jane O'Neil.

column1: The best songs here are also often the funniest. ""Not Good Enough (Dub)"" is a sing-songy admonition against positive thinking set to tipsy
column2: descending piano chords. ""For Practical Purposes (I Love You)"" is a vaudevillian back-and-forth between two reluctant lovers
column3: with splashes of surf guitar and an alluring female vocal. The self-aware ""It's a Hard
column4: Hard Job (Keeping Everybody High)"" is a faux spiritual
column5: with Svenonius cast as a slave to showbiz
column6: while ""(I've Got) Privilege"" explains
column7: over rubber-banding bass
column8: organ flares
column9: and sultry background vocals
column10: why he's onstage and you're not.

column1: Svenonius is still playing his dual role here
column2: singing pop songs while subtly critiquing their conventions
column3: but increasingly with Chain and the Gang he's laying off the ideology to make room for the grooves. Music may lack the crazy ambition of his previous acts or some of the unexpected goofiness of the Gang's debut
column4:
but it's still a modest pleasure and a fine addition to Svenonius' catalog.

Hooks: Figurines have 'em. Hooks everywhere. Hooks in droves. Looking back
column2: though
column3: it's not so much the hooks themselves that powered their mid-2000s breakthrough
column4: Skeleton
column5: but the propulsive
column6: nearly punkish speed at which the Danish crew blew through them. A song like ""The Wonder""-- with its slightly sour
column7: constantly shifting melody and singer Christian Hjelm's vocal-- was seemingly in danger of losing its center
column8: held together by sheer forward motion. Their latest
column9: the self-titled Figurines
column10: could benefit from some of that old pep; the spiny hooks are still there
column11: but you'll have to sort through an overly fussy batch of arrangements to get to them.

column1: 2007's When the Deer Wore Blue found Figurines tempering their furious rhythms and tarting up their creaky tunes with somewhat symphonic psych-pop flourishes
column2: to its detriment. The songs were adequate
column3: but the adornments and sluggish pacing weighed them down. Figurines marks a partial return to the get-up-and-go of Skeleton
column4: although the tempos have slowed some and the tunes are decidedly less direct. They've still got a distinctive sense of melody
column5: all these odd angles and unlikely harmonies. And the band-- now a three-piece after a couple lineup shakeups-- are inventive arrangers
column6: coloring in their knotty late-90s American indie rock-indebted sound with hints of country-rock
column7: ornate British psych
column8: and lots more. But post-Skeleton
column9: they've grown overzealous in the studio
column10: their zig-zag vocals and too-busy-by-half adornment dampening the impact of the songs.

column1: Take ""Free Today""
column2: the album's highlight; its lilting melody and Hjelm's clear-as-day vocal seem practically radio-ready until he spikes the stellar chorus with a completely superfluous ""ay-yai-yai."" Or the jaunty ""Every Week""
column3: all dressed up in strings
column4: bells
column5: and swirling harmonies forced to duke it out for space with the already busy melody. Figurines' records are full of these unusual turns
column6: but there's far too many this time around
column7: and the constant detours leave the record feeling jerky
column8: its melodies muddled. Vocal lines bend so often many lose their shape
column9: and excessive instrumental textures distract as often as they dazzle; these songs just attempt to do way too much in their three minute spans
column10: and it's enough to leave one longing for the clean lines and fiery feel of Skeleton. And the lyrics don't help matters; Hjelm's have never been a focal point
column11: but Figurines' mark-missing stabs at cleverness like ""I love her like a lover should love her
column12: often placed in the songs' pole positions
column13: tend to stick in your craw.

column1: So Figurines is a record of good ideas running counter to themselves; not a disappointment
column2: exactly
column3: just a bit of a jumble. It shoots for melodic knottiness but catches itself in its own tangles. It's never boring
column4: and there's certainly plenty to wrap your ear around. But these sweet songs just feel like they would've been better served by either pulling back or revving up
column5: not the slathering on that takes place here. Hooks
column6:
Figurines got; if only they could've let them be.

Four years ago
column4: Explosions in the Sky ended their last album with a short (for them) song called ""So Long
column5: Lonesome"". It was pretty and melancholy
column6: not so unlike a lot of their other music
column7: really
column8: but as its title suggests
column9: it had the feel of a goodbye. It seemed so final. But no
column10: the Austin quartet is not done. <i>Take Care
column11: Take Care
column12: Take Care finds the band returning with a renewed focus on its most basic sound: multiple guitars with drums and a bit of bass. The piano that helped lend ""So Long
column13: Lonesome"" its sense of cold finality is gone
column14: and the band sounds confident getting back to the setup on which they built their reputation.

column1: The band famously doesn't consider itself post-rock
column2: but if we're being honest
column3: today they may be the last true exponent of turn-of-the-century post-rock-- unlike Mogwai
column4: they never wandered away from drifting instrumentals constructed around loud-soft dynamics and the contrast between soft guitar tones and pounding drums. Most of their other contemporaries from the period are gone or found dub or electronics or something else. But Explosions in the Sky are sticking to their guns-- Take Care is less ragged than Those Who Tell the Truth Shall Die
column5: but it's otherwise a very similar album.

column1: So whether or not you dive into Take Care will largely depend on your appetite for loud/soft instrumental post-rock. If your appetite for it is boundless
column2: you will be very pleased by this album
column3: and probably also its elaborate artwork
column4: which can be folded several ways to make the interior or exterior of a building. At its best
column5: Take Care is ruled by drummer Chris Hrasky. The guitars tend to hang on particular figures or throw up an e-bowed haze
column6: and Hrasky is the one who can cut through that. On ""Trembling Hands"" his drum kit is the lead instrument as he unleashes Keith Moon-worthy torrents of snare
column7: tom
column8: and cymbal
column9: throwing himself at the guitars as though they were a wall to break through.

column1: One could argue that the music here is predictable and even a bit old-hat. We've lived with this sound for well over a decade now
column2: and we have classics to compare it to
column3: including Explosions in the Sky's own work. And that argument holds some water. But the simple fact is that Explosions in the Sky are very good at this particular thing
column4: and it seems as though no matter how many crescendos and diminuendos they play
column5: there remains a certain amount of cathartic power to their music. The emotion in it is ambiguous
column6: and you can read whatever you want into it-- the soundtrack to your rainy day might be the soundtrack to someone else's overwhelming joy
column7:
and that too is important to its appeal.

Whether a classic archetype like Superman or a self-fashioned alter ego like Bobby Digital
column2: embodying a comic-book figure holds a large appeal in hip-hop
column3: an art form driven by mythology and boasting of superhuman capability. But Daniel Dumile might be the only rapper who based his persona on a supervillain whose origin story sounds uncannily like his own. To recap: While a promising student at Empire State University
column4: Fantastic Four nemesis Victor Von Doom conducted experiments attempting to communicate with the dead
column5: and a resulting explosion completely deformed his face. After roaming the world and studying under monks in Tibet
column6: he built a suit of armor with a matching mask to protect him as he sought the destruction of those at fault for his disfigurement.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Dumile
column3: then known as Zev Love X in early-90s rap group K.M.D.
column4: suffered the loss of his brother and musical partner DJ Subroc
column5: who was hit by a car. That same week
column6: K.M.D. were dropped from their label when the cover art of their Black Bastards LP proved controversial. Retreating from hip-hop completely
column7: Dumile plotted his revenge on an industry that had broken him spiritually. This meant performing in lyricist lounges with his face completely obscured; all the while
column8: his legend grew as bootleg copies of Black Bastards make the rounds. Then
column10: after the release of a couple of singles on Bobbito's Fondle 'Em Records
column11: came Operation: Doomsday
column12: an instant cult classic that now gets a well-curated and altogether fun reissue courtesy of MF Doom's own Metal Face label.

column1: Doomsday was birthed at a pivotal point in rap's trajectory-- at the height of the record industry's boom years. Bad Boy's commercial reign was giving purists plenty to carp over
column2: but it still had crate-digging production and New York rappers in its midst. But soon after
column3: rawer collectives like Ruff Ryders and Ca$h Money subsequently took hip-hop to a more hedonistic
column4: nihilistic
column5: and violent place
column6: with Swizz Beatz
column7: Mannie Fresh
column8: the Neptunes
column9: and Timbaland commandeering a clean break from traditionalist
column10: sample-based production. This opened a lane for underground crews who often defined themselves in opposition of these artists: Anticon and Def Jux sought to completely dismantle hip-hop with abrasive sonics and intimidatingly dense lyrics
column11: while Rawkus and Okayplayer had the magnetic personalities and smooth musicianship to be inside operatives potentially bringing mainstream rap to a more positive place.

column1: On the title track
column2: Doom announces his intent instead to ""destroy rap."" Operation: Doomsday doesn't sound like much of a manifesto
column3: though: You may have come for the street cred
column4: but you didn't stay for any hang-ups about authenticity or the state of the genre. That's mostly due to the sonic template established here
column5: chunky and proudly un-quantized drums meeting samples you might hear at your dentist's office or on hold with your cable company: saxes
column6: flutes
column7: and smooth
column8: vintage synths. While the autumnal
column9: twinkling backdrops of ""Doomsday"" or the Coral Sitar-laced ""Red and Gold"" wouldn't upset tables at your local coffee shop
column10: they provide a truly symbiotic relationship with the paradoxically gruff and calm persona Doom manifests here
column11: where the villainy is more implied than anything.

column1: In fact
column2: for an album that introduced the Metal Face alter ego
column3: it's his warmest and most benevolent work
column4: almost entirely bled of the angrier material that would mark future releases. If anything
column5: Doom is still in mourning here
column6: and there's a palpable sense of loss that rears itself sporadically: Doom imagines rejoining his brother in a tomb ""either unmarked or engraved"" and holds a seance with Subroc on ""?"". For an MC not associated with emotional bloodletting
column7: this record has some astounding moments.

column1: If you're familiar only with Doom's post-Madvillainy work
column2: it might be a jolt to hear just how lighthearted this sounds otherwise: Doom sounds surprisingly young
column3: with a sprightly bounce to his muddy rush of words
column4: and the song structures are among his most traditional. Whether it's the entire-verse hook of ""Rhymes Like Dimes""
column5: Doom and Tommy Gunn flowing like blood brothers on ""The Finest""
column6: or the Monsta Island Czars posse cut ""Who You Think I Am?""
column7: Doomsday is above all else an extremely accessible album. In most ways
column8: Doomsday doesn't work on a heady plane: Topically
column9: the majority of it centers around mic skills
column10: women
column11: stick-ups
column12: and alcohol. Though you're never too far removed from a dazzling run of internal rhymes or an ""oh shit!"" pop-culture namedrop
column13: there's no rhymin' for the sake of riddlin'. Doom's technique
column14: vocabulary
column15: and knack for trivia never asks that you come away impressed. He approaches lyrics the same way he does beats
column16: unearthing gems hidden in plain sight
column17: completely legible without a quick check of Google or Roget's.

column1: Doomsday is often held up as Doom's masterpiece
column2: in part because it's a beachhead upon which he'd begin an astonishing five-year run: as King Gheedorah
column3: 2003's Take Me to Your Leader was a more prominent display of his production prowess
column4: while in terms of sheer lyrical mastery
column5: Vaudeville Villain has few peers. And of course
column6: there's Madvillainy
column7: his crowning achievement. Doomsday does have its imperfections and perhaps more than the LPs to follow. Some of its minor flaws can be read as lo-fi charm
column8: the droning wheezes of Scooby-Doo flip ""Hey"" bleeding into the red
column9: and the ""slow it up
column10: speed it up"" gimmick of ""Tick
column11: Tick..."" outstaying its welcome. And of course
column12: there are the skits and the guest appearances from his Monsta Island Czar crew
column13: which are charming but have little replay value.

column1: The album goes a long way toward demonstrating Doom's incalculable influence on some of the leading lights of current underground hip-hop: Lil B has dedicated an entire album to Doom
column2: the lurching production style of Odd Future owes him a heavy debt (most obviously shown in ""Odd Toddlers"" flipping the same sample as 2004's ""One Beer"")
column3: and K.M.D.'s referential raps and playful yet incisive deconstructions of racial politics are a clear influence on Das Racist.

column1: And while Doomsday is a must-hear in just about any format
column2: I can't give enough credit to Metal Face for the actual packaging of the Deluxe Edition. If there's any feeling of sticker shock
column3: you are definitely not simply rebuying a record. The collection of bonus tracks and beats might get a one-time tryout by non-obsessives
column4: but the lunchbox and commemorative playing cards included here are beautifully designed collectors items that justify the purchase price. The coolest inclusion
column5: though
column6: is what brought us here in the first place: the lyrics

Cam'ron's meandering 2006 Jay-Z diss ""You Gotta Love It"" did little to threaten hip-hop's biggest star. But it did have memorable lines about Jigga's newfound love for chancletas
column3: and
column4: more significantly
column5: announced the arrival of Max B
column6: an ex-con rapper with the gift for a gripping melody. Max went on to much under-the-radar creative success. His widely credited ghostwriting for Jim Jones produced some of the latter's biggest hits
column7: and helped Jones' second LP land on the Billboard top 10. He was the musical mastermind behind underground Harlem super-group Byrdgang. And Max's succession of solo mixtapes
column8: from Million Dollar Baby Radio to Coke Wave to Quarantine
column9: established the rapper as a major talent. His style was gritty and unrefined
column10: yet retained immediate pop instincts. Vigilante Season doesn't move too far afield from his mixtape work
column11: despite being his first official solo LP. This is a mixed blessing. For his fanbase
column12: it includes better sound quality
column13: no DJ drops
column14: and several missing pieces from a career that was cut too short. But while it has some great moments
column15: it doesn't stand above some of his better tapes
column16: and may be an uneven entry point for those not steeped in the Biggaveli mythos.

column1: But flawed as Vigilante Season is
column2: investing time in Max's world can be rewarding. Like the biggest rappers of the past few years-- think Gucci
column3: Drake
column4: even Soulja Boy-- Max fills a space that
column5: a decade ago
column6: would have been occupied by producers. He is as much songwriter as rapper
column7: and musically
column8: Max is an old soul. This is most evident on one of the album's best moments
column9: the sublime ""Where Do I Go (BBQ Music)""
column10: which features dual choruses
column11: one of which interpolates Cherrelle and Alexander O'Neal's 1985 R&B classic ""Saturday Love"". His ear for memorable hooks
column12: sung in a grungy slur
column13: gives his music a hazy
column14: intoxicated quality. Max's lyrics don't have the opulent imagery of Gucci or the poetic minimalism of a rapper like the Jacka. But like both artists
column15: his raps sound cool
column16: with an effortless detachment that disguises musical precision.

column1: His lyrics provide a rough
column2: if familiar
column3: street-rap character sketch
column4: with all the rags-to-riches tales and illegal business that image implies. One of Max's particular innovations was to give late-00s New York a more universal appeal
column5: taking an every-thug street-prophet template and coloring it with the melodicism of classic West Coast or Midwest (think Bone Thugs-N-Harmony) gangster rap. Some of this material would be tedious in most rappers' hands. It is pro-forma street music
column6: and brutality and misogyny are a part of its fabric. His work is engaging not in spite of this-- your mileage may vary for obvious reasons-- but because he manages to suffuse this ugliness with an undercurrent of nuanced emotion. There is no redemption in his words themselves
column7: and little sense of the pain underlying it all. Instead
column8: the record's druggy
column9: mournful tone and melancholy songcraft provide a contrasting canvas for Max's cool remove. In this contradiction
column10: his detachment provides balance
column11: raising the emotional stakes. Max is an actor in a drama larger than himself
column12: an unreliable narrator in a chaotic world. In the tension between song and rapper lies the music's power and truth.

column1: The production throughout-- the bulk courtesy of Harlem producer Dame Grease-- sounds dirty and dilapidated
column2: yet remains open to smooth pop songcraft. His beats are tense and compressed
column3: but tackle a range of moods
column4: from the ambiguous nausea of ""White Lines"" to the wistfulness of ""You Won't Go"". Compared with the freewheeling
column5: capricious atmosphere of the now-classic Coke Wave mixtape
column6: Max's lyrics are shot through with bitterness. His frequent target is Jim Jones
column7: who managed to swindle Max out of his publishing in exchange for bail money. This tone
column8: though understandable
column9: makes Vigilante Season a limited introduction to Max's work
column10:
but it does add a further dimension to one of this era's most underrated rap artists.

UK producer Ben Williams
column3: aka Gatto Fritto
column4: makes exploratory
column5: downright jammy electronic music. His self-titled debut is the sound of someone mining every nook and cranny of his influences for a few really specific sounds: the weird warmth of Kraftwerk
column6: Giorgio Moroder's chintzy propulsion
column7: Detroit techno's stalwart intensity
column8: and the goofball sprawl of soundtrack-era Tangerine Dream.

column1: ""Invisible College""
column2: the boldest and longest track
column3: begins with urgent acoustic guitar
column4: then slowly piles on hand-claps
column5: dance percussion
column6: and whining synthesizers before shifting into a melodramatic breakdown thanks to very Doors-like organs. Then
column7: the feverish guitar floats back into the mix
column8: the laid-back L.A. vibes subside
column9: and the track nervously starts all over again
column10: rebuilding itself and shuffling along for another five minutes.

column1: Most of the album reflects this wandering approach to composition. The obliquely catchy ""The Curse"" and ""Hex"" are followed by ""Grinding of the Brakes""
column2: an atmospheric groove that could've come from the soundtrack to Michael Mann's Thief. That song's moody rhythmic energy is derailed for the slow-growing hum of ""Solar Flares Burn For You""
column3: which is subsequently pushed to the side for ""Lucifer Morning Star""
column4: a pulsing track with a woozy vocoded refrain similar to ""The Curse"" and ""Hex"". The most focused songs end the album: ""My Etheric Body"" is based around breakdance rhythms
column5: and ""Beachy Head"" hypnotically builds
column6: giving its undivided attention to moving forward like a proper dance single.

column1: The songs here are either epic
column2: cosmic disco work-outs like ""Invisible College"" (""Grinding of the Brakes""
column3: ""Beachy Head"") or Balearic pop with vocals (""The Curse""
column4: ""Hex""
column5: ""Lucifer Morning Star""
column6: and ""My Etheric Body""). The one song that doesn't fit into either category
column7: ""Solar Flares Burn For You""
column8: is placed right in the middle of the album. Proper sequencing would stick the singing tracks on one side of this slow-growing ambient track
column9: and the space funk on the other. Instead
column10: the songs are all shuffled around
column11: giving the album an unpredictable
column12: searching energy. The kinder word for what's going on here is probably ""improvising
column13: but ""jamming
column14: though totally uncool
column15: is just a lot more appropriate: Improv connotes constant thinking and rearranging while jamming suggests an intuitive
column16:
lost-in-the-music attempt at transcendence.

Eternal Tapestry's first album for longtime

column8: Digitalis

column14: for Three Lobed: Though its guitar jams were interesting and immersive

column1: Beyond the 4th Door

column8: it seems
column9: its compositional mission. Culled from two hours of improvisation

column13: big clouds of tone wrapping around a rhythmic plod. Without notice
column14: though

column16: an unexpected coda full of classic rock gusto. Things rise
column17: fall
column18: drift
column19: and rise or fall again
column20: finally making for an Eternal Tapestry album that feels like

column1: Don't let the name Eternal Tapestry fool you. This isn't wallpaper music
column2: idle sound meant as background hum. Rather
column3: these five pieces are finite and deliberate
column4: each a smartly designed unit of something more. Opener ""Ancient Echoes""
column5: for instance
column6: is a welcome invocation. It begins just with guitar twinkle
column7: a dozen tiny notes shining in quick succession. The bass joins with a thick tone
column8: playing one melody over and over again. The drums come finally
column9: holding steady beneath it all. A synthesizer offers slow
column10: steady hums
column11: and vocals distorted into textural washes snake through the layers like smoke. In its final minute
column12: it finally builds past a drift
column13: threatening an eruption that never comes. Rather
column14: Eternal Tapestry segue into ""Cosmic Manhunt""
column15: a five-minute interlude of sorts that's slightly more aggressive
column16: with guitars finally growling.

column1: It's also a prelude
column2: or a functional transition
column3: into ""Galactic Derelict""
column4: the album's essential seven minutes. A blues-rock recast
column5: its dual guitars stretch menacingly above drums that bob like buoys in a steady tide. This sounds like the version of Earth that never happened
column6: before Dylan Carlson traded high volume for high precision. The guitars cycle perfectly between proper rock lines and squalls of distortion
column7: so that ascendant riffs bend and blur into something bigger
column8: something more like pure momentum. Ryan Carlile's saxophone lines rip through the background
column9: his miasmatic streams serving as an accelerant for the band's most vital moment. They finally lock into proper rock'n'roll form
column10: with both guitarists soloing like this is their moment in the spotlight. Almost without trying
column11: the track becomes a perfect psychedelic blister-- headstrong and hot
column12: five dudes marching headlong in one righteous moment. Long live major-label debuts
column13:
then: This is the sound of Eternal Tapestry finally turning its instincts into conquests.

Singer-songwriter Cass McCombs named his fifth album WIT'S END
column2: not WITS' END. The distinction is slight
column3: but telling. Because ""wits"" usually refers  to an overall sense of sanity while ""wit"" is more commonly associated  with one's cleverness or humor. And this record does not mark the end of  McCombs' good judgment. Quite the contrary. However
column4: it is not funny or  quick or especially nimble-minded. Over the course of his previous four  albums
column5: McCombs fashioned himself an enigmatic vagabond in the classic  Dylan mold
column6: yet it wasn't until 2009's Catacombs that his enigma started to feel more like a complement than a crutch. While he may have let his wit get the better of him before through knowingly obtuse lyrics and showy arrangements
column7: WIT'S END fittingly leaves those days behind. This is a gorgeous album of despair
column8: the most believable evidence yet that McCombs is living up to his own legend.

column1: Catacombs had McCombs stripping away the instrumentation he had built up around his songs
column2: ending with a bare naturalism that suited him well. And WIT'S END goes even further
column3: its empty spaces and deliberate tempos matching  the album's immense loneliness. To get an idea of how desolate
column4: exactly
column5: consider that opening track ""County Line""-- an inching ballad about severe unrequited love with its own frighteningly real
column6: syringe-filled junkie video-- is the jauntiest thing here. Catacombs highlight ""You Saved My Life"" saw McCombs voicing startling sincere and direct affection; if someone played it at a wedding
column7: grandparents might not blink. The direness of WIT'S END suggests the California-born singer may need some more saving; if someone played these songs at a funeral
column8: sons and daughters would bow their heads solemnly.

column1: So yeah
column2: this record is a downer. But there's rare beauty in such darkness
column3: too-- just look at forebears like Leonard Cohen
column4: Elliott Smith
column5: and  Nick Drake. Or even Edgar Allan Poe. Because
column6: along with its mopiness
column7: WIT'S END is creepy as hell. Its gothic eeriness embodies not Poe's famous tales as much as his more ethereal and lovelorn poems. In the author's 1827 verse ""Spirits of the Dead""
column8: he characterizes the titular ghosts as comforting-- ""a mystery of mysteries!"" And that same infatuation with wispy denouements is all over WIT'S END
column9: but much like Poe's spirits
column10: McCombs' songs bring life to their withering characters over and over again.

column1: Take the seven-and-a-half-minute elegy ""Memory's Stain""
column2: in which a shared  thrift-store sweater leads to ruminations on the unwashable blots that  reside in our subconscious only to pop up without warning. ""Boozing is  the highest aim when spittle won't get out Memory's stain
column3: he sings
column4: before a breathy bass clarinet takes over for the back half
column5: its unique  low tones planting many new memories of its own. And closer ""A Knock  Upon the Door"" tells what could be a centuries-old tale of the  tumultuous relationship between a minstrel and his creative muse. The  song's repetitive verse-upon-verse structure stretches out to nearly ten  minutes
column6: but more oddball sounds-- the baroque
column7: recorder-like  chalumeau
column8: a metallic dink in place of a snare drum
column9: and the ominous door tap itself-- keep things intriguingly askew. ""The Lonely Doll""
column10: meanwhile
column11: holds its story of a drunken louse and weeping woman aloft  over a pillow-y Hammond B3 and brushed drums
column12: the woozy lilt a convincing callback to Leonard Cohen's 1967 debut LP.

column1: In a handwritten note to Stereogum
column2: McCombs recently wrote
column3: ""I know people  get lonely because I do
column4: so that's what I end up writing songs about
column5: how you get lonely sometimes and come up with these big ideas that give  you meaning for a second but then leave you like everything else leaves  you."" The statement is economical and accurate
column6: if overly modest.  Because while there are lots of musicians trading in loneliness out  there
column7: most of them often veer into a self-pity that can leave listeners even more far gone. But the intangibility of WIT'S END makes it a more realistic and reliable companion
column8: its elusive secrets offering a queer  comfort. At the start of his first album
column10: Cass McCombs posed the  question
column11: ""Is it dying that terrifies you
column12: or just being dead?"" On WIT'S END
column13: he's come up with an answer; on ""Buried Alive"" he sings
column14: ""If I'm  alive or dead I don't really care
column15:
as long as my Soul's intact."" He's got soul to spare.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16429/homepage_large.9255a49d.jpg|Revenue Retrievin': Graveyard Shift|1434.0|E-40|['Rap'
column3:
'Heavy on the Grind']|2011-04-22 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:31:54.236248|"

Few MCs release as many consistently great rap songs as E-40. The list of veterans with two-decade careers who aren't reiterating old formulas is even shorter. The Revenue Retrievin' series doesn't just cement E-40's legacy
column4: it extends it. With four full-length LPs released in just under 12 months
column5: the records are less a set of distinct statements than a data dump. It's several hundred megabytes of diverse and wide-ranging music whose sense of purpose is proportionate to its overwhelming size. The two most recent additions to E-40's creative renaissance
column6: Overtime Shift and Graveyard Shift
column7: are only vaguely conceptual. Instead
column8: the idea seems to be for E-40 to create a panoramic view of street rap from as many narrative angles as possible.

column1: The entire project suggests a profound level of confidence from E-40. Although there are tracks that seem like potential minor hits or have unique pop sensibilities
column2: the trend-chasing days of 40's career appear to be over. Even T-Pain feature ""Serious"" seems more like a sincere attempt to highlight the singer's strengths
column3: rather than a too-late bone thrown to a chart-rap audience. These are exceptionally balanced records
column4: moving swiftly through a huge variety of production tics and songwriting styles. The meat comes courtesy of producer 40's son Droop-E
column5: who has transformed the sound of hyphy's brief geographically-linked moment into E-40's personal house production style. But just when it seems like post-hyphy minimal bangers start to dominate
column6: the acoustic bass-driven ""43"" switches gears into noir-ish atmosphere. Or ""My Money Straight"" arrives
column7: a revival of the classic Bay area mob music sound with an invigorating verse from RBL Posse member Black C.

column1: Most of the guests here come from the Bay area; rapper Beeda Weeda has a particularly impressive moment on ""In the Morning""
column2: and rising star DB Tha General stands out on the striking ""Streets Don't Love Nobody"". When it comes to guests from outside the Bay
column3: Bun B and Slim Thug's generically titled ""That Candy Paint"" is redeemed by euphoric production. ""Lookin Back""
column4: which features Devin the Dude
column5: is a nostalgic look at both rappers' transformations from struggling artists to successful career rappers. ""Fried"" features Tech N9ne
column6: one of rap's more under-recognized grassroots success stories. For the most part
column7: the guests seem chosen for their musical chemistry rather than any illusions about getting national club or pop radio play.

column1: But E-40 remains the star
column2: and no matter how consistent the songwriting is
column3: it's his rapping that makes this record work. He sketches memorable characters
column4: like ""My Lil Grimey Nigga""
column5: the stick-up kid who was dropped on his head as a child
column6: or the old ex-con who surprises two young hard-heads on ""Streets Don't Love Nobody"" (""Never know who heavy-duty in the streets pushing weight."") Many of the tracks here are archetypal street rap; ""I Love My Momma"" might seem like a hip-hop cliché at first glance. But E-40's lyrics are full of lived-in lyrical details and humorous asides that give his tracks a human touch
column7: like his mother's ""famous banana-nut bread and 7-Up cake."" On the flip
column8: ""Trapped"" is one of the most devastating tracks
column9: a song that seems especially potent considering the state of America's prison industrial complex: ""I feel bad because all I've got is advice/ And I ain't got nothing to show for it
column10: I'm in here for life."" Although street rap doesn't have the media profile it once had
column11:
the Revenue Retrievin' series argues for the continued relevance of rap music speaking to and from America's underclass.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16452/homepage_large.d86f1adc.jpg|Secret Walls EP|28104.0|The Fresh & Onlys|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sacred Bones']|2011-04-22 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:31:54.518284|"

One of the Fresh & Onlys' most appealing traits is their sneaky sense of versatility; they subtly change styles with the effortlessness of putting their shoes on. And they've been tirelessly productive
column2: too
column3: writing more solid songs in the past three years than many bands have in an entire decade.

column1: One of my personal favorites is ""What's His Shadow Still Doing Here""
column2: from the 2009 LP Grey-Eyed Girls. The song is a relatively laconic take on 1950s guitar pop-- but by no means a straight-line take. A stuttering backbeat stays just a little out of step with overlapping guitars
column3: as frontman Tim Cohen turns a tried-and-true lover's protest-- get over that other guy!-- into a slightly freaked-out observation: ""If he disappeared into the clear/ Then tell me dear/ What's his shadow still doing here?""

column1: On their latest EP
column2: Secret Walls
column3: the Fresh & Onlys further mine that sock-hopping sound
column4: albeit with fewer alterations and a looser
column5: more jammy approach. The production is cavernous
column6: there are quite a few languid guitar solos
column7: two cuts run over the four-minute mark (practically an eternity for these guys)
column8: and the closest thing to a bashed-out rave-up is the stormy closer
column9: ""Poison Wine""
column10: which sounds more like something you'd mope to than mosh out about. In a career that's been marked by slight left turns
column11: the band has pulled its first true 180. It's a jarring change-up
column12: and although they pull it off with remarkable ease
column13: it might not appeal to those taken in by what Pitchfork's Marc Masters referred to as the ""non-stop hit parade"" of last year's excellent Play It Strange.

column1: As a career document
column2: Secret Walls makes more sense when taking stock of Tim Cohen's solo outings. Last year's on-the-sly Laugh Tracks and this year's more expansive LP/EP set Magic Trick / Bad Blood contained a fair amount of ramshackle charm
column3: but they also served as a window to the starker side of his songwriting. There's a similar pallor hanging over Secret Walls; the answer to the question asked in the expansive
column4: hollow ""Do You Believe in Destiny?"" involves heading to an island ""where life will be so lonely
column5: while ""Wash Over Us"" ends a relationship in the stroke of a single couplet: ""I wouldn't want to feel that we are something we are not/ We're puppets and our bodies are painted on.""

column1: The latter song is the strongest on Secret Walls
column2: as its last two-thirds gently unspool into softly played keyboard
column3: strung-out guitar lines
column4: and the sound of Cohen's voice crooning and wailing in the distance. It's a neat trick
column5: and it's one they've played before in briefer fashion on ""Arm's Advice""
column6: the closer to the band's 2008 self-titled debut LP. The F&O's aren't even close to repeating themselves at this point-- hell
column7: based on this release
column8: they could change it up again entirely next time (and knowing these guys
column9: that could be as soon as tomorrow). I wouldn't mind another 180 myself
column10: but if they stay on this bummed-out course
column11:
I won't be mad.

column3: the two men of Bass Drum of Death stopped by the Fuel TV studios in L.A. to shoot a pair of performances. One of those tapings made its way to every corner of the nerdisphere within the 24 hours that followed
column4: while the other more or less disappeared into the void that is the Internet. Though their run through GB City jam ""Get Found"" was perfectly pugnacious
column5: the other stint was backing exactly the kind of guys you want to back if web exposure's what you want right now: Odd Future bash bros and Fat Possum labelmates MellowHype.

column1: Overall
column2: it was a relatively staid
column3: unorthodox showing on Bass Drum's part. While Hodgy Beats and Left Brain shared all sorts of voodoo
column4: Colin (first names only) kept time and John kept his eyes glued to his guitar
column5: hair completely obscuring his face
column6: never to be flipped or tossed. That spooky riff he burrowed into was just right
column7: though. While the attention was clearly drawn to their one-time
column8: insanely magnetic bandmates
column9: Bass Drum of Death find themselves blending into an increasingly crowded field of neo-classicist rock bands specializing in fuzzy assault. Their own label even released a few of their more immediate forebears.

column1: One is Wavves' Nathan Williams
column2: whose initial mixture of blown-out grunge nods and 1960s doo-wop melodies became the first in a slew of young
column3: beach-obsessed artists hiding similar vocal hooks and rhythms in swamps of pedal-driven effects. But Bass Drum of Death's smashmouth approach also saddles them with easy comparisons to an even larger group of garage-rock kin. While they do dabble with the same arsenal of ooooohs and aaaaahs
column4: ooooweeooooh's and shooby doo's that Williams has
column5: this Oxford
column6: Mississippi
column7: duo sounds far more effective when whipping up an evil frenzy much like those of Ty Segall. These guys don't showcase a similarly thorough ear for songwriting
column8: but as far as rock'n'roll feats of strength go
column9: GB City
column10: their debut
column11: registers quickly.

column1: Its first half in particular is exactly what you want to throw yourself into at a show. ""Nerve Jamming"" opens shop with a set of puckered power chord shifts every bit as stomach-churning as those in the titular track that follows. The aforementioned ""Get Found"" has snarl to spare here
column2: while ""Velvet Itch"" features a devil-horned
column3: almost industrial rumble to it in which John's vocal performance catches fire. ""I talk to Elvis
column4: I talk to Elvis in my sleep
column5: he scowls. ""He said I'm cracked out/ Oh yeah
column6: I'm cracked out/ But at leeeeeast
column7: I got no-where to be."" While GB City's B-Side feels flimsy and empty by comparison
column8: it also features the album's biggest hook (that of ""Young Pros"") and a song that feels like it could be this band's calling card: ""Spare Room"". It ganks that diamond-coated Phil Spector drumbeat we all know and slows it down to a hopeless crawl. They start tying it up in ropes of guitar and then-- low-end arrives in the form of a nasty
column9: ridiculously feral five-note bass run that cracks the song open. What's inside is nothing but squall and darkness
column10:
not unlike everything their name suggests but only occasionally delivers.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16461/homepage_large.449d93cc.jpg|Mass Dream|29634.0|TV Ghost|['Rock'
column2: 'Experimental'
column4: Cold Fish
column5: is a maelstrom-- 10 hectic songs ripped out in 25 minutes. Stuffed to the seams with wiry guitars
column6: trembling keyboards
column7: crashing beats
column8: and Tim Gick's mad-man warble
column9: it has the creepy tension of a post-punk haunted house where the Cramps
column10: the Scientists
column11: or Pere Ubu might leap out from the shadows at any moment. The band deftly balances precision and abandon-- every moment sounds lunatic and unhinged
column12: yet no track collapses into complete anarchy.

column1: That abandon has subsided a bit on Mass Dream
column2: which doubles the length of its predecessor despite having only one more track. That's by design-- Gick says that his intent was to ""space things out more
column3: let the songs breathe."" And while I miss Cold Fish's farther-flung moments
column4: the band has countered that loss with songs that are deeper and more open. Now
column5: along with all the post-punk echoes rattling around
column6: unexpected reference points pop up. At times I hear the enervated drama of Echo & the Bunnymen's Ian McCulloch
column7: or the stridency of Ian Svenonius during his Nation of Ulysses days. And TV Ghost prove as adept at stark dread as they are at fevered bedlam
column8: mirroring the the spooky air of Women's Public Strain.

column1: Much of that air comes from Gick
column2: whose vocal cracks and squalls guide each track toward a particular emotion
column3: boldly coloring the sonic elements swirling around him. The resulting hues are often bleak-- as he puts it
column4: ""I look at the world around me
column5: take what I don't like about it
column6: and use that in my songs."" But that desolation produces not resignation or depression
column7: but a kind of desperate
column8: coursing energy. Much like a scary movie
column9: TV Ghost's stressed-out tales don't get you down
column10: they get your heart beating. And even if the pulse of Mass Dream is not as consistently maxed-out as that of Cold Fish
column11: it's no less excited.

column1: The example I keep coming back to is a cut buried deep into the LP
column2: ""The Degradation of Film"". It opens with ominous chords that conjure a creaky organ echoing through an abandoned castle. Those chords threaten droney hypnosis
column3: but the band pushes back against somnambulism
column4: their guitars tracing dementia while Gick does his best Vincent-Price-on-helium shiver. Still
column5: the chords persist
column6: tugging at the band like quicksand. It's a tricky balance
column7: one that TV Ghost could've easily steamrolled with speed and volume. But Mass Dream isn't that simple. Its power may sometimes be primal
column8:
but its effect is pretty complex.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16440/homepage_large.d79b71cd.jpg|EPs 1991-2002|168.0|Autechre|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2011-04-21 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:31:55.061133|"

This might seem like the most daunting release of 2011
column2: the very definition of for-fans-only. After all
column3: Autechre made their name by separating those dabbling in electronic music from the truly hardcore. Compared to the rest of Warp's early post-rave/home-listening acts
column4: they were challenging from the start
column5: and their releases only grew more complex and less user-friendly as the years went on. This box set collects 47 tracks from 11 years of Sean Booth and Rob Brown's hyper-productive output. If one EP of Autechre's dense sound art seems forbidding
column6: try about a dozen of them.

column1: And yet. Autechre's late-career complexity is in no way overstated. Albums like 2001's Confield sometimes threaten to abandon form and structure entirely for the pure delight of manipulating digital noise into an endless array of different shapes. Other records are so madly patterned
column2: like multiple electro tracks layered into a writhing whole
column3: that following the duo's logic can be nearly impossible. But perhaps nodding to their roots in club sounds
column4: or having fun with the very idea of this sort of band releasing ""singles
column5: Autechre's EPs have offered some of their most accessible music
column6: even if you have to stretch the definition of ""accessible"" to the breaking point. Dizzying as it may be as a whole
column7: this box is in a weird way one of the better introductions to the duo's work.

column1: The earliest EPs here
column2: 1991's Cavity Job and 1994's Basscadet
column3: aren't far off from labelmate Aphex Twin's first forays into tweaked acid. ""Cavity Job"" opens with a blast of dental drill noise as abrasive as Whitehouse
column4: but quickly launches into a frantic rave tune that would have fit just fine at the era's more hardcore clubs. The four ""Basscadet"" mixes are where things start to get hairy-- moving from jittery techno to haunted ambient-- but the duo's pulsing funk has yet to be shattered the way it soon would be. The average set of human feet may object to the logic of these beats
column5: but they sure are head-nodders. And as far afield from the genre as they would eventually get
column6: Autechre's love for early hip-hop's trunk-rattling low-end and turntable gymnastics are all over these EPs. ""Goz Quarter"" from 1997's Envane EP plays like a playful scratch record made from scraps of digital noise. They're reminders of a time when the borders of hip-hop and what was known (for better or worse) as IDM weren't so ruthlessly policed.

column1: So there's plenty of pleasure here
column2: but plenty of difficulty as well. As the years went on
column3: Autechre became masters of bright melodies that they then drowned in distortion-- their own abstract variation on ""noise pop."" 1999's EP7 might be their most beautiful release
column4: but it's also one of their most disorienting
column5: built from what seems like several hundred gigs worth of glittering little chunks of sound.  From then on
column6: Autechre's music would be about things endlessly falling apart and rebuilding themselves and falling apart again in spectacular fashion. On ""Gantz Graf""
column7: one of their most convoluted beat-and-riff creations becomes subjected to so much abuse that it collapses into screaming noise
column8: as if the track itself is pleading for relief. There's a lot more to listen to in Autechre's later music
column9: and a lot less to hang onto. The music constantly mutates
column10: so it's hard to get bored
column11: but if your attention drifts
column12: it becomes ever harder to figure out how you got from one minute to the next. It's no wonder they were embraced as much by the free improv community around the turn of the millennium. It's music that invites a listener to boggle at its moment-to-moment inventiveness or tune it out entirely.

column1: What's really surprising
column2: listening back to these EPs after so many changes in techno style
column3: is how fresh they still sound. Autechre were often praised for the ""alien"" quality of their music
column4: the way they processed and distorted their synth sounds and programmed beats until they became unfamiliar
column5: and in retrospect it was the best thing they could have done to ensure their music didn't date itself. Only the Cavity Job sounds truly bound to the era of its release. And even the elements that became IDM clichés
column6: like all those thin
column7: tiny beats bouncing madly around the mix
column8: are underused enough now that younger listeners might just hear them as new. So many of the duo's peers have disappeared from the 21st century musical conversation
column9: but Autechre persist. That's partly because they're workhorses who never stopped putting out records
column10: but mostly
column11:
it's because even their most fearsome records have a striking beauty and weird compulsive listenability that few of their contemporaries could match.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16441/homepage_large.ae879071.jpg|Benefit for the Recovery in Japan|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Antiopic']|2011-04-21 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:31:55.240044|"

On March 11
column2: a devastating earthquake and tsunami hit Japan
column3: killing at least 13
column4: 000 people and spawning an ongoing nuclear crisis. In the month-plus since that tragedy
column5: musicians worldwide have been trying to help. Along with benefit concerts
column6: charity auctions
column7: and other fundraisers
column8: the music world's Japanese relief efforts have also included a few compilation albums
column9: including the classical-oriented Classics for Japan - Music for Healing and hit-parading Songs for Japan.

column1: Benefit for the Recovery in Japan is a different kind of benefit compilation. Clocking in at nearly five hours
column2: this sprawling 64-track set sees no contradiction between disaster relief and musical adventurousness. Credit Antiopic label co-heads David Daniell and James Elliott
column3: experimental electronic musicians who picked the album's tracks with help from Regina Greene (whose Front Porch Productions books shows for many of these artists)
column4: fellow electronic experimentalist Greg Davis
column5: and Thrill Jockey founder Bettina Richards. Their choices span ambient drone
column6: fleet-fingered folk
column7: and leftfield rock
column8: with an artist lineup that should have many a music nerd drooling on their tattered back issues of The Wire.

column1: Every cent of the $15 you spend on Benefit will go to Civic Force
column2: a Japanese nonprofit emergency responder
column3: so the cause is clearly worthy. At less than a quarter per track
column4: this mp3-only album offers pretty good value for the money
column5: too
column6: and if you're skeptical you can stream the whole thing. As for musical enjoyment
column7: I definitely don't recommend trying to digest it all in one sitting
column8: and the collection sometimes lapses toward seemingly aimless minimalist exercises more likely to please formally educated musicians than typical music listeners. But if you're looking for a thoughtfully conceived survey of the avant-garde underground
column9: please
column10: look no further.

column1: A somber electroacoustic instrumental from Austrian composer/producer Christian Fennesz opens the compilation
column2: which gives you a pretty good indication of what's to follow. These are thickly textured tracks
column3: sometimes orchestral in scale
column4: which often achieve their emotional effects more through their incredibly detailed sonic palettes than through anything you can transcribe in a songbook. It's a lot to take in
column5: but give it time and the best part about this release is how it allows you to stumble into so many different
column6: miniature sonic worlds
column7: one after the other: the hypnotically layered vocals and bass-heavy pulse of School of Seven Bells
column8: the barely there piano and whispery singing of Grouper
column9: the heavily fucked-with 1980s soft-rock vibes of Matthewdavid
column10: the squalling lushness of Lawrence English
column11: the icier hum of Ben Frost
column12: the articulately jagged punk of the Ex
column13: and the shaggy improv of Jackie-O Motherfucker. Benefit is an appropriately cosmopolitan affair.

column1: The names perhaps most familiar from the indie rock festival circuit are not necessarily the ones responsible for Benefit's most rewarding tracks. An arty contribution from TV on the Radio's Tunde Adebimpe
column2: working with Stars Like Fleas' Ryan Sawyer under the cheeky moniker Stabbing Eastwood
column3: is probably best left for completists (and fans of hilarious growling). Deerhunter/Atlas Sound man Bradford Cox
column4: collaborating with White Rainbow's Adam Forkner as Bradley & Geofrey
column5: gives Das Racist fodder for some future update of their reggae-voice satire ""Fake Patois""; you get the sense Cox has a hard drive full of casual little experiments like this he could post on his blog. Then again
column6: there's an appealing frailty to the Arthur Russell-ish chamber-pop of ""In the Hollows""
column7: by Dirty Projectors bassist Nat Baldwin. Akron/Family's ""Deep Kazoo"" does
column8: indeed
column9: get in deep with kazoo; Bear in Heaven's tenderly plainspoken ""The Days We Have"" is a glistening electro-folk pleasure that could warrant a Cornelius remix.

column1: But Benefit isn't really about cherry-picking hits. There are other compilations for that. It's best if you let this one wash over you
column2: accepting the breadth and depth of its varied sonic experiences with
column3: yeah
column4: an open mind and open ears. Plenty of listeners could get their first exposure to luminaries like Rhys Chatham (who closes the set's first half on an ambient
column5: meditative note)
column6: Sam Prekop (though the Sea and Cake frontman's blips and bloops here are certainly no Oui)
column7: or the Boredoms (leader Shinji Masuko's airy
column8: ethereal ""Botsuon""). Or they could be introduced to much-loved younger talents
column9: from the densely intricate guitar playing of James Blackshaw to the hauntingly immersive sound fields of Tim Hecker to the spaced-out electronic innovations of Oneohtrix Point Never. Look
column10: I'm dubious about benefit compilations in general
column11: and the wanky wind-chimes avant-garde scene in particular. But if good things can ever come out of horrible events
column12:
what Antiopic has accomplished here is surely worth getting behind.

"|15329.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15329-benefit-for-the-recovery-in-japan/|7.7|Marc Hogan

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16455/homepage_large.cf096c0a.jpg|Jonny|29312.0|Jonny|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Merge']|2011-04-21 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:31:55.424566|"

Jonny is Norman Blake and Euros Childs
column2: two 90s indie rock lifers with very different songwriting styles. Childs
column3: whose psychedelic outfit
column4: Gorky's Zygotic Mynci
column5: called it quits five years ago
column6: has continued to churn out similarly charming
column7: distinctly unpredictable pop songs under his own name since. He's your wild card. Blake
column8: whose vocal harmonies and melodic skillset you may have heard by way of his work in Teenage Fanclub
column9: has been equally active over the years
column10: though rarely on his own. He's a glue guy. Together they form what can (in certain circles) be loosely termed as a supergroup. But Jonny
column11: their first full-length as a duo
column12: doesn't approach that construct with much of a straight face. Although they've played and recorded together in the past
column13: here they sound as though they're still finding out how to best combine their quirks.

column1: Take for instance pub-rocking opener ""Wich is Wich""
column2: a sub-two-minute boogie that functions more as curio than attention-grabbing salvo. While the groove is sturdy
column3: its relatively short length doesn't allow it to leave much of a dent at all. It feels instead like a song that never quite became a song. While you'll find equally
column4: confusingly short scraps on the tail end of Jonny (see: the country shuffle of ""I'll Make Her My Best Friend"")
column5: there's enough great songwriting at play here to make that kind of wham-bam-on-to-the-next approach all the more frustrating. On tape they can be just as good as they are on paper. The burble and harmonies of ""Candyfloss"" is proof of that.   Merge
column6: their label home
column7: has hailed their union as ""the advent of an irresistibly infectious new strain of psychedelic pop."" But Jonny retains the feel of old
column8: familiar parts being slapped together to form something old and familiar. There's a good reason why these two have followings on their own.

column1: Euros Childs' stamp on these songs is particularly strong
column2: his Welsh-accented vocal tics and corkscrewing organ flourishes much more obtrusive in the mix than Blake's far more palatable contributions. In fact
column3: the latter's long-developed ear for vocal harmonies is responsible for not only smoothing a lot of Jonny's edges
column4: but also corralling his bandmate for some genuinely beautiful vocal performances. It's not difficult to discern who penned what throughout
column5: but like the aforementioned ""Candyfloss"" (also
column6: ""English Lady"" and ""Circling the Sun"" and ""The Goodnight"" and ""Never Alone"" and so on)
column7: Blake's gilded harmony arrangements lend a much-needed constant to an affair that sheds its skin from track to track. Aside from two very melodically inclined minds joining forces
column8: what spurs Jonny to succeed in its own strange way is the audible heart and enthusiasm with which they try everything here. Sandwiched between what sound to be two more experiments in need of more time
column9: ""Cave Dance"" is an experiment that drones on for 11 minutes. Eleven. From red-blooded rock circus to synth dream to Fleetwood Mac-indebted krautrock coda
column10:
it goes on and on and on. They're having so much fun.
