column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16456/homepage_large.632ac3ea.jpg|In and Out of Youth and Lightness|5106.0|Young Widows|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Temporary Residence']|2011-04-21 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:31:55.584917|"

Back in the 1990s
column2: there was a particular male vocal style that pretty much ran shit in underground rock: A clenched
column3: detached
column4: sneery tough-guy sing-speak
column5: a swaggering couldn't-care-less nasal honk that spoke to passivity and aggression in equal amounts. Girls Against Boys
column6: Morphine
column7: Urge Overkill-- these bands had little in common musically
column8: but they all worked some variation on that particular vocal style. For whatever reason
column9: it's gone almost extinct in indie rock over the past 10 years or so
column10: but Young Widows frontman Evan Patterson is the rare guy who still sings that way. And for those of us who spent way too much time in our younger years devouring issues of Alternative Press and Magnet
column11: that sort of voice is enough to bring back some powerful memories
column12: regardless of what Patterson might actually be saying.

column1: Ever since Young Widows rose from the ashes of the Louisville post-hardcore band Breather Resist in about 2006
column2: most of their best moments have come from that sort of memory-shock: <i>Oh yeah
column3: this is how bands used to get shit done. Their rhythm section churns and sputters like pigfuck never went away. Patterson's guitar tone has a clangor that we don't hear too often anymore. The particular sort of tense groove that the band specializes in-- it's a relic of a bygone era. But after three albums of this stuff
column4: Young Widows haven't really made much of an impression on their own. They sound dangerous
column5: but it's danger by association.

column1: The band's debut album
column2: 2006's Settle Down City
column3: remains their greatest moment-- a bracing blast of spilt-beer stink and ashtray grime. In and Out of Youth and Lightness finds the band switching up their style
column4: stretching out into longer songs and going more for atmosphere than for brooding rock fury. At times
column5: Patterson seems to strive for a certain Nick Cave depravity in his vocals and in his lyrics
column6: and he never gets there. Some of his lyrics just sound silly: ""Shakin' that fire in your fist. Shakin'! Shakin'!"" The band used to keep a tight balance between tension and release
column7: but moments of release rarely come on this album
column8: and so the tension they work so hard to build never registers the same way. The album stretches nine songs over 48 minutes
column9: and few of these songs needed to be as long as they are.

column1: Still
column2: these guys are all great musicians with serious chemistry and a strongly defined idea of what they want to be doing
column3: so they can still conjure some serious intensity even when they're reaching for something that doesn't quite work for them. When Patterson stops singing and the band disappears into a gnarled
column4: ugly groove
column5: they become a potent force. And when they keep things hard and short
column6: as on album standout ""Future Heart""
column7: they still make a bluntly effective unit. Now that indie rock has moved on from these sorts of forbidding sounds
column8: there's a hole out there that needs filling. And when the band really locks in
column9: they fill it. Even if their whole style is essentially a throwback
column10: there's plenty of room out there for throwback done right. But on too much of Youth and Lightness
column11:
they're not the machine they could be.

"|15342.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15342-in-and-out-of-youth-and-lightness/|5.7|Tom Breihan

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16454/homepage_large.316ae847.jpg|Canary|5711.0|Southeast Engine|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Misra']|2011-04-21 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:31:55.751020|"

Southeast Engine hail from Athens
column2: Ohio
column3: a former coal-mining town that
column4: in addition to resting in the foothills of the Appalachians
column5: has popped up on a few ""Most Haunted Cities in America"" lists. That might scan as a bogus bullet point
column6: but given the subject matter of his outfit's fifth full-length
column7: frontman and chief songwriter Adam Remnant seems to have a very strong attachment to the history around him. Canary is a 1930s museum piece and concept album centered around one Appalachian family trying to shoulder its way through the Great Depression. It's built on traditional American musics like gospel and bluegrass and blues-based rock
column8: but it finds its spiritual roots in protest. And while its sonics and song structures are about as fresh as its subject matter
column9: its attention to detail and local focus make for a singular achievement. That and they find the strength to see each moment quake.

column1: Because despite the yellowed nature of Remnant's lyrical work (the word ""kin"" makes an appearance as does the Devil and the phrase ""give a lick"")
column2: throaty
column3: contemporary folk-rock signifiers abound. In fact
column4: his rolling vocal styling bridges the gap
column5: fittingly
column6: between Dr. Dog's Scott McMicken and Conor Oberst. While opener ""Curse of Canaanville"" saunters in at a pace in line with the former's band
column7: it eventually erupts into a steam-powered surge not unlike one of Jeff Mangum's breaks. Elsewhere
column8: ""Cold Front Blues"" cribs some melody from Oberst's early wailer ""Something Vague""
column9: going a bit further to take on the torque of his wild-eyed delivery. ""Oh but Vera don't get sad/ I know things these days are bad
column10: Remnant croons. ""They may take our land
column11: our home/ All kinds of worse-case scenarios!""

column1: But it's not always such a downer. Though Canary clearly suggests that yesteryear's nightmares aren't that different from today's
column2: it also speaks with a great deal of hope. The titles of ""New Growth"" and slightly psychedelic ""At Least We Have Each Other"" alone communicate that. That said
column3: one needn't have studied Greil Marcus and the Band or spent serious time at the Smithsonian to really chew on the images and roots at work here. All in all
column4: this is pastiche that plays to very clear strengths. Whether it's fingerpicking and fiddles (""Mountain Child"") or piano-fueled strummers like the gorgeous ""Ruthie""
column5: these arrangements and melodies prove Remnant's close attention to detail provides a great deal of support. While few really stand out on their own
column6: together they lean on one another to impressive effect. As a result
column7:
it has the feeling of an album that really holds together. Now that's an anachronism.

"|15345.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15345-canary/|7.3|David Bevan

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16422/homepage_large.94662d65.jpg|Return of 4Eva|28901.0|Big K.R.I.T.|['Rap'
column3: Mississippi's Big K.R.I.T. is pretty good but nothing amazing: With the empathetic warmth in his sticky drawl
column4: he makes a convincing Southern everyman
column5: and he has enough rhythmic dexterity to really stick to beats. On the new
column6: free-for-download mixtape Return of 4Eva
column7: he invests the cars-and-girls talk he's already been doing with a sort of conscious-rap sensibility; toward the back end of the tape
column8: he leaves behind boasting to talk about poverty and racism and materialism
column9: sometimes coming up with a truly evocative line. But he's also lost some of the snarl that made his delivery so great on tracks like last year's Curren$y/Wiz Khalifa collab ""Glass House"". He can get a bit clumsy when he tries to transform himself into some kind of loverman. And even in his strongest moments
column10: he still sounds a whole lot like T.I. without much of T.I.'s effortless
column11: charismatic confidence. He could still become an excellent rapper
column12: but it hasn't happened yet.

column1: As a producer
column2: though
column3: he's good enough that he could be half a Ying Yang Twin and his music would still be well worth the hard-drive real estate. On last year's free online album K.R.I.T Wuz Here
column4: he marked his place in a lineage of organic
column5: soul-sampling Southern rap producers that includes giants like Pimp C and Organized Noize
column6: making hard-thudding personalized version of the tracks he must've heard growing up. On Return of 4Eva (still free
column7: still online)
column8: he progresses even further
column9: turning his sound into a sleepier
column10: woozier flutter-- a comfortable bed for his voice to sink into. Refracted versions of guitar and organ sounds wind their way through oceans of bass
column11: all building into a perfectly evocative
column12: nostalgic sound. Every once in a while
column13: he'll come with something harder
column14: like the skeletal keyboard bloops of ""My Sub"" or the horn-and-organ thunder of ""Sookie Now"". But for the most part
column15: he focuses on turning classic Southern rap sounds into comfort-food background music-- the sort of thing that sounds absolutely gorgeous in a car on a warm spring afternoon
column16: when you're driving slow with the windows open. There's a reason that Return of 4Eva dropped just as the weather was getting warmer.

column1: In a sense
column2: Big K.R.I.T. is like a hip-hop version of a group of rock revivalists. The same way that
column3: say
column4: Band of Horses turns dusty Neil Young guitar epics into something simple and comforting
column5: K.R.I.T. trades on our collective memory of mid-90s Southern rap and turns that into brilliant invitations to nostalgia. At the end of ""Sookie Now""
column6: we hear a sample of Don Draper philosophizing in ""Mad Men"": ""There is the rare occasion when the public can be engaged on a level beyond flash-- if they have a sentimental bond with the product."" K.R.I.T. included that sample to draw attention to his younger rap peers; he's the type of old soul who still complains about ""ringtone rappers"" sometimes. But it could just as well describe the Pavlovian attachment some of us have to a beautifully looped-up soul sample. And Return of 4Eva is absolutely packed with cascading looped-up falsetto harmonies. Sometimes
column7: it feels like a set of variations on the beat for OutKast & UGK's ""Int'l Players Anthem (I Choose You)"". And since ""Int'l Players Anthem"" is one of the greatest rap songs of the past 10 years
column8: that's no complaint.

column1: Return of 4Eva doesn't have too many guests
column2: but most of the people who do show up are Southern rappers who peaked maybe seven years ago: Chamillionaire
column3: David Banner
column4: even Ludacris on a remix of last year's ""Country Shit"". All those guys sound reinvigorated; K.R.I.T.'s amber-hued production gives them a context that just works for them. And one of the real revelations here is K.R.I.T.'s own singing voice. Taking on a few hooks himself
column5: he's got a thoughtful
column6: bluesy coo that seems custom-built for his tracks. It's fun to imagine what might happen if K.R.I.T. teamed up with an honest-to-god great rapper for a full-length. He and Yelawolf have been teasing a mixtape together for a while
column7: and that could be incredible. But for now
column8: Return of 4Eva
column9: all glowing warmth and lazy-afternoon drift
column10:
stands as one of the finest rap releases of 2011.

"|15312.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15312-return-of-4eva/|8.2|Tom Breihan

Until last year's Rough Trade-released Black Noise
column2: I had a difficult time thinking of Pantha du Prince as a normal artist. Minimal electronic music
column3: mind you
column4: is not rock when it comes to larger-than-life presences: Most of these guys look like bike messengers with better connections at the Apple store. But Pantha
column5: who to that point had released two albums of bell-laden
column6: dreamlike productions
column7: seemed more like a techno vampire (I'll admit that his spooky/scary haircut had something to do with this). To date his peers have treated his work like you'd treat a historical structure: hands-off. Remixes and collaborations have been thin on the ground; for the most part
column8: we aren't used to hearing Pantha's singular style deconstructed.

column1: This is partially because Pantha is so completely out of step with electronic music trends. His work for the Dial label could loosely be considered ""minimal
column2: a style whose prominence was already fading in 2007 when Pantha broke through with his much-loved This Bliss. We heard what happens when foreign bodies are introduced to Pantha's music on last year's Panda Bear collaboration
column3: ""Stick to My Side"": The normally serene Noah Lennox sounded like a bull in a china shop amidst Pantha's compulsively orchestrated beauty.

column1: XI versions of Black Noise collects the various remixes that trickled out last year and adds several more for good measure. ""Stick to My Side"" features prominently
column2: as no fewer than five artists take a swing at a track that dripped with potential but ultimately fell flat. If there's a lesson in XI versions
column3: it's just how deft a touch it takes to grapple with Pantha's idiosyncrasies. Pantha has talented friends though
column4: and the vast stylistic range of the remixers here helps compensate for the fact that they hardly cast a wide net for their source material.

column1: It's encouraging when the big names come out throwing punches. Four Tet takes ""Stick to My Side"" and surrounds Lennox's voice with the type of psychedelic curlicues he uses himself. Animal Collective take on the shifting
column2: sighing ""Welt Am Draht"" and suffuse it with sour
column3: humid vocals. Efdemin adds a backbone to ""Stick""
column4: suppressing Lennox's vocals until they just barely peek through his smokey tech-house. Walls strip ""Stick"" of much of its beatific pulse and turn it into a hazy church song (or
column5: roughly: a Panda Bear track). Others are less successful. Moritz von Oswald and Lawrence (one of Pantha's few distinct contemporaries) take on ""Welt"" and ""Stick""
column6: respectively
column7: but both offer more linear
column8: soft-focus house variations that feel a bit mushy.

column1: As such
column2: XI versions works best as a companion for smitten Black Noise fans
column3: and it offers a couple of nice moments that Four Tet and Animal Collective completists might want to keep in their back pockets. XI versions doesn't work as a full-length
column4: but it still comes off as a curious win for Pantha (who
column5: remember
column6: didn't actually contribute any new music here)
column7: showing both how potently his work can be refashioned and how difficult it is to do so. Those whose interest was piqued by Black Noise are encouraged to seek out This Bliss or the rewarding works by Lawrence and von Oswald (as Maurizio). No one here fully owned Pantha's intricate castles of sound
column8:
but it's refreshing to hear them try.

In a recent video
column2: Guillemots lead singer Fyfe Dangerfield and drummer Greig Stewart play live ""in a little woodland
column3: by a disused railway line"" in north London. Wrens and robins chirp. Standing against a graffiti-emblazoned gray brick wall
column4: the scruffily bearded Dangerfield strums an acoustic guitar casually
column5: almost haphazardly. Stewart
column6: wearing a pair of white-rimmed shades you might see on one of Biff's henchmen in Back to the Future
column7: runs his drumstick along the bars of an iron gate-- gently
column8: almost tenderly. Dangerfield's formidable falsetto soars through the space's cavernous reverb
column9: dexterously communicating heartache. If you're in the right mood
column10: it can be powerful stuff: an affecting mix of traditional earnestness and experimental impulses.

column1: This uneasy balance between balladeer sentimentality and avant-garde adventurousness runs through the Guillemots' discography. On 2006 debut Through the Windowpane
column2: which earned the four-piece a Mercury Music Prize nomination
column3: these competing urges resolved themselves gloriously in songs like fragile opener ""Little Bear""
column4: romantic ode ""Made-Up Lovesong #43""
column5: and northern soul shimmy ""Trains to Brazil"". But 2008's Red meandered through ambitious yet unremarkable Britpop. And Dangerfield's 2009 solo nod
column6: Fly Yellow Moon
column7: suggested the band's schmaltzy side had conquered all. Never mind that Billy Joel cover: Walk the River shows Guillemots still have a few eccentricities up their sleeves
column8: though they remain a long way from their mid-2000s peak.

column1: Guillemots' third album is mournful
column2: lushly arranged
column3: and conflicted as ever about whether it wants to be singer-songwriter comfort food or forward-thinking pop. The song from the video
column4: ""I Don't Feel Amazing Now""
column5: feels overdone
column6: muddling its unspectacular
column7: melancholy lyrics with the full studio gamut of strings and choral backing vocals. But first single ""The Basket"" is a lot more effective
column8: simultaneously a cryptic love song (""You knock me over/ Come on and do it again"") and a propulsive
column9: kaleidoscopic assault on a culture where there's ""a masterpiece that no one bothered painting/ Everybody's too busy with those baskets of theirs."" Think of a grown-up Supergrass (there's theremin). The ominously ornamented title track is a sample-ready testament of survival
column10: while the electronic sunshine of ""I Must Be a Lover"" offers a needed break from all the gloom.

column1: For a band that once stood out for its too-much-ness
column2: Walk the River now gives us too much of the wrong things: too many midtempo songs
column3: too many minor-key acoustic strums
column4: too many codas that outstay their welcome without really connecting. But Stewart's bustling drum work
column5: MC Lord Magrão's rippling guitar
column6: and Aristazabal Hawkes' sensuous bass-- even Dangerfield's supple voice
column7: which might suit the band's namesake seabird-- ensure there's something interesting happening beneath even the most mawkish sentiment or the baggiest quasi-epic. Just not always something particularly new or vital
column8: the way Through the Windowpane and its predecessor EP felt. That woodland video comes closest so far
column9:
so maybe the fresh air will do them some good.

""Oh
column2: I don't know who I am
column3: and I don't know what I'll be
column4: coos Laurel Sprengelmeyer of Little Scream
column5: above acoustic guitars that run like rivulets. Sprengelmeyer sings her self-doubt at the start of the second verse of ""The Heron and the Fox""
column6: the quietly reflective
column7: sadly nostalgic centerpiece of her stellar debut
column8: The Golden Record. An Iowa native now living in Montreal and recording there with members of Arcade Fire
column9: the National
column10: and A Silver Mt. Zion
column11: Sprengelmeyer sounds both worn from experience and inspired by something she can't yet imagine
column12: the peripatetic sort who's old enough to be wise but young enough to be adventurous. That's the great thread that runs through this album
column13: a perfectly mixed bag of graceful folk
column14: coiled pop
column15: and expansive art rock. Lyrically
column16: Sprengelmeyer seems to yearn for the past; stylistically
column17: though
column18: she presses for a bold polyglot future of twisted contexts. Here
column19: she gets both.

column1: It'd be easy to separate The Golden Record's 10 songs into a few orders: There are the mostly still drifters
column2: like the gently swollen ""Black Cloud"" and the reverb-washed break-up of ""People is Place"". There are songs that rock and lurch
column3: like the violin-trilling stomp ""Boatman"" and the snarling-and-smiling ""Cannons"". There are those experiments
column4: like ""Guyegaros""
column5: that fit neither. Segregating the songs
column6: though
column7: means selling Sprengelmeyer short as some manic amateur unable to unify or control her ideas. But most every move she makes as Little Scream is a good one: ""Cannons"" is as incisive and propulsive as the best of St. Vincent
column8: an oft-occurring but fairly inadequate comparison. She sculpts guitar noise and synthesizer squiggles into a perfectly odd pop song that's as aggressive as it is endearing. The same goes for ""Red Hunting Jacket""
column9: a somehow cheerful cavalcade of handclaps and guitar abrasion punctuated by a vamp of boogie-woogie piano and spiraling flute lines. The song itself is an excavation of forgotten memories from a relationship built on the run-- ""What can we communicate that won't just turn to dust?"" Sprengelmeyer sings
column10: her band twisting deliriously beneath. A kick drum thunders through a scrim of noise and samples at the start of ""Your Radio"". It's the resolute beginning to a charged electric track that eventually rises to arena sizes
column11: with tiered harmonies and a band whose trust in repetition pays off in a coda that suggests the Dead C scoring a battlefield scene. She brings the same sort of control to ""People Is Place""
column12: one of those gentle tracks that builds over its four minutes to a gorgeous instrumental groan
column13: glowing long tones breaking against a piano like waves against a shoreline. Each look is as convincing as the next.

column1: The Golden Record is a wide-open exploration of Sprengelmeyer's sensibilities
column2: the introduction on which she's able to explore both her most spare and extravagantly orchestrated impulses. It's easy to imagine a scenario where
column3: after a year or two of touring these songs
column4: watching audiences respond
column5: and feeling herself grow tired of certain tracks and maybe not others
column6: Sprengelmeyer circumscribes herself as a writer
column7: favoring a handful of styles versus the horde she delivers here. That's not necessarily a bad thing
column8: either
column9: as every approach sounds assured and evolved. There's no stylistic filler
column10: no dilettante drivel badly in need of an editor. An album of Sprengelmeyer's quiet songs would be as welcome as a full-length of her quakes. For the time being
column11: though
column12: The Golden Record is the document of a real-life wanderer who sings about drift and regret
column13: dreams and reality
column14: in songs that know enough not to sit still. The Golden Record is an infinitely approachable and enjoyable welcome by an artist who sounds like she's here now
column15:
for the duration.

San Francisco's cup has long runneth over with very good garage bands
column2: so the outpour into neighboring Oakland should have been expected. One of that city's most notable garage albums of late
column3: Hunx and his Punx's Too Young to Be in Love
column4: serves as a nice introduction to Shannon Shaw. She provides quite a few of the album's best moments with her brassy
column5: impassioned alto
column6: possessing loads of singing ability and an irresistible charisma. As one of Hunx's ""Punkettes
column7: Shaw proved a talented enough roleplayer to convince you she deserved her own band. Luckily
column8: she's actually had one for a while now.

column1: On Shannon and the Clams' debut
column2: 2009's I Wanna Go Home
column3: Shaw and co-songwriter and guitarist Cody Blanchard added a rockabilly punch to the loosey-goosey garage-punk of the Growlers and early Black Lips records. Though the album was an all-around solid exhibit of Shaw's charms as a frontwoman and her chemistry with Blanchard
column4: Sleep Talk is a refinement
column5: a streamlining
column6: an improvement in every way.

column1: That spike in quality begins with the band's heightened versatility. While I Wanna Go Home split the difference between rumbling
column2: rousing rock tunes and sultry slow jams
column3: Sleep Talk is impressively diverse. Shaw wails and shouts her way through the dark proto-punk of ""Toxic Revenge""
column4: conjuring the leather jackets of Max's Kansas City
column5: punctuated with a cacophony of saxophones. Album highlight ""Tired of Being Bad"" combines Shaw's captivating
column6: emotive vocals with Apollo Theater soul
column7: an unexpected but welcome match.

column1: In addition to Shaw's ability as a singer and her infectious vocal tics-- she whoops and yelps all over ""Old Man Winter""
column2: and her raspy growl on ""Done With You"" could strip the bark off of trees-- Sleep Talk benefits from some unique songwriting. ""The Woodsman"" serves as a striking R&B murder ballad
column3: while the production on the record-- which could accurately be described as ""dusky""-- will likely be mistaken as ""lo-fi"" when it's simply vintage
column4: a common misconception for modern music recorded without the assistance of computers.

column1: Elsewhere on Sleep Talk
column2: Blanchard exists as Shaw's equal counterpart. His guitar licks sound untrained but impressive
column3: understated and effective but eager to cede the spotlight to the band's frontwoman. As a backing vocalist
column4: Blanchard is arguably even better
column5: adding a classic R&B vibe to both ""Tired of Being Bad"" and the album's title track while bolstering ""Oh Louie"" with a cascading 1950s rock'n'roll baritone.

column1: ""Half Rat"" tests the band's use of dynamics by switching from diaphanous to rough-hewn and back
column2: providing a stirring crescendo and fierce climax for the album-- replete with drum rolls
column3: a galloping chorus
column4: and everything coming apart at the seams by the song's finish. It's a kind of overview of Sleep Talk's strengths
column5: showing how productively Shannon and the Clams can combine grit and prettiness
column6:
how effortlessly they mix the salt with the sugar.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16426/homepage_large.7f460b06.jpg|TRON: Legacy Reconfigured|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Walt Disney']|2011-04-19 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:31:56.859178|"

A sad fact of Daft Punk fandom: Once exemplars when it came to making dance albums that played like pop albums
column2: for the past five or six years the duo's often been more enjoyable once they've been remixed
column3: or when they venture into the visual. Their last proper album
column4: 2005's Human After All
column5: was poorly sequenced and way too long
column6: full of tracks that were just blandly
column7: grindingly repetitive. It was almost anti-pop but not in a truly out-there way. Good for DJs
column8: in other words
column9: and bad for those of us playing along at home.

column1: Given their lack of interest in making pop records now
column2: it's been unsurprising that much of Daft Punk's activity over the last half-decade has been about crafting raw material for remixing (including masterfully remixing themselves on 2007's live-album-meets-DJ-mix set Alive) and the cinema (including their foray into art-house territory in Electroma from 2006). Here then is an album that combines the two. When it was announced that DP would be recording the score for the TRON reboot
column3: it seemed like the natural next step in the duo's 21st-century trajectory. A slick pop science fiction film
column4: with a Disney-sized budget lavished on its special effects
column5: would surely provide their lushest visual accompaniment yet. And while the symphonic elements of the TRON: Legacy soundtrack made it very different from Human After All
column6: as a home-listening prospect it played out in much the same way. Not so much fun to listen to minus the film's visual razzle-dazzle
column7: and primed for creative remixers to turn the results into something closer to pop.

column1: TRON: Legacy Reconfigured succeeds as much as most remix projects do
column2: which is to say about 50% of the time
column3: and without Daft Punk's name attached to the project it's doubtful it would have attracted much attention. The list of remixers sure doesn't inspire much confidence
column4: at least if you're not afflicted by a serious case of 1990s nostalgia.  From Paul Oakenfold to Photek to Moby to the Crystal Method
column5: it's full of names whose best work (using the phrase very loosely in some cases) is a decade or more behind them. If Daft Punk shaped a lot of the past 10 years
column6: whether via indie kids glomming onto Discovery or brutalist dance-rock producers picking up from Human After All
column7: much of Legacy Reconfigured seems sonically stuck in the late-90s era of super-clubs and ""all-star"" remixes on CD single.

column1: The best tracks here are hugely unsubtle pop-dance tunes with big acid-meets-electro riffs-- in other words not too dissimilar from from what DP were peddling circa Homework. That's not a negative
column2: of course. The Crystal Method's redo of ""The Grid"" is cheesily anthemic and unabashedly big in a way that's sadly rare these days
column3: and Oakenfold's ""C.L.U."" has a sturm-und-drang epicness that the original soundtrack approached rarely. Much of Legacy Reconfigured is what many of us were actually hoping for from the actual Legacy score
column4: and from Daft Punk in general: grandiose electronic pop full of bombastic hooks
column5: without the genteel orchestral touches that felt like a lame cop to Hollywood tradition.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: Legacy Reconfigured can't keep that intensity up across a whole disc. Plenty of these remixes are just inert filler. Oddly
column3: many of the weakest remixes are by younger producers
column4: like Teddybears' ""Adagio For Tron""
column5: which could be any squelchy and interchangeable French dance single of the past five years. Who knows
column6: maybe the new jacks were cowed by working with material from a group they consider a formative influence rather than just peers. In any event
column7: taken as a whole
column8: what we're left with is a solidly middle-of-the-road project building off a solidly middle-of-the-road movie score. The best you can say is that Legacy Reconfigured is less disappointing than Legacy itself. No one expects much from Paul Oakenfold these days
column9: so it's a pleasant surprise here. But it's hard not to expect more from Daft Punk
column10:
even with how often they've missed in the last decade.

"|15317.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15317-tron-legacy-reconfigured/|5.0|Jess Harvell

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16419/homepage_large.2cd056f3.jpg|Outside|4985.0|O'Death|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ernest Jenning']|2011-04-19 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:31:57.027530|"

O'Death are a New York City-based quintet playing scrappy
column2: Americana-seeped folk songs-- they can be menacing and frantic
column3: or odd and quiet-- in the slapdash spirit of Tom Waits. For O'Death
column4: at least
column5: it's the New York bit that tends to trip people up: It's easy to feel distrustful of (real or imagined) hipster mobs
column6: and to feel proprietary about music as raw and unpretentious as the classic country and folk O'Death mine. And while these days every band that enlists a fiddler gets subjected to an Americana litmus test-- Are they southern? Are they poor? Are they really wearing overalls? Are the overalls real?-- the thing about folk music is that it's impossible to render inauthentic: Inclusiveness is its crux. Most bygone genres are too inextricably tied to their respective times and places to ever really be ""revived
column7: so what gets trotted out
column8: instead
column9: is an approximation of a feeling-- and hey
column10: that's just art.

column1: For O'Death
column2: the feeling in question is urgency: They've always been revved-up and eager
column3: but Outside
column4: the band's third full-length
column5: is also earnest and persuasive
column6: a collection of intensely personal
column7: intricately assembled folk songs. The best of these tracks plead for your attention: Opener ""Bugs"" is soft and heartbreaking (""I know that days don't come back
column8: please believe in me
column9: Greg Jamie sings
column10: his voice high and plaintive)
column11: unfurling like a lost Elliott Smith track. It's a sentiment that's revived on the heavy
column12: rhythmic ""Pushing Out""
column13: which contains a line (""This year could last forever
column14: this year could never start"") instantly familiar to anyone who's ever had a long
column15: cold
column16: ennui-laden New Year's Day.

column1: Most of O'Death's prior releases were about a kind of lunatic energy; Outside is more studied
column2: and its references are broader (besides the Americana they typically pull in
column3: there's plenty of world music at work here
column4: from Balkan folk to Klezmer). The band's 2009 tour was interrupted when drummer David Rogers-Berry was diagnosed with osteosarcoma
column5: a form of bone cancer. After a course of chemotherapy and a shoulder replacement
column6: O'Death returned to play a triumphant set at the Newport Folk Festival the following summer
column7: and that sense of redemption (and optimism) ultimately keeps Outside from ever feeling defeated. Songs that begin forebodingly resolve themselves (""Back of the Garden""
column8: ""Ghost Head""); the sun rises again; the world is still big and full of sound.

column1: Ultimately
column2: O'Death's instrumentation (banjo
column3: fiddle
column4: ukulele) and name (it's taken from an ancient Appalachian dirge that's been reinterpreted by everyone from Ralph Stanley to Sam Amidon) can feel like something of an albatross. Sure
column5: the band is rooted in American folk
column6: but they're also adventurous listeners and composers
column7: and Outside is unclassifiable in the same way records by northern contemporaries Beirut and Man Man are unclassifiable-- folk music
column8: it turns out
column9:
is a broad and fluid thing.

"|15315.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15315-outside/|7.9|Amanda Petrusich

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16446/homepage_large.ce18fdc6.jpg|Outmind|28977.0|Matthewdavid|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Brainfeeder']|2011-04-19 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:31:57.187888|"

Of all the artists working in Los Angeles' experimental beat scene
column2: Matthewdavid might be the strangest. The producer
column3: whose real name is Matthew McQueen
column4: runs the sound-collage cassette imprint Leaving Records
column5: and as a musician
column6: makes tracks with little regard for traditional structure and composition. His texture-heavy style takes the already blunted traits of West Coast instrumental hip-hop (blown-out beats
column7: woozy atmospherics) and jumbles them up even further to build something uniquely psychedelic.

column1: McQueen's debut full-length
column2: released on pal Flying Lotus' Brainfeeder imprint
column3: throws a bunch of ideas on the table at once-- you've often got tape hiss
column4: field recordings
column5: warped bass
column6: and scratchy ambience all rubbing elbows in the same song. It's a heady
column7: no-holds-barred approach to production that's sometimes very appealing. On a track such as ""Like You Mean It""
column8: which is grimy and dubstep-leaning but fleshed out with strings and vocal samples
column9: there's this cool kaleidoscopic quality
column10: like spinning the radio dial between three or four vaguely similar stations at the same time.

column1: The flipside is that with so much swirling around
column2: Outmind can feel disjointed and even kind of exhausting. I don't think it's an error in execution-- it seems McQueen wants to keep edges frayed to reinforce the record's hallucinatory vibe. Take ""Cucumber-Lime""
column3: all gurgling and ambient-- there's an undercurrent of melody that wants to match up with the rolling beat but is always about a half step behind. It doesn't congeal into something more substantial-- and maybe that's McQueen's point
column4: to keep things loose and process-driven-- but to these ears
column5: the song sounds half-formed.

column1: It can be hard to shake this unfinished quality
column2: especially on quieter interstitial pieces like the weirdly minor Flying Lotus collaboration ""Group Tea"". What ultimately makes up for these shortcomings
column3: though
column4: is that when these songs are working
column5: they really don't sound like much else. The warbling psych-pop-meets-crunching post-dub of ""Being Without You""? That thing could warrant its own subgenre. His ambition and willingness to try just about anything in the quest for new
column6: weird sound combinations here is commendable. So even when McQueen stumbles
column7:
it's exciting to hear him lay it all out there.

New Jersey's Family Portrait have for too long existed seemingly to serve the purposes of others. Acting as a sort of house band for the Underwater Peoples label (they formed when Real Estate needed an opening act at a party)
column2: the four-piece has played the background while its brother and sister acts-- Real Estate
column3: Andrew Cedermark
column4: Beach Fossils
column5: Julian Lynch-- found their niche and made their names. Now with their self-titled debut
column6: Family Portrait look ready to finally come into their own
column7: distilling the essence of UP's familiar fuss-free garage jangle while carefully crafting their own unique voice.

column1: Though the album doesn't start out that way. Opening mid-tempo tracks ""Glide Part I"" and ""Wait"" are worrisome red herrings that find Family Portrait rehashing the same weary sounds they have (quite charmingly) half-assed on one-off singles and EP splits in the past. But what follows is anything but bland: While it's easy to describe their sound and play connect-the-dots with similar bands
column2: it has a strange magic
column3: an unmistakable allure you can't quite put your finger on
column4: that makes music this simple so very satisfying.

column1: Credit co-producer Julian Lynch
column2: who injects his own personality into a few of these tracks
column3: showcasing reverb-rippled guitars and the watery textures that have peppered his own recordings. (Lynch's most recent full-length
column4: Mare
column5: feels like a relevant touchstone here.) In particular
column6: the gorgeous ""Instrumental"" gets a necessary boost from Lynch's explorations. But he also knows when to leave the group alone. There's a reason for Family Portrait's reputation as a really fun band-- when they're rolling
column7: like on ""Other Side"" or ""Killer Statements""
column8: it's best to just hit record and try to capture some of their intense
column9: one-take energy.

column1: Family Portrait's other secret weapon is frontman Evan Brody. He's not a great singer by any stretch
column2: and his voice is often drowned out in the mix (a symptom of the record's organic production). But Brody knows how to drag out a vocal hook (see the mirrorball-speckled prom waltz ""Come Back to Me"")
column3: and his enthusiasm is contagious on the sun-burnt paisley-pomp of ""Interlude - Never Should've Been There"". He's clearly a guy who
column4: even when his group is playing second-fiddle
column5: couldn't be happier doing anything other than singing in a band. And now with this solid debut
column6:
it's safe to say he's got himself a really good one.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16445/homepage_large.5cd5d939.jpg|The English Riviera|7244.0|Metronomy|['Rock'
column2: 'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Atlantic'
column3: 'Big Beat'
column5: England's Metronomy have traveled an impressive stylistic distance in the short span of three albums. The group began in 2006 as glitchy electronic smirkers
column6: proffering a garishly irreverent take on chinstroking IDM. Yet for their third full-length effort
column7: The English Riviera
column8: they've fully transitioned into a sleek
column9: urbane pop-rock outfit
column10: taking polished cues from the well-heeled likes of Steely Dan and Phoenix.

column1: The subtraction and addition of band members during that time surely played a role
column2: yet Metronomy have largely always been the baby of singer and multi-instrumentalist Joseph Mount. And while the music Mount and his comrades are making might sound a lot different from what they were turning out at the group's inception
column3: the two sounds do have a philosophical kinship. There's a significant amount of deliberation apparent in both sonic approaches; as loopy as ""early"" Metronomy may have been
column4: when you're making electronic music mostly without words that isn't meant for the dancefloor
column5: craft is necessarily going to be a major selling point. Likewise
column6: finely calibrated pop-rock invites an appreciation of its studio-sculpted contours.

column1: As you'd imagine given that description
column2: The English Riviera is an extremely listenable album
column3: starting with ""We Broke Free""
column4: an exquisite
column5: low-slung slice of 70s studio rock redolent of Boz Scaggs and the Dan. That seductively contented vibe pervades much of the record
column6: including ""She Wants""
column7: ""Loving Arm""
column8: and the waltzing ""Trouble"". While still vigorously scrubbed
column9: songs like ""Everything Goes My Way""
column10: ""The Look""
column11: and ""The Bay"" reflect dance and indie sensibilities
column12: aligning those efforts more closely with the likes of Phoenix
column13: Hot Chip
column14: Junior Boys
column15: and Stars. But where Steely Dan's lounge-lizard odes were laced with irony and venom
column16: and where the springy pop of Phoenix is animated by giddy energy
column17: Mount's immaculate compositions remain mostly inert. Almost all of the songs on The English Riviera sound great
column18: yet few of them really emotionally or physically involve the listener
column19: and there's little to take away besides an appreciation of that effortlessly attractive sheen. Metronomy deserve a ton of credit for so quickly and satisfyingly mastering a sound that's so disparate from the band's origins. However
column20: the group hasn't quite figured out how to animate its precise creations with personality or passion
column21:
suggesting they'd be best served by not immediately leaping to another sonic identity with their next release.

column2:
'Experimental']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['4AD']|2011-04-18 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:31:57.641205|"

The stylization of the name tUnE-yArDs in print is a bit off-putting
column3: but it at least gives people fair warning: This is not an act with any interest in politely conforming to expectations. tUnE-yArDs is the music project of Merrill Garbus
column4: a songwriter
column5: vocalist
column6: percussionist
column7: and ukulele player who has fused elements of acoustic folk
column8: R&B
column9: funk
column10: Afro-pop
column11: and rock into a bold
column12: uncompromising hybrid all her own. Garbus is blessed with an extraordinary voice
column13: and she wields it with great confidence
column14: always coming off in total control of her phrasing while seeming totally uninhibited in her expression. There's an authoritative quality to her voice-- she often sings with a commanding
column15: full-bodied boldness
column16: but even at her softest
column17: Garbus sounds assertive and forthright.

column1: w h o k i l l
column2: Garbus' second album as tUnE-yArDs
column3: delivers on the promise of her 2009 debut
column4: BiRd-BrAiNs. Unlike that album
column5: which she recorded almost entirely on her own using a digital voice recorder and the sound editing program Audacity
column6: w h o k i l l was mostly made in traditional studios in collaboration with bassist Nate Brenner
column7: engineer Eli Crews
column8: and a handful of other musicians. The music benefits from the increased professionalism
column9: but Garbus has not abandoned her lo-fi aesthetic. As on BiRd-BrAiNs
column10: Garbus layers sound to create a patchwork of contrasting textures. This time around
column11: the greater clarity allows for more exaggerated dynamics. This is most apparent in ""Gangsta""
column12: a carefully arranged track that evokes danger and fear with bluntly abbreviated blasts of horn noise and sounds that cut in and out erratically like a set of headphones with a busted wire or a cell phone that can't hold its signal. On the opposite end of the spectrum
column13: she creates an almost unsettling intimacy on ""Wooly Wolly Gong"" by mixing the ambient hum of room sound with closely mic'd arpeggiated chords and vocals.

column1: Brenner's presence on bass is the biggest difference between w h o k i l l and BiRd-BrAiNs. His style is loose and jazzy
column2: with fluid
column3: melodic lines that add dimension to Garbus' compositions. She sounded so isolated on BiRd-BrAiNs
column4: but suddenly her music is like a conversation
column5: with Brenner's parts bouncing off her voice and rhythms like thoughtful banter. He brings a janky funk to ""Es-so""
column6: a zippy groove to ""Bizness""
column7: and a delicate weight to the airy ""Doorstep"". On ""Powa""
column8: his lead lines slink around Garbus' slo-mo rock riff as if in a subliminal duet with her expressive vocal performance. That song builds steadily over the course of five minutes until it reaches a stunning climax in which Brenner's bass bounces gently as Garbus hits a glorious high note like a feral Mariah Carey.

column1: Throughout w h o k i l l
column2: Garbus confronts thorny issues of race
column3: gender
column4: body image
column5: and privilege in ways that are pointed but nuanced. She mostly sticks to personal narratives
column6: suggesting big ideas and complex tensions in her subtext while emphasizing the urgency of small moments and concrete details. She's most direct in the opening cut ""My Country""
column7: in which she wrestles with guilt over her own privilege
column8: but she's more thought-provoking when in murkier
column9: more ambiguous territory
column10: like when she sings about a sexual fantasy involving the brutal cop who arrested her brother in ""Riotriot"" or when she wonders aloud why she does not have more black male friends at the end of ""Killa"". Garbus is particularly fascinated by violence; most of the tracks on w h o k i l l deal with power struggles that arise from inequity and lead to further cruelty and injustice. Her lighter moments are still quite complicated-- she playfully wrestles with negative body image in ""Es-so""
column11: while that same lingering disgust and self-doubt brings a moving subtext to ""Powa""
column12: an ode to a lover who can get her to momentarily let go of stress and insecurities.

column1: Back in 1983 Sonic Youth's Kim Gordon wrote an essay for Art Forum that suggested that when we go to rock performances
column2: we pay to see other people believe in themselves. A lot of what makes w h o k i l l and tUnE-yArDs' excellent live performances so compelling is the degree to which Garbus commits to her ideas and displays a total conviction in her personal
column3: idiosyncratic
column4: high-stakes music. This
column5: in and of itself
column6: is very inspiring and empowering. This unguarded
column7: individualistic expression encourages strong identification in listeners
column8:
so don't be surprised if this record earns Garbus a very earnest and intense cult following.

The tools Liz Harris uses to make music as Grouper tend to be pretty basic: piano
column3: guitar
column4: synths
column5: drones
column6: hiss
column7: and lots of reverb. If you've been following along with the twists and turns of noisy ambient music these last few years
column8: this collection of elements may sound familiar
column9: possibly bordering on cliché. But it's all in how you fit the pieces together. Despite sharing characteristics with a lot of other current music
column10: Harris' has a distinctive sound that she pretty much owns. These short LPs
column11: released at the same time and that share an overall aesthetic
column12: sound beamed in from another realm
column13: and they also sound like they could have come from no one else.

column1: Part of the distinctiveness can be traced to Harris' voice
column2: which floats above the music and can sound delicate and shrouded and mist and can also evince an approachable earthiness. Particularly on Alien Observer
column3: she layers her voice in a way that occasionally brings to mind Julianna Barwick
column4: but Harris sounds comparatively distant and less immersive. Her voice haunts these songs instead of leading them; it's a presence and not a personality
column5: and the voice and instruments are in balance
column6: serving each other without any one element becoming more prominent.

column1: The other aspect that sets Grouper apart is an approach to sound that feels somehow both cruder and more sophisticated than the majority of the lo-fi crop. It's crude in the sense that it seems to hearken back to the dark
column2: home-recorded songs of an earlier era. David Pearce's music as Flying Saucer Attack
column3: recorded mostly during the 1990s
column4: was often referred to as ""rural psychedelia
column5: and that description would fit this pair of records. This music feels both spacey and expansive and also oddly intimate and grounded
column6: the work of someone who has mastered her tools and knows how to get the most out of them. The sophistication comes from the care in presentation. This music doesn't sound like it was built from mistakes or thrown together
column7: it seems precisely ordered and arranged even while it's often muffled and warbly and distorted. Every sound exists for a reason.

column1: Alien Observer is the more accessible of the two discs
column2: and also has a slightly better arc.  The opening ""Moon Is Sharp"" begins one of those impossibly beautiful vocal drones that just tears out your insides
column3: as Harris begins in shapeless ethereality and gradually finds her way to an unadorned but breathtaking melody. The title track does away with the drone and puts Harris' vocal over a quivering keyboard line. On ""Vapor Trails"" and ""She Loves Me That Way"" the record turns a few shades darker
column4: but a twinkling music box melody that opens ""Mary
column5: on the Wall (Second Heart Tone)"" feels like awakening from an uneasy sleep
column6: groggy and halfway hallucinating as you re-enter the world. The closing ""Come Softly (For Daniel D)"" feels like a proper conclusion
column7: as Harris' naked voice over a skeletal keyboard figure gradually disappear over the horizon.

column1: Dream Loss is heavier on the distortion and EQ
column2: and with an atmosphere that alternates between the hissy
column3: open drift of the stratosphere with the thick
column4: all-encompassing immersion of the ocean floor. The tracks here feel less like songs and more like moods
column5: studies
column6: and shapes. ""I Saw a Ray"" flirts with noise music
column7: with a bit of industrial grind added to the held tones
column8: while ""Soul Eraser"" seems to crumble into dust and regenerate itself simultaneously.

column1: Harris has indicated that the two records
column2: dating from different periods (the tracks on Dream Loss are older)
column3: have threads connecting them. They certainly feel like companions. Dream Loss is only slightly less engrossing than its counterpart
column4: and the differences are minor. But placed on a continuum
column5: these records highlight how 2008's luminous Dragging a Dead Deer Up a Hill
column6: her last full-length album
column7: was an unusual entry in the Grouper catalog. That record was built almost exclusively with acoustic guitar and voice
column8: and the songs had an ancient air to them
column9: like they'd been carved into petrified wood with a hammer and chisel. These records are closer to the narcotic drift of earlier records like 2007's Cover the Windows and the Walls. But it all feels like Grouper
column10: and whether she's working in realm of rough-hewn folk or amniotic drift
column11:
this is music that takes you places.

"|15332.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15332-a-i-a-alien-observer-a-i-a-dream-loss/|8.1|Mark Richardson

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16424/homepage_large.c8812d1b.jpg|Black Sun|7288.0|Kode9 & the Spaceape|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hyperdub']|2011-04-18 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:31:57.982843|"

Dubstep's crossover bid-- whether James Blake's introspective fragility or Katy B's pop hybridization-- is starting to obscure one of the genre's initial strengths: the way it could transmit anxiety. The soupy low-end and skittering hi-hats of a 2006 Hyperdub side made the ideal soundtrack for a sense of encroaching doom-- whether it was Burial's affecting desolation or a bracing dose of Kode9 & the Spaceape. The teamup of Hyperdub's flagship producer with the earthen-voiced poet resulted in an underappreciated full-length
column2: Memories of the Future
column3: which shot chest-collapsing bass and gutter synthesizers through firebrand reggae. Their next prominent collaboration was a cover of the Specials' ""Ghost Town"" that appeared on 5: Five Years of Hyperdub and made the already grave original sound like a Less Than Jake song by comparison. If there are standard-bearers for dubstep's more evocatively disquieting tendencies
column4: it's these two.

column1: Given how many trends have shifted in the past five years
column2: it's not worth debating how Black Sun fits in the current post-Blake
column3: post-Rusko
column4: post-Magnetic Man landscape. Instead
column5: the album has the tricky but crucial task of keeping an archetypal strain of bass music part of an increasingly busy conversation. It does that to an extent
column6: but a few key  changes to the partnership's approach prove how much the formula can stretch. The duo's tension-driven personality has been preserved
column7: but the tweaks are  noticeable-- instead of sinking into a single-minded atmosphere  of futurist foreboding
column8: the music is more sprightly and intricate
column9: adding subtle stylistic retorts to the production's more aggressive traits.

column1: An easy case study would be to compare the 2009 version of the album's titular single with the ""Partial Eclipse Version"" that appears here. The original track was a bit of a left turn at the time-- woozy 8-bit drones and a funky-inflected rhythm. Revamped here
column2: its frantic rush is dialed  down just enough to amplify the old-school Detroit feel that was overpowered in the original mix-- less a panic attack than a nervous glance over  the shoulder. The deceptively simple beats for ""Love Is the Drug"" and  ""Otherman"" set  dissonant
column3: uneasy chords against sturdy
column4: upbeat funky house rhythms
column5: forcing otherwise unpredictable melodies into an offhand catchiness. And with its sizzling  analog synthesizer decay
column6: ""Kryon""
column7: the  beautiful album-closing collaboration with Flying Lotus
column8: feels less like a gratuitous guest spot and more like a culmination of Black Sun's equilibrium between pressured propulsion and elegiac calm.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the Spaceape still resonates
column3: thanks to a voice suited for slow-burn  tension and corrosive damnation. This time around it's less smothered in filters and reverb
column4: giving him a little more clarity. Whether he's abstracting a harrowing  physical breakdown (""Black Smoke"") or sprinting through war-zone  resilience (""Bullet Against Bone"")
column5: the Spaceape finds a way to make even the most  severe lyrics hit as slickly and nimbly as the snare rolls he  weaves through. Tension and anxiety don't always have to be cavernous  and austere
column6: and Black Sun reveals a way for dubstep's vanguard to express their more ominous impulses in a way you can still dance to
column7:
no matter how the steps change.

"|15310.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15310-black-sun/|7.7|Nate Patrin

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16420/homepage_large.64d37366.jpg|The Head and the Heart|29611.0|The Head and the Heart|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2011-04-18 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:31:58.149308|"

Recorded and released on their own dime
column2: the Head and the Heart's self-titled debut is one of the biggest grassroots success stories of the past year. The Seattle band managed to sell 10
column3: 000 copies by word of mouth alone
column4: which is impressive for any unsigned act
column5: especially in this economic and business climate. They're touring relentlessly and have landed some enviable opening gigs for Vampire Weekend and
column6: ahem
column7: Dave Matthews. The result is a deal with Sub Pop and
column8: inevitably
column9: a re-release of their debut.

column1: That would be a remarkable story if the album were innovative or intriguing
column2: if it offered some new take on Pacific Northwest folk-rock
column3: if it had personality beyond its success. Instead
column4: The Head and the Heart is a lackluster mélange of vaguely old-time instrumentation
column5: wan gospel harmonies
column6: and heart-always-on-sleeve songwriting. Jon Russell and Josiah Johnson trade off lead vocals
column7: each trying to out-earnest the other
column8: while Charity Thielen's violin traces placid swirls around the melodies. But it's Kenny Hensley's piano that distinguishes the band and broadens their palette
column9: for better or worse. He injects some much-needed pomp into ""Ghosts"" and ""Heaven Go Easy on Me""
column10: goosing these songs out of their tasteful torpor. On the other hand
column11: he constantly falls back on the tactic of repeating chords to convey general drama
column12: which recalls Coldplay more than Tin Pan Alley.

column1: The band's name is intended to emphasize both emotion and intellect
column2: yet so many of these songs fall flat in both aspects. They're capable lyricists
column3: although prone to lapses in judgement. ""I wish I was a slave to some age-old trade
column4: Russell sings on ""Down in the Valley""
column5: ""like riding 'round on railcars and working long days."" Neither of those examples truly qualifies as an ""age-old trade
column6: and the implication of indie slumming may have some listeners clicking Move to Trash before the first Elizabethtown chorus. The song is a travelogue that goes nowhere at all.

column1: Such nods to history and to hard labor are meant to give this album the sheen of authenticity
column2: but it doesn't take long to see through to the calculation beneath. Musically
column3: the band's old-time approximations resemble the Avett Brothers
column4: but
column5: without that group's effortless harmonizing
column6: easy melodicism
column7: and demonstrative vocals
column8: the Head and the Heart sound anonymous
column9: their drama wholly predictable. Conceptually
column10: they're close to Mumford & Sons: opportunistic in their borrowings
column11: yet entirely unimaginative in the execution. Theirs is a thoroughly timid
column12:
tentative take on Americana: roots music without the roots.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16442/homepage_large.ee4f578c.jpg|Bespoke|989.0|Daedelus|['Jazz'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ninja Tune']|2011-04-18 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:31:58.355778|"

The term ""bespoke"" refers to the detail-oriented process of making custom-made clothing; it's also the name of the new full-length from Los Angeles-based electronic veteran Alfred Darlington
column3: aka Daedelus. Excluding the man's sartorial fixations
column4: the name seems like an ill fit. Throughout his decade-long career
column5: he's been seemingly averse to the process of tightening and self-editing
column6: instead choosing to stuff every idea that pops into his head into misshapen
column7: often uninteristing bursts of sound. As a result
column8: his discography is less impressive for its breadth (at least 10 full-lengths and countless more EPs in 10 years) than it is for its lack of a single coherent
column9: enjoyably listenable statement. At this point
column10: it's understandable if folks interested in the sort of experimental-leaning music that Darlington trades in have simply left him be
column11: assuming he would never make an album worth listening to more than once.

column1: It's a pleasant surprise
column2: then
column3: that Darlington's made his first truly decent-sounding album with Bespoke. Thematically
column4: the record takes a few cues from cosmopolitan house and stuttering techno figures
column5: but anyone walking in from off the street (or a club floor) expecting a dance-leaning record might as well turn back around; this is a Daedelus record
column6: which means ""form"" and ""unification"" are dirty words around these parts. The whole thing is an enjoyable mess
column7: and when this record is really cooking
column8: listening to it has the pleasurable effect of someone messing with a radio dial.

Dave Grohl didn't make it easy for himself. Not long after Nirvana dissolved in April 1994
column2: following Kurt Cobain's suicide

column4: a Petty fan
column5: that was a dream job. Though he would drum with them during a ""Saturday Night Live"" performance later that year
column6: Grohl ultimately declined

column1: At the time
column2: that decision was probably daunting. Grohl had already spent some time in a Seattle studio recording a humble demo tape that would become Foo Fighters' debut
column3: one for whose release rights major labels were already grappling. But the sizable shadow cast by Cobain and the weight of his legacy and death was immense. This week
column4: coupled with Wasting Light
column5: their seventh full-length
column6: Foo Fighters have been screening their new
column7: somewhat revisionist
column8: sometimes 3-D retrospective documentary
column9: Back and Forth. There's some great footage early on during what was Grohl's very first tour (opening for Mike Watt) with his brand new band. There
column10: despite having never heard any of the yet-to-be-released Foo Fighters songs
column11: young Nirvana fans were showing up early and in numbers. ""Marigold!"" they'd scream out between songs

column1: The idea of Grohl opening for anyone now seems just as ridiculous as him having to field requests for anything but one of the two dozen modern rock hits he's released since. But in Wasting Light
column2: Grohl is attempting to come full circle. The plan was to go back to basics
column3: in a few ways: 1) record the album to tape in Grohl's San Fernando Valley garage
column4: 2) hire famed Nevermind producer Butch Vig to man the boards
column5: 3) bring former Germs
column6: Nirvana
column7: and Foo Fighters guitarist Pat Smear back into the mix
column8: 4) have founding Nirvana member and bassist Krist Novoselic down from Seattle to guest on some of the recordings. As Grohl says during Back and Forth
column9: before recording began in earnest
column10: ""I love that we're going to make an album at home. It's going to sound like it was recorded in a house. I know it will.""

column1: It doesn't. In fact
column2: said garage was built with the arena in mind
column3: and as a result Wasting Light sounds just as mammoth and capable of knocking out teeth as anything Foo Fighters have recorded since the late 90s. That's more a product of force than hooks. As evidenced by the opening roar of ""Bridge Burning"" and ""Rope"" or metallic uppercuts of ""White Limo""
column4: the new
column5: three-guitar attack in place provides a wallop that wasn't there before. Vig is renowned for sugaring up recordings
column6: but here
column7: the aim seems solely about knocking down walls. Front to back
column8: Wasting Light meets that cause with lean
column9: workmanlike aplomb. Grohl's screams haven't registered this dangerously
column10: gleefully shredded in years-- if he was hoping to exorcise some demons
column11: it sounds as though he made that happen.

column1: But Foo Fighters' long-standing foundation has been built on fist-pumpers. While Wasting Light features a host of worthy set-openers

column3: quiet-LOUD formula and crescendos-- see: alt-rock lullabies ""Arlandria"" and ""These Days""
column4: or the pop-punk door-to-ass closer ""Walk""-- come closest to matching the energy of his best work. In theory
column5: as a form of therapy
column6: it still works. Former Hüsker Dü frontman and fellow 80s punker Bob Mould guests semi-audibly on the Zeppelin-like crunch of ""Dear Rosemary"" and then of course
column7: there's Novoselic's turn on ""I Should Have Known""
column8: where the latter's bass sounds as round and bowling ball-heavy as it did on Nirvana's ""Sliver"".

column1: There's a scene not long into Back and Forth

column3: ""People really resented me for starting this band

column5: that's what I do."" It's true. He always did. It's just that
column6: this time out

it's his melodies that are missed most.

On Graceland

column4: or it could be yesterday. Those were the days of miracles and wonder

column6: however
column7: haven't been too kind: Even as his influence has grown

column1: To his considerable credit
column2: however

column5: both Graceland and The Rhythm of the Saints have proved enormously influential to a new generation of indie-pop songwriters from the Shins' James Mercer to Vampire Weekend's Ezra Koenig. Simon
column6: who turns 70 this year

column8: gospel
column9: and world music. So Beautiful or So What blends them all into a pop sound that's simultaneously laidback and spry
column10: almost self-consciously alluding to his past triumphs.

column1: Replacing Brian Eno
column2: long-time cohort Phil Ramone co-produces
column3: and the pairing is comfortable
column4: if not complacent. They've corralled a small band to suggest a live-in-the-room intimacy and spontaneity
column5: and ""Rewrite"" and ""Love Is an Eternal Sacred Light"" crackle with energy. Some of the ambient elements from Surprise remain
column6: but they're couched in the earthy rhythms of the percussion and the spidery guitars. His voice still strong
column7: Simon shows off his own fretwork more prominently
column8: especially on the short
column9: sweet instrumental ""Amulet"". Only the sampled sermon on ""Getting Ready for Christmas Day"" sounds out of place; contemporary listeners may be more likely to connect it to Moby's pre-millennial techno-folk than to its true source material
column10: a 1941 sermon by Reverend J.M. Gates.

column1: Even as his band gets smaller
column2: Simon's ideas grow larger. He's addressing enormous spiritual matters
column3: specifically the nature of God. In ""Love and Hard Times""
column4: He and Jesus show up for a surprise inspection of Earth
column5: and it's a bit too precious until Simon interrupts and turns it into a sweet love song about love songs. God Himself narrates ""Love Is an Eternal Sacred Light""
column6: bemoaning that humanity doesn't get his jokes

column1: So Beautiful or So What can be stodgy in its emotions and a bit too devoted to its motifs
column2: but there's something humanizing about the album's shortcomings. It is
column3: thank God
column4: no attempt to get his affairs in order

column6: end-of-life affairs. Simon's not worrying over redemption on these spiritual inquests; he's much more concerned about what he'll do in heaven once he gets there. Turns out
column7: he'll be listening to his favorite American tunes. In ""The Afterlife""
column8: ""Be-Bop-a-Lula"" and ""Ooo Poo Pah Doo"" form a celestial language

column1: Those reference points-- Gene Vincent and Jessie Hill

column3: Graceland
column4: and King's assassination on the title track-- all well predate Y2K

column9: and like John Updike
column10: Simon cherishes small epiphanies
column11: which resound like bombs in the marketplace. So perhaps the epiphany of So Beautiful or So What is that Paul Simon turns out to be a character in a Paul Simon song: An aging songwriter still struggling to connect

column13:
and still cranking the Dixie Hummingbirds.

Not everyone mellows as they age. Just most of us. Whatever the medium
column2: but especially in music
column3: the most outlandish stuff tends to come first. But this natural swing toward calm and control can be hell on musicians who made their names playing startling
column4: violent
column5: or unhinged music. That sort of ragged intensity is tough to maintain over the long haul; many bands don't even want to
column6: whatever their fans might say.

column1: Despite a 30-year career and a deep discography
column2: Meat Puppets are always going to be defined in the minds of many listeners by their first three albums
column3: which caromed from thrashing hardcore to psychedelically tweaked country-punk to beautiful rustic psychedelia. With records that singular
column4: it's unsurprising that people might want more like them

column6: or even to the more traditional (if still wild) boogie rock they made in their second phase. Like all the music the Puppets have made in the last 10 years
column7: Lollipop lacks even the occasional kick of their 1990s major label albums. At this point you can take these newest Puppets albums for what they are

column1: The band had already pointed to the more laid-back direction their career might take as early as album number three
column2: Up on the Sun
column3: a collection of super-loose melodic jams that was both amazingly skillful (check out that guitar) and woozily unconventional (check out those song structures). That looseness and wooziness is nowhere to be heard on Lollipop. As with its two 21st-century predecessors

column1: Lollipop is a bit of a step up from 2009's Sewn Together. The ballads are less maudlin
column2: for one thing; ""Town"" is as achingly sad and good as this sort of thing gets. And for a band that once blasted its hooks to bits
column3: the Puppets have embraced the stick-in-your-head tunefulness that always lurked under the skronk and blare. But the problem remains the same: Where their records once strained and burst from too much wildness
column4: now they threaten to get so competent they'll go flat. There are plenty of great tunes here
column5: just not much character. Lollipop's as catchy as your average power-pop record
column6:
but still hardly as essential as the band's peaks.

column10:
we get the Sunsets' sophomore album. That's Lil-Wayne-in-2006 levels of productivity.

But Smith never sounds like someone rushing to crank out literally hundreds of songs. His songs have an enormously appealing loose
column11: homespun quality-- muffled
column12: refracted

column17: equally flat female interjections on others. The whole thing sounds like something they could've bashed out in a long afternoon

This

column2: the heartbroken jangle on ""Pretend You Love Me"". And Smith has a lyrical mischievousness about him

love with you baby/ I am dumb and so are you."" And ""Teenage Thugs"" has to be one of the first punk songs in history that doesn't identify with juvenile corner toughs but with the grown adult weenies who are afraid of them.

Many of Smith's defining qualities-- his self-deprecating lyrics

part of me hopes he stays his lane and keeps making these sugary jangles forever.

Is 2011 turning out to be the year UK bass music goes semi-mainstream? Well
column3: kinda. Sorta. Not exactly. For one thing
column4: genres like dubstep and funky have been moving away from the club fringe and toward the center of the pop conversation for a while now. (In the UK itself
column5: they've been at the center for some time already.) Dubstep sonics
column6: however toned-down or disguised
column7: can be heard in all sorts of chart music these days. And now we have a full slate of singers with (sometimes very loose) connections to bass culture
column8: several of whom have released albums in 2011 aimed as much as folks who need songs as folks who obsessively collect dubplates.

column1: Thing is
column2: and not a little ironically
column3: the singer whose songs have the strongest sonic connection to UK bass is also the most pop
column4: Katy B
column5: where the hard-hitting drums and wobbler bass effects are sweetened by her I-wanna-be-a-star delivery. Meanwhile
column6: dubstep fans
column7: juiced on the weird rhythmic experiments of his early singles
column8: have been scratching their heads trying to figure out why James Blake's album so firmly lashed itself to the mast of indie-crooner culture. And in the middle
column9: we have Jamie Woon.

column1: Almost the exact middle
column2: actually. Young and school-trained London singer Woon's debut album
column3: Mirrorwriting
column4: sits between Katy B and James B
column5: pop theatricality and singer-songwriter calm
column6: club culture and bedroom indie
column7: old-school soul and modern electronic R&B
column8: extroverted and introverted. And tying it all together is the language of UK bass. His first major single
column9: 2010's justly lauded ""Night Air""
column10: announced him as one of a number of young English artists for whom garage
column11: and everything that came after
column12: was just another bit of pop language to use. And from the slow-motion jungle syncopations and muted bass blare of ""Street"" to the stuttering retro-rave breakbeats that drive ""Spirits""
column13: the computer-assisted Woon makes sorta-pop from the last 20 years of UK dance the way current U.S. guitar kids draw from surf-rock and girl-groups.

column1: But if that's all Woon was doing
column2: he'd be just another indie one-man-band with a full software suite
column3: making specialist music with materials from stuff with more pop-appeal. A couple things about Mirrorwriting make you wonder though if Woon really is destined for crossover success. One is his voice
column4: which is the instrument that turns many of these songs from sorta-pop to real-deal pop. Much has been made that Woon went to the same school that gave us Amy Winehouse. His delivery is low-key for most of Mirrorwriting
column5: far from her roadhouse belting
column6: but the guy's clearly got chops
column7: and an elastic way with a number of styles.

column1: And unlike a lot of guys making a murky late-night brand of indie-soul right now
column2: Woon's pleasingly warm and smooth tone
column3: mixed mostly up-front with little obscuring reverb or distortion
column4: gives you the feeling that he could have a straight R&B career if he wanted. His restraint and lack of melisma trickery seems more like a choice to fit the slow drift of the music
column5: not a limitation
column6: and his use of HTDW/Blake style heavily processed vocals is careful
column7: like Burial samples deployed as background harmonies. Woon wants these songs to appeal to folks for whom digitally tweaked singing is an occasional fun special effect
column8: rather than the whole draw. And while the album's mostly full of left-field R&B
column9: there are also hints of Hall and Oates
column10: 80s Brit synth-pop
column11: house
column12: and more. There's also an occasional and unfortunate tendency toward limp VH1-ready MOR ballads
column13: which it must be said comprises the album's weakest stuff
column14: though thankfully Woon doesn't indulge this side as much as a truly crossover-minded hack might.

column1: Woon's attempted to bridge so many opposed vibes here that you'd want to praise his ambition
column2: even if he couldn't pull it off. The fact that Mirrorwriting really does manage to blur so many different musical worlds into something so smoothly unified is Woon's real achievement. But because of that very in-betweenness
column3: Mirrorwriting is still likely to rankle genre partisans of all stripes. Too slick and synth-heavy and modern for fans of Winehouse-style retro-soul. Too subtle for true dubstep fans wanting more club thunder. Not subtle enough for those heart-on-sleeve beat weirdos who've made James Blake a cause celeb. So it'll be interesting to see if it really is the wide mass of pop and indie listeners that winds up embracing Woon's everything-at-once approach. Whoever his audience turns out to be
column4:
Woon's managed one assured and beguiling hybrid of UK bass pressure and slick blue-eyed soul.

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
ring pedal tones and a
<script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
long
column2: arcing shape

column1: There are two main instruments here
column2: Hauschka's piano and his computer. (Occasional percussion
column3: horns
column4: accordion
column5: and bass synthesizer add color.) The piano he prepares
column6: in the tradition of John Cage
column7: with any number of small objects-- paper clips
column8: clothespins

column10: tinny timbres and harmonics. (You can watch him prepare his piano in a fascinating series of videos on NPR.org.) Thus the piano
column11: or a few notes of it
column12: anyway

column14: congas
column15: and spluttering ride cymbals.

column1: The computer is used as a multitrack recorder
column2: allowing him to build each song in a succession of parallel lines. There is very little evidence of digital post-processing; it sounds
column3: for the most part
column4: like he has played each part in full in real time
column5: rather than cutting and pasting phrases and fragments into a post-hoc collage. (For anyone interested in a really close examination of his method

column7: for lack of a better word

column10: in contrast

column1: The preparations give Hauschka an enormous range of timbres to work with
column2: lending the music a wonderful sense of depth and texture

column4: layering parts in short
column5: repetitive bursts

column1: Ultimately
column2: the album succeeds not in imitation

column5: but the vast majority of it sticks to a single sampled chord. This is something else. It isn't so much that it's a facsimile of house

column9: stumblingly
column10: and embellishing along the way with ideas borrowed from jazz and pop and classical music. It's gleefully polyglot
column11: confident even in its own clumsiness-- awed by the scope of its subject and humbled by its own limitations
column12: but still bright-eyed and unstoppable. If you've ever
column13: while learning a language

column15: you'll know what I'm talking about. Curious
column16: constantly in motion
column17: full of puzzle-like counterpoints and arresting chord changes
column18: it's a joy to listen to
column19: and one of the brightest
column20:
most invigorating records I've heard all year.

column1: This is Chatham

column3: well

column6: really

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
<script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
Steadily

column8: Albert Ayler

column16:
breathing room.
