A list of adjectives to describe Bill Callahan's writing and music is a list of contradictions. He's penetrating
column2: he's ironic
column3: he's intimate
column4: he's elusive
column5: he's distant and calcified
column6: he's vulnerable and warm-- it's all there
column7: album to album
column8: song to song
column9: and sometimes line to line. His voice is low and his songs are slow
column10: so it's easy to mistake him for being sad. As a lyricist
column11: he writes meticulously about distance: the distance between people and other people
column12: and between people and themselves. He's a cartographer of broken roads. But more than sadness
column13: his writing represents a stoic quest for understanding in the face of knowing that these gaps usually can't be filled. ""There's no truth in you
column14: there's no truth in me
column15: he sang on 2003's Supper. ""The truth is between.""

column1: Apocalypse is his first studio album since 2009's Sometimes I Wish We Were an Eagle. The contrast between the two is stark. Eagle was a bath of strings
column2: open-air ambience
column3: French horns
column4: and soft
column5: measured drums. It was delicate and planned
column6: it called out warm. Lyrically
column7: the songs were direct and steady admissions of the kinds of sentiments that rise to light after funerals and breakups-- an exercise in what we normally call ""vulnerable.""

column1: Apocalypse
column2: ostensibly recorded live in the studio with a small band
column3: is idiosyncratic and reluctant. Its narrators chew grass in silence and give you a too-long stare. They have meltdowns in foreign hotel rooms. And they come to us in a sound that is spare and liberated from Eagle's insistence on being gorgeous every single second. It's occasionally distorted
column4: even ugly
column5: a word I wouldn't use to describe almost anything Callahan's done since he recorded as Smog.

column1: One of his most remarkable tricks-- and one he returns to all over Apocalypse-- is the ability to sound both controlled and casual at the same time. The songs here are filled with silly
column2: borderline bad ideas that an artist with less confidence might've scrubbed after taking a long walk and a good rest. ""Baby's Breath"" speeds up and slows down in a way that sounds unrehearsed
column3: devolving into distorted guitar toward the end. The sloppy backing track on ""America!"" quotes what sounds like Civil War songs and 50s jungle-rock. (It also casts Johnny Cash and Kris Kristofferson as part of an imagined U.S. military force and ends on an acidic joke about American imperialism: ""Well everyone's allowed a past they don't care to mention."") A few songs feature
column4: prominently
column5: the flute.

column1: But the feeling of spontaneity is also in Callahan's voice and delivery
column2: which brings out the emotional dimension of the lines in ways the lyric sheet can't. On ""One Fine Morning""-- one of two songs to use the album's title-- he sings
column3: ""It's all coming back to me now: my apocalypse
column4: my apocalypse."" The lyric is literally a realization
column5: but it's the way he sings it that brings the feeling across: Curious and questioning
column6: like he actually figured it out while tape was rolling. On ""Universal Applicant""
column7: he describes a moment where he shoots a flare gun into the air
column8: and punctuates it with a sound: <i>fffff
column9: pouh-- the flare burning and going off. The music falls silent for a few seconds. It's an aside that anchors the song. Ironically
column10: it's not in the lyric sheet.

column1: All these apparent accidents and asides produce a strange effect: It's like Callahan is alive in the music while it's being documented. It's vital that way
column2: but permeable
column3: like a friend who can tell the same story over and over again with subtle variations and capture their audience each time.

column1: For me
column2: Callahan's albums always return to questions of truth in song. For some people
column3: the acoustic guitar-- when compared to the synthesizer-- is truth. For some
column4: it's a line as unambiguous as ""Most of my fantasies are of making someone else come
column5: from 1997's Red Apple Falls. For others
column6: it might be a line like ""You always wanted to be the fire part of fire
column7: from 2005's Woke on a Whaleheart-- a crowning example of Callahan at his most profoundly anti-poetic. He sets up alone and sings a lot of lines about feelings that start with the word ""I"" and doesn't use Auto-Tune
column8: and so it's tempting to think of him as being a truth-teller. But it's more interesting-- and more flattering to him
column9: I think-- to acknowledge the way in which he tries to climb to truth from so many different angles
column10: where he finds footing and where he loses it
column11: and the things he sees along the way.

column1: One of Apocalypse's prettiest and most agreeable songs is called ""Riding For the Feeling"". It's a slow waltz. Callahan strums an acoustic guitar and sings close to the mic. The drums are brushed and patient. The sound alone tells us it's honest. And yet the scenario presented in the song is so strange: Callahan singing about moving
column2: leaving
column3: disappearing. Callahan singing about being in a hotel room with the television on mute
column4: listening to demo tapes: ""My my my apocalypse
column5: he calls it-- the other song where the album's title comes in. ""I realize I had said very little about waves or wheels/ Or riding for the feeling/ Riding for the feeling/ Is the fastest way to reach the shore.""

column1: The richness
column2: as I hear it
column3: is that the line describes how elusive-- and maybe even impossible-- honesty is. I don't have a clear idea of what ""riding for the feeling is
column4: but I wonder if that's the point: it's a journey toward something vague and variable. It's about the distance between how simple things feel when you experience them and how cluttered and gummed-up they come out sounding in song or verse. It's about the distance between something like Eagle's ""Jim Cain"" and ""America!"": The healthy-looking guy standing in a field telling you in past tense about his heartbreak and the one barking at you live and uncut from an Australian hotel room. One sounds too close to their feelings to make sense of them
column5: the other sounds too far away to embody them. Which is more honest?

column1: When his first records as Smog started coming out
column2: it would've been easy to situate Callahan in an axis of singer-songwriters who sounded both rooted in American folk traditions but also radically disjointed from them: Dave Berman (of Silver Jews)
column3: Cat Power
column4: and Will Oldham (then playing as Palace). Berman has retired
column5: Cat Power has slowed down
column6: and Oldham
column7: like Callahan
column8: has become the kind of musician who only makes sense within the context of himself. Callahan has nothing to add to the general conversation about music in 2011 but is making the best albums of his career. And despite the superficial changes he makes to his sound or focus
column9: everything he's done ends on similar gestures: a stare
column10: a nod
column11:
and the quiet question of whether trying to get to the heart of something is the same thing as actually getting to it.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16406/homepage_large.5703e7df.jpg|The Family Sign|160.0|Atmosphere|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rhymesayers']|2011-04-13 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:32:00.824738|"

Lots of indie-rap figures wallow in self-pity
column2: bemoan their own bad habits
column3: snap at those who make life hard for them
column4: and somehow find a way to wrap all those emotions up into a resilient shell. But Atmopshere's Slug established a particular knack for it when he broke outside the Twin Cities about a decade back-- every heartfelt line about lonely people or fractured relations was offset by an offhand remark that took some the sting out of his lamentations. Atmosphere got tagged as ""emo rap"" because there wasn't an easier go-to term for a barfly raconteur with female troubles
column5: but while Slug's lyrics spoke to the same sour impulses that drove teenage misery
column6: they did so through the experiences of someone who discovers to that misery when you grow up.

column1: The catch is that growing up also means growing out of a few things
column2: and The Family Sign catches Slug at a point where he seems to be tilting more towards plainspoken sincerity. The hard-drinking
column3: love-stressed
column4: party-fatigued persona that made him a breakout cult figure 10 years ago might sound somewhere between disingenuous and ridiculous coming from a 38-year-old today. But in stripping some of the more larger-than-life traits of misspent youth away from his approach
column5: he's also lost some of the outsized arrogance and aw-shucks smartassedness that gave his more po-faced moments a three-dimensional context or sharp emotional counterpoint. While The Family Sign has a specific titular focus on loved (and formerly loved) ones and the way people define themselves through them
column6: the real conceptual leap on this album is how patriarch maturity means less jokiness
column7: more earnestness
column8: and a traveled perspective that doesn't leave much room for not giving a fuck.

column1: What room is left winds up parceled out over a couple of highlights. As blunt as the premise is
column2: the negligent alky father meets stoner pickpockets of ""Bad Bad Daddy"" has a certain caustic bite to it. And the road-ravaged
column3: detail-rich narrative of ""Millennium Dodo"" evokes the same harebrained excitement-slash-disorientation that made the best moments of 2003's fantastic Seven's Travels stand out. Pointing out his car's mirror-ball décor as an homage to Escape From New York or noting the resemblance between a Best Western clerk and ""WKRP in Cincinnati"" nebbish Les Nessman is the sort of pop-culture debris that's evocative enough to transcend reference-dropping and hint at the metaphorical reserves in Slug's brain. But the track also starts out with a couplet-- ""I only act like an asshole/ Why don't ch'y'all stand back
column4: let the man grow""-- that explains the rest of the album's almost total lack of sardonic edge.

column1: Heartfelt moments haven't necessarily been beyond Slug's grasp-- When Life Gives You Lemons
column2: You Paint That Shit Gold highlight ""Wild Wild Horses"" and ""Lifter Puller"" off Seven's Travels are genuinely moving in a way that few indie-rap love songs are. But here love songs are deployed a bit blank-facedly
column3: strings of clichés
column4: shrugging platitudes and half-thoughts drawn together into a husk of what used to be a compellingly contradictory personality. The idea of a banal yet subtly tense reunion with a long-forgotten ex in ""Your Name Here"" is undercut by the fact that there's not enough interesting personal details to make Slug's rejected reconnection come across like anything more than a petty dismissal. And while ""The Last to Say"" is 100% worth hearing if it convinces just one woman to leave the abusive asshole that blackens her eyes
column5: it's weird that it sounds less emotionally invested than the sharp-spitting breakup kissoff ""Just for Show"".

column1: As Slug's performative role dials down the emotional resonance
column2: the beats have followed suit into a low-intensity churn
column3: one that undercuts what could've been a set of adventurous live-band hip-hop with a uniform lethargy that tops out at mid-tempo. While the instrumentation of When Life Gives You Lemons signaled a wealth of potential new directions for Atmosphere's production
column4: The Family Sign runs almost entirely on gloomy ballads heavy on maudlin piano chords and keening guitar riffs. That latter instrument's maybe the most interesting sonic component of Ant's post-sampling compositional phase
column5: and Nate Collis cranks out Black Keys-ian twang (""Bad Bad Daddy"")
column6: psychedelic noir (""My Key"")
column7: and eerie slide (""The Last to Say"") with versatile ease. And if Erick Anderson's keyboards tend to provide more texture than melody
column8: at least he's as handy with Jackie Mittoo reggae riffs (""Just for Show"") as he is with new wave glow (""I Don't Need Brighter Days""). But there's little to cut through the fog-- with the exception of the joy-buzzer jolt of ""She's Enough"" and the flailing attempt at Nilsson-style AM pop on ""Ain't Nobody""
column9:
this is music that conflates maturity with exhaustion.

'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['We Are Free']|2011-04-13 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:32:00.993760|"

There's a particular stance that singer Molly Siegel takes when Ponytail plays live
column3: usually at the start of their shows
column4: where she looks ready to throw herself headlong into battle. You can see it in this clip of ""Beg Waves""
column5: a song that originally surfaced on the Baltimore group's second record
column6: Ice Cream Spiritual. Siegel stands rooted at the edge of the stage
column7: right in the audience's faces
column8: with her tiny frame spread as wide as it could possibly go. She'll often compound the feeling by dressing in a football shirt and daubing smudges of makeup on her cheeks. That posture works as a kind of harbinger of her subsequent response to the music
column9: which involves a full-blooded commitment to the cause
column10: complete with facial spasms
column11: the spouting of a strange un-language in place of lyrics
column12: numerous tussles with the crowd
column13: and an unyielding physical reaction to the sound.

column1: In some respects Siegel's visceral scuffling against the band's noise lies in marked contrast to the nature of Ponytail's music-- the word ""joyous"" is often invoked to describe their work
column2: and with good reason. But that dichotomy is where Ponytail find their meaning
column3: with guitarists Dustin Wong and Ken Seeno interlacing ray-of-light guitar lines that provide the inexorable uplift
column4: while Siegel thrashes around like she's trying to escape from her own skin and bones. That vigor and commitment to the cause
column5: particularly Siegel's uninhibited shredding of her self on a regular basis
column6: must be immensely taxing. So it's perhaps unsurprising that this third Ponytail record
column7: which bears a title that perfectly reflects their single-minded vision
column8: comes at a time when they are on hiatus
column9: pursuing other projects
column10: taking a breather from such an all-consuming interest.

column1: The opening ""Easy Peasy"" works in much the same way ""Beg Waves"" did on Ice Cream Spiritual
column2: as a slow-build entry point into the record. It begins with a minute or two of anticipation
column3: where the members gradually layer on each element that makes the overall sound function
column4: almost as though they're putting an arm around your shoulder and gently ushering you into their world. But once those components are all put together-- the abstract noise
column5: the vocal yelps
column6: the giddily plaited guitar lines
column7: the galloping drum patterns-- the song only devolves further into maniacal glee
column8: where the tempo constantly stop-starts
column9: never reaches an even meter
column10: and ultimately races breathlessly to the finish line with a great lurch of pace at the end.

column1: That Beefheart-like tendency to avoid consistent rhythm and keep the audience guessing is partly what makes this music feel so alive. Couple that with the natural exuberance that bleeds out of the playing
column2: and it's hard not to get lost in the infectious indulgence of Ponytail's music. That said
column3: there are a few changes this time out. ""Flabbermouse"" is less dense than most of their material
column4: with the crosscut guitar playing kept on an even keel throughout and matched with acres of space; and Siegel's parts are more refined than before
column5: often only amounting to a few snatched words or disappearing altogether on ""Beyondersville/Flight of Fancy"". The latter falls in line with the bare-bones experimentation of Wong's excellent Infinite Love album from last year
column6: where guitar patterns are splayed out and looped over a rhythm track that never settles into a solid groove.

column1: There's been a subtle evolution of Ponytail's approach over their three-album career
column2: and tracks like ""Beyondersville/Flight of Fancy"" and the vast metallic sheets of noise that open ""Music Tunes"" at the close of this album keep that forward-thinking pattern firmly in place. But there's also plenty of material here to satisfy fans of their older sound. ""Honey Touches"" has been a staple of their live set for a while and is ostensibly the straightest track here
column3: with Hyman guiding the band through a series of steady rhythm patterns and Siegel hinting at what's to come with her opening word: ""en-er-gy."" It's also one of the few Ponytail tracks where you can discern some of her lyrics. ""I know it's not that fun"" is the mantra that closes the song
column4: which taps into that lopsided Ponytail ideology
column5: where control and abandon make perfect bedfellows
column6: and the most ""fun"" song on the record comes to a close with the singer claiming it's the exact opposite.

column1: There are further deviations from the Ice Cream Spiritual aesthetic as the record progresses-- ""Tush"" takes a few unintelligible words from Siegel and loops them over a series of bathetic riffs; ""AwayWay"" returns to the wide open spaces of ""Flabbermouse"" before delving into that furiously exhilarating noise they are so adept at plundering. But it's in the closing ""Music Tunes"" that the record peaks. Here
column2: that knotty riffing that Wong and Seeno can pile up so well is set to a long build up that
column3: some four minutes in
column4: takes an abrupt turn into great expanses of robo-noise
column5: which ping back and forth and suck in another burst of that ""en-er-gy"" to close the record on a barely contained high. At the time of writing this review there's a message on the We Are Free website
column6: which is layered over a picture of grunge titans Soundgarden
column7: that reads: ""Ponytail has not broken up"". It's a welcome reminder of this band's current status
column8: because one hopes that Do Whatever You Want All the Time isn't an end
column9:
but another new beginning.

If this isn't the first review you've read of Smart Flesh
column2: you're likely already aware that the Low Anthem recorded much of the record with a bunch of friends in an abandoned pasta sauce factory near their hometown of Providence
column3: Rhode Island.  It's a delectable PR morsel
column4: used as a metaphorical device for the people who created it: A community of workers rolling up their sleeves to humbly pull long hours manufacturing food is a quirky image of increasingly archaic American industriousness
column5: a pat likeness for a band like Low Anthem working within time-honored and respected folk tropes. The physical labor used to be the only tedious thing in the scenario; here
column6: the product is drudgingly tiresome
column7: too.

column1: Smart Flesh begins with a cover of George Carter standard ""Ghost Woman Blues""-- a pretty display of their harmonic compatibility that establishes the LP's thematic thread of being supernaturally inhabited. The cavernous
column2: almost living sound of Smart Flesh gives it distinction from their previous album
column3: the word-of-mouth success <i>Oh My God
column4: Charlie Darwin!
column5: and adds tactile weight to clarinet moans and harmonies that might otherwise waft away. But they're more or less haunted by those who still walk the earth: At times recalling Bob Dylan's astringent rambles
column6: Tom Waits' picaresques
column7: Leonard Cohen's mordant balladry
column8: the Band's idealized Americana
column9: or even Cat Stevens
column10: the Low Anthem's sensibilities scan as tasteful and easily identifiable.

column1: But what do they bring other than hearts in the right place? For the most part
column2: it's a sort of presumably arch intellect and ripe lyrical bent that's nowhere near as clever as it thinks. Is their entry in the ""love is the drug"" metaphorical game any less played out because they use the word ""apothecary"" instead of ""pharmacy?"" Singer Ben Knox Miller remembers where he was when the world stopped turning on ""Boeing 737""
column3: but what of the forced reference to Philippe Petit of Man on Wire fame? Is it just another attempt by Low Anthem to siphon charm from a pat acknowledgement of liberal arts culture?

column1: Such aspirations could've been forgiven had they found more vibrant compositions. The Low Anthem are mostly hands-off in the museum of American folk tradition
column2: mistaking dragging tempos for gravitas
column3: blank arrangements for hymnal transcendence
column4: and Mel Bay melodies for
column5: well... they're pretty much employed as expected. At least ""Boeing 737"" tries to kick up dust
column6: but the thickness of the reverb makes them sound like they're merely running in place-- it's sort of a weird collaboration between Pig-Pen and the Arcade Fire.

column1: With minimal effort
column2: you can find plenty of other acts putting their own idiosyncratic spin on the early 20th century canon
column3: many of whom simply have better songs. But the Low Anthem will be fine: Sadly
column4: this sort of thing always finds an audience that rewards it for its deference. (And
column5: at the very least
column6: the Low Anthem lack the pandering
column7: salt-of-the-earth vibe of Mumford & Sons and the po-faced seriousness of the Avett Brothers.) But as long as the Low Anthem discount the idea that this music was once meant to stir the blood
column8: rile the soul
column9: and actually be exciting
column10:
it's always going to be historically inaccurate in a way no amount of sepia-toned ambience can overcome.

It's been four years since the surprising commercial success of MGMT's Oracular Spectacular
column3: and a steady stream of vaguely pysch
column4: synth-loving bands continues to flow from that record's neon wake. In the corner of higher aspirations
column5: you have Columbia-signed fresh-facers Foster the People
column6: whose labelmate status with MGMT gives off a bit of a ""the calls are coming from inside the house"" feeling. Portland synth-poppers Starfucker
column7: on the other hand
column8: have been doing the spacey headband thing for almost as long as MGMT have (or
column9: more accurately
column10: were)-- and
column11: yet
column12: it proves difficult to resist comparison. Their 2008 self-titled debut had the same shoddy
column13: in-development synthy sound that many of us heard from those Wesleyan boys when their Time to Pretend EP was circulating around 2005; on Starfucker's sophomore effort
column14: Reptilians
column15: there are a few moments (the drum sounds on opening track ""Born""
column16: the mortality-questioning nature of ""Death as a Fetish"") where that influence is extended to MGMT's forebears
column17: the Flaming Lips.

column1: To dismiss Reptilians-- and Starfucker's general style

The sonic fidelity here is about a million times better than that of their debut-- an improvement no doubt abetted by the band's jump to recovering-but-still-fighting indie Polyvinyl. What you're getting here: a fair amount of intricate synth work paired with catchy alt-indie melodies that would fit in perfectly as transitional music to almost any show on the CW. At times
column5: the former can overshadow the latter-- minus some blaring MIDI'd-to-death horns
column6: the twinkling tunnel of ""Bury Us Alive"" is the kind of rabbit hole that bands like Bear in Heaven should think about heading down more often. They clearly demonstrate the capability to make ""hits
column7: too; the anthemic ascent of ""Julius"" and ""Mystery Cloud"" seem like the kind of stuff that
column8: for better and for worse
column9: would get stuck near the top of the Hype Machine or elbo.ws charts for a while. There's something innately appealing to the best of this band's melodies-- whatever it is almost completely lacks originality
column10: granted
column11: but it's hard not to see the small promises hidden within this record's modest highlights.

column1: Whatever goodwill that gets built up in the record's enjoyably familiar first half is slowly chipped away at during its back end. As a whole
column2: Reptilians is 41 minutes long-- not exactly as bad as listening to 2112 three times in a row or anything
column3: but the running time on this thing nonetheless feels like a slog. A glut of midtempo dithering mostly takes up the second half
column4: and while some of the songs situated there are decent on their own
column5: together they congeal into an asymmetrical mess
column6: exposing Reptilians' front-loaded wiring.

column1: Oh
column2: and another thing: This band's name sucks-- and I say this in an era of truly terrible
column3: roll-your-eyes-until-you-die monikers. With a band name like Police Academy 6 or Nid and Sancy
column4: though

column6: an enjoyably stupid public self-prank that makes for good conversation at the least. Naming your band Starfucker
column7: on the other hand
column8: seems like an action on the level of cursing around your friends for the first time in grade school-- it's blunt
column9: and it might get a laugh or two
column10: but it's strictly juvenile. It's almost as if they picked the name to dare people to listen to their record. Seeing as how they're still a ways away from being anything more than a blog concern
column11:
I'm not too sure the gambit is working.

On paper
column2: TV on the Radio's recent accomplishments look like the work of textbook careerists. They left renowned indie label Touch and Go to join Interscope. Their major-label debut boasted a cameo from David Bowie. Singer Tunde Adebimpe starred opposite Anne Hathaway in a Jonathan Demme-directed drama. Guitarist/producer Dave Sitek made a record with Scarlett Johansson and is now possibly joining Jane's Addiction. Of course
column3: one listen to any TV on the Radio album quickly dispels any notion of calculated opportunism. Even as their art-rock soul has blossomed out of their home-recording roots into something bigger and bolder
column4: their music is still fraught with a simmering unease; even the dancefloor-ready maneuvers of 2008's Dear Science exuded a jittery
column5: restless energy that was as tense as it was celebratory.

column1: However
column2: as Nine Types of Light suggests
column3: perhaps they just needed to get out of Brooklyn. The new album marks two significant changes in TVOTR's methodology: It was made in the wake of a one-year hiatus following six years of non-stop recording and touring; and it was recorded in Los Angeles
column4: where Sitek has been steadily building his celebrity clientele list over the past few years. Both factors seem to have influenced the sound and feel of the album: Nine Types of Light is unquestionably TV on the Radio's most patient
column5: positive recording to date
column6: taking its cues as much from Dear Science's serene ballads (""Family Tree""
column7: ""Love Dog"") as its brassy workouts. Each of the band's albums has opted for a tone-setting opening salvo
column8: and mission statements don't come more concise and clear-headed than Tunde Adebimpe's ecstatic
column9: falsettoed hook on Nine Types' first song
column10: ""Second Song"": ""Every lover on a mission/ Shift your known position/ Into the light.""

column1: Love songs are
column2: of course
column3: nothing new for TV on the Radio
column4: but they're usually cast against the grim backdrop of life during wartime: <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/8197-desperate-youth-blood-thirsty-babes/"" target=""_blank""><i>Desperate Youth
column5: Bloodthirsty Babes' doo-wop serenade ""Ambulance"" spoke of emotional commitment using the language of hospital care; Return to Cookie Mountain's ""Province"" effectively equated a declaration of love with an act of radicalism. On Nine Types of Light
column6: however
column7: there seems to be a more concerted effort on the band's part to not let external pressures sully their inner spirit: Set to steady shuffle beats
column8: ""Will Do"" and ""You"" are impassioned
column9: open-hearted addresses delivered free of any political context
column10: while Kyp Malone's ""Keep Your Heart"" feels like a riposte to Cookie Mountain's defeatist ""I was a lover before this war"" refrain
column11: promising instead to ""keep your heart
column12: if the world all falls apart."" Malone's stutter-funk standout ""No Future Shock"" takes this don't-let-the-bastards-get-you-down sentiment to more delightfully absurd extremes
column13: channeling pervasive anxieties over everything from global economic collapse to invasive airport security into a new dance move (""Do the no future! Do the no future!"").

column1: Coming four songs in
column2: ""No Future Shock"" at first feels like an anomaly on an album that frontloads its more elegiac material; the notion that Nine Types is a more subdued
column3: comedown counterpoint to Dear Science is further posited by Adebimpe's six-minute
column4: mid-album centerpiece
column5: ""Killer Crane""
column6: a pretty
column7: proggy pastorale that gently ebbs and flows with flourishes of strings
column8: piano
column9: banjo
column10: and mellotron. But the album's second half is more in step with Dear Science's manic swagger; though mid-tempo exercises ""New Cannonball Blues"" and ""Forgotten"" never catch fire to the same degree (even with the late-song intrusion of the horn section)
column11: ""Repetition"" is an exhilarating display of Adibempe and Malone's motor-mouthed repartee set to a krautrock thrust. And as weird as it was to see Liars' Angus Andrew faithfully singing INXS' ""Guns in the Sky"" in a promo vid for Beck's Record Club last year
column12: Nine Types' massive
column13: arena-rattling closer
column14: ""Caffeinated Consciousness"" proves that song must hold a special place in the hearts of Brooklyn's post-punk class of 2002.

column1: In the past
column2: TV on the Radio have tried to undercut their more rockist ambitions with dissonant textures and queasy atmospherics
column3:
or lace their prettiest ballads with subversively ominous lyrics. But Nine Types of Light shows how TV on the Radio's transmissions can be just as effective and affecting when delivered free of static and noise.

The short version of the pre-release trailer for Low's C'mon was nothing but a still shot of Alan Sparhawk
column2: sitting at a table in front of a microphone with headphones on

column6: clanging guitar line ties together the decidedly scattershot lyrics. On the groaning
column7: eight-minute ""Nothing But Heart""
column8: Nels Cline appears on steel guitar

column2: ""Especially Me""
column3: riding a bobbing 6/8 rhythm with a haunting

column5: at least until a rush of strings carries the song to its closing verse. Sparhawk and Parker showcase their distinctive harmonies on twinkling album opener ""Try to Sleep""-- if all this is beginning to sound like a tour of the various twists and turns in Low's direction over the years
column6: there's a good reason for that. Having covered a good deal of ground since breaking out of their original slowcore mold
column7: on C'mon
column8: Low seem undecided on a direction forward.

column1: As such
column2: C'mon feels more like a collection drawn from throughout the last decade than a completely cohesive album. This could be viewed as the band sorting through the progress it's made in search of the next turn-- there are even a few songs that come close to revisiting the glacial sparseness of their earliest music. This is all to say that
column3: if you already like Low

column6:

column3: Vol. 9: The Witmark Demos: 1962-1964
column4: which collected rough recordings that Bob Dylan made as part of his first two publishing deals. They were impromptu sessions in a glorified broom closet

column6: including ""Don't Think Twice It's Alright"" and ""Blowin' in the Wind"". At nearly 50 tracks

column9: roughest
column10: unfinished forms

column1: The Brandeis show was recorded in May 1963
column2: which is auspicious: Just two weeks later
column3: Dylan would release his second album
column4: The Freewheelin' Bob Dylan

column9: he was billed under Pete Seeger and Jean Ritchie

column11: more established acts.

column1: As scholar Michael Gray writes in the new liner notes (which weren't included in the bonus version)

column5: the tapes provide a valuable snapshot of pre-fame Dylan
column6: who gives a rambling performance that balances gravity with levity. ""Talkin' John Birch Paranoid Blues"" and ""Talkin' World War III Blues"" scoff at anti-communist scaremongering and war-profiteering justifications
column7: and Dylan's barbed satire provokes some laughs from his audience. He addresses the same subjects on the dead-serious ""Masters of War"" and ""Bob Dylan's Dream""
column8: on which his earnest strumming and mournful harmonica evoke a sense of solitude
column9: as if sanity in the face of such madness has isolated him from humanity.

column1: The setlist is
column2: however
column3: lackluster
column4: showcasing what would become deep-album cuts to the neglect of his better material. By the time he winds up his lengthy intro to ""Talkin' Bear Mountain Picnic Massacre Blues""
column5: his talking blues delivery has grown tiresome even. Of course

column7: at seven songs (six-and-a-half if you discount the excerpt of ""Honey
column8: Just Allow Me One More Chance"")
column9: Brandeis is necessarily slight. It needs context. In that regard
column10: it might have been interesting to hear this set as one of the many live performances from that same folk festival
column11: if only for the opportunity to contrast Dylan with his contemporaries and to determine his place within the folk scene. Otherwise

column13: they'd swapped out their rhythm section and tempered their debut's hypno-rock clatter into a more relaxed
column14: jangly groove that they would ride out for two more albums before disbanding in 1991.

column6: post-Velvets power-pop-- a sound that ruled college radio airwaves in the mid-80s but which boasts few notable contemporary adherents-- and blissfully strum away as if they were performing in hammocks. And there's good reason to believe that

column1: Despite the myriad

column4: or trying to prove their relevance to a younger generation. The nerviest track here
column5: ""Time Is Right""
column6: seems to mock this very idea
column7: with Glenn Mercer sardonically declaring
column8: ""Gotta do something/ Get in with the crowd."" But even if the Feelies aren't exactly challenging themselves on Here Before
column9: they still prove themselves masters of arrangement
column10: strategically positioning key elements to give these seemingly simple songs a greater dynamic impact. Examples include the glorious guitar solo that pushes the accelerator on ""Should Be Gone""
column11: the stop/start snare-drum triggers on ""Later On""
column12: or the strange

column14:

column6: he set up a tent in the sculpture garden and lived on the grounds
column7: making extensive field recordings of bird screeches
column8: traffic

Noah Lennox's Panda Bear project has always been about making ""difficult"" music scan as almost radio-friendly

column3: at least in part

column5: along with the avant-techno types he reveres. Like those disparate influences
column6: Lennox has used potentially off-putting compositional and textural ideas to craft some of the most inviting music of his era. In turn

column9: sun-woozy synths
column10: droning kraut-surf-ambient-pop songs

column1: Tomboy
column2: Lennox's fourth solo album as Panda Bear
column3: was mixed with Pete ""Sonic Boom"" Kember of Spectrum/Spacemen 3. And again
column4: in a way there's little here that's any further out-there than the blissful psychedelia and dream-pop Spacemen 3 and their peers were playing in the late 1980s

column1: But despite Tomboy's shorter songs and more conventional structures-- especially compared to the loose percussive jams of Lennox's 2007 solo breakthrough Person Pitch-- he's still committed to pushing his music to strange places. And few of his chilled-to-the-point-of-entropy acolytes can match Lennox for warped hooks. Forget comparing his gorgeous voice to their mumbling. Unlike many chillwave and dream-pop artists (and Spacemen 3)
column2: Lennox is blessed with the ability to actually sing
column3: and he knows enough about crafting harmonies to do more than vaguely nod in the direction of 60s pop. So Tomboy is a pretty singular mix of the eerie and the inviting.

column1: Despite the murk and terror and noise of Animal Collective's earliest music
column2: there's never been anything particularly ugly about Lennox's mature solo work
column3: starting with 2004's Young Prayer. But even then
column4: he wasn't comfortable playing the laid-back hippie stereotype that's been laid on A.C. by detractors in recent years. Young Prayer might still be the most emotionally wrenching album in the Collective's catalog
column5: an album written by a young man wrestling with some heavy shit. Lennox's father was dying of brain cancer while Young Prayer was being written. ""[My father] got to read the lyrics
column6: which was the most important thing to me
column7: he told me in 2005; Young Prayer was a last attempt at confirming the good his father had done for him.

column1: Musically
column2: the album was the least bleak
column3: least difficult thing an Animal Collective member had recorded to that point. But the unembellished recording-- you could almost hear the empty rooms in which it was recorded-- only heightened the fragility of the songs. ""I didn't want to spend a lot of time producing it or thinking about how I wanted to get it to sound
column4: Lennox said in that same interview. ""I just wanted to get it out quickly."" Tomboy is a much more considered record
column5: with thickly layered psych-style production. There's also another heavy dose of dub

column2: if not the emotionally blasted vibe
column3: of Young Prayer after the ornate structures and epic lengths of Person Pitch. Instead of a Young Prayer we now have a ""Surfer's Hymn"". Instead of a naked guitar and a lot of blank space in the recording we get a wall-of-sound rush and percussion that's like Steve Reich by way of IDM. But the spare droning quality and devotional feeling of the music remains. There was plenty of church music in the Beach Boys and Arthur Russell
column4: too
column5: and Tomboy has a similar quality of embracing both summer fun and hushed spirituality.

column1: The trouble with recording a ramshackle epic like Person Pitch is that you set up a portion of your audience to expect the next album to be at least as grand in both scope and design. There are certainly no obvious peaks on Tomboy like ""Bros"" or ""Good Girl/Carrots""

But the scaling back on Tomboy in no way represents a scaling back of ambition on Lennox's part. In a way

column4:
and very few have the chops or inventiveness to pull off.

column1: Wiz has managed an unusual trajectory
column2: rising from a modest army brat to a squelched major label deal at Warner Bros. and back to the independent route. He was prolific-- perhaps too prolific
column3: releasing nine mixtapes and two officially sanctioned albums before this major-label lunge. By 2010's Kush & Orange Juice
column4: an exceptionally laidback and tasteful mixtape that made him a star
column5: Wiz solidified his identity: affable smoker
column6: limited rapper
column7: inspirational survivor
column8: melodic genius. And all before the age of 23.

column1: Now signed to Atlantic Records
column2: home to compromised contemporaries Lupe Fiasco and B.o.B
column3: Wiz runs the risk of having his loose
column4: gliding style trampled by this new partner's A&R department. That's not quite the case-- Rolling Papers is a singular document with just a handful of exceptions. The album's lead single
column5: the Super Bowl-adopted anthem ""Black and Yellow""
column6: is a driving song
column7: but Wiz seems dazed in the delivery. He has never been a complicated writer
column8: but on a song meant to whip up some frenzy
column9: he is shockingly relaxed. ""Stay high like how I'm supposed to do/ That crowd underneath them clouds can't get close to you/ And my car look unapproachable/ Super clean but it's super mean.""

column1: These are an abysmal few bars from the song
column2: but they (or any of his lyrics
column3: really) do little to explain Wiz's appeal. He does atmosphere
column4: and the team of producers here-- a varied bunch that includes Norwegian mercenaries StarGate
column5: Wiz's in-house crew I.D. Labs
column6: and the Floridian pop-rap savant Jim Jonsin-- has given this album surprising cohesion. It cascades
column7: never rushing into anything. Opener ""When I'm Gone"" ambles along
column8: a somber piano line playing out softly for nearly a minute before introducing the propulsive guts of the song. Only when Wiz attempts to burst forward
column9: as on disjointed closer ""Cameras""
column10: <span> is he susceptible to his own limitations. Ambitions low
column11: tone lower.

column1: There's an urge to throw weed metaphors around a Wiz Khalifa review-- it is his love
column2: his leisure
column3: his reason for living. Taking his time is only a product of this blunted life. Which is a boon on ""The Race""
column4: the best song here
column5: a luxurious
column6: decadent ode to success that couldn't sound more like a vacation. But weed is also his curse. Consider the Sublime-like ""Fly Solo""
column7: also produced by I.D. Labs
column8: which is pure dorm-room junk. Or ""No Sleep""
column9: a shameless bid for Benny Blanco-produced house-rap glory. No one could be less suited to this sort of thing than Wiz. Still
column10: if you seek texture and assurance
column11: there are few recent songs as masterfully casual as ""Hopes and Dreams"" and ""Rooftops""
column12: the latter of which features his friend and sonic compatriot Curren$y (one of just three guest spots on this album). The rippling opening notes of ""Hopes and Dreams""-- a far-off guitar strum
column13: a stuttering drum machine
column14: Wiz's dank voice-- are all vibe
column15: all presence
column16:
all persistence. Call it mood music for the mindless.

The Raveonettes may have written only a handful of distinct melodies in their career
column2: but their presentation has given them the staying power. Their theatrical sense was there from the beginning-- we saw band members Sune Rose Wagner and Sharin Foo sitting on motorcycles on the cover of 2003's full-length debut
column3: Chain Gang of Love
column4: and a movie poster tableau for of 2005's dusky Pretty in Black-- but by their 2009 album
column5: In and Out of Control
column6: they had toned down the visuals and made their most aimless record to date.

column1: In concept alone
column2: then
column3: the duo's fifth LP
column4: Raven in the Grave
column5: is a corrective step. The untangled pop of In and Out of Control has been reconfigured and dipped in black eyeliner as the Raveonettes veer toward 1980s goth. It's a canny move
column6: since dark sounds and moods have been creeping back into indie after a long stretch of beach-obsessed escapism.

column1: The thing is
column2: darkness isn't the best look for the Raveonettes. The album title suggests a tongue-in-cheek approach
column3: but this might be the band's most joyless release yet. It's not like they're missing the mark on their source material
column4: either. The cloudy
column5: Disintegration-like synths of ""War in Heaven"" and the metallic beat of ""Apparitions"" both suggest their comfort with this material. But there's none of the spiky propulsion that has marked their best music. In the case of one-two fizzle ""Summer Moon"" and ""Let Me on Out""
column6: they seem to have completely forgotten to write melodies. And though lyrics have frequently been placeholders for these guys
column7: the adapted angst on display here is an ill fit. There's a ""War in Heaven""
column8: you see
column9: because ""I hate it/ When they forget/ To let people in."" The problem in ""Evil Seeds""
column10: on the other hand
column11: is that rain causes the protagonist to ""betray the ones I've come to love the most."" These wasted words seem too shoddy even for the back of someone's spiral notebook.

column1: There are spots where light shines in. Three songs
column2: in fact
column3: are among the strongest the Raveonettes have recorded
column4: which makes the album seem like even more of a missed opportunity. Opener ""Recharge & Revolt"" is their most majestic shoegaze moment yet
column5: while ""Ignite"" is a particularly sweet slice of 1990s alt rock
column6: with a thrilling build and sweetly sung yet morbid chorus that suggests the band hasn't completely lost their sense of humor. Then there's ""Forget That You're Young""
column7: which is hands-down the best song on the album and a true career high. It's always hard to tell with this pair

column9:
a potential new way forward for a band that could use one.

""Based."" Lil B's buzzword doesn't really have a clear definition
column2: but it has
column3: nevertheless
column4: spawned a distinctive aesthetic. A search through music given the ""based"" tag on BandCamp reveals a whole bunch of rambling rappers aping B's free-associative flow and just as many oddball producers putting out home-recorded
column5: sorta stoned-sounding beats that maybe-- just maybe-- Lil B will one day rap over. ""Based"" has evolved from a style of rapping (and a wonky world philosophy) to a know-it-when-you-hear-it sound. New Jersey producer Clams Casino is one of the sonic architects behind ""based music."" His beat for Lil B's ""I'm God""
column6: featuring a stretched-out sample of Imogen Heap's ""Just For Now""
column7: is the ""based music"" blueprint.

column1: ""I'm God"" isn't included on Instrumental Mixtape; the beats here are even more diffuse
column2: and it wouldn't really fit. It speaks to Clams' rarefied vision that he refuses to find room for an in-demand instrumental on a free download but includes an untitled final track
column3: a bizarre
column4: minute-long footwork-like manipulation of ""Teddy's Jam"" from 1980s new jack swing group Guy. This collection of instrumentals doesn't simply survey Clams' production; it turns his rap beats into moody compositions and flips the basic beat-tape concept into an album-like collection of electronic music.

column1: Clams Casino productions generally bring together conventional hip-hop drums
column2: a sensitive ear for off-to-the-side melodies
column3: and an overdose of oddly moving atmosphere. ""Motivation"" begins with a buzz of in-the-red static and a moaning vocal sample
column4: and then suddenly the beat drops and the vocal sample begins eerily humming along. Later on
column5: blasts of bass rumble through
column6: and animal noises arrive instead of a breakdown. When the beat drops the next time around
column7: it's accompanied by some rainy
column8: Blade Runner-style keyboards. The bird squawks and the keyboard melody are wrapped up in the beat
column9: and it repeats
column10: riding-out for a bit
column11: before abruptly ending with a patch of industrial drone.

column1: But it's Clams' attention to hip-hop structure that makes these beats so emotionally devastating. The desperate melodrama comes through in the hesitant build-up and explosive arrival of the drums. And the lingering sense of sadness is communicated when those drums sneak away and all that's left is a layer of whimpering electronic haze. For all of their experimental tendencies
column2: these songs are essentially
column3: sample-based loops. ""Illest Alive"" is an artful slicing and dicing of Bjork's ""Bachelorette"" and as revealed in an interview with Pitchfork last week
column4: ""Realist Alive"" is Adele's ""Hometown Glory"" slowed
column5: slurred
column6: and made well
column7: glorious. Even those few productions that ape established hip-hop styles
column8: like the Bay Area wobblers ""Brainwash by London"" and ""She's Hot"" maintain this tension between dogged structure and brash experimentation.

column1: Instrumental Mixtape makes it clear that Clams Casino is part of an expanding group of up-and-coming innovative rap producers like Araabmuzik
column2: the Block Beattaz
column3: DJ Burn One
column4: Droop-E
column5: and Lex Luger. But his beats
column6: when heard without vocals
column7: become even more interesting and arguably better. Full of subtle production flourishes (pulsing percussion on ""All I Need""
column8: a sliver of flute on ""Numb""
column9: muffled gun-shot sound effects on ""Cold War"") and possessing a true artist's comfort with indulgence (nearly every track is caked with effects)
column10: his music can be heard alongside a genre-spanning scene of musicians like How to Dress Well
column11: Tim Hecker
column12: Burial
column13: Toro Y Moi
column14: and James Blake
column15:
all of whom mine the oddly melancholic effect of digital glitch.

Last summer
column2: Snoop Dogg headlined the backpack-centric Rock the Bells tour
column3: performing his classic debut album
column4: Doggystyle
column5: in full every night and drawing rapturous reviews. This year
column6: Snoop will make a few stops on Charlie Sheen's continuous-trainwreck Violent Torpedo of Truth tour
column7: performing a song that he and Sheen have apparently recorded together. That duality is pretty much circa-2011 Snoop in a nutshell. He's a rap legend
column8: and he's also an unapologetically inane public figure
column9: someone who's more famous for being famous than he is for rapping. He seems to enjoy both roles in equal measure. And so late-period Snoop albums become weird
column10: uncentered artifacts
column11: with no real idea or consistent personality pulling them all together. You get sweeping attempts at crossover hits
column12: nasty street-rap throwbacks
column13: and bizarre cross-genre collaborations that any self-aware A&R never would've allowed. And even though Snoop is nowhere near the commercial force he once was
column14: he can still round up a fuckton of famous people whenever he decides to record an album. Not too many artists would bury their Kanye West collaborations on track 18 of their albums
column15: but that's what Snoop does on Doggumentary
column16: his latest reminder to the world that he's still an active musician.

column1: More than many of Snoop's recent efforts
column2: Doggumentary has something of a sonic identity. Snoop mines slick
column3: slapbass-heavy 1980s R&B and computer-funk on the album
column4: working with producers like Fredwreck
column5: Jake One
column6: and Battlecat to conjure the smooth soul of the early Reagan era. Another rap veteran recently did great things with that same loose aesthetic playground: Big Boi on last year's excellent Sir Lucious Left Foot. But where Big Boi and his collaborators attacked that stuff with a giddy sense of experimental joy
column7: Snoop just lets it sit there
column8: as if his older-than-time persona will be enough to sell whatever he wants. And so vast stretches of the way-too-long Doggumentary drift by
column9: making no impression whatsoever.

column1: Snoop is still a perfectly capable rapper
column2: but he doesn't let off a single memorable line on the whole album. Instead
column3: his greatest strengths now are his delivery-- he can stick right to whatever beat the world throws at him-- and his wizened
column4: familiar voice. Since neither of these things has changed in the past decade
column5: every new Snoop verse feels like a verse we've heard before
column6: with the possible exception of the parts of the gently moralistic ""Peer Pressure"" where Snoop tells kids to project inner strength and resist alcohol and drugs-- messages that directly contradict almost every other song on his album.

column1: With Snoop more often than not acting as a big blank at the center of his own album
column2: many of the best moments on Doggumentary belong to his collaborators: E-40 letting loose tumbling flows over chaotic Rick Rock production on ""My Fucn House""
column3: R. Kelly bringing regal grace to an eerie Lex Luger beat on ""Platinum""
column4: Devin the Dude's loping everydude warmth on the otherwise shameful ""I Don't Need No Bitch"". As for Snoop himself
column5: the best parts come in the moments where he stops rapping altogether and sings instead
column6: or where he raps so easily that he might as well be singing. It's surprising that he doesn't do that more often here
column7: since the mostly-sung ""Sensual Seduction"" was his last serious solo hit. And here we get ""Boom""
column8: with Snoop skipping lazily over a sample of Yazoo's deathless electro classic ""Situation""
column9: and ""Wet""-- a song inexplicably written for Prince William's bachelor party-- where Snoop intones freaky come-ons through heavy Auto-Tune over the Cataracts' spaced-out synth squirts.

column1: And then there's ""Superman""
column2: the acoustic-ramble Willie Nelson duet that absolutely shouldn't work but somehow does. Snoop and Willie are both braided
column3: weed-addicted elder-statesman outlaw figures
column4: so it makes sense that they'd get along. But this song
column5: like the supremely silly 2008 Everlast collab ""My Medicine""
column6: shows that Snoop's gravelly drawl is pretty well-suited for country music. If he ever decides to push himself again
column7:
that's one direction available to him. But let's be serious: Snoop Dogg is not pushing himself anytime soon.

Is it a minor cosmic retribution that the bands doing the best job of recreating American indie rock of the 1990s are coming from the UK? Leading the way this year is Yuck
column2: with their self-titled LP; now emerging from the DIY scene that spawned the like-minded Male Bonding
column3: Pens
column4: and Spectrals
column5: London-via-Manchester quartet Mazes make a commendable entry into that realm with their FatCat debut
column6: A Thousand Heys.

column1: Lacking the comprehensive guitar sprawl of Yuck or the arty abrasiveness of Male Bonding
column2: Mazes instead embody the shambling approach to verse-chorus songwriting found in Pavement acolytes BOAT. It's the sort of stuff dubbed ""slacker"" because it gives the impression that its consciously chosen smart-dumb persona could be overcome with effort. From the lyrical standpoint of A Thousand Heys
column3: the outside world is indeed a terrordome of obligations
column4: demands
column5: and entanglements that are best left to others to sort out. A sampling of singer Jack Cooper's aspirations: ""I wanna sit at home without a job
column6: ""I never want anyone to have my name
column7: or most pointedly
column8: ""I never want to get out of bed
column9: no way."" But it's all delivered in a tart
column10: smart-alecky voice that lets you know it's inertia rather than crippling depression that gets him to this point.

column1: Despite the brisk tempos and the frazzled guitar tone
column2: it's all too approachable to classify as punk rather than power pop. The hook of ""Surf & Turf / Maths Tag"" has exquisite classic rock architecture
column3: belying Cooper's tendency to treat life as a spectator sport: ""I've lived a thousand days/ A thousand heys were thrown my way/ I get off trains and wave like Beatles at JFK."" Call a song titled ""Go Betweens"" too on-the-nose if you must
column4: but the exuberant chorus blasts off in such a way that the namedrop is earned.

column1: But as A Thousand Heys progresses
column2: as the hooks soften around the edges
column3: its derivativeness comes to the forefront. ""Boxing Clever"" is little more than adroit Pavement karaoke
column4: while ""Wait Anyway"" and ""Cenetaph"" make an ill-advised dip into bite-sized Crazy Horse guitar jams. Even stranger is how ""Vampire Jive"" and ""Eva"" blur by in a minute and a half combined; all of a sudden the album's center has disappeared
column5: and Heys is damn near over.

column1: Though it boasts a couple of heaters
column2: A Thousand Heys butts up against the same problem faced by so many others working in this timeless but relatively basic template-- there are undoubtedly listeners who won't ever get enough of this stuff
column3: but how can you distinguish yourself while still maintaining the spirit of your predecessors? Had the precocious spark of the first half been duplicated in the second
column4:
there'd be more than enough big choruses to make it a moot point-- a single ""hey!"" can have more impact than a thousand lesser ones.

Burial puts out music seldom enough that when he does
column3: it's an event. It's a scarcity thing: Instead of flooding the market with music
column4: he keeps fans wanting
column5: and he and the labels he works with know how to capitalize on that desire. A limited
column6: vinyl-only collaboration with Thom Yorke and Four Tet
column7: on the latter's Text Records
column8: was released with only a week's advance notice and sold out in no time. With the exception of the limited
column9: vinyl-only pressing
column10: Hyperdub followed a similar strategy for this release
column11: Burial's first new solo material since 2007
column12: and label boss Kode9 helped build the anticipation by premiering tracks on Benji B's BBC radio show.

column1: Not many electronic producers can command that type of hype. Fortunately
column2: Burial hasn't disappointed us. Anyone who feared that he might have moved on to a new sound-- perhaps
column3: like James Blake
column4: embracing pop songwriting-- can breathe a sigh of relief: This is the same melancholic Burial we've known and loved from the beginning. But listeners who wondered if the formula might be wearing thin
column5: diluting itself amidst all the rainy pitter-patter and tear-stained chords
column6: can also breathe easy. While sticking to the emotional terrain he's known for
column7: Burial also subtly pushes his sound in new directions.

column1: ""Street Halo"" is the closest Burial has come yet to the straighter cadence of house and techno
column2: with shuffling hi-hats and a crunchy handclap/fingersnap sound accentuating the 4/4 pulse; the middling tempo backs off dubstep's quick snap and eases into a relaxed
column3: rolling house groove. The backbeat bassline even recalls
column4: however unconsciously
column5: Ricardo Villalobos' ""Dexter""
column6: which isn't necessarily as absurd as it sounds: Both artists have a thing for accidental syncopations and splintering percussion. As always
column7: Burial's beats are oblique
column8: with a hazy percussive clatter lurking behind crisp
column9: timekeeping accents. And again
column10: he has made mournful
column11: a cappella vocals the melodic focus of the track
column12: and everything is suffused in a suggestive layer of static and grit. But he's a masterful arranger
column13: frequently switching up elements-- focusing one minute on a blunt
column14: rave-inspired bassline
column15: and the next on supersaturated vocal harmonies that sound like overdriven Cocteau Twins. The track follows a counterintuitive logic
column16: abandoning the predictable structure of breakdowns and buildups in favor of twists and turns you don't see coming
column17: including a fake fade-out at the end.

column1: The second track
column2: ""NYC""
column3: is even better. It's got all the yearning you could want from Burial
column4: thanks to its keening vocal lead and stately synthesizer pads. Taking his virtual razor to a long strip of female vocals
column5: he seems to have cut and pitch-shifted it in such a way that it hangs in the balance between meaning and pure sound
column6: with slippery nonsense syllables giving way to clearer phrases (""...when I'm around"") loaded with ambiguous emotion. Rhythmically
column7: Burial takes up the staggered cadences of UK garage
column8: long a favorite of his
column9: but he slows the tempo to around 115 bpm. It's a brilliant move
column10: giving garage's whipcrack syncopations an additional spring in their step; when combined with those floating keyboards and vocals
column11: the groove feels almost deliriously buoyant. (As a visual analogy
column12: I'm reminded of the underwater acrobatics in the video for Portishead's ""Only You""
column13: which turns out to make a superb visual accompaniment to Burial's screwed kinetics.) It's strange to think that so few producers have explored grooves like this at similar tempos; in Burial's hands
column14: it's a perfect merger of the pensive and the sensual.

column1: ""Stolen Dog"" is also based upon a mid-tempo house groove
column2: but the rhythm is less urgent than on the other two tracks
column3: its elements restricted to a thumping kick drum
column4: faint hi-hat tick
column5: and faint
column6: syncopated rimshots signaling the distant ghost of 2-step garage. There's a sing-song feel to the lilting synthesizer melody and the layered vocals over the top; it feels almost like a lullaby
column7: with soothing chord changes doing their best to keep the darkness at bay
column8: as dissonant bursts and ghostly clatter loom in the background. It might be the least essential of the three tracks here
column9: but it's every bit as carefully thought out. Somehow
column10: despite a sound bank that has long since become familiar
column11: Burial keeps finding new ideas to animate his worn
column12:
mournful samples.

What exactly do you want from Lil B? In most cases
column2: that sort of statement would come off as defensive
column3: but with Based God
column4: it's actually something of an invitation. As a cult of personality artist with a seemingly endless capacity for productivity
column5: Lil B's career is singular but very difficult to categorize or navigate. For newcomers
column6: there is no single document that serves as a proper introduction-- not even the supposedly comprehensive Free Music: The Complete MySpace Collection will do
column7: because it consists of 676 tracks and none of them is ""Wonton Soup"".

column1: His self-awareness aside
column2: I can't say whether Illusions of Grandeur-- Lil B's most cohesive and coherent collection of songs in a long time-- is an acknowledgement of the weirdly ephemeral nature of his musical output. In places it appears to be an olive branch to the Okayplayer faction of rap fans who view him as a scourge upon the supposed purity of the genre. That's what I got out of the pre-leak version of ""Based 4 Ya Face""
column3: which boasted a Public Enemy-sampling 9th Wonder beat and verses from ""real hip-hop"" torchbearers Jean Grae and Phonte (a solo version is included here). 9th Wonder fits surprisingly well; there is a nice synthesis between B's slack cadence and 9th's unobtrusive soul simmer. In addition
column4: Illusions is B at his most grounded topically and lyrically. For the most part
column5: he's back in his Berkeley homebase
column6: remembering zoned-out hours spent in coffee shops
column7: surveying the endless and depressing cycle of violence
column8: speaking directly to his fans and detractors
column9: and carrying an attitude that appears at odds with his flippant
column10: uncensored approach to music-making: he really cares.

column1: Of course
column2: Lil B's buffet-style consumption experience and stream-of-consciousness flow are still in place. Listening to him at times is like panning for gold-- you get some real nuggets
column3: but you have to work for each one. For those who want to put in the effort
column4: though-- and there a lot of people who do-- B seems to shapeshift into whatever form the listener chooses. The title track and ""Cocaine Killer"" can be viewed as some incredibly ill-formed storytelling if taken as linear narrative
column5: or as the stray thoughts indigenous to the harried nickel-and-dime hustler. There are pop-culture non sequiturs that make the Kool Keith comparisons apt
column6: and there are startlingly cogent revelations.

column1: Illusions of Grandeur
column2: therefore
column3: is as erratic as we've come to expect; despite the record being relatively ""cohesive"" and ""coherent"" for Lil B
column4: it's also a conservative addition to his catalog. While Illusions will certainly earn B some brownie points from those who like their hip-hop lyrical
column5: this approach doesn't get to the core of why Lil B has resonated with so many people. Then again
column6:
Based God's probably got something already cooked up that'll please his core fanbase.

Hanna is a film about a ""badass survivalist girl""; the Chemical Brothers have never seemed particularly badass
column2: but it's fair to count them as survivalist
column3: both because last year's Further was their best record in ages and they're the only act from the late-90s electronica boom making music anyone would want to listen to. The Chems are known for welding techno beats to a distinctly rock aesthetic
column4: and for much of the past 10 years they have functioned exactly like a rock band: standard album-tour-relax schedule
column5: few collaborations
column6: monster festival-headliner gigs. (And they can refer to themselves as ""superstar DJs"" all they like
column7: but their last widely available DJ mix came out in 1998.) For fans of the Brothers
column8: Hanna represents the shockingly rare opportunity to hear a work by the duo whose intentions fall outside their longtime M.O. of making techno for rock fans.

column1: I haven't seen Hanna; it appears to be a thriller set in Eastern Europe with a young female protagonist-- gifted in the art of action-- who eludes a ruthless intelligence operative. Digitized techno mysticism has been a go-to soundtrack of choice for this genre ever since The Bourne Identity rubber-stamped Moby's ""Extreme Ways"" as the perfect mix of heady paranoia
column2: Euro style
column3: and kicking things. The Chems-- with their widescreen sound
column4: relentless bravado
column5: and sturdy belief in entertainment-as-art-- are well suited for this kind of work.

column1: Hanna sounds a lot like a standard Chemical Brothers album--
<script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
saturated
column2: acidic keyboards; thundering drums; styles and signifiers used to bludgeon-- but with a bit more room to breathe. The band isn't deft enough to avoid the mewling vocals and tinkly music-box of the repeated ""Hanna's Theme"" (pathos: noted) but it's also not deft enough to apply any subtlety or grace to the Eastern scales and pulsing 2-4 beat of ""Escape 700""
column3: which is kind of the point. This is a band accustomed to soundtracking a light show that would put most stadium rock bands to shame; the chances of them easing off the gas or thinking too hard about the marriage of music and cinema were slim.

column1: The soundtrack offers some of the hard-charging thrills the Chems avoided on Further
column2: and it does so in an environment in which the onus of excitement isn't placed solely on the duo. This results in some terribly limp interstitial ""atmospheres""-- the Chems have never had the stomach for this kind of track; they sometimes seem bored (I am)-- but they add welcome contrast to their car-chase songs. Hanna aims for mystery and portent
column3: a slight but welcome tonal shift from the band's urban
column4: galactic edginess. The louche grooves of ""Car Chase (Arp Worship)"" are a bad fit for the steadily gaining tension they refer to
column5: but its beefy synthesizer roundhouse is the album's most head-nodding moment. They can't help but pepper ""The Devil Is in the Beats"" with the type of goofily serious vocal nonsense (""Rock the beat!"") they've always traded in.

column1: Hanna mostly wins in the sea of Hollywood action soundtracks
column2: but it's marginal as a Chemical Brothers album (I prefer it to their dry
column3: overstuffed mid-decade works). The Chems have rarely acknowledged anything outside their own blinding neon aesthetic
column4: which is to say that not only would the Chems never know they were in a creative rut
column5:
they would be unlikely to believe in ruts. Hanna doesn't represent anything more than a slight change-up from a group used to throwing fastballs.

Working under the name Craft Spells
column2: Stockton
column3: Calif.'s Justin Vallesteros makes music for bedsitters who dream about being social. Though often addressed to a love interest either real or imagined
column4: Idle Labor is above all a lonely album that rarely betrays its origin as a solo project. Sonically it recalls Wild Nothing it the way it mines a large swath of 1980s synth pop
column5: but its clear emotional tenor gives it a distinguishing perspective and personality.

column1: Idle Labor exists in a time frame best described by the title of its ebullient centerpiece-- ""After the Moment"". These are sketches of romantic problems and solutions with the wounds still fresh and the thoughts uncensored. Taken as a whole
column2: it could be read as a narrative following Vallesteros from heartbreak to infatuation and back
column3: a few months' worth of romantic uncertainty boiled down to a taut and hooky album.

column1: In a maundering yearn somewhere between Jens Lekman and Ian Curtis
column2: Vallesteros introduces himself as a lovelorn melodramatist over sunstroked
column3: near-Balearic pop. But as the narrative begins to hint at physical contact
column4: the music works in lockstep
column5: and Vallestreros builds tracks more as a dance producer than a singer-songwriter. And that's where he hits his stride-- while his vocals remain a central fixture
column6: the post-punk mordancy is softened by locomotive arrangements that stack synth pads
column7: ringing guitar
column8: and primitive drum programming.

column1: ""Party Talk"" starts a mid-album mini-suite with Vallesteros as a nebbishy Woody Allen character trying to decode a mutual romantic connection from casual conversation. But he leaps forward during the upbeat ""From the Morning Heat""
column2: and by the fantastic morning-after celebration ""After the Moment""
column3: something has apparently clicked; Vallesteros repeats the chorus as if he knows it's the best he's written.

column1: The emotional high is predictably short-lived
column2: and even within its brief half-hour runtime
column3: more than a few of the melodies take detours and left turns. ""The Fog Rose High"" has the feel of a gothier Beach Fossils
column4: while the anodyne dream-pop scruff of ""You Should Close the Door"" could have been a Radio Dept. B-side. But as with so many bedroom auteurs' debuts
column5: it's tough to separate the creation from the creator
column6:
and Idle Labor shows the promise of a precocious songwriter who isn't claiming to have anything totally figured out just yet.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16407/homepage_large.7bbfbc4c.jpg|Human Hearts|2916.0|Maritime|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dangerbird']|2011-04-07 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:32:10.549423|"

In hindsight
column2: it seems unfair that Maritime were introduced to the world as a collaboration between former members of two bands with incredible rhythm sections. Dismemberment Plan bassist Eric Axelson and former Promise Ring drummer Dan Didier are among the most muscular and interesting players to emerge from mid-to-late-90s indie rock
column3: and expectations were high for Maritime's 2004 debut
column4: Glass Floor
column5: to capitalize on the well-documented energy of both bands. For many who harbored such expectation-- myself
column6: admittedly
column7: included-- Glass Floor was a baffling disappointment
column8: a seemingly flat and lifeless album from musicians who had proven themselves capable of so much more.

column1: Three consistent and thoroughly enjoyable albums later
column2: it seems clear that Glass Floor was not a misstep
column3: but rather the first step toward something different; simply put
column4: Maritime do not create rhythm section music. While both the Dismemberment Plan and the Promise Ring often thrived on fast-paced collisions between complex and memorable individual parts
column5: Maritime take a more holistic approach
column6: often anchored by former Promise Ring vocalist Davey von Bohlen's ever-evolving melodic focus. Von Bohlen
column7: whose minimal yelps were central to the Promise Ring's appeal
column8: has grown into a mature and expressive singer; he not only sounds fully in control of his own voice
column9: but he also seems more willing than ever before to let loose with a little bit of flair and panache.

column1: The second Maritime album since Axelson's departure and the addition of bassist Justin Klug
column2: Human Hearts comes off as the most studio-centric batch of Maritime songs yet
column3: a well-constructed but less immediate foray in texture and layering. Opener ""It's Casual"" crams the emotional meat and bones of its chorus into a single vocal harmony
column4: a well-timed and well-executed gesture made all the more powerful by the space that surrounds it. ""Black Bones"" is evocative in its tone and setting
column5: pulling back to emphasize von Bohlen's vocals whenever the song threatens to buckle under the weight of its own atmosphere.

column1: Still
column2: Maritime are at their most undeniable when they really lay into it. ""Annihilation Eyes"" may be the best song they've ever recorded
column3: making full use of guitarist Dan Hinz's spiky guitar lines to spruce up a solid midtempo rocker. Hinz continues to be Maritime's secret weapon
column4: his angular
column5: high-on-the-neck playing adding post-punk bite to songs that occasionally lean a little bit too heavily on mood and ambiance. Von Bohlen's increasingly self-possessed vocal style flatters his writing immensely here
column6: as lines that previously might have seemed offputtingly precious now register as winks and not whimpers.

column1: That Maritime have released their third straight solid record is encouraging
column2: but no longer particularly surprising. Yes
column3: a high-profile indie rock pedigree can be an albatross; but it's also a pretty good indicator that a band will have the experience and foresight to weather unreasonable expectations and fight the good fight. Maritime's musical development has become a compelling narrative of its own
column4:
each subsequent record in many ways both improving upon and elucidating the last.

There's a cute little joke lurking in the background of Alfonso Cuarón's otherwise bleak dystopian thriller Children of Men. The film is set in the year 2027
column3: and at one point a deejay overheard on a car radio introduces ""a blast from the past all the way back to 2003
column4: before spinning the Kills' country-blues serenade ""Wait"". Even if 2003 was only eight years ago
column5: for the Kills
column6: it might as well be 24
column7: given how far Alison Mosshart and Jamie Hince have been able to push the limited parameters of their guitar/drum-machine set-up and develop an identity increasingly distinct from their formative junior-Royal-Trux roots.

column1: But even as the Kills have gone from covering Captain Beefheart on their debut 2002 EP
column2: Black Rooster
column3: to teaming up with Spank Rock producer XXXChange for 2008's electro-fied Midnight Boom
column4: Mosshart and Hince have always conveyed a sense of anxiety and nervous energy through their music. And the duo's lusty performances eagerly play up the ambiguity of their platonic partnership. It's a quality that defines them as much as Mosshart's feverish moan
column5: Hince's hand-slashing guitar riffs
column6: and the synthetic beats-- just Google ""the Kills + sexual tension."" And even though the will-they/won't-they question has been definitively tilted toward the latter
column7: that doesn't mean the Kills can't continue to summon that frisson through roleplay. But on Blood Pressures
column8: there's a creeping sense that their individual preoccupations outside the band-- Mosshart as Jack White's feisty foil in the Dead Weather; Hince as the paparazzi-hounded fiancé of the world's most famous supermodel-- has diffused some of that intensity
column9: as the duo attempts to evolve its dynamic.

column1: Sonically
column2: Blood Pressures retreats from Midnight Boom's dancefloor directives and energized
column3: in-the-pocket pop. The new album feels at once a return to the Kills' beatbox-blues origins as well an attempt to broaden their palette with more sensitive
column4: intimate turns. Notwithstanding the motorik garage-rock of ""Heart Is a Beating Drum"" and brash
column5: big-beat stomp ""Nail in My Coffin""
column6: this album will present Hince and Mosshart with fewer opportunities to stare each other down suggestively on stage in predatory
column7: fuck-or-fight fashion. Whether it's the swampy reggae groove of ""Satellite""
column8: the clock-punching blues-rock prowl ""Damned if She Do""
column9: or the mid-album tandem of Hince's Lennon-esque reverie ""Wild Charms"" and Mosshart's slow-simmering answer track ""DNA""
column10: there's an overarching sense of restraint and resignation that's disappointing in light of how fearless and adrenalized the band sounded on Midnight Boom.

column1: On that album's standout moments (the desperation of ""Last Day of Magic""
column2: the spiky outbursts of ""Tape Song"")
column3: you could hear Mosshart really pushing herself to project a more passionate persona from behind the Kills' ultra-cool
column4: cigarette-smoky pose. By contrast
column5: Blood Pressures' would-be emotional centerpiece The Last Goodbye"" is a maudlin piano ballad that feels oddly disaffected
column6: with Mosshart singing in an overly poised
column7: uncharacteristically lower register as if trying to channel some aging-diva caricature. A far better barometer of the Kills' maturation is the more understated but infinitely more affecting ""Baby Says""
column8: a melancholic Mosshart/Hince duet set to a steady backbeat
column9: ideal for filling in the awkward silences on a couples-retreat road trip gone bad. In other words
column10:
it's precisely the sort of interstate love song that the golden-oldies DJs of 2027 will be all over.
