""Roll With the Winners"" was a classic track from Clipse's We Got It 4 Cheap
column2: Vol. 2 mixtape
column3: but Pusha T
column4: that duo's more visible half
column5: is a whole lot easier to root for when he's losing. From 2004 to 2006
column6: Clipse were down and out
column7: forgotten by their label even though they'd made a hit album
column8: written off by an industry that preferred its crack-sales talk bigger and dumber. And the group responded by making their best music ever
column9: exceeding even their great debut
column10: Lord Willin'
column11: with the two Got It 4 Cheap mixtapes and Hell Hath No Fury. On these records
column12: Pusha and older brother Malice projected raw
column13: unbridled animosity rendered in dense
column14: twisty language that showed them to be two of the best writers of their rap generation. But after those displays of hunger
column15: ferocity
column16: and intelligence
column17: they went on autopilot
column18: cranking out a few mixtapes and another album that sounded utterly tapped-out and devoid of inspiration.

column1: A year ago
column2: the group's critical and commercial future looked dim
column3: and Malice embarked on an unexpected religious journey that led him to write a Bible-informed memoir. And all of a sudden
column4: Pusha seems to be closer to stardom than he ever came in the Clipse. Kanye West snapped him up as a solo artist and made him the linchpin of Kanye's G.O.O.D. Music roster. Pusha got to step onstage at the VMAs in a ""Miami Vice""-looking dinner jacket and deliver a shattering closing verse on ""Runaway""
column5: and Kanye made room for Pusha verses in a ton of his G.O.O.D. Friday mp3s. Now Pusha has a label boss who appears to have full faith in him
column6: and that label boss happens to be the most visionary producer in rap today. If ever there was a time for Pusha to make good on all his underdog promise
column7: this is it. Instead
column8: he's given us a mixtape so flat and lazy that I almost don't know why it exists at all.

column1: Fear of God is less than 40 minutes long
column2: and too much of that running time is given over to pointless freestyles over well-circulated tracks
column3: or to tracks so flimsy that they barely exist. This is when Pusha should be establishing himself as a major artist
column4: not freestyling over Soulja Boy's ""Speakers Going Hammer"". On opening song ""My God""
column5: Pusha snarls
column6: ""Bear witness as I unveil this instant classic
column7: but nothing about the tape suggests that he's interested in making any sort of classic. Pusha has some serious gifts in his favor: a great snarling delivery
column8: a vivid eye for detail
column9: a writer's gift for getting well-trod ideas across in ways nobody could've expected. But too often on Fear of God
column10: he's just filling space with flat
column11: workmanlike rhyme patterns and out-of-gas punchlines: ""Money on my mind like my pillow is a vault."" ""Touch It""
column12: in which Pusha and Kanye beg for head
column13: is the weakest Kanye West track in years
column14: complete with a beat that must've been sitting around Kanye's hard drive forever. And on ""Open Your Eyes""
column15: producer Nottz turns ""Bohemian Rhapsody"" into pitched-up chipmunk soul
column16: which nobody ever needed to hear. On too much of Fear of God
column17: nobody even seems to be trying.

column1: But when the mixtape does crackle to life
column2: we see a whole other side of the solo rapper Pusha could be. ""Raid"" has an absolutely vicious piano-driven Neptunes beat and an on-fire cameo from 50 Cent
column3: and Pusha raises his game accordingly
column4: giving his most energetic performance of the mixtape. And on ""I Still Wanna""
column5: he shares a churning
column6: operatic Rick Ross-type beat with Ross himself
column7: and everyone comes out sounding bloodthirsty. If Pusha had made a whole mixtape of songs like these
column8: it would've been incredible.

column1: Otherwise
column2: though
column3: it's just a confusing affair. On his G.O.O.D. Friday tracks and his My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy verses
column4: Pusha sounded like Kanye had lit a fire up under him; that fire seems nothing but a barely-glowing ember through most of Fear of God. And considering the amount of faith Kanye seems to have in Pusha
column5: I can't understand why he'd do so little to prove Kanye right. At the beginning of his freestyle over Jay-Z's ""Can I Live""
column6: Pusha says that he's recording at the Emirates Palace in Abu Dhabi. If that's true-- and it might be-- it makes no sense. Pusha shouldn't have to leave his basement to record a ""Can I Live"" freestyle. And unless that freestyle turns out to be as sharp as what he was doing on <i>We Got It 4 Cheap
column7: Vol. 2
column8: he shouldn't even be letting us hear it. Right now
column9:
I'm just hoping Pusha makes an album strong enough that we can all pretend Fear of God never happened.

A lot has happened in the two years since Alela Diane released her breakout album
column2: the simultaneously imaginative and earthy To Be Still. Among other things
column3: she married her bass player-turned-guitarist
column4: Tom Bevitori
column5: and saw her touring band gel into something a bit more prominent and permanent-- namely
column6: Wild Divine
column7: which includes Bevitori
column8: guitarist Tom Menig (Diane's father)
column9: bass player Jonas Haskins
column10: and drummer Jason Merculief. Her third album reflects these developments in its more robust
column11: full-band sound as well as in the writing credits she shares with her husband and father. Musically
column12: Diane sounds more settled on these songs
column13: with the road-tested band bolstering her distinctive vocals and helping to mold her songwriting into slightly more dynamic shapes.

column1: In other words
column2: those pesky comparisons to old friend Joanna Newsom no longer apply. Diane trades fraught freak folk for dusty country-rock that recalls the rough-and-tumble outlaw hits of Jessi Colter and Rita Coolidge
column3: if they were backed by the Flying Burrito Brothers. Like those two singers
column4: there's something both slick and scuffed up about Diane's vocals; rather than otherworldly
column5: she sounds deeply rooted in our own world
column6: with a soulful delivery that illuminates the galloping ""White Horse"" and opener ""To Begin"". ""Heartless Highway"" (with its subtle reference to 1970s underground Nashville documentary Heartworn Highways) is a lonely tour song written in Germany
column7: and while there are literally hundreds of songs about this subject
column8: Diane imbues it with a tough-minded homesickness
column9: as if she's working through the heartache to get to the next show.

column1: Lyrically
column2: Diane can be just as startling as ever
column3: employing a stream-of-conscious style that bends toward unexpected details or strange turns of phrase. ""Amidst the gold
column4: there is dust in every heart
column5: she sings on ""Of Many Colors""
column6: which is
column7: oddly enough
column8: an ode to her new husband. Her songwriting hasn't lost any of its barbs
column9: so that when she makes a fanfare of the words ""There is good
column10: there is still good"" on closer ""Rising Greatness""
column11: it resonates all the more forcefully.

column1: Whether navigating the rocky rapids of ""White Horse"" or decorating ""The Wind"" with pedal steel teardrops and mandolin trills
column2: Wild Divine craft agile arrangements that echo British folk music and American roots. If they lapse into gentle lite-folk anonymity at times
column3: it's because they're more interested in supporting Diane's vocals than in living up to their name. That's a wise strategy
column4: as Diane's appeal is based squarely on her husk-dry voice delivering those thorny lyrics
column5:
but this self-titled album gives the impression that they're constantly aware of holding back. Such restraint is ultimately unwarranted: Diane is a strong enough presence as a singer and as a songwriter that she can more than hold her own.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16378/homepage_large.2488835b.jpg|Some Cold Rock Stuf|29588.0|J.Rocc|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Stones Throw']|2011-04-06 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:32:13.328674|"

It's kind of unsettling when a record comes right out and says it's going to be difficult-- not just once but repeatedly. Still
column2: sometimes it's necessary
column3: especially when an artist's background carries certain expectations. J.Rocc has spent decades in the turntablist vanguard as part of the Beat Junkies
column4: has an enviable position as Madlib's go-to DJ
column5: and for years has been a regular contributor to Stones Throw and Now-Again. But if you come to his new release
column6: Some Cold Rock Stuf
column7: expecting familiar beat-tape material
column8: virtuosity
column9: or amped-up reworkings of 1970s funk breaks
column10: prepare to be disoriented by a series of warnings: ""The secret is not apparent to the casual listener
column11: ""I like the quiet moment
column12: and this song is that. If you're not in that sort of a mood then you can always take it off
column13: ""If you do not want to hear
column14: other people want to hear.""

column1: Some Cold Rock Stuf bumps heavy here and there
column2: and old heads will smile in recognition at the leadoff track (""Rocchead's Delight"")
column3: which updates that old De La Soul interstitial
column4: ""Cool Breeze on the Rocks"". But the slippery thing about this album is that it seems calculated to make your head swim instead of nod. Some Cold Rock Stuf wades through hazy psychedelic ground that resembles introspective
column5: mid-90s trip-hop more than the futurism of contemporary underground West Coast beat-music. If the trippier moments approach the acid-fried fringes of the Gaslamp Killer
column6: they lack his fine-tuned ear for exciting abrasion; if the mud-fidelity loops and international dalliances are simpatico with Madlib
column7: it lacks his idea-shuffling brevity.

column1: That personality deficit would be easier to overlook without some odd sequencing at work. The first track's hyperactive sample montage sinks right into the quicksand of ""Don't Sell Your Dream (Tonight)""
column2: a woozy amalgamation of parched guitars
column3: wind noises
column4: and codeine drum breaks that threatens to lull the listener into a daze. It's an early transition that's almost as bewildering as the album's wound-down conclusion
column5: ""The Truth""
column6: an Ambien lurch laced with a weepy
column7: disembodied string loop and ultra-minimalist snares and kickdrums. But the slow start and slower finish belie a somewhat livelier middle section. The Bollywood-tinged ""Party""
column8: the carnival atmosphere of fuzz/funk/Tropicália splice-job ""Play This (Also)""
column9: and the vintage b-boy Latin breakbeat of ""Too Many Clowns"" feel like they were airlifted in from a completely different album to jolt this one out of its stupor. If this record's trying to impart some sort of consistent personality
column10: it's a hard one to grasp.

column1: But hard to grasp isn't necessarily the same as hard to like. And while the uptempo cuts are the most immediate pleasures
column2: even the foggier bits have a way of insinuating themselves into your head. When the bleary-eyed stuff expands into something with a bit more kick
column3: it's easier to appreciate what J.Rocc was shooting for-- slow-building meditations. ""Chasing the Sun"" starts off as another spaced-out
column4: chant-driven ether frolic-- and then it ratchets up the jitteriness and intensity of the break and integrates a stirring piano loop. And while the re-stitched
column5: sax-driven jazz of ""Malcolm Was Here (Part 1+2)"" sinks you into a hypnotic swing-beat groove at first
column6: there's a bracing hairpin turn toward tense John Carpenter g-funk in its leftfield second half.

column1: Some Cold Rock Stuf makes more sense as a collection of scattered concept pieces than a unified statement. Prospective buyers who want a potential escape hatch from the feature presentation are treated to a special gimmick thrown in with a physical purchase-- a ""mystery disc
column2: one of three randomly-selected EPs containing a handful of unlabeled
column3: untitled bonus cuts. And while that's a fun idea for an extra
column4:
it's not like the first disc isn't enigmatic enough.

column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Family Vineyard']|2011-04-06 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:32:13.755050|"

""I want to tour with Phish because the kind of music we make is more in tune with their aesthetic
column3: said Sonic Youth's Thurston Moore in 1998. ""We deserve each other."" Moore might've been kidding
column4: but he was onto something. If ""jam band"" means what Wikipedia says-- ""extended musical improvisation over rhythmic grooves and chord patterns""-- then it's not a stretch to say Sonic Youth belong to a lineage of underground jam bands. Start with the guitar forays of Velvet Underground and Television
column5: move through the krautrock of Can and Faust
column6: then dive into droners Spacemen 3 and Acid Mothers Temple and feedback hounds Bardo Pond and Dead Meadow. All are more inclined toward punk edge and avant-garde dissonance than Phish
column7: of course. But it's undeniable that they all like to jam.

column1: If you buy this idea even a little
column2: you'll probably dig Chris Forsyth's Paranoid Cat. It begins with a title track that's essentially 21 minutes of jamming
column3: albeit a thoughtful
column4: well-planned kind. Forsyth has always put care into even the most chaotic music by his other band
column5: the unclassifiable Peeesseye
column6: and he maintains that approach here. Interlocking his roaming guitar with the pedal steel of Marc Orleans and piano of Hans Chew
column7: Forsyth unfurls the winding three-part opener in ways that evoke all the acts mentioned above. But there's also a folk twang that brings to mind early-1970s Neil Young
column8: and a symphonic repetition that recalls Glenn Branca's Lesson No. 1. Imagine Branca's ensemble covering ""Down by the River""
column9: and you have some idea of this track's particular magic.

column1: The rest of Paranoid Cat maintains that vibe pretty well. ""New Pharmacist Boogie"" is garage rock with the drums erased
column2: evoking a beat-less take on jammy Velvet Underground tracks like ""Booker T."" and ""Melody Laughter"". Closer ""Anniversary Day"" starts out like Galaxie 500 covering ""Heroin""
column3: then floats into more Young-style pastoral drift. But don't let all these comparisons mislead you-- Paranoid Cat is by no means derivative. It's more like historical musical commentary
column4: an amalgam of time-tested sounds that adds new insights to what it echoes. Besides
column5: even if Paranoid Cat belongs to some underground jam-band canon
column6: it's rather unparalleled today. Jim O'Rourke's longer-form pieces swim in the same water; some of what MV & EE do when chasing Neil Young comes close; and Bardo Pond are still valiantly taking hits off of this kind of loose expansion. But as tempting as it is to keep searching for influences in Paranoid Cat's stretched-out essays
column7:
zoning out to its thoughtful strains is even more fun.

Outside of geographic proximity (Norman
column4: Okla.
column5: and Denton
column6: Texas
column7: are only 150 miles apart)
column8: psychedelia is the only obvious link between the Flaming Lips and Alan Palomo's project Neon Indian. The Lips often veer to the darker side of psych
column9: especially recently (see their 2009 dread-filled opus Embryonic)
column10: while Palomo deals in a day-glo take on 1980's pop. So when Wayne Coyne revealed that they were banging out a fast collaboration-- as he put it
column11: ""that shit should be ready to go pretty quickly""-- the first question that came to mind was whether the result would lean more toward sun or shadows.

column1: That's settled immediately by the opener on this four-track
column2: 22-minute EP
column3: the ominously titled ""Is David Bowie Dying?"" It's not completely clear what the lyrics have to do with Bowie's potential demise
column4: but the music feels like an elegy
column5: a kind of spaced-out funeral march. With its slow
column6: crunchy beat
column7: cutting sonic debris
column8: and Coyne's weary intonations
column9: it would fit well among Embryonic's doomy mantras. ""Take your legs and run/ To the death rays of the sun
column10: he sings with resignation
column11: followed by a stoic chant of ""goodbye
column12: goodbye."" It's pretty morose
column13: but hypnotic and fully-realized-- impressively so considering how quickly it was made.

column1: The rest of the record shares those dark qualities-- much of it is stark
column2: cavernous
column3: and full of murky low end. But the other three tracks are less polished
column4: more loose and experimental. Which is not to suggest they're somehow unfinished. Their sounds are more suited to an amorphous form
column5: making it tough to tell exactly what Palomo contributed. Even on ""Alan's Theremin""-- an eight-minute soundscape that ranks with the weirdest stuff by either act-- there's no telling what came from that instrument (or even if he actually used one). But Palomo's anonymity reflects an internal coherence. This isn't a case of musicians who just met randomly throwing sounds at each other. As unpredictable as the music can be
column6: very little comes off as gratuitous or out of place.

column1: Still
column2: if you're looking for something as song-like as ""Is David Bowie Dying?""
column3: stick around for the closer. As with the first cut
column4: its title-- ""Do You Want New Wave or Do You Want the Truth Part 2""-- makes a specific reference
column5: in this case to a Minutemen song. But again
column6: how the music relates to that title isn't overt. The track sounds more like a krautrock jam
column7: with a muffled bass groove that could've been ripped from a Can outtake. In keeping with the record's vibe
column8: it blows apart near the end
column9: with individual sounds dying off into the ether. It's a dark way to end
column10:
but it suggests open space rather than closed perfection. Turns out this collaboration is as much about implication as explication-- as much about what these artists could do as what they actually did.

""I wanna take this tape and blow up ya fuckin' stereo!"" These are the first brash
column3: goofily antagonistic words shouted on the Death Set's sophomore record
column4: Michel Poiccard. It's a sort of perfect mantra for the Baltimore-by-way-of-Australia band
column5: which makes an enthusiastic racket mixing ADD punk
column6: leftover electroclash
column7: and Licensed to Ill-era Beastie Boys. Sadly
column8: the shouting voice belongs to founding member Beau Velasco
column9: who died in 2009 of a drug overdose
column10: only a year after the release of the band's debut
column11: Worldwide. Even when not stated explicitly
column12: most of Michel Poiccard feels like a love letter to Velasco from remaining founder Johnny Siera; there's a sadness and longing tucked into even songs that aren't ostensibly about Velasco.

column1: The most prudent elegy for Velasco would be continuing to smash shit up. And on tracks where they do-- the sweat-drenched ""Chew It Like a Gun Gum"" and ""A Problem Is a Problem It Don't Matter Where You From""-- his spirit feels appropriately channeled. Credit producer and Baltimore club fixture XXXChange for giving these tracks bulkier production as well as livelier drums (a marked improvement over Worldwide's dinky beat programming).
But elsewhere the Death Set ignore their wilder instincts in favor of a more emotionally hefty
column2: ruminative feel
column3: which makes sense considering the circumstances. ""I Miss You Beau Velasco"" is an ethereal goth-pop track that's as dour and weirdly uplifting as an early Smashing Pumpkins tune
column4: while ""Can You See Straight?"" retains a hard-charging velocity and still taps into something unexpectedly somber.

column1: It's a shame Siera couldn't rein in the focus a little more
column2: as the material in between these exciting (and sometimes touching) songs requires considerable patience. The in-jokes and throw-away interludes you can easily brush off; the life-affirming schmaltz (""It's Another Day"")
column3: dunderheaded pop punk (""Michel Pioccard Prefers the Old (She Yearns For the Devil)"")
column4: and phoned-in guest spots from Diplo and Spank Rock
column5: however
column6: are harder to ignore. For a band as unhinged and forcefully wacky as the Death Set
column7: powering on in the face of tragedy can't be easy. When they do
column8:
the results can be great fun or surprisingly thoughtful. But do some quick math-- 17 tracks in 35 minutes with only a few keepers-- and Michel Poiccard comes up too short.

Flux Outside

column6: sense-assaulting work to date.

column1: Every sound on Flux Outside-- and there are many
column2: coming in from  all angles-- gleams
column3: buffed to an electroid sheen. Frontman Ryan  Schafer
column4: who produced the Bangs' previous LPs
column5: turns over the production duties to ex-Sparklehorse member Scott Minor
column6: with indie superproducer Dave Fridmann handling the mixing. Minor and Fridmann help deepen the band's drums and tease out some alluringly glitzy new textures without altering the dynamic scramble that powered 2009's fine Let It Beep. For all the instrumental bombardment
column7: the Bangs manage to maintain  order
column8: never veering too far off course even when they're taking sharp  curves at 100 MPH. The record's got a constant forward motion
column9: and its 50 minutes seem to zip by in double-time.

column1: The Bangs' greatest strength isn't so much the almost mechanistic turn-on-a-dime cohesion of their future rock
column2: but how they manage to  wrangle their pristine assault into appealing shapes. Highlight ""Silver Steps"" zig-zags its way into a rousing straightahead  chorus
column3: and while ""Bull Elk"" comes on like a tornado

column5: Flux Outside is a generous
column6: sweaty
column7: markedly human  record
column8: powered as much by groovy southern-rock melodies as the steely  synth shrapnel that seems to jut out from everywhere. It's a rare thing  indeed to hear a musical unit nail that midpoint between those  frequently oppositional tendencies time and again. Still
column9: there are  times when the fast-moving currents in the Royal Bangs sound cause them  to barrel through their hooks
column10: lessening their impact and causing the  distinctions between one ripcord track to the next to blur a bit. But  the Bangs seem to place every drum stutter
column11: keyboard whirr
column12: and Schafer  howl on equal footing
column13: a nice testament to the tightness and democracy  of their musical unit
column14:
so pushing the songwriting further to the forefront could come at the risk of toppling the delicate balance the not-so-delicate Flux Outside achieves. May they never learn to sit still.

column11: yet

column13: well
column14: forever

at least try to act surprised.

To be an American fan of UK new wave in the 1980s was to acknowledge that your homegrown culture wasn't giving you what you needed. New Order
column3: the Cure
column4: Depeche Mode
column5: and Siouxsie and the Banshees made broadly appealing pop music but also made sense to outcast kids in the U.S. because they clearly came from somewhere else. Drop any of them into your average American town and they would be mocked; the straight world would make fun of their haircuts and clothing and make-up. That was part of what drew people to them. They were theatrical and sensitive. They were singing about feelings. They were androgynous. Those drawn to this music at the time articulated a cluster of associations and feelings around these qualities that endures two decades later.

column1: Cold Cave's 2009 full-length debut
column2: Love Comes Close
column3: tapped into the emotional space of 80s new wave. It wasn't just that the group sounded like bands from that decade
column4: though that was certainly part of it. But like Peter Murphy
column5: Ian Curtis
column6: or Robert Smith
column7: Cold Cave leader Wesley Eisold has a voice that's both strong and vulnerable
column8: a low croon with a deeply embedded ache. And when used with basslines and spiky guitars that sound lifted from some lost band on Factory
column9: his voice perfectly conveyed the drama of being a teenage outsider.

column1: That feeling continues on Cherish the Light Years
column2: but here everything has been blown up to a degree that borders on absurdity. From opening cut ""The Great Pan Is Dead""
column3: Cherish feels like a John Hughes film projected in an IMAX theater-- guitars wail
column4: synths scream
column5: and the whole thing is loud
column6: loud
column7: loud. And Eisold responds in kind
column8: his voice rippling with a new desperation-- he'll come running as stars explode
column9: hearts break
column10: and we all yearn for salvation. It's a bracing and brilliant album opener
column11: stating in no uncertain terms
column12: ""This is now a different band."" Just a few short years ago
column13: Cold Cave were a home-recording project beholden to the sound of early industrial and minimal synth. The throbbing murk in that music made you think something was wrong with your stereo-- many tracks barely qualified as noise
column14: forget about songs. But on Cherish
column15: Cold Cave sound like they're storming the gates of the mainstream
column16: ready to appeal to anyone with an ear for big
column17: bold
column18: goth-pop.

column1: And they succeed. All nine tracks are well crafted and memorable
column2: with sections that poke out on first listen and worm their way into your consciousness with further plays. ""Underworld USA"" begins with a dark synth thump and a lonely guitar but quickly explodes into a raging anthem for the disaffected. Eisold wants to dream and cry and let the night pass him by-- he sings of the meek inheriting the earth and rhymes ""missionary"" with ""cemetery."" And then ""Confetti"" is subtler
column3: opening with a delicate synth line and a gorgeous reverb-laden guitar that sounds lifted from a 4AD record circa 1986. ""I feel so good on the outside
column4: Eisold sings-- when you're feeling miserable
column5: you'll take what you can get. These songs are tuneful and empathetic studded with sharp observations; it's the kind of music that makes you wish your life would fall apart a little bit
column6: just so that you could wallow in it.

column1: But the songs never stay in one place. The contrast between ""Alchemy Around You""
column2: which adds a trumpet and thickens the production further
column3: and the following ""Burning Sage""
column4: a bleak and bass-heavy tune with synth from noise-master and CC member Dominick Fernow that hearkens back to the band's industrial origins
column5: brings to mind the eclectic experimentation of Kiss Me-era Cure. These guys are ready to fold anything into their aesthetic. It all gets a little claustrophobic at points
column6: and when that happens the vocals of Caralee McElroy
column7: who contributed to Love Comes Close
column8: are missed. But if Cherish finds Cold Cave going for it and trying their hand at new wave pop anthems
column9: they're still sweating the details. These songs and arrangements are like catnip for those who crave the bleak romantic end of new wave.

column1: There is one issue that keeps Cherish from being an unqualified home run: The mix and mastering job are brickwalled to the extreme
column2: squashing all the production detail and rendering this 40-minute LP tiring to listen to as a whole. It was a strange choice to make this record so incredibly loud and compressed; this music wants to bring you closer
column3: but the monolithic sonics have a way of keeping you at arm's length. Not to mention that this kind of ultra-loud mastering brings to mind albums that touch on some of the same sounds and feelings but in a heavy-handed way-- Bloc Party's Intimacy or the Killers' Day & Age

column6: this music deserved better. Even so

column9:
and Wes Eisold comes across as an artist with a vision that will resonate with a larger audience.

For an ""opera"" with not one but two concepts behind it
column3: Hyphenated-Man sounds pretty grounded. That's because both of Mike Watt's overarching ideas lend themselves to short
column4: pithy songs rather than bloated suites or pompous narratives. Watt's guides are the small
column5: detailed characters in the work of 15th century painter Hieronymus Bosch
column6: and the minimal punk of his own pioneering band the Minutemen. Basing each of the album's 30 songs on a Bosch character (and giving them names like ""Jug-Footed-Man"" and ""Confused-Parts-Man"")
column7: Watt wrote everything in Minutemen ""econo"" mode
column8: using late bandmate D. Boon's guitar. The goal
column9: he says

column1: Judged on that scale
column2: Hyphenated-Man is a full-on success. The way Watt and his band the Missingmen blast through each taut musical nugget evokes early Minutemen albums such as The Punch Line and What Makes a Man Start Fires? As on those classics
column3: each track fires by so quickly
column4: you might not absorb one before you can catch up to the next. Nearly every song uses sharp turns
column5: gruff energy
column6: and snapping beats
column7: making them all echo each other like rhyming lines in a poem. And like Bosch's characters

column9: united by an artistic cause.

column1: What gives those brothers personality-- and keeps Hyphenated-Man from being just a Minutemen nostalgia trip-- is the way Watt injects himself into every moment. His hard-working
column2: art-punk-in-a-flannel-shirt persona courses through each syllable of his Dada-ish lyrics
column3: and his voice stretches to match the music's spilling energy. ""Panderin' to work the shill/ Procurin' ink for the quill
column4: he wryly sings about ""Bird-in-the-Helmet-Man"". Later he grunts through a dizzying portrait of the hard-luck ""Belly-Stabbed-Man"": ""A belly with ears stuck to some legs/ No arms or chest-- not even a head/ Stabbed with truth
column5: fuckin' gets bled!""

column1: Much of Hyphenated-Man has that kind of blunt
column2: unblinking tone. It sounds like Watt is using Bosch's figures to confront some hard truths
column3: but he does so in a spry
column4: often joyous way. That's especially impressive given how sentimental this album could've been. After Boon's passing in 1985
column5: Watt didn't listen to the Minutemen much until the We Jam Econo documentary was made in 2005. But rather than getting him down
column6: revisiting his past has given Watt an electric charge. While his solo work has often been inspired
column7: on Hyphenated-Man he sounds thoroughly possessed. At age 53

Mike Watt might have just made his best post-Minutemen work.

column7: Nine Inch Nails
column8: U2
column9: Depeche Mode
column10: and PJ Harvey just to name a few. Coming after a scrappy
column11: low-profile debut

column13: but fortunately

column15: bolder
column16: and brighter follow-up that adds new dimensions to the Pains' sound while nearly equaling the songwriting of their debut.

column1: The first three tracks on Belong-- the title track

column7: Pains nudge themselves slightly out of their comfort zone

column6: we
column7: and us. But this newfound stress on speaking directly to the listener doesn't come without its awkward growth spurts: It's worth questioning whether striving for the perfect chorus at times comes at the cost of fully thought-out verses. The group's momentum also gets occasionally jarred by a stray lyric that can be overreaching or undercooked.

column5:

column3: Stephen Wilkinson's Bibio project continues to surprise. His first three albums combined tape-distressed versions of British folk with warbly ambient interludes
column4: and he gradually added vocals that hinted at proper songs. During this stretch
column5: he seemed like someone who wanted to completely master one idiom before he could muster the courage to move on to another. But on his 2009 album
column6: Ambivalence Avenue
column7: Wilkinson moved outside of his comfort zone. His ear for mood and texture was still there
column8: but suddenly his vocals were up front and he was tossing in hip-hop breaks and dense samples to craft a weirdly bent style of electro-pop. It was an exhilarating record. You could feel an artist stepping outside of himself and venturing boldly into new territory
column9: and the sense of adventure was contagious.

column1: Mind Bokeh is no less daring than Ambivalence Avenue
column2: and it covers just as much ground
column3: but here you can feel Wilkinson bumping up against his limitations. His talent for production is fully intact
column4: but some odd choices sabotage the record. Instrumental sections like the title cut and the closing ""St. Christopher"" show a sound technician firmly in command of his material
column5: folding twinkly keyboards
column6: crackly loops
column7: and gently insistent beats into tracks that are evocative and detailed enough to reveal more with repeated listens. Wilkinson's terrific understanding of sound is undiminished
column8: and he still moves easily between genres and gets most of the key details right. But the further he explores recognizable song forms
column9: the more often the album stumbles.

column1: In the case of ""Take Off Your Shirt""
column2: that stumble becomes a full-on face plant. Wilkinson's exploratory spirit is a wonderful thing
column3: but glammy power pop in the vein of Phoenix is something he should absolutely
column4: positively leave to someone else. With its blocky guitar riff and canned beat
column5: ""Shirt"" is stiff and downright unlikable. Fortunately
column6: it doesn't get any worse
column7: but there are still too many ho-hum moments that feel weirdly off. The six-minute ""Pretentious"" brings the flow of the album to a halt only two tracks in
column8: with a woozy synth-driven lope that's a bit too close to anonymous chillwave and is not redeemed by the tacked-on vocals. Along the same lines but better is ""Light Seep"". Here
column9: the repurposed AM radio pop of Ariel Pink would seem to be an influence
column10: as Wilkinson mixes a funky wah-wah guitar with percussion that sounds like a Wurlitzer preset. To my ears
column11: it sounds like a so-so take on something Keyboard Money Mark was doing in the late 90s
column12: but ""Seep"" is at least listenable and a good example of Wilkinson's eclecticism working for him.

column1: On the plus side
column2: ""Wake Up!"" is very much a continuation of the best of Ambivalence Avenue
column3: with its surging Dilla-fied samples grafted to a vocal performance that finds Wilkinson filled with yearning
column4: sounding almost desperate. And ""K Is for Kelson"" is a convincing slice of bouncy indie pop that sounds like it's being sung by a robot on holiday in the tropics. These songs are short and sweet
column5: making their point and getting out
column6: which works to their advantage. But on the lengthier tracks
column7: Mind Bokeh seems to hover in an unsteady place between pop song form and soundscapes
column8: and the flaws-- repetitive melodies that don't quite gel
column9: the voice just a bit too high in the mix-- become more evident. There is enjoyable music here
column10: and I've no doubt that the Bibio project has plenty of life on it. But now that Wilkinson has spent a few years trying new things
column11:
a little focus might do him some good.

With their terrifically engaging 2009 deubt album
column3: Jewellery
column4: London-based Micachu and the Shapes superficially came off as a trio of gleefully amateurish kids bashing out a noisily tuneful brand of junkshop-pop
column5: breaking rules because they didn't know any better. In truth
column6: the group's lead singer and mastermind
column7: Mica Levi
column8: studied violin from a young age (her mother is a cellist) and received a classical indoctrination at music school. As you spend more time with Jewellery
column9: you begin to realize that even its roughest-hewn
column10: seemingly random elements carry such a concentrated punch that they could only be the product of an artist who was extremely focused and in control of her materials.

column1: Given her history
column2: it makes perfect sense that Levi would gravitate toward a project like Chopped & Screwed

column4: an orchestral ensemble made up of strings and woodwinds. It also makes sense
column5: knowing the breadth of Levi's sonic interests and her hunger for experimentation

column9: even when things feel aimless

column1: As its title suggets

column3: disoriented sensation in the listener. Don't expect to hear molasses-thick male voices drawling about candy paint over slow beat claps here
column4: however. The Shapes' and Sinfonietta's kinship with the likes of DJ Screw is all about aiming for that same feel of dislocation. The way they go about attempting to achieve it is certainly creative-- basically
column5: the ensemble saws or trills away on their instruments while the Shapes pluck and hammer at homemade stringed or percussive contraptions (the rotating doohickey Levi plays is particularly nifty)
column6: alternating between frantic and syrupy-slow tempos seemingly at a whim. Above the maelstrom
column7: Levi slowly and lowly intones lyrics that are frequently incomprehensible.

column1: More important are her melodies
column2: which make ""Everything"" and ""Low Dogg"" the album's standouts
column3: as Levi's arty appetites contend with the razor-sharp pop sense she displayed throughout Jewellery and that I hope she always retains. The likes of ""Unlucky""
column4: ""Fall""
column5: and ""Not So Sure"" aren't as immediately riveting but do the best job of replicating screw's woozy allure. That said
column6: there's an awful lot of connective tissue here-- fairly lengthy passages (especially for such a short album) bridging the more immediate moments. If the performance had been longer
column7: such sequences would be acceptable interludes. As it is
column8: it feels like dead patches make up almost half of Chopped & Screwed. Shelve it next to the Knife's Tomorrow
column9: in a Year as an effort that hearteningly shows an inspired artist staking out bold terrain
column10: but one that only fitfully delivers the impact of the artist's previous
column11:
pop-focused work.

As much as the standard model has shifted from the full-length album to the individual track
column3: there's still a lot of baggage to the phrase ""singles band."" A group with a couple of great songs and a few unremarkable ones might've gotten more of a pass for hiding the mediocrities on B-sides back when ""sides"" were the only game in town

The Sandwitches have many ways to sing about devotion. On their 2009 debut
column2: How to Make Ambient Sadcake

column5: a band for which Cooper and Alexander sang backup) for a sound that splits the difference between rockabilly and first-wave country & western. The 1950s jaunt of Ambient Sadcake and the ethereal

Early album standout ""My Heart Does Swell"" provides a little country shuffle to go with the heartsick vocals and a toy piano solo(!). And then ""Miracle Me"" splinters into the realm of unfiltered sadness

column11: the Sandwitches has only hinted that they had the skill to craft such effortlessly beautiful songs.

column2: overcast rock
column3: either. ""Black Rider"" shows a nuanced sense of dynamics
column4: calmly ambling about and then building toward a proper climax with rising levels of aggression. A similar method yields even better results on ""Over the Moon""
column5: where a descending
column6: countrified guitar line eventually gives way to climactic
column7: violent catharsis

column1: The album's few low points come when those builds don't quite reach fruition. ""Heaviest Head in the West"" starts out as a slow-burning rockabilly tune
column2: complete with the band's two singers caterwauling desperately while striking their guitars
column3: which is brought down to a simmer. But an inexplicable tempo change eventually peters out with no forward moment

column4: trying to figure out the whereabouts of her man who ""says impossibly good things.""

column2: Alexander and Cooper are singing the beautifully sad refrain
column3: ""He's coming back to me
column4: and it sounds more like the protagonist trying to convince herself. It's the kind of arresting song that would have been perfect as the closer for Mrs. Jones' Cookies. But even with the minor sequencing miscue

a band that makes the primordial seem fresh.

column4: and every element goes toward reinforcing Mercer's dark drama. In fact
column5: perhaps the main spark in this collaboration is how it gets both artists outside their comfort zones: Burton's beatmaking priorities draw Mercer out of his indie-pop realm and reveal the breadth of his songwriting
column6: while Mercer's eloquent concision keeps Burton sharper and more focused. Both men show us something new
column7: even as they struggle to break free of the gravitational pull of their other projects.

column1: On the second half
column2: however
column3: that tension releases
column4: and Meyrin Fields powers down with the loping reggae approximation of ""An Easy Life"" and the buoyant drift of ""Heartless Empire"". The arrangements are less insistent and sinister
column5: but the melodies remain slightly chilly. ""An Easy Life"" was originally released as an iTunes exclusive to the album
column6: and it sounds similarly tacked-on here. ""Heartless Empire"" does it one better
column7: but throws everything-- grinding guitars
column8: a whistled solo-- at a song that simply isn't very memorable. Still
column9: this EP sounds like more than the sum of its parts. Maybe it's the realization that Gnarls Barkley will never top ""Crazy"" or that the Shins may never re-form
column10: but there's an intriguing sense of desperation on these songs
column11:
as though both Mercer and Burton are realizing that this band could indeed be their lives.

The announcement of Soundgarden's 2010 reunion was exciting on several counts; first
column3: that meant Chris Cornell would stop his fucking around with Audioslave and Timbaland. But more importantly it would be the return of the only band that really sounds like Soundgarden. While Bush
column4: Godsmack
column5: and Creed spawned from the most easily cloned DNA of Soundgarden's peers
column6: few bands attempted to possess either the chops of their SST days or the dexterous
column7: expansive pop-metal that would come later.

column1: And yet
column2: instead of reissuing any of their mammoth LPs for a much-needed rediscovery
column3: A&M chooses to strip mine the Soundgarden vaults for barely new compilations. Even more so than the poorly curated and bafflingly packaged hodgepodge of career retrospective Telephantasm
column4: Live on I-5 comes off like an experiment to figure out the minimum amount of effort required to separate a Soundgarden fan from $9.99. Rather than capturing the band at the peak of its powers
column5: I-5 documents the Down on the Upside tour that found Soundgarden worn out by that album's grueling recording sessions
column6: punishing substance abuse
column7: and most importantly
column8: each other.

column1: That the title references a stretch of highway along the Pacific instead of a single venue is in itself telling: though I-5 ends up a pretty faithful recreation of Soundgarden's setlist at the time
column2: it's pieced together from a handful of West Coast dates
column3: and you can tell by how the crowd noise pipes in at random intervals and volumes like a hovering apparition. As such
column4: there's really no ebb and flow
column5: no tension
column6: no sense that this needed to be Soundgarden's first live document. At the very least
column7: Kim Thayil
column8: Ben Shepherd
column9: and Matt Cameron are highly skilled musicians doing efficient yeoman's work here-- there's an anachronistic pleasure in hearing Thayil's serpentine soloing wailing through the very unhip wah-wah pedal
column10: and how they manage to pummel through the closing ""Jesus Christ Pose"" is nothing short of miraculous considering the torpor that precedes it. They give a very professional performance
column11: nothing less
column12: nothing more.

column1: So what we're basically left with is a live album whose perverse main draw is the chance to hear a good portion of Soundgarden's most iconic tracks given the Lizard King treatment by someone whose vocal cords were clearly on the business end of way too many bottles of vodka. Let's not mince words-- Chris Cornell sounds terrible here
column2: and he's pretty much all you can hear when he takes the mic. Granted
column3: hearing him go all Tarzan on record provided some of Soundgarden's most visceral thrills
column4: and oddly enough
column5: he has no problem hitting the climactic high notes of ""Spoonman"" and ""Rusty Cage"". But nearly everything else just finds his vocals tattered and flailing in and out of tune like a flag in a torrential downpour
column6: making you wonder just how bad things really got if these were truly the top-shelf recordings. Even the choice of covers here lack inspiration-- ""Search and Destroy"" and the even more ubiquitous ""Helter Skelter"" are given Blueshammer makeovers
column7: no different from any number of bands doing the same thing at a sports bar near you.

column1: Look
column2: that rating up there is a reflection of the presentation
column3: not of the underlying material: God knows any record with ""Rusty Cage"" on it deserves better. The problem is that this was
column4: at best
column5: a 1997 cash-grab that probably would've worked in that economic climate
column6: and now you just get to debate whether it's a cynical move on Soundgarden's part or
column7: more likely
column8: something they had absolutely nothing to do with at all. If you want to get excited about their upcoming album
column9: see them live now. Or listen to Louder Than Love
column10: Badmotorfinger
column11:
or Superunknown-- they hold up just fine.

Rafter Roberts' songs bounce and bend with an oddball sort of charm
column2: and each record finds him following his muse in a slightly different way. His latest LP as Rafter
column3: Quiet Storm
column4: finds him once again staking out new territory. Released abruptly in late January

column1: Quiet Storm doesn't really sound like black metal at all
column2: nor does it sound like
column3: in Rafter's words
column4: ""Darkthrone meets the Kinks meets Lee Perry."" But the record is reminiscent of Microphones/Mount Eerie godhead Phil Elverum's recent dalliances with the dark arts
column5: namely
column6: Mount Eerie's 2008 EP
column7: Black Wooden Ceiling Opening. Both that record and Quiet Storm apply a similar amp-blown aesthetic to the songs. But while Elverum's affection for lo-fi and disquieting distortion is nothing new
column8: Rafter's music has never sounded this harsh and abrasive-- almost every drum hit on this record crackles and blasts through everything else surrounding it. The technique adds a crunchy texture to the material
column9: foregrounding Rafter's debt to the spikier end of 1990s indie rock. Elsewhere
column10: the new dressings add an ominous
column11: discordant feel to the record's more dirge-like moments (see album closer ""Born Again"" and the clattering din of ""Coldness of Space"").

column1: Rafter has experimented with recording fidelity in the past (see: 2008's Sex Death Cassette)
column2: and Quiet Storm is arguably his most successful venture in this arena so far. Ironically
column3: though
column4: the sound of the record ultimately holds it back. There's simply too much noise here
column5: and it's often  poorly placed. The more melodic material falls flat in this setting
column6: and tedium truly sets in during the album's mid-section
column7: where melody is set aside almost entirely in favor of twitching electronics and toppled percussion. At its best
column8: though
column9: the scattered
column10: ramshackle nature of Quiet Storm manages to transcend these difficult passages. And for those who'd rather hear Rafter in a different sonic guise
column11:
chances are you won't have to wait long for him to change it up again.

There's a sense of unfinished business surrounding Subtle
column4: the Doseone-fronted collective who dabbled in high concept pop/rap crossovers that always seemed to fall agonizingly short of the wider audience they deserved. Their final record together
column5: ExitingARM
column6: felt like an overt push toward accessibility
column7: mainly due to its adherence to finely honed song structures that were executed with zipped-up brevity. Subtle called it quits in 2009 shortly after ExitingARM failed to reach beyond their immediate fanbase
column8: but one of its founder members
column9: Jordan Dalrymple
column10: has continued to develop various threads from that record with this first album under his Antonionian guise. It's short
column11: with a combined runtime of just over 30 minutes
column12: and works around the same catholic mash-up of pop
column13: rock
column14: funk
column15: R&B
column16: and hip-hop influences that his prior band thrived upon.

column1: The slightly clumsy moniker Dalrymple has chosen to adopt is a nod to the work of Michelangelo Antonioni
column2: the Italian filmmaker who was prone to dabble in abstraction
column3: despondency
column4: and societal and personal dysfunction. If Dalrymple shares one aspect with his almost-namesake
column5: it's in his partiality for the metaphysical
column6: which is strung out across the opaque lyrics that are voiced throughout most of these recordings. This is an album that's all about feeling
column7: of conjuring up a particular mood
column8: where the words are an additional splash of color for the listener to decipher. Those song-based tracks are spliced up by two scene-setting pieces-- the opening ""The Desert""
column9: which sets a baleful tone via compacted beats and great washes of treated harmonies; and ""The Desert Pt. 2""
column10: the penultimate track that's about as close as Dalrymple gets to straight-out rock
column11: with its fuzzy guitar and manically chanted vocal incantations.

column1: The wide stylistic gap between those two songs indicates the general direction of Antonionian
column2: which ultimately fragments into different junctures with every new turn it takes. The vocal tone
column3: pushed high into a falsetto range for the most part
column4: works as an anchor of sorts
column5: giving the album its only common motif
column6: although it's difficult to feel grounded in an Antonionian ""sound"" at any particular moment. A case in point: ""My Mind's I"" is a jittery pop track that matches an aching lyric from Dalrymple with furious acoustic strumming and a sea of choral voices. This is followed by ""Vanquished""
column7: a downcast ballad full of melodramatic cries
column8: which in turn gives way to ""The Ride""
column9: a light mid-range number that marries the soft-focus pop of Air with the quirky impulses of Bruce Haack.

column1: It might sound like a messy conglomeration of styles-- and it certainly takes more than a few listens to becomes fully acquainted with the Antonionian world-- but Dalrymple is a meticulous arranger who just about knows how to slot all the pieces together. Occasionally he'll plunge too close to outright homage; ""Into the Night"" is one-part Ladytron synth snarl and one-part Prince-circa-Parade airiness
column2: while the following ""Fate's Not Particular"" is a disappointingly played-straight diversion into shrill indie rock. That taste for diversity is partly what made Subtle tick
column3: but what's lacking here is the overriding edge that made that project work. In short
column4: Doesone could conjure up whole worlds of possibility through a series of carefully obfuscated lyrics
column5: but Dalrymple can't quite pull off the same trick despite adhering to similar methodology. There's a sense that he's meandering with no particular destination in mind here
column6: which is fine if that's his only intent
column7:
but his prior work suggested he's capable of so much more.

The title of Faded Days implies the kind of misremembered nostalgia prevalent in a lot of modest
column2: underground strains of recent indie music. It's a title that evokes images of dusty shoeboxes in the attic
column3: overflowing with weather-beaten photos from broken 35mm cameras. As artists embrace obsolete technology as tools for creation
column4: Faded Days at first glance seems to be heading down that path: a celebration of the past
column5: a lament for when times were simpler.

column1: ""I've seen better days
column2: sings Cameron Allen in a dejected tenor on album opener ""Oskar""
column3: minutes before wistfully urging the grass in his lawn to grow; what starts out as a young man peeking over his shoulder at the days gone by ends with him pleading for the sands of time to hurry along. It quickly becomes clear that Faded Days-- written and recorded by Allen in what sounds like a bedroom setting-- is actually a collection of songs meant to put more distance between its creator and his past
column4: a final look into the haze of yesteryear. On the very next song
column5: Allen pledges to ""change myself
column6: rearrange shelves
column7: turning the humdrum chore of reconfiguring his living space into a significant act of revision.

column1: The main theme of Faded Days turns out to be how the past eventually blanches and evaporates under the dark
column2: looming shadow of the horizon. The lyrics that aren't concerned with the past are cautiously optimistic for what the future holds. Musically
column3: Allen uses his effects-laden drone-pop to render his past even blurrier. At times
column4: his propensity for loop-based
column5: floating stateliness is eerily reminiscent of fellow Georgian Bradford Cox
column6: making instrumentals like ""Collision"" and bouncy
column7: ambient-leaning garage-rock tracks ""Nowhere (Beth)"" and the aforementioned ""Rearrange Shelves"" sound like skeletal Atlas Sound demos.

column1: At times the similarities between the two projects veer toward suspicion
column2: like the vocal melodies on ""Children"" or the chord changes on ""Oskar"". Many of the tracks bear interesting production flourishes that provide depth to the minimalism of the songs (Faded Days is thoroughly a ""headphones album"")
column3: showing that Allen has an incredibly adroit ear for production. But that unfortunately doesn't save ""Spider Crawls"" or ""Children"" from plodding along and sounding a little too sparse. The album loses momentum toward the end
column4: with Allen dragging his pedals through psychedelic soundscapes and dragging the album right behind him.

column1: On album highlight ""Window Seal""
column2: Allen siphons his instruments into a gorgeous
column3: dreamlike state
column4: its glacial measure augmented by a simple piano progression
column5: celestial
column6: chiming guitar
column7: and distorted synthesizer. An egg shaker keeps time as Allen draws anguished melancholy from his sleepy
column8: boyish vocals that unconvincingly project a very specific kind of emotional distance-- the kind that comes from someone so broken that he's too numb to control the tone of his voice.

column1: Ultimately
column2: Faded Days is the product of a young songwriter and sound architect that proves he holds a wellspring-- almost an entire world-- of ideas
column3: but isn't quite sure how to fully flesh them out yet. Cameron Allen has very good reason to look straight ahead to the future
column4:
because Faded Days sends him off on the right path.

In 2011
column2: Pearl Jam celebrate the achievement of having been Pearl Jam for a very long time. It's their 20th anniversary
column3: and they're marking the occasion with a blowout
column4: yearlong victory lap: a massive curated festival
column5: a career-spanning documentary directed by Cameron Crowe
column6: and loving reissues of their second and third albums
column7: Vs. and Vitalogy. It's an unusually protracted foray into the limelight for what was once a chronically spotlight-averse band
column8: but they seem to be wearing the moment lightly
column9: savoring it for its valedictory worth and gladly soaking up the adulation. In the years that spanned the original release of these two albums
column10: they spent most of their effort scrambling to escape stardom
column11: and Vs. and Vitalogy bear their struggle's deepest marks.

column1: This willful abdication of fame has become their most well-known
column2: oft-told story
column3: and seeing these records given lavish repackaging only highlights that it feels like ancient history now. Consider: The opening salvo in Pearl Jam's war against commercialism was their decision
column4: for 1993's Vs.
column5: not to make a video for MTV
column6: a situation with no present-day analogue. Their protracted feud against Ticketmaster seems similarly remote now that Pearl Jam seemingly never stop touring: whether you live in Albany
column7: West Palm Beach
column8: Ljubljana
column9: or Katowice
column10: Pearl Jam probably just stopped by or will be there shortly
column11: treating their entire discography like an all-you-can-eat buffet. These days
column12: few bands are more comfortable in their own skin than Pearl Jam
column13: and the monolithic mass culture bearing down on them in 1993 has vanished into thin air.

column1: But even if the media context has long crumbled
column2: the sound of a young band absolutely freaking the fuck out is still loud and clear on Vs. and Vitalogy
column3: and it makes them Pearl Jam's most resonant and affecting records. Their huge-selling debut
column4: Ten
column5: hit with an impact that could not be repeated
column6: and they would go on to make some very good music later in their career. But as a band
column7: this remains their most vital and endearing period-- the last time the entire world cared deeply about what Pearl Jam would do next.

column1: Their music
column2: as always
column3: remains the least complex part of this equation. Pearl Jam's retooled take on classic rock was often lumpy and flat-footed
column4: and they sounded hopelessly unfashionable next to their punk-influenced contemporaries. But focusing on these flaws
column5: as most rock critics did and still do
column6: misses out on the music's signature virtue
column7: which is communication. It is this burning and self-evident need for human connection
column8: more than anything else
column9: that has always elevated and redeemed their most dubious efforts
column10: and it was a quality personified by Eddie Vedder
column11: an empathetic lead singer who transmitted a vivid emotional intensity. At its most winning
column12: Pearl Jam's music exudes his best personality traits: warm
column13: earnest
column14: generous
column15: passionate
column16: and
column17: yeah
column18: harmlessly dopey sometimes.

column1: Consider
column2: for example
column3: Vs.'s cringe-inducing gun-control song ""Glorified G"". ""Kindred to being an American
column4: Vedder pronounces in a hokey fake-jingo accent
column5: over a corn-pone Skynyrd guitar lick: it's the sort of wince-inducing mess we get when he attempts to be caustic. Vs. is filled with this sort of clumsily wielded
column6: early-90s political indignation
column7: and it can make for precarious listening. Nevertheless
column8: Vedder's anguished tenor anchors us through some rough waters-- including ""Dissident""
column9: which
column10: for some reason
column11: focuses on the Lifetime movie-worthy story of a lonely spinster giving shelter to and falling for a charismatic young revolutionary
column12: only to surrender him to the authorities. It is a profoundly ludicrous song. But the way Vedder hollers ""she gave him away
column13: you'll catch yourself momentarily shaking your head in disgust at the woman's cowardice. Hell
column14: even ""Glorified G"" boasts a killer bridge.

column1: In retrospect
column2: however
column3: Vs. appears as the moment where it became crystal-clear that Pearl Jam's ballads were ultimately stronger than their rockers. For all their clenched fury
column4: songs like ""Go""
column5: ""Animal""
column6: and ""Blood"" mostly just thrashed awkwardly in place. ""Daughter""
column7: by contrast
column8: is plaintive and lovely
column9: and ""Elderly Woman Behind the Counter in a Small Town"" has survived nearly two decades of dorm-room slaughtering intact
column10: an effortless and sunlit acoustic ballad that Rod Stewart could have written for Every Picture Tells a Story.

column1: By the time of 1994's Vitalogy
column2: Pearl Jam had spent a lot of energy on extra-musical fights. Recorded during breaks on their strenuous Vs. tour and subject to the communication breakdown of the entire band
column3: Vedder took his strongest hand yet in the album's direction
column4: pushing further from arena rock pyrotechnics. Somewhere in there
column5: the original drummer-- good-natured hesher Dave Abbruzzese-- was fired due to ""personality conflicts."" (Read: he enjoyed being famous.)

column1: The resulting album is still a defiantly weird beast
column2: though not really in the way Vedder intended it to be. Under his direction
column3: Vitalogy became their ""experimental"" album-- which
column4: in Pearl Jam lingo
column5: translates to ""the one with all the most transparently awful ideas."" On ""Spin the Black Circle""
column6: we are treated to the spectacle of an empathetic
column7: intuitive surfer straining to be a splenetic NYC punk rocker
column8: while the band behind him falls over itself trying to keep pace with a simple hardcore riff. The polyrhythmic chanting of ""Aya Davanita"" sounds like corporate-retreat weekend warriors seeking their inner third eye in a drum circle. The accordion-and-tuba spoken-word of ""Bugs"" is an avert-your eyes
column9: car-crash attempt at Captain Beefheart surrealism. And ""Hey
column10: Foxymophandelmama
column11: That's Me"" is an eight-minute sound collage featuring snippets of dialog from mental patients.

column1: Here's the funny thing
column2: though
column3: about all of Vitalogy's ill-advised wandering-- it paid off elsewhere. Through all these misadventures
column4: you can hear what was once the most rigid rhythmic backbone in rock began to stretch and pull like taffy
column5: so that when Pearl Jam relax into a Stooges/MC5 proto-punk groove on ""Last Exit""
column6: they sound rough
column7: loose and limber like never before. In the snarling
column8: adenoidal ""Satan's Bed""
column9: Vedder actually manages one or two acerbically funny lines. It all came together on ""Corduroy""
column10: which moves fluidly from quiet brooding to seething explosions to
column11: in the chorus
column12: a simple
column13: humane plea
column14: set to Vedder's single greatest melody.

column1: ""Corduroy""'s famous plea
column2: of course
column3: was from Vedder to his own too-adoring fans. ""I don't wanna be held in your debt
column4: he sang shakily to millions-- and
column5: entranced
column6: they screamed it back at him. The poignancy of Vitalogy
column7: and the source of its actual weirdness
column8: is how it veers from Vedder's impulse to hide from everyone and his instinctual desire to reach out. Nothing captures these warring impulses better than ""Nothingman"" and ""Better Man""
column9: two folk-rock pillars of their catalog that are as open-hearted and yearning as anything they ever wrote. Even when he was trying his hardest to scowl at the world
column10: Vedder couldn't help feeling
column11: all over the place
column12: for everyone. Misanthropy was always unbecoming on him. Most of his best
column13: most beloved
column14: and resonant songs are about other people's problems: ""Nothingman""
column15: ""Better Man""
column16: ""Daughter""
column17: ""Elderly Woman"". In concert
column18: the kiss-off of ""Corduroy"" has become Pearl Jam's most joyful
column19: communal moment.

column1: Live
column2: Pearl Jam have always been a legendarily intense experience
column3: and they've made an alarmingly consistent practice of making at least momentary believers out of anyone who sees them. The Vitalogy and Vs. reissues come bundled with a recording of the band at their early peak
column4: at a 1994 show at Boston's Orpheum. It's a rousing set
column5: and it opens compellingly
column6: on Ten's slow-burn ""Oceans"". But years of live-Pearl-Jam-recording fatigue has dulled the impact of another official release-- this is a band that once decided to officially release every single show of a world tour
column7: after all-- and Live at the Orpheum Theatre contains no real revelations. As they have done for years
column8: they cover Neil Young's ""Fuckin' Up"" (the version on Live on Two Legs hits harder.) They play ""Even Flow""; they don't play ""Jeremy"". The only real surprises are when Vedder drastically changes the words to ""Immortality""
column9: and when he brings out Mudhoney's Mark Arm for a vicious rip through the Dead Boys' ""Sonic Reducer"". (Unable to bring himself to utter the dreaded g-word
column10: he introduces Arm as ""one of the forefathers of... uh... all the great music that everyone listens to."") It's a fine set
column11: but it's hardly necessary.

column1: In the ensuing decade-plus after Vs. and Vitalogy
column2: Pearl Jam have gone from utter exile to a comfortable perch on the fringes. That's where they sit now
column3: finding refuge in their live shows
column4: which have developed a traveling-cult aura that clearly recalls the Grateful Dead's. For the members of Pearl Jam
column5: however
column6: the live shows don't just bring together their faithful; they rewrite the band's own troubled history. In 2011
column7: it doesn't matter what song they drag out in concert: ""Lukin""
column8: the one-minute punk brain-fart from No Code? The poignant but relatively rare B-side single ""I Got Id""? The ukulele song from Binaural? No worries: The crowd knows every word and will go absolutely apeshit for it. They can thrash joyfully through ""Spin the Black Circle"" as if Jeff Ament and Mike McCready didn't grit their way through the recording session. Hell
column9: they can even play ""Bugs"" live now if they want. These days
column10: they have the aura of happy
column11: weathered warriors
column12: proud to have just made it out together. The live show remains the most optimal set of conditions to give yourself over to their ham-fisted grandeur; go see them
column13:
if you have a chance. They'll be by soon.

column1: Live
column2: Pearl Jam have always been a legendarily intense experience

column8: they cover Neil Young's ""Fuckin' Up"" (the version on Live on Two Legs hits harder.) They play ""Even Flow""; they don't play ""Jeremy"". The only real surprises are when Vedder drastically changes the words to ""Immortality""

column11: but it's hardly necessary.

column7: it doesn't matter what song they drag out in concert: ""Lukin""

column10: they have the aura of happy
column11: weathered warriors
column12: proud to have just made it out together. The live show remains the most optimal set of conditions to give yourself over to their ham-fisted grandeur; go see them
column13:
if you have a chance. They'll be by soon.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16369/homepage_large.27f9dba6.jpg|The Return of Mr. Zone 6|27649.0|Gucci Mane|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Bros.']|2011-03-30 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:32:30.410361|"

Gucci Mane is having a rough 2011. He started the year facing trial for parole violation-- the same charge that's kept him in prison for a pretty good chunk of the past two years. After his lawyer filed a plea of mental incompetency
column2: he had to spend some time in a psychiatric institution. When he got out
column3: he pretty much confirmed his own insanity by getting a giant tattoo on his face: an ice cream cone with lightning bolts shooting out of it. The Appeal: Georgia's Most Wanted
column4: the commercial album he released late last year
column5: shot for crossover status and failed to get there. This year's Gucci 2 Time mixtape was a muddled mess. And Waka Flocka Flame
column6: Gucci's protégé and an infinitely shittier rapper
column7: has been outshining his onetime mentor for at least the past six months-- scoring huge radio hits
column8: changing the face of rap
column9: and completely dominating Brick Squad Mafia
column10: the new mixtape from Gucci's 1017 Brick Squad crew. Gucci
column11: who was rap's most exciting figure a year and a half ago
column12: is on a profound losing streak
column13: and it's easy to hear The Return of Mr. Zone 6
column14: his new street album
column15: as an attempt to reverse that slide.

column1: It's also Gucci's attempt to update his style in a changing rap landscape. When Gucci was peaking
column2: he was working regularly with producers like Zaytoven and DJ Speedy
column3: whose twinkly
column4: playful beats made an ideal backdrop for his slurry
column5: melodic choruses and joyous bursts of wordplay. But thanks to Waka Flocka's rise
column6: the dark
column7: synthetic heaviness of crunk is now back in vogue
column8: and Gucci's adjusted his sound to match. Gucci's main collaborator on The Return of Mr. Zone 6 is Drumma Boy
column9: the Memphis producer who's worked extensively with Gucci's onetime foe Young Jeezy and who also helmed Waka's anthem ""No Hands"". Drumma favors gothy string-churns and overdriven snares
column10: and his beats have a grim majesty. But they aren't really suited to a rapper as gleefully drunk on language as Gucci. And so Gucci tends to slow his delivery here
column11: putting more threat in his voice and easing up on the dizzy fun.

column1: But this is still Gucci Mane
column2: and he still comes up with some seriously sticky hooks and great turns of phrase: ""I'm a dinosaur
column3: you a herbivore/ I use words and verbs you ain't heard before
column4: ""Get ya head bust wide for ya old-man pride."" (His explanation for the ice-cream face tat is a bit unsatisfying
column5: though: ""Ice cream on my face and chain cuz that's the life that I live
column6: shawty."") Even though it's not really where he lives
column7: Gucci can do this kind of crawling menace as well as almost anyone. With his delivery slowed down
column8: he's still got one of the greatest voices of any rapper working: a marble-mouthed mutter that sticks to beats like peanut butter. And there are plenty of other nice moments on The Return: Master P coming back from faded-mogul oblivion to grunt like it's 1997 again
column9: Birdman turning in one of his hardest verses ever
column10: Wale continuing on in his evolution toward brutally emphatic strip-club rapper.

column1: But there are also a few completely awful ideas. Gucci doesn't need to devote an entire track to relationships and feelings
column2: the way he does on ""Better Baby""; he's at his best when he's making fun of that stuff. And he damn sure doesn't need to spend a whole song singing through Auto-Tune
column3: which he does on ""My Year""; rappers try to sing all the time
column4: but never quite this tunelessly. These groaners mean that Gucci's still nowhere near recapturing the momentum he had a couple of years ago. And while a few moments of that old brilliant lunacy would've gone a long way toward saving the day
column5: he instead focuses on cranking out one solid banger after the next. The resulting album is perfectly effective
column6:
but it's almost never inspired.
