column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16365/homepage_large.4bf1b0c4.jpg|Moody
column2:
Standard and Poor|27656.0|Obits|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2011-03-30 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:32:30.976394|"

If there's one thing Obits don't have
column3: it's a hip new sound. When the New York City-based quartet's debut
column4: I Blame You
column5: arrived in 2009
column6: it sounded refreshingly back-to-basics. The band played amped-up roots rock-- twangy Creedence Clearwater Revival riffs delivered at speedy
column7: Wipers-worthy tempos. No samplers and no drum machines
column8: just four scowling dudes and some tube amps. Co-frontmen Rick Froberg and Sohrab Habibion did time playing raw and heavy post-hardcore-- in Hot Snakes and Edsel
column9: respectively-- but Obits jettisoned the atonal bashing in favor of space and subtlety.

column1: Moody
column2: Standard and Poor
column3: the band's second full-length
column4: is in many ways a repeat performance. Guitar duties break down along familiar lines: Rick Froberg hammers out the power chords while Sohrab Habibion plucks the echo-laden leads. Drummer Scott Gursky pounds out four-on-the-floor rhythms with mechanical precision. Obits even hired the same producers
column5: Eli Janney and Geoff Sanoff. Two years on the road has put some wear-and-tear on the quartet's psyche
column6: though. I Blame You tempered stormy feelings with the occasional glimmer of major-key hope-- the ringing open-chord chorus of ""Lilies in the Street"" or the Phil Spector stomp of ""Back and Forth"". This time around the quartet is a shade grumpier. Songs are
column7: by turns
column8: bitter
column9: weary
column10: and defeated. ""Self medication don't seem to improve my station
column11: sings Froberg on ""New August"". ""I'm so tired
column12: tired of my dreams."" Habibion
column13: who sings two songs on the record
column14: is similarly down in the dumps. ""You're hanging on to scraps
column15: I'm taking what is mine
column16: he yells on ""Standards"". ""I just see a ghost when I look into your eyes.""

column1: Nothing can crush a rock song like good vibes
column2: though. So it doesn't hurt that on <i>Moody
column3: Standard and Poor
column4: life-affirming thoughts are few and far between. Album opener ""You Gotta Lose"" rides in on a propulsive ping-ponging garage-rock riff. The three-chord refrain that closes ""No Fly List"" gets Froberg whelping at

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>

his sandpapery best. But the second half of the record sags. Two instrumentals-- ""Spot the Pikey"" and stormy closer ""I Blame Myself""-- feel tossed off and inessential next to gnarled rockers like ""Killer"". And even with Janney and Sanoff behind the boards
column2: the record sounds murky and loose. I Blame You spoofed pro-studio production-- adding a jokey disclaimer that read
column3: ""Xtra compressed for maximum listener fatigue."" <i>Moody
column4: Standard and Poor could stand some additional punch in the rhythm section
column5: though.

column1: Obits are only on their second record
column2: but a generation has gone by since Froberg and Habibion first plugged into a Marshall stack. Three out of four band members are old enough to have seen Nation of Ulysses play live. While Obits may have ditched the buzz and scrape of their roots
column3: that music's sweaty abandon
column4: or the pursuit thereof
column5:
is still deeply embedded in Obits' sound. And that never goes out of fashion.

"|15257.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15257-moody-standard-and-poor/|6.8|Aaron Leitko

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16364/homepage_large.8e00a509.jpg|Rio Arriba|29582.0|Chancha Via Circuito|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['ZZK']|2011-03-30 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:32:31.661085|"

There's a future and there's the past
column2: and we call the thing in-between ""the present."" One of my favorite portraits of the present-- and one that I think has become more and more common since the late 20th century-- is one that combines a technocratic near-future with a raw
column3: distant past. Paul Simon sang about it in 1986: ""These are the days of lasers in the jungle
column4: lasers in the jungle somewhere""-- the idea being that both the lasers and the jungle seemed slightly out of reach but still evoked the current moment. In indie music
column5: it's become a familiar trope: Animal Collective-- who are sometimes described as ""tribal"" despite playing shows where three guys stand at podiums of decks and wires and flashing lights-- are a good example. It's a particular kind of nostalgia-- not just for James Murphy's unremembered 80s
column6: but a kind of pre-verbal
column7: collectively remembered moment that we can't access without electronics.

column1: Chancha Via Circuito is a young Argentinian producer named Pedro Canale who makes music generally referred to as ""digital cumbia""-- a modern interpretation of a sound originally forged in Colombia when African slaves lived there during Spanish occupation. Rio Arriba is a dreamy
column2: neo-primitive mix of chopped-up pan flutes
column3: folk guitar
column4: Coke-bottle percussion
column5: and booming
column6: electronically treated drums-- an almost shamanistic sound that carries its own landscape: underbrush
column7: riverbanks
column8: campfires. The melodies are simple and repetitive; the rhythms-- or the standard cumbia rhythm
column9: at least-- have an uncanny quality of sounding like their upbeats are snapping back against their downbeats
column10: firmly in step but rebelling against the next bar. They're hypnotic but jerky
column11: a kind of rhythmic paradox.

column1: As I understand it
column2: Cumbia in Buenos Aires has long been treated as bottom-rung culture for people who are poor
column3: old
column4: or both-- a reputation complicated by the way in which the city
column5: according to DJ/rupture
column6: ""look[s] wistfully towards Europe."" (The local brand of cumbia is actually called ""cumbia villera""-- shantytown cumbia.) But
column7: Canale-- along with several other young producers and DJs on ZZK Records and throughout Buenos Aires-- have been revisiting and revising it over the past several years. Some of the modern permutations-- like Pibes Chorros or Damas Gratis-- feel populist and celebratory
column8: filled with aggressively synthesized accordions and saxophones. In live videos
column9: kids bounce up and down with homemade flags while dudes in sunglasses mash keytars next to lines of barely clothed girls. It's a party.

column1: Others-- like Chancha Via Circuito-- are more downtempo and atmospheric. Like Burial's Untrue
column2: Rio Arriba is informed by dance music more than it actually functions as dance music. One of the interesting things about CVC and some of the other people surrounding ZZK is that they've managed to make a mutated form of cumbia that actually appeals to upscale locals
column3: too. Zizek-- the club that ZZK Records grew out of-- is in Palermo Soho
column4: a part of Buenos Aires known for its dressed-down fine dining and locally owned boutiques-- basically
column5: one of those DIY microcapitalist fantasias. And what's interesting
column6: I think
column7: is that in both cases-- the Zizek world and the Damas Gratis/Pibes Chorros one-- the unglamorous sound of cumbia is being reclaimed by a younger
column8: more local audience as something to celebrate.

column1: Canale lives on the outskirts of Buenos Aires
column2: and ""chancha via circuito"" roughly means ""pig on the circuit"" (or loop)-- a reference to the train he takes out from the center city every night
column3: and an image that only reinforces the impression that Rio Arriba is
column4: like an old Sexy Sounds of the Jungle-type exotica record
column5: meant to be a journey. The album is dressed with samples that sound like hooting owls or jangling change-- small
column6: ambient ornaments that give the music a sense of mystery.

column1: And actually
column2: it's when Rio Arriba hints more strongly at the dancefloor-- on a couple of the guest-vocal tracks toward the end-- that I fall out of its spell. Most of the time
column3: it's is incredibly repetitive
column4: but the repetition shows patience and restraint. And it's that patience and restraint that always  makes me feel like I've never gotten enough from the album
column5: but it's  also what makes me able to listen to it over and over again
column6: absorbing  its mood a little more each time. Because it never bangs my door down
column7:
I'm happy leaving my door open.

column4: Katy B was widely credited for bringing vocal finesse and feminine pop appeal to an increasingly aggro dubstep-crossover arena. She dropped a fantastic Benga-backed debut single
column5: ""Katy on a Mission""
column6: that vocally wrung out both elation and longing over his abrasive
column7: buzzing stutter-step. And she kept that streak going with a couple of guest spots on Magnetic Man's self-titled record: The eerie come-on ""Crossover"" and the ecstatic jungle throwback ""Perfect Stranger"" were album highlights that proved her voice could breach the barrier of heavy-duty bass and plant its feet firmly atop it. Two UK top 5 hits later-- ""Katy on a Mission"" and the Ms. Dynamite collaboration ""Lights On""-- and members of the English music press started to peg her as the next singer to bring crossover legitimacy to bass music.

column1: Turns out that'd be selling her a bit short. After pairing up with Rinse FM's tastemaker station head Geeneus and co-producer Zinc
column2: Katy B has used On a Mission as a chance to posit herself as a genre-spanning pop singer who isn't tied down to a single thing
column3: no matter how well it suits her. It's a move that makes a lot of sense
column4: since versatility is the key to a good dance album-- let the voice establish itself
column5: and the niche will either find itself or get broadened in the process. ""Katy on a Mission""
column6: ""Lights On""
column7: and ""Perfect Stranger"" reappear here in radio-edit lengths
column8: and these three tracks help define her as someone who can play off dubstep and funky basslines with a tone that drips with cool defiance
column9: stings with melancholy
column10: and still grabs at you when it's being reduced to a skeletal echo. But there's enough stylistic extension here that Katy finds a way to transcend enough signifiers to call herself pop above anything else.

column1: The big standout here is ""Broken Record""
column2: a four-on-the-floor thump with electro underpinnings and a breakdown that perks up longtime dance fans with a judiciously dropped ""Amen"" break. It's one of those club-tested/radio-ready tracks that sounds good anywhere
column3: not out of focus-grouped button-pushing but the way Katy sells it: coyly yearning and melodically sweet on the verse
column4: intense and swooping on the chorus
column5: wracked with ambiguity throughout. And then she finds another gear when the song finally shifts into the titular hook near the end-- the way she rolls her delivery of the line ""like-a-bro-ken rec-ooooord"" is the stuff that song-length buildups were made for. And there's more of that going around on the other new tracks
column6: laid out in a number of different modes-- the trapped yet defiant punchback of opener ""Power on Me""
column7: the sour resentment of ""Why You Always Here""
column8: the slyly perilous seduction that drives ""Witches Brew"". It's a repertoire that gives her the appeal of a 1990s rave diva with contemporary pop-R&B refinement
column9: minus the Auto-Tune.

column1: That alone would make her another noticeably talented if semi-anonymous vocalist. But she also provides a breather from pop's current fascination with vacant navel-gazing. It's not just the nods to decades-old house and jungle that provide a perspective on dance-music culture that predates the tyranny of the David Guetta era-- though Geeneus and Zinc get all the credit in the world for following up Katy's early breakthroughs with a first-rate collection of beats that reunite the disparate splinters of bass music culture past and present. What puts On a Mission over the top is Katy's way of expressing herself with emotions that extend past ""wooo
column2: druuunk"" into more nuanced and detailed relationships with booming systems and the people who flock to them. As danceable as these tracks can be
column3: the undercurrents of nuanced frustration and uncertainty in Katy's tone-- especially in the surrender of ""Power on Me"" and the torn-up estrangement of ""Go Away""-- amplify the tricky dynamics of relationships and hook-ups to rarefied levels
column4: creating a tension to the music that makes epics out of dissatisfaction. And when she withdraws just a bit for one of the more introspective cuts
column5: a haunting mid-tempo meditation on love and identity called ""Disappear""
column6: her caught-up bewilderment says softly and resonantly what lesser singers couldn't accomplish with overblown histrionics. A genre-bound narrative might still see Katy B slotted into a narrow role that can't quite contain her
column7:
but her voice is doing its best to prove otherwise.

column10: on Merge Records
column11: the independent label located within walking distance of his North Carolina home that landed a major Grammy last month. That's not bad for a writer who used to howl and strum into the microphone of his Panasonic boombox and opine that a real songwriter wasn't a career-oriented songwriter.

column1: But in 2002-- when Darnielle made the leap to 4AD and
column2: more saliently
column3: into a proper studio with an ensemble of backing musicians-- his zealous fans started talking about his music as though it were foreign policy. Some loved the new adventurousness and accessibility
column4: apparent from the great bloom of Mountain Goats fans during the last decade. But there are those who insist that the only real Mountain Goats is the atavistic Mountain Goats
column5: the static-y
column6: crackly
column7: mildly manic stuff that Darnielle made mostly alone for more than a decade. To wit
column8: the Mountain Goats forums
column9: which Darnielle hosts on his own website
column10: are a minefield of hot-blooded criticism about the band's rock music
column11: lobbed not by online trolls but by those who might spend hundreds to track down Darnielle's earliest
column12: most primitive releases. After the band released ""Damn These Vampires""
column13: the positive jam that opens All Eternals Deck
column14: Mountain Goats drummer Jon Wurster told me the vile was so rich he simply stopped reading the boards.

column1: This matters now because
column2: despite the fan fusillade
column3: Darnielle has pressed on with his rock band
column4: crafting and sharpening his skills and charisma as a frontman. Paradoxically passionate but controlled
column5: uncompromising but instantly likable
column6: All Eternals Deck is a certain career highlight for Darnielle. And
column7: like many of the most memorable Mountain Goats songs
column8: it's also about survival
column9: or battling back from very dark places to ""follow the light."" Indeed
column10: most every song here holds some key to the future
column11: some talisman meant for perseverance. During ""Damn These Vampires"" and ""Beautiful Gas Mask""
column12: it's didactic
column13: warm advice. Occasionally
column14: however
column15: it's a reflection on the past
column16: when some rocky relationship made more sense
column17: when the world seemed framed by more favorable horizons. The poignant ""Age of Kings""
column18: for instance
column19: reminisces about a wasted love that once suggested a divine blessing. But just as the strings turn anxious
column20: Darnielle remembers the time he might have fixed it all; his regret feels less like self-pity
column22: and more like a future lesson.

column1: All Eternals Deck is officially the third album for the rock band the Mountain Goats
column2: or the trio of Darnielle
column3: longtime bassist Peter Hughes
column4: and Superchunk drummer Jon Wurster. On 2009's The Life of the World to Come
column5: though
column6: Wurster and Hughes felt more like plainspoken accompaniment
column7: simply keeping time and stretching the sound around Darnielle when not sitting out nearly half a dozen tunes. After four years of live practice
column8: they now sound like a properly developed unit that's comfortable with its ideas and approaches. There are no ham-fisted reggae rubs or overreaching rock moments; instead
column9: the band simply plays with nuance and purpose
column10: elaborating the lyrics by first understanding them.

column1: Darnielle replaces his rhythm section twice here
column2: and the success of both songs suggests that the evolution of the Mountain Goats doesn't stop with a rock trio. ""Outer Scorpion Squadron"" should forever quell the gripe that Darnielle can't sing. Above an economical string section
column3: Darnielle speaks of survival with grace and delicacy. The record's one great experiment
column4: mid-album curveball ""High Hawk Season""
column5: swaps the rhythm section for a harmonizing trio known as the North Mountain Singers. Though Darnielle plays acoustic guitar
column6: they treat the song like an a cappella ensemble would
column7: adding bass and texture against his lead line. A call to power
column8: it's one of Darnielle's pinnacles as both a bandleader and songwriter
column9: and a revelatory break from his past. ""Who's going to stand his ground
column10: and who's going to blink?"" he sings
column11: as though winking to his detractors.

column1: Three songs on All Eternals Deck lift directly from the lives of veteran American actors-- Charles Bronson
column2: Judy Garland
column3: and her daughter
column4: Liza Minnelli. In each instance
column5: we see a star in peril
column6: whether it's Garland during the overdose in London that killed her or tough-guy Bronson trying to hold it together for one more feature. In both cases
column7: Darnielle invokes their birthplace
column8: their cradle of innocence
column9: again using the past as a catalyst for perseverance. On ""Sourdoire Valley Song""
column10: Darnielle smartly cuts the other way by referencing the Olduvai Gorge
column11: the Tanzanian ravine sometimes referenced as the birthplace of mankind. An old man struggles and dies
column12: and the world turns. Our struggles
column13: the implication goes
column14: are forever and for everyone-- stars
column15: successful songwriters
column16: ancient hominids thought to be extinct. Even if it means you ""crawl 'til dawn on hands and knees
column17: though
column18: you keep going if you can. Lucky for us
column19:
the rock band the Mountain Goats have done just that.

Thomas Wincek appears to be the type of musician who can never sit still
column3: who is always looking for a new avenue to relay his impulses through. Collections of Colonies of Bees and Volcano Choir are among the bands that keep him busy
column4: and here on All Tiny Creatures' debut full-length he's undertaken the thankless task of finding a group of eight different vocalists to collaborate with the band on certain tracks. Justin Vernon is the closest Wincek gets to finding a constant in his career-- the pair have teamed up in both the aforementioned bands
column5: and Vernon returns here to add a vocal turn to the standout ""An Iris"". To cement his workaholic stature
column6: Wincek released the latter song and ""Glass Bubbles"" ahead of this record
column7: and both of those tracks are complemented by beautifully packaged mixtapes that feature further unreleased material.

column1: It's clear that a great amount of care and attention to detail has been spread all over this record; it's there in the diligent curation of those singers and in the themed cover art by Aaron Draplin. It's also there in the music itself-- Wincek and fellow guitarist Andrew Fitzpatrick have an intuitive knack for delicately stacking up spidery riffs so they work perfectly in tandem
column2: while drummer Ben Derickson and bassist Matthew Skemp demonstrate a mastery of subtly infectious and understated grooves. Some of the touchstones for this music are clear from the outset; the opening ""Holography"" is driven by the kind of ever-cycling drumbeat Klaus Dinger made his trademark in Neu!
column3: and the compressed guitar squall is reminiscent of the tones Archer Prewitt lays over the Sea and Cake's best tracks. But the breezy vocal humming and frantic soloing toward the end of the song pitch it in a realm where those influences are infused with an unlikely prog and pop crossover
column4: ultimately positioning it in a space unique to All Tiny Creatures.

column1: From that point on
column2: this is music that sucks you in
column3: that creates a realm full of niggling little harmonies and treated sounds so densely layered that they reveal more only with repeat plays. Vernon's vocal isn't even the most alluring part of ""An Iris""-- the song finds its weight through a lightness of touch in the guitar melodies and a puzzling loop that sounds like the noise a person emits when someone treads on their toe. That song sets the emotional tone for the record
column4: with most of Harbors bearing a bittersweet ambiance that its vocalists tap into. In some cases
column5: such as Ryan Olcott's hoarse tones on the Playlisted ""Glass Bubbles""
column6: it's those vocals that temper the bouncing guitar lines from shifting the track too far toward ebullience. In others
column7: that crestfallen feeling can be more overtly felt in the instrumentation
column8: such as the chiming guitars on ""Breathing Set""
column9: or the muted electronic passages of ""Valves or Hatches"" and the Eno-esque ""Triangle Frog"".

column1: It's striking how Harbors manages to form a central aesthetic that's identifiable as All Tiny Creatures but can also fold in a wide array of influences. The whimsical backing vocals on ""Cargo Maps"" are reminiscent of the kind of experimentation Brian Wilson was mapping out for the Beach Boys on tracks like ""Roll Plymouth Rock""
column2: and the stop-start segment of ""Aviation Class"" manages to bridge Wincek's fascination with Warp-style electronic artists and his leanings toward more traditional forms of shiny guitar pop. The focus starts to slip a little toward the end
column3: with another diversion into ambient drift on ""Reservoirs"" and more ""ahh-ahh"" vocal passages in ""Tine Feature"". But the rippling guitar and choir-like singing of the closing ""Plankton March"" ties the loose ends together and again showcases this group's gift for sifting bundles of sincerity into song via the disparate elements at their disposal. That sense of focus on making emotionally redolent material
column4: and keeping the overall thrust of the project in view despite having many hands on the tiller
column5:
are ultimately what makes Harbors solidify into a satisfyingly cohesive whole.

It's been over 20 years since the Tout Puissant Orchestre Poly-Rythmo last made a studio LP. More than two decades away from anything is a long time
column2: but in popular music
column3: 20 years is practically a geologic epoch-- everything changes
column4: from the sounds on the records to the social conditions under which they're made. Back in their 1970s heyday
column5: Poly-Rythmo were a nearly unmatched force
column6: playing easily in any style on the stage and developing a sound all their own in the studio. Founded in 1966 as the Sunny Blacks Band (sometimes written Sunny Black's Band) by singer/guitarist Mélomé Clément
column7: the group took the name Poly-Rythmo in 1969 in reference to the fact that they played all rhythms
column8: and over the next 16 years
column9: they recorded over 50 albums and hundreds of 45s for pretty much every label that ever operated in Benin.

column1: The band was hobbled by the 1982 deaths of guitarist Papillon and drummer Yehouessi Léopold
column2: and eventually petered out as the 80s wore on. A flash forward to the last few years finds the band finally being discovered by listeners outside of West Africa
column3: the archival efforts of the Analog Africa
column4: Soundway
column5: and Popular African Music labels bringing the band's achievements into the light. And as with several of the their counterparts
column6: the renewed interest brought the band back together. Or a new version of the band
column7: at least. The 10-piece group that cut Cotonou Club contains five original Poly-Rythmo members-- Clément
column8: singer Vincent Ahéhéhinnou
column9: guitarist Maximus Ajanohun
column10: saxophonist Pierre Loko
column11: and bassist Gustave Bentho-- joined by six other musicians
column12: some of whom have a bit of history with the group.

column1: Does the new Poly-Rythmo measure up to the old? In a few very important respects
column2: it does. It's never going to be the 70s again
column3: of course
column4: and there is a certain spirit of invention and restless creativity on the best of the classic Poly-Rythmo records that a project like this has little hope of recapturing. But it's more than a simple nostalgia trip. For one thing
column5: it doesn't entirely give in to the appetite for funk that caused European and American audiences to get interested in the first place. Sure
column6: most of the music leans that way
column7: but Poly-Rythmo were always an eclectic band
column8: and they haven't forgotten that here
column9: mixing in a bit of highlife and rumba and taking a few surprising side trips into jazz. The result is something that feels a little like one of their old LPs with more studio polish-- producer Elodie Maillot took care to record the band on analog equipment to get some semblance of the natural warmth of their old albums
column10: but the sound is left unadorned
column11: just the band playing.

column1: Amongst the new songs
column2: they revisit a few past glories of Beninois music
column3: including their biggest hit
column4: ""Gbeti Madjro"". On it
column5: they've recruited Benin's biggest pop star
column6: Angelique Kidjo
column7: to share the lead with Ahéhéhinnou while the band holds down the classic breakneck Poly-Rythmo groove
column8: derived from a blend of funk and vodoun ceremonial rhythms. The band spins through tough Latin funk on ""Koumi Dede""
column9: setting merengue piano against stabbing guitar and making room for a startling jazz solo by keyboardist Moïse Loko. Gnonnas Pedro's classic ""Von Vo Nono"" (featured on Analog Africa's Legends of Benin compilation) gets a slowed-down heavy funk treatment
column10: the twin guitars of Ajanohun and Fifi LePrince put air in the highlife lilt of ""Ma Vie""
column11: and there's even an unexpected collaboration with Franz Ferdinand's Nick McCarthy and Paul Thomson on ""Lion Is Burning""
column12: a thumping Afrobeat rave-up that's been slotted as a bonus track.

column1: I don't expect Orchestre Poly-Rythmo to return to their old prolific ways
column2: but it's good to hear from them again. A common theme with these West African bands that have returned in the last decade-- think Bembeya Jazz and Orchestra Baobab-- is that they were dominant in their best years
column3: but the stories ended unsatisfactorily. Coming back now and releasing albums that are close to the level of their classic material
column4: not to mention playing around the world to big crowds
column5: provides a sort of closure. It ends a long song on a high note
column6: and if we're lucky
column7: maybe even begins a new verse. Twenty-odd years ago
column8: when Poly-Rythmo last made a studio album
column9:
they were at their lowest ebb. Cotonou Club finds them at another high.

Capillary action is a physical phenomenon in which liquid rises against gravity. For instance
column3: if you have a small puddle on your kitchen counter and put the edge of a paper towel in it while holding the towel vertically
column4: water will spread up the towel. In the most basic sense
column5: capillary action is liquid moving in an unexpected direction. This is what makes it an effective name for Jonathan Pfeffer's band-- unexpected directions are at the root of Pfeffer's songwriting
column6: which is partly predicated on defying the momentum of uninterrupted 4/4 rhythms. We used to call what he does math rock
column7: but that's not quite adequate to cover all the weird jazz elements the latest lineup of the band brings in
column8: or the way he and the band tease listeners with bits of surprisingly poppy melody before yanking out the rug.

column1: The opening couplet of the second verse on the album
column2: ""It's agreed that this is a suicide mission/ But we're past the point of no return now
column3: feels almost like a private joke between band and listener-- by the time we hit it
column4: we've already swerved through a couple of time signatures
column5: a few start-stops
column6: and a breakneck prog-funk groove
column7: and it's clear that this is not a relaxing album. That won't be a surprise to people familiar with the band
column8: but the way they go about it will. Whereas 2008's So Embarrassing often reverted to brutal
column9: punk-inspired noise rock as a sort of punctuation mark
column10: those outbursts are largely curtailed here
column11: in favor of sophisticated vocal harmony and passages that borrow from free jazz. Pfeffer also leaves his electric guitar in the case
column12: sticking to a nylon-stringed acoustic
column13: while the band is built around upright bass
column14: drums
column15: trumpet
column16: and accordion.

column1: Thing is
column2: I didn't even notice the lack of electric guitar until the third time I listened to the album. The band wrings remarkable volume and aggression out of its setup
column3: due partly to the fact that Dan Sutherland's drums are recorded with a heavy emphasis on the low end. They snap like you're in the room with them
column4: which makes songs like album highlight ""Feeding Frenzy"" sound explosive. On that song
column5: the drums are augmented by a battery of other percussion
column6: including gongs
column7: woodblocks
column8: and handbells. In fact
column9: there's not a single non-percussion instrument on the song other than voices
column10: but again
column11: it doesn't call attention to its novelty.

column1: Not everything works as well. Sometimes a weird rhythm just sounds weird-- ""Sweepstakes"" has what sounds like a pre-composed vocal melody that doesn't really agree with the lyrics
column2: and it makes for an awkward vocal. A band that pushes itself out of usual rock comfort zones as unflinchingly as Capillary Action is almost inevitably going to have moments that don't work as well as others
column3: though. It's being willing to take those risks and succeeding most of the time that makes them a good band
column4:
and Capsized a good album.

The group of musicians loosely (and reluctantly
column2: on their part) grouped under the slowcore moniker in the early 90s left behind a glut of material that's ripe for rediscovery. Leading lights Low have carved out an enduring legacy
column3: but their former peers
column4: including the desolate sounds of former Sub Pop act Codeine
column5: Jeff Martin's brittle Idaho
column6: and hushed Trance Syndicate signings Bedhead
column7: are rarely cited as touchstones by contemporary artists. The slowcore approach ostensibly took impossibly sad material
column8: both musically and lyrically
column9: and pushed it into a hemmed-in framework
column10: where feelings of agitation and despair were expressed in the same forlorn way as a resigned late-night drinker slumped over his umpteenth whiskey at the bar. Occasional traces of this sound do surface-- Mogwai are clearly fans of the wrenching emotional heave at the center of Codeine's music-- but it's rare to find a band so clearly indebted to the style as Texas three-piece True Widow.

column1: But there's a lot more to this band than a generous nod toward their slowcore antecedents. For one thing
column2: True Widow's guitars are much louder and grittier
column3: with a vast bone-crunching slab of murky distortion laid thick over the snail-paced grooves they settle into. They've even taken a stab at coining their own genre
column4: ""stonegaze
column5: to describe this sound
column6: although it's perhaps unwise to assume this is anything other than an inter-band joke. Some of the titles (""Blooden Horse""
column7: ""Skull Eyes""
column8: ""Doomseer"") suggest material that is far darker than the wares actually on offer here
column9: but it's clear that True Widow get their kicks from throwing a spanner in the works on occasion. It's there in the mysterious
column10: over-long
column11: but strangely fitting title of the record
column12: and in the mix-up of Josh Homme-style churning riffage circa the first Queens of the Stone Age album and the floaty
column13: angelic vocals of bassist Nikki Estill on the opening ""Jackyl"".

column1: That song is a fine demonstration of this band's complete mastery of control-- the seething guitar sound of Dan ""D.H."" Phillips makes it feel like they might spin off into recklessness at any moment
column2: but they never do. Instead
column3: True Widow slump into ennui and remain locked down there for the duration. The majority of the vocals are sung by Phillips
column4: who enters the fray with ""Blooden Horse""
column5: which compliments Estill's cooing with pangs of foreboding and cold-sweat rumination. The lyrics are wrung out with the same shaved-down discipline as the music
column6: where nothing ever topples over into over-wrought emoting. Despite this rigid adherence to restraint
column7: much of this material proves to be emotionally affecting-- Phillips' work peaks on ""NH""
column8: which plays out like a slo-mo dip into the bleak blues of Mudhoney's ""If I Think"" and Codeine's ""D""
column9: with great lashes of poignancy added via Estill's heavily reverbed backing vocals.

column1: The sludge-like pace rarely abates
column2: but there are variations in mood
column3: principally in the lengthy ""Boaz""
column4: which Phillips floods with light through a soaring vocal line that pulls the song out of its squalid origins. The only true misstep is ""Night Witches""
column5: the sole concession to a quickening of pace that ends up feeling forced
column6: especially as we are immediately dipped back into the mire with the wonderfully doomy ""Wither"". The torporific riffing of the closing ""Doomseer"" is where True Widow sign off
column7: and they use its nine-minute runtime to subtly evolve their sound
column8: with odd whistling noises at the midway point and a surprise lurch into a different time signature. There's even a subordinate push out of their lockhold groove when Phillips hits a guitar solo two-thirds of the way in
column9: causing the song to peter out into ambient noise. But ""Doomseer"" ultimately embodies everything this band does so well
column10:
where those basic slowcore tenets-- raw emotion tightly mastered and boxed into a corner where it's antithetically filtered into barely restrained stoicism-- are given another welcome gasp of air.

At least in the United States

So far she's done okay-- her single ""Price Tag"" is performing well at pop radio and digital retail-- but it's hard to say whether she's going to have much traction in the U.S. market.

column1: Mainly
column2: Jessie J seems to be surplus to demand. The contemporary pop landscape is already crowded with well-defined female pop stars-- postmodern disco artiste Lady Gaga
column3: fierce soul goddess Beyoncé

column8: and the results are competent but generic.

column1: In some cases
column2: it is all too obvious that the writers are trying to write a ""type"" of song. ""Casualty of Love""
column3: for example
column4: sounds like Alicia Keys' wonderful ""If I Ain't Got You"" stripped of melodic complexity
column5: ambiance
column6: soul
column7: and sentimental resonance. The single ""Do It Like a Dude"" is dancehall pastiche that isn't too far off from Robyn's ""Dancehall Queen""
column8: but trades that singer's warmth and humanity for spiteful hectoring. The acoustic ballad ""Big White Room"" aims for beautiful simplicity
column9: but its delicacy is drowned out by a clumsy and overwrought vocal performance.

column1: Jessie J's persona seems most defined when she is being totally obnoxious. Though she mostly sticks to the predictable un-nuanced phrasing of many young singers desperate to prove that they possess a ""good voice
column2: she sometimes employs a snarky singsong that is very shrill
column3: but at least somewhat distinct. She goes over the top with this affectation on the bratty rocker ""Who's Laughing Now""
column4: a song that could very well be the nadir of modern pop's fixation with attacking ""haters."" The track has her lashing out against acquaintances who she claims bullied her and dissed her early music
column5: but now show an interest in her since she has attained some degree of success. While it is fair to distrust people who transparently want a piece of you
column6: the details in the lyrics seem a bit too minor to merit her intense vitriol. The song is a humorless expression of galling entitlement; the sound of a person who will conflate any form of criticism or disapproval with an attempt to crush her soul. ""Who's Laughing Now"" seems to be pitched as a motivational song
column7: but it's so narcissistic and myopic that it's hard to imagine anyone connecting with the singer's petty grudges and desperate need for constant affirmation.

column1: Cornish is an alum of London's prestigious BRIT School
column2: the arts academy that has launched the careers of several notable young British singers including Amy Winehouse
column3: Adele
column4: Katy B
column5: Jamie Woon
column6: and Kate Nash. Weirdly
column7: of this crop of singers
column8: only Cornish very obviously seems like a person who went to a school for pop stars
column9: with all the tackiness that would imply. She shares their polish and poise
column10: but none of her peers' individual style. Whereas Adele and Winehouse also have powerhouse voices
column11: they fit into clear aesthetic niches and invest their songs with depth and humanity. Jessie J doesn't have even a fraction of their restraint; her idea of showcasing her gift is to shoot for a blaring melisma on ""Mamma Knows Best"" that makes Christina Aguilera seem as subtle as Joni Mitchell by comparison.

column1: On the same weekend Jessie J was getting her first big push in America as the musical guest on ""Saturday Night Live""
column2: the music video for Rebecca Black's ""Friday"" was just beginning to spread around the Internet as a viral sensation. ""Friday"" took off because people were calling it the worst song ever and mocking its dopey lyrics and awkward approximation of standard modern pop tropes. The biggest difference between Black's song and the contents of Who You Are is that while Jessie J gets the expected formula of pop ""right
column3: the hapless Black gets it ""wrong."" But in that ""wrongness"" lies a humanity that J cannot approach. Even through bad vocal processing
column4: Black sounds like a specific person. Also
column5: the lyrics of ""Friday"" may be undeniably clunky
column6: but there is a magic to them that makes the song funny and immensely quotable
column7: like a lot of great pop songs throughout history. Jessie J's lyrics are no less banal and artless
column8: but they lack charm entirely. When she's not going off on bitter rants against those who doubt her
column9: she mainly sings forgettable boilerplate or spouts vapid utopian nonsense
column10: as on the utterly nauseating ""Rainbow"". Black gets attacked for representing the worst of modern pop
column11: but she's a gawky 13-year-old amateur backed up by a Z-grade production company. If you need to rail against dumb
column12: soulless music
column13:
Jessie J is a far better target.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16350/homepage_large.3f43d317.jpg|Fabric 56|22184.0|Derrick Carter|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fabric']|2011-03-25 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:32:41.714320|"

Derrick Carter was one of the earliest second-wave Chicago house artists to make it big in Europe. He's the type of name that can pack houses and play festivals overseas but can probably walk around his native Chicago without being noticed. Carter hails from a generation of electronic artists who have enjoyed this peculiar fame dichotomy
column2: and like many of those producers
column3: he has built his reputation on DJ sets and remixes more than his original productions. This makes him a natural choice for Fabric's bi-monthly mix series
column4: a legacy artist who still has pull.

column1: Carter absolutely deserves his reputation behind the decks; he favors aerobic
column2: loud tracks that lean heavily on jackin' house (more specifically the type of fleshed-out
column3: studio-produced house music that Chicago was churning out in the 1990s after the style gained its footing) but has also been willing to step outside that style to incorporate modern artists (e.g. Hercules and Love Affair) into his mixes. It's tough to say what went wrong on Fabric 56; Carter's first commercial mix since 2005 trades heavily in classic Chicago sounds
column4: but it's devoid of the humor and pacing that have marked Carter's best work.

column1: Carter has never been shy about leaning on tracks with major funk and disco influences
column2: and Fabric 56 sounds particularly indebted to funk and R&B from the 1970s. Tracks like Roger Sanchez's ""My Organ"" contribute to a steady
column3: dense mix that sometimes feels like the classic rock version of house music: age-old rhythms punctuated by horns
column4: hammond organs
column5: and a noticeable sense of The Way Music Should Be. These moments are charmless at best and more often suffocating; this mix replaces house's self-referential up-with-people/up-with-dancing ethos with a self-congratulating largesse. If you like your dance music funny
column6: dubby
column7: or sexually suggestive (instead of aggressive)
column8: look elsewhere.

column1: That Fabric 56 doesn't represent my personal house music utopia is hardly Carter's fault; that the mix barrels along without thought given to the dynamics of volume and tempo certainly is. Carter's choices undoubtedly play better in large rooms on world-class soundsystems
column2: but the constant
column3: hard-charging attitude makes Fabric 56 a poor choice for home listening. Loathe to disrupt his selections
column4: Carter lets the tracks here play for five and six minutes at a time
column5: but they lack a narrative
column6: sonic or otherwise. Carter is normally known for  the rampant sexual energy of his sets
column7: but Fabric 56 isn't particularly erotic or sultry. The mix actually closes with a spiraling
column8: up-tempo jazz freakout; this is Carter's idea of a comedown.

column1: Carter has never been house music's most subtle DJ
column2: but his aggressive tone and execution backfire here. Though his legacy is already secure
column3:
Fabric 56 was an opportunity to document Carter's style for a new audience; his history-indebted tracklist suggests this might have even been his intent. Carter told the Chicago Reader that DJing is ""work"" for him at this point; let's consider Fabric 56 just a bad day at the office.

"|15241.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15241-fabric-56/|5.1|Andrew Gaerig

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16353/homepage_large.e84c58e3.jpg|Mazes|28493.0|Moon Duo|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sacred Bones']|2011-03-25 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:32:42.300121|"

For artists from David Bowie to the Birthday Party to Liars
column2: seeking refuge to record in Berlin has resulted in some very dark
column3: very far-out releases. So when psychedelic pop twosome Moon Duo-- which features Wooden Shjips' Erik ""Ripley"" Johnson on guitar and fellow San Franciscan Sanae Yamada on keyboards-- decided to head to the German capital to craft their second proper full-length
column4: Mazes
column5: one could reasonably expect the results to be a bit tortured or mysterious. Where their noticeably toothy debut
column6: Escape
column7: often threatened to slip backwards into the scuzz-laden heavy-psych of a Wooden Shjips record
column8: Mazes is an exercise in accessibility and concision
column9: using familiar
column10: melodic pop templates to support their drone and krautrock tendencies.

column1: Mazes operates very simply
column2: with Yamada setting up the repetitive
column3: unexpectedly hooky keyboard patterns (usually using a variation of organ sounds) and Johnson
column4: displaying some of his best guitar work to date
column5: dropping monstrous
column6: zoned-out sounds over her backdrops. While there are plenty of gnarly effects pedals being stomped all over Mazes
column7: Johnson for the most part refrains from using his guitar to blanket these songs in trance-inducing washes of noise. Moon Duo are still able to achieve awing levels of depth here
column8: but it's made more impressive considering how easy these songs are to follow. Where some of their output (and the same can be said about Wooden Shjips) is about getting lost in the fog
column9: the band helpfully lays a trail of breadcrumbs.

column1: This is also a much more consciously rhythm-focused album that its predecessor
column2: and when songs fall flat (""Scars"") it's usually because Moon Duo haven't taken the time to make sure the groove is properly locked in place. The one you'll hold on to tightest is ""When You Cut""
column3: a deranged sock-hop that rains a torrential boogie on Mazes with such force that it threatens to wash everything else out. Yamada and Johnson work with such precision and symbiotic rigor
column4: going ape over the handclap-filled drum programming
column5: it's a mystery as to why Johnson keeps singing
column6: ""I feel the walls closing in on me."" Instead
column7:
it feels as if the doors have been flung wide open.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16347/homepage_large.79aa54b1.jpg|Other People|28371.0|Primary 1|['Pop/R&B'
column2: 'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Atlantic'
column3:
'Grow Up']|2011-03-25 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:32:42.852414|"

Maybe someday we'll learn more about what happened in the process of making Other People
column4: Joe Flory's first-- and
column5: allegedly
column6: last-- record as Primary 1. In fact
column7: any tidbit would be more helpful than the scraps of info we have. Initially scheduled for a release last fall
column8: the UK synth-pop producer's proper debut for Atlantic was postponed
column9: replaced with an effervescent
column10: new-wavey single
column11: ""Never Know""
column12: as well as a corresponding candy-painted clip
column13: with a tentative LP release date for ""February 2011."" That deadline came and went. Then
column14: in the beginning March
column15: the record was unceremoniously dumped onto the Internet as a UK-only digital release
column16: announced a mere 10 days prior and billed as Primary 1's ""posthumously released debut album."" An attached statement noted that Flory was already working on new music under a different guise. That particular item was framed a bit like a promise
column17: but it felt more like an apology.

column1: So
column2: what happened? It's possible that Flory encountered the same obstacles that would trip up anyone making the transition from bedroom beat fiddler (see: 2009's pleasantly loping
column3: intermittently charming mini-LP Mess Detective) to major label Pop Artist. That theory doesn't scan too well
column4: though
column5: when you consider Flory's innate pop sense
column6: as evinced by ""Never Know"" and the brazen
column7: dizzying melodic spirals of ""Princess"". It's hard (although not entirely impossible) to imagine any label willing to stifle such a playfully accessible voice. Maybe he cracked under self-applied pressure; he told Tom Breihan in a Rising interview last year that the idea of creating something more tangibly coherent than his bedroom-pop collection Mess Detective was proving ""really
column8: really difficult.""

column1: Regardless of the hows and whys
column2: Other People often feels as unexpectedly rush-jobbed as its release date. Front-to-back
column3: the record feels disjointed and scattershot
column4: as the ""hits""-- namely
column5: ""Princess"" and ""Never Know""
column6: as well as Flory's exquisite Bowie-esque collaboration with the Cardigans' Nina Persson
column7: ""The Blues""-- are placed throughout the LP and tempered mostly with overcast mood pieces that verge on MOR-pop purgatory. These slower cuts sometimes work-- closing track ""Get Rope""
column8: for example-- but otherwise they interrupt any chance at an even flow. The dirge-like ""Magic"" is anything but
column9: and even a track like ""Swimming Pools""
column10: which worked on Mess Detectives and fit more to that release's bedroom aesthetic
column11: sounds quite out of place here.

column1: We may never know what the problem was with Other People
column2: but it's far from a disaster. As the title of the album's opening track suggests
column3: it's an ""A-OK"" effort
column4: and pop aesthetes will find a fair share to salvage before the whole thing disappears in a sinkhole of 1s and 0s. As ""final"" releases go
column5: though
column6: the whole thing is less of a disappearing act and more of a slow
column7: hope-nobody-notices retreat. Whatever he does next-- if we do
column8: in fact
column9: hear from him again-- well
column10:
let's just hope he's got his nerve back by then.

Fucking Queen. For all their reported bombast
column2: pomp
column3: and tendency to overshoot and double-slaughter any semblances of good taste
column4: everything you've heard about them is still true.  They're one of the few phenomena who deliver on the hype
column5: regardless of how you approach them.  Hate or love proggy album suites?  Doesn't matter
column6: Queen will make you feel good about your choice.  Can't stand operatic drama
column7: or can't get enough unitard-clad frontmen?  Love to hate prime 1970s hard rock with arena sheen?  Welcome to the greatest/most horrible band of the 20th century.  They did and wanted it all.  Yet
column8: so much of Queen's music is still under-recognized even by people who know and love the hits.

column1: Freddie Mercury (born Farrokh Bulsara on the British colony of Zanzibar
column2: East Africa)
column3: guitarist Brian May
column4: drummer Roger Taylor
column5: and bassist John Deacon comprised one of the most successful
column6: effective
column7: and productive bands of the rock era-- indeed
column8: by some estimates
column9: the most successful rock band of all time (having spent more time atop the UK album charts than any other act).  And how did they do this?  With: a gay male lead singer who specialized in operatic vocals and classically classed piano playing; an insanely talented lead guitarist who may actually have been more valuable as a songwriter or quasi-orchestral arranger of his instrument; a drummer who not only possessed the highest vocal register in the band (and this is Queen we're talking

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
about)
column2: but also arguably the greatest songwriting range; a non-singing bassist who managed to pen one of the greatest karaoke anthems of all time
column3: ""Another One Bites the Dust"".  Like the Beatles
column4: Queen capitalized on major group synergy
column5: and as a result
column6: forged a career that was as varied and resourceful as any act in rock.

column1: Queen formed in late 1970
column2: when Mercury (late of art school) joined up with May and Taylor (late of the Cream-ish band Smile).  Deacon joined the following year
column3: and the newly dubbed Queen played shows
column4: rehearsed
column5: and recorded their self-titled debut.  Though they had to wait a couple of years for a release
column6: Queen is quite clearly the work of an assured group of young men. May's album opener ""Keep Yourself Alive"" was an early anthem and showcase for his multi-tracked guitar. It didn't really have the operatic flair of the band's later hits
column7: but it was catchy
column8: well-produced
column9: and just ridiculously easy to fist-pump along to in concert.  Mercury-penned songs like ""Great King Rat"" and ""My Fairy King"" offered ample evidence where Queen's more precocious interests lie
column10: though even then
column11: the songs rocked way harder than their titles let on.  Indeed
column12: a song like ""Son and Daughter"" is like the lovechild of Black Sabbath and Ziggy Stardust
column13: taking the most potent attributes of both
column14: and refusing to tone down anything in favor of a harmonious mix. And they were just getting started.

column1: Queen II-- the first of two albums they released in 1974-- was the mini-breakthrough. Part of this was due to diving with abandon into recording experimentation
column2: particularly the elaborate vocal and guitar overdubs that would soon become the band's trademarks.  May wrote most of the music for the album's ""Side White"": the stately (if modest by Queen standards) guitar prelude ""Procession"" leads directly into the still-statelier would-be rock anthem ""Father to Son"".  Sounding like a hippie-era group sing-along crammed face-first into murky
column3: early-70s proto-metal
column4: it's another good example of Queen's penchant for at least attempting to unite disparate musical worlds-- even if the end result was more than a bit bloated.

column1: However
column2: Mercury's ""Side Black"" was the masterstroke
column3: and the first real evidence of the double-decker Fabergé egg that would become Queen's career on record.  ""Ogre Battle"" (a live holdover from the time of the first record) begins with a long
column4: ominous fade into screeching vocal harmonies and flailing
column5: backwards drums and guitars.  The song busts and tumbles its way into the ""The Fairy Feller's Master-Stroke""
column6: a dry run for the kind of music-hall rock they'd perfect with the next album's ""Killer Queen""
column7: and which should probably win a few awards as the world's most apt Queen song title.  ""Nevermore"" is a piano and vocal ballad that nicely introduces the album's central epic (and direct ""Bohemian Rhapsody"" precursor) ""The March of the Black Queen"".  And the people noticed: The album produced a UK hit with a remake of the up-tempo gallop ""Seven Seas of Rhye"" from the debut.  Dizzying
column8: overstuffed
column9: and unflinching
column10: Queen II is a die-hard fan favorite
column11: and arguably the band's most underrated record.

column1: Sheer Heart Attack (also 1974) not only improves on every aspect of their sound suggested by the first two records
column2: but delivers some of the finest music of their career.  First off
column3: the band had mastered the recording studio.  Tracks like the hit ""Killer Queen""
column4: ""In the Lap of the Gods""
column5: and the hyper-vaudeville ""Bring Back That Leroy Brown"" simply could not have appeared on previous records due to the complexity of the arrangements
column6: and the amazing job by the band and producer Roy Thomas Baker in getting umpteen dozens of overdubs and edits to sound like cohesive recordings.  And they rocked! ""Stone Cold Crazy"" predates speed-metal (and was eventually covered by Metallica)
column7: ""Brighton Rock"" was May's theretofore best guitar showcase
column8: and for heaven's sake
column9: ""In the Lap of the Gods... Revisited"" ends the album with an explosion. Even Taylor's ""Tenement Funster"" (sample lyric: ""My new purple shoes been amazing the people next door"") and Deacon's bouncy ""Misfire"" bring good things to the table.  This is the band at the height of its powers.

column1: After ""Killer Queen"" and Sheer Heart Attack
column2: there was no looking back. 1975's A Night at the Opera was reportedly the most expensive album ever produced at the time
column3: and even if the only thing you knew about it was that it contained ""Bohemian Rhapsody""
column4: you'd have a pretty good idea of the kind of record to expect.  Yet the fun hardly stopped there: ""Death on Two Legs (Dedicated to...)"" was a heavy
column5: hilarious kiss-off from Mercury to their former manager; ""Lazing on a Sunday Afternoon"" and ""Seaside Rendezvous"" were further entries into the band's vaudeville-rock canon; ""You're My Best Friend"" was Deacon's first big hit for Queen
column6: while Taylor's ""I'm in Love With My Car"" was another good
column7: slyly funny rocker.  And if you're still in need of fireworks
column8: May's ""The Prophet's Song"" features an amazing solo-through-delay vocal performance from Mercury that eventually transforms into a call-response choir
column9: and further still into one of May's best guitar solos.  No punches pulled
column10: no expense spared: A Night at the Opera was Queen at the top of the mountain.

column1: Perhaps unsurprisingly
column2: 1976's A Day at the Races feels a bit retread. Even down to its Marx Brothers-derived title
column3: the album doesn't retain the same quantum-leap progression from its predecessor as the ones had before.  Indeed ""The Millionaire Waltz"" borrows liberally from ""Bohemian Rhapsody""; classical piano playing
column4: massive vocal overdubs
column5: and a big rock breakdown-- but without much of the surprise or humor.  Rather
column6: the best tracks here are the ones where Queen is willing to go outside of their already established template: ""You Take My Breath Away"" is one of Mercury's best ballads
column7: sung without a trace of irony or camp
column8: and a good example of the band's perhaps underrated abilities as songwriters.  ""Somebody to Love"" was the record's biggest hit
column9: and positions Mercury as the gospel church soloist amidst walls of choral backdrop (i.e. him
column10: May
column11: and Taylor). Taylor's ""Drowse"" is a hazily burnt (dare I say ""chill""?) piece of psychedelia that sounds unlike anything else in Queen's catalog-- and is yet another reminder of the power in the band's democratic songwriting ethos.

column1: As much as any band
column2: Queen commands the best audio quality money can buy
column3: and these remasters sound great.  There are lots of new bonus tracks
column4: live versions
column5: and B-sides-- none of which are required listening but-- particularly in the cases of the a cappella vocal tracks for ""Bohemian Rhapsody"" and ""Bring Back That Leroy Brown""-- are good fun for fans. Furthermore
column6: the Deep Cuts: 1973-1976 disc is an admirable attempt to introduce some of Queen's non-hit album tracks to folks otherwise familiar only with the band's UK #1s (all 18 of them)-- though it contains nothing previously unreleased. Still
column7: bang for the buck has always been one of Queen's strong points: Jump in
column8: be prepared for anything
column9: and most of all
column10:
check your modesty at the door.

column1: Freddie Mercury (born Farrokh Bulsara on the British colony of Zanzibar
column2: East Africa)
column3: guitarist Brian May
column4: drummer Roger Taylor
column5: and bassist John Deacon comprised one of the most successful
column6: effective
column7: and productive bands of the rock era-- indeed
column8: by some estimates
column9: the most successful rock band of all time (having spent more time atop the UK album charts than any other act).  And how did they do this?  With: a gay male lead singer who specialized in operatic vocals and classically classed piano playing; an insanely talented lead guitarist who may actually have been more valuable as a songwriter or quasi-orchestral arranger of his instrument; a drummer who not only possessed the highest vocal register in the band (and this is Queen we're talking

about)

column1: Queen formed in late 1970
column2: when Mercury (late of art school) joined up with May and Taylor (late of the Cream-ish band Smile).  Deacon joined the following year
column3: and the newly dubbed Queen played shows
column4: rehearsed

column10: though even then

May wrote most of the music for the album's ""Side White"": the stately (if modest by Queen standards) guitar prelude ""Procession"" leads directly into the still-statelier would-be rock anthem ""Father to Son"". column4: ominous fade into screeching vocal harmonies and flailing

There are two ways to interpret the feeling that these remixes of Ellen Allien's 2010 album
column2: Dust
column3: frequently outstrip their source material. The first is that Allien's recent
column4: modest productions provide ample fodder for dance-oriented producers to work with
column5: the originals aiming at a different effect. The less charitable interpretation notes that a far-flung
column6: diverse cast of remixers had no trouble improving upon Allien's recent output. Wherever you come down
column7: there's no denying that Allien-- still a prominent Berlin artist after all these years-- has really cool friends. The cast includes dedicated techno recluses (Kassem Mosse)
column8: sound architects (Tim Hecker)
column9: genre veterans (Aux 88)
column10: and young upstarts (Nicolas Jaar
column11: We Love).

column1: Dust Remixes feels a bit like an olive branch to electronic heads
column2: as most of the material here appropriates Allien's originals in the service of Berlin-style club music
column3: even if releasing them as an album-- rather than as a series of 12""s-- throws that utility into question. Most noticably
column4: many of these remixes cultivate an air of suspense and momentum that Allien's increasingly relaxed productions lack. Where a track like ""My Tree"" moved in and out of focus on Dust
column5: here it sustains its circular drum pattern and builds into a thwumping bass sequence. There are some truly inspired moments: John Roberts unbuttons his collar on ""Should We Go Home""
column6: unleashing a spacey
column7: jazzy synth line. Heretofore disappointing BPitch artists We Love turn ""Sun the Rain"" into gauzy
column8: rocking electro. These treatments make Allien's originals seem quiet and reserved in comparison
column9: even if they didn't need much help seeming that way.

column1: Arguably the two largest names here
column2: Jaar and Hecker
column3: make a different kind of sense
column4: as both have participated in the techno deconstructions to which Allien seems increasingly drawn. Jaar's track
column5: more a cover version than a remix and one unable to imbue any tunefulness into Dust's worst track
column6: is one of his least inspired productions. Hecker sounds like Hecker
column7: natch. Mosse's remix of ""Our Utopie""-- which sees him just taking the best
column8: clubbiest section of the song and playing it for a long time-- is as lazy as it is funny.

column1: I enjoyed Dust because it was a considered
column2: veteran move that felt comfortable in its own skin (sometimes overly so)
column3: but I can't get away from the feeling that Allien is getting outhustled more often than not. Remixes ultimately isn't a great listen-- Dust hardly merited this sort of concentrated rethinking-- but its highs are significantly higher than those of Dust
column4:
and it confirms both how closely Allien remains tied to her techno roots as well as how curiously off-center her work has been.

New York-based producer FaltyDL (Drew Lustman) is one of the most prominent American artists working within the boundaries of the UK bass scene. Lustman is a stylistic nomad
column2: but he rarely settles on just one scene or sound. While genre wonks will have no trouble cherrypicking the elements of Lustman's sound-- drum & bass
column3: dubstep
column4: deep house
column5: UK garage-- it's difficult to determine what basket any individual moment falls into. You Stand Uncertain is that rare album whose influences seem obvious and simultaneously difficult to pin down on any one given track.

column1: The effect is sometimes schizophrenic: the best track on Uncertain is the last one
column2: ""Waited Patiently"". It features an otherworldly low-end
column3: jazzy piano chords
column4: ratcheted
column5: clacking snares
column6: sampled soul vocals
column7: and Lily McKenzie's decidedly more modern R&B croon. In other words
column8: it's genre signifier on top of genre signifier. All of this speaks to an urge to definitively label something that is neither necessary nor particularly healthy. But I would like to convey that Uncertain is both familiar and frustrating
column9: possibly because Lustman's imagination sometimes outstrips his range
column10: possibly because he so ably incorporates these sounds but owns them only infrequently.

column1: Lustman's drums remain at the core of his sound; they are usually quick
column2: often syncopated. They patter shallowly
column3: never reaching down to punch you in the ribs. When this is paired with a female voice-- a frequent counterpoint for Lustman-- it effects a harsh
column4: sour R&B sound that can be both exciting and off-putting. I love the pacing of ""Brazil""
column5: and I can lose myself in its patient urban blues
column6: but the coiled
column7: digitized diva blurts that punctuate the track snap me back to reality.

column1: He seems in better control of these elements on Uncertain than he did on 2009's Love Is a Liability
column2: pairing his percussion with richer keyboards amidst grander track design. (That the art of both albums features noir-y female snaps
column3: with Uncertain's color standing in contrast to Love's black and white
column4: is likely a happy coincidence.) Uncertain is idiosyncratic-- the geeky sci-fi splash of ""The Pacifist""
column5: the wa-wa jazz of ""Eight Eighteen Ten""-- in ways that Love never was. Lustman is still searching for a unique personality
column6: but he seems more assured and focused here than on previous releases.

column1: You Stand Uncertain is just too perfect a title for this album. It feels fresh and invigorated when it's spinning
column2: reassuringly foreboding like a cinematic thriller playing to script. Afterwards I remember very little. There isn't a single track here that could feature in a mix or a DJ set. Lustman's clacking
column3: clacking
column4: clacking snares are the closest thing he has to a calling card. The album as a whole isn't quite able to leverage that into a recognizable aesthetic
column5:
but it comes tantalizingly close.

Chillwave might already be remembered as a flash-in-the-pan brainchild of a bunch of stoners with too much free time on their hands
column3: but the concept behind the music was actually pretty good: draw all the warmth from faintly remembered songs
column4: and then flip it into something fresh. Unfortunately
column5: very few artists were able to actually get it together enough to make that concept a reality
column6: and most of it just sounded kind of watery and half-assed. Hard Mix
column7: aka the South Carolina-based Noah Smith
column8: released the appropriately titled single ""Memories"" in July
column9: as chillwave was gasping its last breath. But instead of emulating what came before
column10: he made good on the genre's promise
column11: finding a direction in a fuzzy
column12: kind-hearted pulse and confident
column13: direct drums.

column1: Defaults
column2: the debut LP from Smith
column3: was recently released for free online to little fanfare. Which is too bad
column4: because it's a smart
column5: modest record that reveals itself only on repeated listens. ""Memories"" is still the centerpiece
column6: and its vocal hiccups repeat themselves throughout the record. At points
column7: though
column8: this becomes repetitive. ""I'm Gone"" immediately follows ""Memories"" and they may as well be one extended track. In more experienced hands
column9: this could be a good thing: repetition and multiple movements with slight variations are the building blocks of great dance music
column10: but the details are lost here. ""Memories"" worked so well on its own
column11: there's no need to expand on its basic premise.

column1: In retrospect
column2: the decision to give Defaults away for free online both helps and hurts the record. It's clearly a work that Smith labored over
column3: but also one that doesn't show his full potential. It's immediately marginalized by its sanctioned accessibility
column4: and could very well go unnoticed. However
column5: Hard Mix is still a new artist with a ways to go before he's able to transition from the world of flash-in-the-pan blog hype to something more. By continuing to do what the rest of the scene around him failed to do
column6: he has a chance to transcend being pigeonholed and shift into a whole new space where being innovative doesn't necessarily mean pushing boundaries. If the bright moments on Defaults say anything
column7:
it's that Hard Mix has it in him to make a dance record worth reminiscing about.

The book isn't closed yet on Pharoahe Monch

And despite the huge hitch in his career arc-- eight years between his 1999 solo debut Internal Affairs and his excellent 2007 comeback Desire-- he always seemed like each dispatch from the studio could erase the aftereffects of his protracted absence.

column1: But name me one MC

There's still bursts of press-rewind brilliance-- ""Haile Selassie Karate"" is a condensed dose of high-density abstraction

In five seasons on Adult Swim and a handful of specials and live concert tours
column2: ""Tim and Eric Awesome Show
column3: Great Job!"" has established itself as one of the most aggressively strange programs in the history of television as well as one of the finest sources for oddball novelty music. Among the show's musical highlights include the cheeseball rock tunes of Pusswhip Banggang
column4: the alarmingly cheerful ""All the Food Is Poison""

column7: Tim Heidecker
column8: Eric Wareheim
column9: and their composer Davin Wood display a jingle writer's knack for melody
column10: packing absurd humor into compact
column11: ruthlessly effective hooks.

column1: Starting From Nowhere

column3: takes their musical collaboration in a different direction. Heidecker's deep fascination with tacky 1970s and 80s aesthetics is foregrounded in a set of songs that strive to evoke the sound and feeling of vintage soft rock
column4: but the comedy is dialed down considerably
column5: to the point that many of the tracks barely register as comedy.

column1: For example
column2: the opening track ""Cross Country Skiing"" is such a close approximation of earnest
column3: gently harmonized folk pop that if it appeared on a new Fleet Foxes record
column4: you would just take it as a given that Robin Pecknold enjoys winter sports. Other tracks are spot-on pastiches of Steely Dan
column5: the Doobie Brothers
column6: Jackson Browne
column7: and the Eagles. The lyrics are often ridiculous
column8: but even the silliest moments could pass as sincere if you didn't know anything about Heidecker's comedy career. If there is a joke here
column9: it's that this music sounds like what it sounds like.

column1: The thing is
column2: all of the songs on Starting From Nowhere are written and executed with far too much precision and care to come off like a shallow mockery of soft rock. (Like
column3: say
column4: Yacht Rock.) Heidecker and Wood may be connoisseurs of kitsch
column5: but they obviously love this music. The sophistication and detail on display here is rather stunning; you just can't arrive at pastiche with this kind of accuracy without genuine obsession.

column1: But without funny jokes
column2: what exactly is the point of this album? Cut-out bins around the world overflow with music that sounds exactly like the contents of Starting From Nowhere. Indie bands such as Belle & Sebastian and Destroyer filter these sounds through the sensibilities of distinct
column3: modern songwriters. Wood may nail the aesthetics of a particular era
column4: but that high level of competency isn't the same thing as writing great songs. This is ultimately mediocre music that sometimes recalls the sound and feeling of excellent music
column5: and the only thing that Heidecker brings to the table is a smirking irony that is not particularly appealing when separated from hilarious comedy. If you genuinely want to listen to this kind of music

column7: investigate Steely Dan's back catalog-- their slick
column8: jazz-influenced rock has a darker
column9: dryer wit than anything Heidecker can manage on this album.) If you want excellent novelty pop
column10: cross your fingers for another season of ""Tim and Eric Awesome Show
column11:
Great Job!""

Baby Dee is what you might call a late bloomer. When she released her first LP
column2: Little Window
column3: she was already in her late forties
column4: and her biography read like a Tom Waits song. According to a story she told NPR
column5: she fell in love with the harp at age four after discovering the one inside an upright piano during a neighborhood piano-smashing party. Later
column6: she often played harp in Central Park while wearing a bear costume. She had stints as a church organist and a Coney Island sideshow. Her music is an equally paradoxical blend of spiritual uplift and tin-megaphone banter.

column1: The transition from street artist to professional has been gradual. By 2008's Safe Inside the Day
column2: she'd learned how to make a commercial album
column3: and her signature harp and accordion gave way to grand piano-- a more typical and versatile foundation. With her remarkable life experience now paired with recording practice
column4: Baby Dee has made her best album yet just a couple of years shy of her 60th birthday. Idiosyncratic but ruggedly classic
column5: Regifted Light is old-fashioned art music with a sheen of downtown grit. Dee caresses and pounds producer Andrew WK's Steinway D to life with the lyrical bluster of Gershwin and the nimble thematic development of Sondheim. It's a welcome change of pace from the post-minimalism that's rampant in indie piano music.

column1: Opening instrumental ""Cowboys With Cowboy Hat Hair"" establishes the album's harmonic environment
column2: making this more of a song cycle than a collection of individual pieces. Over martial snares
column3: Dee works a theme from the C Minor scale-- light on the sharps as to lean it toward bright C Major-- up and down the keyboard. The theme rolls back and forth on itself and fractures across different octaves in odd places so that lone high notes ring out ornamentally. Regifted Light never strays too far from this tonal vicinity
column4: which creates a unified wistfulness that Dee articulates in every shade from happy to sad. The diversity arises from Dee's inspired handling of the shallow pool of intervals-- you never know which way the themes will veer next
column5: into upper-register dances or lower-register thunder-- and is abetted by conversational accompaniment for bassoon
column6: cello
column7: and glockenspiel.

column1: Dee has an incredible voice that has drawn unavoidable comparisons to Antony Hegarty's. In fact
column2: it is more unusual than Antony's
column3: and more inclined toward musical theater. A little of it goes a long way
column4: which is why it works so well appearing on just four of the 12 songs here. The scarcity gives it an outsized
column5: mythic quality. Dee suddenly appears
column6: utters wisdom or metaphysical fables
column7: and vanishes into the music again. Within a single line
column8: her voice flickers through not just different emotions
column9: but personalities.

column1: ""The moon is my redeemer/ The moon is my befriending Jesus
column2: Dee drawls on the title track
column3: merging pagan and monotheistic traditions into a sense of human tenderness that overarches eons. The notion that with each ""regifting"" of the light
column4: its ""gentleness increases"" could sound forced and trite in a different context
column5: but in Dee's hands it feels at-ease and hard-won. ""Brother Slug and Sister Snail"" is a Joanna Newsom-like animal allegory where Jesus sings from the cross
column6: ""I am a worm and not... a... MAN!"" But nobody hears him. The narrative topology is strange
column7: but not for strangeness' sake: The elegant music bends it toward profundity.

column1: Baby Dee tends to get written about with words like ""flamboyant"" and ""campy
column2: and ""The Pie Song"" demonstrates why: Dee bashes out mad-composer chords while demanding pie with the indefinable undercurrent of menace minted by the Frogs. While ""The Pie Song"" is not representative of Regifted Light
column3: those who want to hear the album as camp will do so
column4: despite the fact that Dee's theatrics have been scaled back
column5: and at any rate are not campy but piercingly sincere. The camp pigeonhole is always difficult for transgender artists to avoid in the mainstream. But Dee is simply a musician making very earnest art about a very unusual life. Regifted Light doesn't seem built to shock or cajole
column6: but to connect with all sorts of people
column7:
and to last.

column4: Love

column1: Unfortunately
column2: the group's other attempts to unabashedly rock out on Space on Tuesday aren't quite as successful. There's a haughty self-importance that seems to infect Leika whenever they decide to make with any sort of overt rock-like maneuvers. These grand gestures come in two flavors: Either there's

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>

column3: either the music exchanges its energetic and joyous swagger for a numbing stiffness (as on ""Fake Mission to Mars"")
column4: or the need to say big important things via AABB rhyme schemes trumps the need to make a song enjoyable. (The hyper-earnest babble on ""Shrunken Heads"" is the main offender there.) And then there is ""Sitting Pretty""

column6: the album actually alternates between these two types of songs
column7: as if a shameless fun-loving Jekyll is forced to ground by a portentously pompous Hyde.  I don't doubt that
column8: if given a chance

column10: as Space on Tuesday shows time and again
column11:
there's work to do before that can happen.

column7: the foundational tracks sound golden in mp3 or vinyl format. The latter is pure pop and pure Lowe
column8: a typically self-deprecating gem whose vocal hook is inescapable. Even more satisfying is ""American Squirm""

column1: Both lyrically and sonically
