It seems absurd to say that Tower Recordings got shafted when indie-folk rose to prominence in the 2000s. After all
column2: the Wire article that gave the movement one of its names-- ""New Weird America""-- was centered on the Brattleboro Free Folk Festival that Tower helped run. And the band ended shortly after
column3: so anyone just starting to notice had nothing new to tout. Still
column4: as New Weird America morphed into freak-folk and people like Devendra Banhart and Joanna Newsom got more attention
column5: talk of Tower Recordings seemed too rare given their influence and significance.

column1: No need to feel bad for them
column2: though-- it's doubtful that they cared much about fame
column3: and besides
column4: band members have been too busy with subsequent projects to worry about it. The wandering journeys of Matt Valentine and Erika Elder (aka MV & EE)
column5: the reverent folk of Patrick Gubler (aka P.G. Six)
column6: and the haunting pop of Samara Lubelski have all expanded the Tower sound
column7: showing how inimitable and durable it is. Maybe people were hesitant to compare Tower to their descendants out of respect.

column1: The growth continues with Metal Mountains
column2: which includes Gubler and Lubelski but is led by Helen Rush in her first significant musical activity since Tower dissolved. Given a chance to stretch her mesmerizing voice across half an hour of material
column3: she guides the music like a soft wind swirling a cloud. Every sound echoes
column4: reverberates
column5: and lingers
column6: making Golden Trees practically nothing but atmosphere. Sometimes the original sonic events that begin each tune-- Rush's gentle hums
column7: Gubler's guitar plucks
column8: Lubelski's violin tones-- are distant memories by the end.

column1: Because of this amorphous feel
column2: Golden Trees evokes some music outside of the Tower universe. A natural comparison is the Velvet Underground's self-titled 1969 LP
column3: whose patient reverence is shared by Metal Mountains' gradual development. Additionally
column4: the band's drone-leanings recall recent Finnish avant-folk
column5: particularly the engrossing hymns of Lau Nau. What's unique about Metal Mountains is the indelible ambiance surrounding these traits. There's such consistency here
column6: it's hard to imagine any single sound without the others.

column1: In fact
column2: you might find Golden Trees too consistent. Without percussion to emphasize pace
column3: each tune has a similar
column4: indefinite tempo. Time gets lost
column5: and tracks drift and hang rather than moving forward. As the tracks melt together
column6: you might swear the guitar part or vocal line you're hearing has happened before. But for me
column7:
such recurrences are what give Golden Trees its peculiar magic. Its cycling sounds and moods feel less like repetitions than dreamy déjà vu.

The last time we saw the Strokes in a music video they were dead. In the visual for 2006's ""You Only Live Once""
column2: the quintet wore all white  while dark liquid filled the room
column3: leaving them drowned and floating.  And if that really had marked the end of the band
column4: few would've been  surprised. Their third album
column5: First Impressions of Earth
column6: had  them limping
column7: desperately trying to expand the signature sound that  looked to be swallowing them up like so much black water. It didn't  work. And the Strokes are too cool and too smart to become one of those  bands that puts out a record every few years just so fans can sing the  oldies back to them
column8: right? So they went away-- to an array of  lackluster side projects
column9: to families
column10: to anywhere but the Strokes.

column1: As late as November 2009
column2: Julian Casablancas was non-committal on the  subject of a fourth Strokes album. ""We've been trying to do it for  years
column3: he said. ""I'm always available and they know that but getting  together is tough."" Guitarist Nick Valensi went  even further: ""I'm not even sure we're going to make a fourth album at  this point."" But still
column4: here we are with Angles
column5: not a roaring comeback as much as a glorified spit-balling session.

column1: The album attempts to rebuild the band from the ground up. Whereas Casablancas had previously written nearly every part of the group's songs including guitar solos and basslines
column2: he steps back on Angles
column3: which features songs from other members. And this revised process is  evident in the credits: ""All Music Written and Arranged by the  Strokes."" Casablancas called the new way ""Operation Make Everyone  Satisfied
column4: which sounds condescending enough. And while the more  democratic move may seem generous
column5: the singer threw his clout around by separating himself from the rest of the recording process and sending his vocals to the band via electronic files. And the album's oddly collaborative origins are evidenced in both its scatter-shot diversity and its lurching fragmentation.

column1: With its sprightly
column2: dueling fret  work and familiar
column3: cascading chorus
column4: first single ""Under Cover of  Darkness"" hinted that the Strokes had come to terms with being the  Strokes-- after dalliances with other styles and sounds
column5: they seemed  content with a revival in their own image. But
column6: for better and (mostly)  worse
column7: that is not the case. Though this band was routinely slapped with  claims of 1970s plagiarism upon their arrival
column8: it's unlikely that many people have ever mistaken a Strokes song for one by Lou Reed or Television. So it's ironic that their mimicry can be uncanny on Angles. But traces of scummy CBGB punk are sometimes replaced with big-snare 1980s flash. ""Two Kinds of Happiness"" pilfers one-time tour mate Tom Petty for the palm-muted and hiccup-phrased verse before ramping things up in a whooshing vintage-U2 hook. And ""Games"" is another 80s throwback
column9: utilizing crystalline synths and distant hand claps to help prove its dour and strained point about ""living in an empty world."" Opener ""Machu Picchu"" recalls ""Down Under"" dudes Men at Work. These are not the expected influences for a Strokes album.

column1: Which would be fine-- great
column2: even-- if they were carried through with anything  resembling charm or commitment. Throughout
column3: the album is hobbled by  disconnections-- between verse and chorus
column4: lyrics and music
column5: intent and  execution. Casablancas' ambivalence about his own actions crops up  often. On the ugly prog wannabe ""Metabolism"" he declares
column6: ""I wanna be  outrageous/ But inside I know I'm plain."" Disjointed closer ""Life Is  Simple in the Moonlight"" has him confessing
column7: ""There's no one I  disapprove of or root for more for than myself."" And while the singer's  singed self-loathing was present in the Strokes from the beginning
column8: it  was always tempered with music that provided some uplift. But on the  sad-eyed and drum-less ""Call Me Back""
column9: he's left to moan about how ""no  one has the time
column10: someone's always late"" against a single guitar and  ethereal keyboard. Listening to the track
column11: it's pretty easy to see why people may not be returning his calls.

column1: Yet there are still those moments when you remember why it's a good thing that these five guys stayed together. The beatific ""Gratisfaction"" is so easy-going and straightforward in its Thin Lizzy-meets-Billy Joel strut that it immediately rushes past nearly every other song here in the race for greatest hits-dom. Even better is ""Taken For a Fool""
column2: which is the only track on Angles to really offer something refreshing while also sticking with That Strokes Sound. The song's verse is air-tight and bizarrely funky like some lost tape from David Bowie's Lodger
column3: while the  hook relieves the syncopation with to-the-point brashness. Talking about  his general sonic goals in 2009
column4: Casablancas said
column5: ""The ideal for me is  to get really out there but have it go full circle and sound pretty  normal."" It's a worthwhile aim
column6: and ""Taken For a Fool"" nails it.

column1: As news about the Strokes' shaky resurgence has continued to flow over the last few months
column2: two of the group's contemporaries chose to bow out.  The White Stripes-- who faced off against the Strokes in a friendly  Coolest Band Alive competition for a few years in the early aughts--  officially broke up after a hiatus on February 2 in order to ""preserve  what is beautiful and special about the band and have it stay that way.""  Meanwhile
column3: fellow wry New Yorkers LCD Soundsystem will wrap up their  run April 2 at Madison Square Garden. As it happens
column4:
that's just one day after the Strokes will play the same venue to kick-start their second life. Everybody wants to quit while they're ahead. Some actually do it.

David Kennedy is the kind of electronic artist that drives casual fans crazy. He performs and/or produces under three different names (his own and the two attached to this mix); he has a boatload of singles under a cast of genre banners; he's behind one of UK bass' most consistently rewarding labels
column2: Hessle Audio; and he has never released a full-length album. Following him to date has required the type of dedication that
column3: unfortunately
column4: too often deters people from electronic music fandom. Far from obscure
column5: though
column6: Kennedy is a hotly tipped wunderkind
column7: prominent enough that electronic-focused site Little White Earbuds named him the defining artist of 2010. This is how an artist that many people have never heard of ends up helming not just the next installment of the popular FabricLive series
column8: but a highly anticipated installment.

column1: At his core
column2: Kennedy is a relentless style maven
column3: a forward-looking producer and DJ whose curiosity and appetite for the new and regional can make him seem skittish
column4: even standoffish. (To wit: he often gets credit for being one of the first European DJs to adopt the Footwork sound
column5: and its brash repetition suits him perfectly.) He deals in a stridently rhythmic brand of techno
column6: borrowing the syncopation of dubstep
column7: but with amped-up tempos and elements of reggae
column8: UK funky
column9: drum & bass
column10: and Detroit techno stirred in.  The pileup of styles gives Kennedy's music and mixes a casually aggressive tone; he's not actively trying to batter your sensibilities
column11: but he doesn't care if he does. Remember when suburban skateboarders began listening to Wu-Tang instead of NOFX? Kennedy's cuts have that sort of edgy
column12: athletic bend to them.

column1: FabricLive 56 represents a chance for Kennedy to display his voracious appetite at work. He wastes no time
column2: racing into 56 with his own
column3: ominous ""Hawker"" before cutting into a slice of the notoriously icy Berghain sound from Leon Vincent. It feels... a little unfriendly
column4: to be honest. Kennedy's quick cuts-- the mix touches on fully 30 tracks-- sometimes feel like they're in the service of his waning attention
column5: rather than the listener or the track.

column1: The payoff for this thrill-seeking is the same sense of energy and quick momentum that Kennedy instills in his productions. And for all his new-school ethos and exploration
column2: Kennedy has a healthy dose of ""classic DJ"" in him: FabricLive 56 isn't merely a sequenced
column3: curated set of tracks with transitions. He frequently lays the tracks on top of one other
column4: letting elements of each bustle against each other. Toward the end of the mix
column5: Kennedy has settled into some more recognizable tracks-- Burial's ""Pirates""
column6: Girl Unit's ""IRL""
column7: Addison Groove's ""Fuk tha 101""-- but he takes ownership of them. At one point he lays the Eastern reeds from Pinch's ""Qawwali"" under MJ Cole and Wiley's ""From the Drop""
column8: creating dubby
column9: tense trip-hop. There is a sense of history
column10: too
column11: of Chicago house (the up-with-dancing mantras of Julio Bashmore's ""Battle for Middle You"")
column12: of German minimal
column13: and of the type of dubstep he and his peers have obviously moved on from.

column1: This makes sense: Kennedy hails from a scene of artists who are redeploying classic tools-- 808s
column3: simple sampling-- in the service of ""new"" dance music. The novelty of this music-- and it does feel novel-- lies in its aggressive technique more than its sound design or genre signifiers. He caters to that aggression throughout FabricLive 56 without ever losing sight of his responsibilities as a DJ. Waiting for a statement release from an artist with this mindset may be futile
column4:
so let's instead consider FabricLive 56 a snapshot of Kennedy's current fetishes; expect it to date quickly.

Simon & Garfunkel's 1970 swan song
column2: Bridge Over Troubled Water
column3: was both their most effortless record and their most ambitious. The duo spent most of the 1960s as a highly regarded folk act distinguished by their intuitive harmonies and Paul Simon's articulate songwriting
column4: yet compared to the Greenwich Village revivalists
column5: whom they tried to emulate on songs like ""A Simple Desultory Philippic"" and ""Bleecker Street""
column6: they were pretty square. By Bookends in 1968
column7: they were settling into themselves
column8: losing their folk revival pretensions and emphasizing quirky production techniques to match their soaring vocals. Two years later
column9: Bridge did that album one better by revealing a voracious musical vocabulary that spanned gospel
column10: rock
column11: R&B
column12: and even classical. As this thoughtful reissue attests
column13: the album sounds unique even 40 years later
column14: driven and defined entirely by their own personal musical and political obsessions.

column1: This diverse album contains the roots of Paul Simon's subsequent incorporation of African and South American rhythms into astute pop songs
column2: especially ""El Condor Pasa (If I Could)"". The tune is hundreds of years old
column3: but Simon came to it via a contemporary Peruvian group called Los Incas. He wrote new English lyrics about the rural versus the urban
column4: and he and Garfunkel sang them over the original instrumental track. Especially coming after the grandiose gospel of the title track
column5: the song sounds both exotic and humble. Later
column6: ""Keep the Customer Satisfied"" swells with gargantuan blasts of brass
column7: ""Baby Driver"" revs up some R&B sax
column8: and ""Cecilia"" sounds impossibly infectious with its pennywhistle solo and handclap/thighslap percussion. Despite the breadth of sound-- and despite the splintering of their relationship-- Bridge sounds like a unified statement enlivened by styles and rhythms not often heard on pop radio at the juncture of those two decades.

column1: The album cuts on Bridge hold up arguably better than the singles-- or maybe it's just that we've all heard the title track and side-two opener ""The Boxer"" so many times
column2: while songs like ""Keep the Customer Satisfied"" and ""Baby Driver"" still sound less familiar
column3: and therefore full of surprises. Especially on this subtle remastering
column4: Bridge reveals a surfeit of strange
column5: exciting sonic details
column6: as Simon
column7: Garfunkel
column8: and co-producer Roy Halee insert small flourishes of sound
column9: such as the disruptive skiffle beat on ""Why Don't You Write Me"" or the audience rhythm section on the live version of ""Bye Bye Love"". The title track derives its outsize drama not only from Garfunkel's intense
column10: measured vocals but also from the resonating percussion
column11: which mimics the echoing crack of sound against a cathedral wall. Thanks to the echo-chambered vocals
column12: disembodied organ
column13: and Joe Osborn's melodically prominent bass
column14: ""The Only Living Boy in New York"" sounds practically weightless
column15: as if Manhattan were as lonely and desolate as the moon. Even after it's been Zach Braff'ed
column16: the song still retains its considerable evocative power and remains one of the most natural and surprising juxtapositions of sonics and sentiment in Simon's catalog.

column1: ""The Only Living Boy in New York"" conjures a very specific sense of melancholy abandonment
column2: which makes it a companion to the title track's pledge of steady friendship and devotion. In some ways
column3: Bridge sounds like a chronicle of Simon and Garfunkel's career and collaboration over the years
column4: especially the album-ending send-off. The live ""Bye Bye Love"" reveals a greater kinship with the Everly Brothers than with Dylan
column5: and an even stronger engagement with their audience; clapping a massive backbeat and yelling along with the song
column6: that rambunctious crowd in Ames
column7: Iowa
column8: remains one of their most intuitive collaborators. As the noise dies down
column9: the quiet ""Song for the Asking"" adds a brief epilogue that reveals their simple mission ""to make you smile."" It's a modest close to both the album and the musical collaboration between these two old friends.

column1: Instead of non-album cuts from those same sessions (some of which have been compiled previously)
column2: this edition adds a DVD with a television special from 1969 and a new making-of
column3: which emphasize the duo's social awareness and sonic innovations
column4: respectively. Directed by Garfunkel's Catch-22 co-star Charles Grodin and airing on CBS in 1969
column5: ""Songs of America"" mixes live footage with political rallies and American landscapes
column6: depicting Bridge as a response to the heavily politicized turmoil of the preceding decade. Simon & Garfunkel ponder the ramifications of Vietnam and Woodstock
column7: MLK and RFK
column8: Cesar Chavez and the Poor People's March. At that time such political images were extremely controversial
column9: especially coming from such seemingly nonthreatening folkies as Simon & Garfunkel
column10: and the show was a commercial failure
column11: beaten in the ratings by a Peggy Fleming ice-skating special. But today it plays as a highly instructive time capsule
column12: offering entrée into that era and a valuable glimpse at the duo's chemistry while hinting at their conflicts.

column1: This edition presents Bridge as an end-of-an-era document
column2: that era being both the 1960s and their career together. Instead of acrimony
column3: however
column4: we get devotion and bonhomie
column5: as Simon gives Garfunkel good songs to sing and Garfunkel sings them so well. Perhaps because it never addresses their restlessness or any particular social issue too directly
column6: the album proves both visionary and revisionary
column7: as the two ponder both their own and their country's past while looking ahead to new musical adventures. That Simon & Garfunkel split up shortly after recording this album only makes the sentiments more fleeting and the songs more affecting
column8:
lending them a timeless quality that transcends genre and generation.

If you want to keep things simple
column2: Helioscope
column3: the second album from  Leeds quintet Vessels
column4: should be filed in the post-rock section along with Mogwai and Godspeed You! Black Emperor. If you want to be accurate
column5: however
column6: then there's some explaining to do. Vessels are fond of the stirring (and often unsubtle) dynamic shifts that the aforementioned groups pioneered
column7: but their bombing runs aren't deployed in quite the same manner. While their quieter moments sometimes center around gently plucked guitar figures
column8: they can just as often involve other sounds and textures. Helioscope also proves Vessels capable of crunching numbers as efficiently as the most studious math-rockers. And while using vocals doesn't automatically make one's post-rock less post-y
column9: Vessels' infrequent (though effective) use of them is just another weapon in their well-stocked arsenal.

column1: It takes a little while for Helioscope to show its cards
column2: though. Based solely on the first few minutes of ""Monoform""
column3: Vessels would seem like another perfectly OK instrumental rock group. The arpeggiating synth and nimble
column4: insistent drumming bring to mind recent Maserati or older Trans Am
column5: and the switch of focus from the heavy bass tones to a rolling xylophone in the second ""verse"" is a nice twist. As the song progresses
column6: however
column7: it becomes clear that Vessels are more interested in taking a road less traveled
column8: opting to eschew the expected crescendo for some scenic meandering. It's only after mucking around for about three minutes-- including a minute-long segue into what seems like a different song altogether-- that they decide to pump up the volume and blow out the speakers. Delaying the presumably inevitable climax allows that pro-forma soft-to-loud move to actually surprise
column9: which is an achievement in itself.

column1: Thankfully
column2: Helioscope offers plenty of pleasant surprises. Vessels can switch from constructing limber instrumentals around pleasantly warped guitar samples (""Later Than You Think"") to a track like ""Art/Choke""

column7: Piano Tuner
column8: Prostitute""
column9: with the gentle quaver of Brighton-based singer-songwriter Stuart Warwick at the mic. The end result of that collaboration is a shimmering tune that gives Elbow a run for their post-Radiohead money. Even when Helioscope offers a more traditionally post-rock track

column11:
Vessels' way with arrangements and sonics produces something refreshingly out of the ordinary.

As a member of pioneering minimal/dub/techno outfits Basic Channel and Rhythm & Sound
column2: Moritz Von Oswald has spent more than a decade imbuing machine music with human warmth. More recently
column3: he's doing the opposite-- making warm bodies sound like machines.

column1: Moritz Von Oswald Trio is his group of living
column2: breathing musicians-- an all-star ensemble that also includes Max Loderbauer (NSI
column3: Sun Electric) and percussionist Sasu Ripatti (Vladislav Delay). It's a unique concept: a live band that performs minimalist dance music-- well dressed
column4: clean-shaven
column5: and ready to jam.

column1: Horizontal Structures is the group's second studio LP
column2: following a debut
column3: Vertical Ascent
column4: and a live album recorded during an appearance at New York's Le Poisson Rouge. As with the trio's previous output
column5: the compositions on Horizontal Structures are entirely improvised. The record's four long
column6: languid tracks all stretch more than 10 minutes. But the group uses that freedom sparingly. The music has no solos and no dramatic shifts in tempo. A steady pulse-- typically a drum machine or sequenced pattern-- is introduced
column7: then embellished upon using live instrumentation and effects. It's tonal
column8: but never directly melodic. In fact
column9: individual expression of any sort is extraordinarily disciplined-- limited to modest knob tweaks and percussion fills. Like Von Oswald's work with Basic Channel and Rhythm & Sound
column10: the music makes heavy use of extended repetition. The tracks may be jammed out on the fly
column11: but the results are tightly governed by the trio's shared affinity for minimalism.

column1: But reserved and mechanical as it is
column2: Horizontal Structures is a very warm record. Von Oswald and his regulars soak the music in reverb and atmosphere. This time around
column3: additional musicians augment the trio-- Paul St. Hilaire (aka Tikiman) on guitar and Marc Muellbauer on double bass. Both toss a few swatches of dubby riffage and jazzy rumbling into the mix
column4: as on ""Structure 2""
column5: which pours glassy drones atop a percussive sequencer pattern and Rhodes piano tinkles. The mood is similar to electric-era Miles Davis
column6: minus the fury. ""Structure 3"" and ""Structure 4"" make use of more traditional dub-techno elements-- burbling echo
column7: reverb spikes
column8: and phased hi-hat chatter-- but keep the pulse relaxed. ""Structure 1"" is an anomaly-- a loose
column9: surprisingly abstract meditation that only gradually congeals into a rhythmic form. Though it's music is deeply informed by the club
column10: Moritz Von Oswald Trio steers clear of hard kicks and bass. Where most live bands strive to deliver physical intensity
column11: these guys headed down a different
column12:
more zoned-out path.

Although it still has pretty amazing cachet
column2: I bet most electronic music nerds would agree that Kompakt's facing a tough brief as it powers through its second decade as a label. For starters

column4: the Knife

column3: the music so artfully spiky

column2: Indian
column3: and Caribbean rhythms

column5: there's  very little touch on display here; most of the tracks are blunt instruments  that feel like they were composed in two stages-- the complicated but  occasionally unfocused production first
column6: the aimless caterwauling later. I listened  to this record about 15 times and still had trouble retaining any of it

column10: icy synths
column11: bongo drums
column12: and some fun-fair-haunted-house-ready chanting.  It may not work as a song

but that's a long way from feeling it.

""Not every new bass-music record has to be a huge sea change

column4: Mosaik

column7: purplish bounces and metallic swirls on ""Feromonikon""
column8: voluptuous Applescal-like synth matrices on the title track

column10: while listening to it

column1: With a decade's worth of singles and remixes already in the can
column2: Siriusmo is no newcomer

column4: and then reconstitutes itself as a dance track around this new axis. The way Siriusmo clips and bends his tones helps him to reconcile such extremes into coherent songs; he has the skills to realize anything in his prodigious imagination. And for all of his technical ability
column5: his imagination is the star here. A former keyboardist in a 1970s-style funk band
column6: Siriusmo brings a hot and jammy sensibility to his productions. While many could rock a dance floor
column7: the concise lengths and jocular set-pieces give you a hint as to Siriusmo's true ambition: to make a pop long-player rather than a collection of singles.

column1: This dude is quite the showman. At the beginning of ""High Together""
column2: warm-up keyboard vamps are met with sampled audience applause that gradually gives way to boos. Both responses being equally disproportionate to the little keyboard squiggles
column3: there seems to be a joke here about electronic music taking itself too seriously; a crime of which Siriusmo cannot be accused. ""Call Me"" is 51 seconds of vintage boom-bap with wobbly phone-ringing samples. There are wacky vocal monologues
column4: cartoonish sound effects
column5: and cool voices intoning Siriusmo's name with a hint of irony. His music can feel like hotness and a loving satire of hotness simultaneously. But all this personality serves to make the record cohesive. When the electro-pop of ""Einmal In Der Woche Schreien"" pivots into the glassy funk of ""Good Idea"" with a perfectly-placed whistle
column6: you know you're hearing something that wants to be more than the sum of its parts.

column1: Siriusmo succeeds admirably in this goal
column2: most of the time: The diversity is coherent and the gags elicit smiles. His almost hammy sensibility is winning
column3: paired with his obvious awareness of its potential to bog down the sheer musicality of Mosaik. But things finally start to unravel a bit in the home stretch
column4: as Siriusmo's zany notions start to get the better of his taste. ""Peeved"" gives us something like a cut-and-paste Captain Beefheart and works about as well in context as you'd imagine

column7:
especially when they result from an adventurous sensibility that makes all the high points possible.

column4: their first release since Long's departure
column5: remaining members Daniel Martin-McCormick and Damon Palermo have abandoned guitars and drums and with them the dubby post-punk alchemy of earlier efforts. In their place are a series of aqueous electronic discoscapes that are are every bit as confrontational. And what this release lacks in hooks or noisy cross-pollinating
column6: it makes up for in continuity. Whether it's the mania of Martin-McCormick's vocals or commitment to head-hitting
column7: rhythmic expanse
column8: it's still obvious that you're listening to Mi Ami.

column1: It's not only made clear by Martin-McCormick's distinct
column2: flailing vocal work. At four songs in just over 30 minutes
column3: Mi Ami are still as economical as they were when wielding guitars-- as many ideas are at play
column4: you never get the sense that anything has been shoehorned into any given portion of a song. In fact
column5: by virtue of their sonics
column6: this is a far sparer and roomier affair than anything else they've crafted until now. What's most problematic about that
column7: though
column8: is that it leaves Martin-McCormick's vocals out in the open. With just a sampler and a keyboard to compete with in the mix
column9: Martin-McCormick doesn't have much else to slam into here
column10: an issue that's at its most jarring in the early seconds of standout closer ""Echo"" or the EP's brooding title track. The quilled texture of his voice simply doesn't match up well with the smooth
column11: temperate tones this band is playing with as a duo
column12: despite their typically violent
column13: overwhelming interplay.

column1: That said
column2: whether working with this palette is a one-off experiment or the beginning of a lengthier adventure isn't easy to hear. Dolphins is both hypnotic and staggering at times
column3: but it lacks the extraordinary stamina that those earlier Mi Ami long-players kept from end to end. Take for instance the neon groove of ""Hard Up""
column4: a song whose pulse can only be matched in murmurs by the blank wandering of ""Sunrise"". That they're able to so accurately translate their singular energy from one setup to the next is a feat. Should they decide to stick with it
column5:
finding a way to spread all of that out would be another.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16314/homepage_large.9c49e8a6.jpg|Approaching the Energy Field|1366.0|The Eternals|['Rock'
column2: 'Experimental'
column3: 'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Addenda'
column5: the Eternals are a band operating in the wrong era. Their multi-genre stew-- full of funk
column6: dub
column7: jazz
column8: hip-hop
column9: and post-punk-- always takes me back to the late 1990s. That was a time when many cutting-edge bands were so obsessed with rhythms from outside rock's mainstream
column10: their classic forms and brand-new mutations
column11: that it was hard to even sell them in some quarters as ""rock."" At the time
column12: this rhythmic-centric synthesis seemed to some of us like the genre's future
column13: but the moment
column14: unfortunately
column15: passed quickly. Few current indie bands are paying tribute to Sun Ra or King Tubby
column16: blending various strains of Afro-Caribbean rhythm culture and cutting the mix with rock's bite.

column1: Of course
column2: the Eternals aren't some post-rock analog to the current wave of lo-fi 90s nostalgia. They come directly out of the tradition
column3: and over the course of four albums released in the last decade
column4: they've kept its stylistically promiscuous vibe alive. But in any era
column5: even one crowded with likeminded bands
column6: they would be unique. Mostly that's down to vocalist Damon Locks and his wild changeups. Many of those late-90s bands peddled instrumentals. The rest had singers who (being way charitable here) seriously lacked for charisma. That's not a charge you could ever seriously aim at Locks
column7: whose fearless vocal acrobatics
column8: sometimes straining against his skill set
column9: are what set him apart from most indie singers
column10: then or now.

column1: Punk sneer
column2: cosmic P-Funk rapping
column3: cracked crooning
column4: wizened reggae mysticism: Locks rarely sings the same way twice on Approaching the Energy Field. His dub-style chatting and ""mystic space voice"" chanting have more hair-raising conviction than his more conventional (and technically just-okay) singing
column5: just as the Eternals' music gets better the more it strays from homages to familiar genres and into weird combinations. But as on the previous albums
column6: its Locks' abundance of personality and weird way with a hook that elevates the Eternals beyond an experiment in making new rhythms out of old
column7: a band with both a deep love of post-funk history and the chops to scramble that history into new shapes.

column1: Still
column2: musically
column3: this is the most varied and accomplished Eternals set yet. Approaching the Energy Field covers a wider range of sounds than even their first three albums
column4: which were already pretty diverse: The jagged beats of Anti-Pop style ultra-underground hip-hop; the jumpy syncopations of UK bass music like broken beat and dubstep; spaced-out George Clinton synthesizer epics; low-key Latin jazz. It's clear the band knows and loves these sounds; you get the feeling they could ape any of them convincingly if they wished. But they're also too restless to play things straight
column5: to simply pay homage to their influences and obsessions.

column1: Aside from their commitment to rhythm
column2: that desire to bend the rules and mix things up is still the Eternals' greatest asset. It's why the album's best moments are those which can be pegged to no particular genre
column3: even when the beats drop away
column4: like on ""I Let the Telephone Ring""
column5: which evokes Spaghetti western soundtracks
column6: Stravinsky-ish orchestral music
column7: and the fragile dream-pop ballads of A.R. Kane. The Eternals may be out their own in their own in the once again guitar-centric world of indie rock circa 2011
column8: but that just means we're doubly lucky they're still listening so widely
column9:
still pushing themselves to come up with such unexpected new hybrids.

One of the few things more depressing than actually listening to Lupe Fiasco's new album
column2: <i>Lasers
column3: is imagining the monumentally emasculating studio sessions it took to make it. It's easy for label heads to see the commercial success of arena-rap like ""Empire State of Mind"" and ""Love the Way You Lie""-- or crossover debuts such as Nicki Minaj's Pink Friday and B.o.B.'s The Adventures of Bobby Ray (Lupe turned down the Alex Da Kid beats to ""Airplanes"" and the Smeezingtons' ""Nothin' on You"") -- as a public mandate for more of the same. But wouldn't it just be easier to find someone down for the cause rather than to remake the public persona of someone who's already established?

column1: Lasers simply sounds bad
column2: playing against every single one of Lupe Fiasco's strengths and creating new weaknesses. Surveying the current pop-rap landscape and retaining nothing worthwhile
column3: it's at once chaotic
column4: bored
column5: and yet unyieldingly abrasive-- overblown
column6: forced choruses
column7: rawk guitar tracks that had to be laid down by a guy with a ponytail
column8: mixing as subtle as a nu-metal record. There's a guy on several of these songs singing putrid hooks through what sounds like vocal filters retrieved from Dan Deacon's recycle bin-- he's named MDMA. This is a coincidence of cosmic proportions.

column1: And then there's single ""The Show Goes On""
column2: so gallingly lazy
column3: I'm at least willing to view it as some sort of next-level parody of A&Rs asleep in the hit factory-- it would certainly be a more clever indictment than ""Dumb It Down"". This is one that ""interpolates"" Modest Mouse and trades Isaac Brock's fuck-all optimism for Lasers' most blatant attempt to siphon juice from Recovery's redemption-story treacle. Look
column4: ""Float On"" is a great song
column5: not a sacred text but interpolated into a half-Branson
column6: half-Disney brass fanfare somehow cheapens it worse than any appearance on Kidz Bop or ""American Idol"".

column1: But if this was simply ""man
column2: shame about some of the beats and hooks
column3: someone might assume they stumbled onto a review of Food & Liquor or The Cool. Whether it's self-sabotage or a total lack of inspiration
column4: the major difference here is that Lupe isn't working hard or playing hard. Doing just enough to escape his 16 bars before the next bombshell chorus blows
column5: he fills his verses with guh-inducing wordplay
column6: one-note concepts (the central metaphor of ""Out of My Head"" was deep enough to support a Drew Barrymore/Hugh Grant movie)
column7: or stock attempts at anguish (""Beautiful Lasers (2 Ways)"")
column8: uplift (""Coming Up"")
column9: and non-conformity (""State Run Radio"").

column1: You can't knock him for trying something new
column2: but the tools he should be using-- his rubbery wordplay
column3: thoughtful commentary
column4: sheer love of the art form-- get ditched
column5: with nothing interesting to replace them. This is mostly true even on the songs that sound like Atlantic's reward to Lupe for holding up his end of the bargain. Or maybe I'm wrong about all this and in time
column6: Lasers will make the bean counters happy enough to grant Lupe the resources to and freedom to do whatever he envisions as his classic. Then again
column7: his emo past is well noted-- as is the chip on his shoulder. Lupe often has enough trouble staying out of his own way
column8:
yet Lasers doesn't suffer for that reason; it just feels like the flaming wreckage of a project that never had a prayer.

It's been almost six years since the Psychic Paramount's last album
column3: Gamelan Into the Mink Supernatural. Normally a hiatus that long indicates a need to reform
column4: retool
column5: or in some way restart. But apparently this New York trio just gestated
column6: growing their music into something wider
column7: thicker
column8: and harder to define. In huge jams that soar
column9: crash
column10: and smolder-- often at the same time-- the band pumps extra blood and muscle into their sound
column11: as if stretching a balloon into a blimp.

column1: If you're familiar with Gamelan
column2: you might wonder how the Psychic Paramount could make their sound any bigger; their crunchy noise and rumbling rhythms already filled speakers. On the surface
column3: II is actually pretty close to Gamelan
column4: at least in volume. But the way it plays out is more widescreen
column5: more 3-D. The songs encompass more moods and tempos
column6: more shifts and builds
column7: more ideas and moves. And the rippling guitars
column8: cloudy bass
column9: and exploding drums create sonic lava that coats the stereo space.

column1: Given that scope
column2: it makes sense that the Psychic Paramount have been called post-rock. (The same tag was laid on the band that guitarist Drew St. Ivany and bassist Ben Armstrong previously inhabited
column3: Laddio Bolocko.) After all
column4: they're instrumental and they like to build to crescendos. But where most post-rock bands rely on quiet/loud shifts to create dynamics
column5: these three manage to ebb and flow while sticking to a maxed-energy attack. So while they may ascend at one point and descend at another
column6: they never sound like they're retreating.

column1: Which puts II closer to the relentless psych-noise of Japanese bands like Fushitsusha and Marble Sheep than the cine-drama of Godspeed You! Black Emperor or Mogwai. It also has the bluesy immolation of Comets on Fire and the hammering weight of Lightning Bolt
column2: but the impressive thing about II compared to all of these groups-- even compared to Gamelan-- is how controlled and confident it sounds. It's as if they decided to make fire by patiently rubbing sticks rather than violently striking a match. And just as Glenn Branca forged an Ascension by pounding at one chord
column3: the Psychic Paramount find fuel by drilling to the bottom of single riffs.

column1: They can get complex
column2: too-- songs like the chopping ""RW"" and jazzy closer ""N5 Coda"" share a math rock vibe with Don Caballero and Oxes. But they're rarely just connecting dots. They're more interested in following intuition than patterns
column3: and II is way more physical than mental. Its density
column4: pace
column5: and exuberance are
column6: for anyone that likes to get lost in sound
column7: basically a sonic amusement park. Still
column8: even if you can close your eyes on this roller coaster<i>
column9: you can't turn off your brain. In fact
column10: the way the Psychic Paramount infiltrate your ears
column11:
they're more likely to switch that particular organ into overdrive.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16275/homepage_large.2f9782fe.jpg|Blessed|4600.0|Lucinda Williams|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Lost Highway']|2011-03-16 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:33:05.565312|"

The 2000s were Lucinda Williams' most prolific decade
column2: as well as her most conflicted. She released four studio albums and one double live
column3: more than matching her output for the previous two decades combined. Drifting away from country music (which had little use for her as a songwriter or as a performer) and toward a gritty strain of roots rock
column4: Williams grew more confessional in her lyrics
column5: which have grown blatantly autobiographical and have coalesced into a larger story built around her romantic ups and downs. Rather than refining her craft
column6: this development has actually had a deleterious effect on her music. In contrast to her first two country-blues albums and her three truly country albums
column7: her four records from the previous decade have been alternately alienating and ingratiating
column8: self-indulgent and self-denying-- eager both to please an audience and disdain them. Her once effortless lyricism has become rigid and workmanlike
column9: with clichéd phrases standing in for complex evocations and words seemingly chosen less for their intrinsic meaning and more for their adherence to her AABB rhyme schemes.

column1: Blessed
column2: her ninth studio album
column3: marks the culmination of another trend in Williams' career
column4: one that is much less concrete than the mechanisms of meter and rhyme. Her songwriting has become increasingly about the present rather than the past. Sweet Old World (1992) and Car Wheels on a Gravel Road (1998) possessed a heady notion of personal history
column5: exploring the ways we hold onto old lovers and how certain places (an old juke joint
column6: the town of Pineola
column7: Miss.) can evoke such bittersweet memories. Blessed has only one prominent concrete noun-- in ""Copenhagen""
column8: named for the city where she learns of a friend's death. And why shouldn't Williams be more interested in the here and now instead of the there and then? If her 2000s albums have rendered her life as it happens
column9: then these new songs chronicle a new and unprecedented chapter: happiness and contentment. In 2009
column10: she married her manager Tom Overby
column11: which means she's writing songs about finding her joy and from the perspective of a happy woman. ""Sweet Love"" is a straightforward love song that recalls a time when Williams could make simple sound endlessly complex
column12: and ""Convince Me"" and ""Kiss Like Your Kiss"" (written for True Blood) are her sexiest songs since ""Right in Time"" 13 years ago.

column1: Happiness suits her
column2: but Williams' frustrating tics remain-- the constant repetition of phrases
column3: the inflexible song structures
column4: the compartmentalized melodies-- and are matched with anonymous roots rock courtesy of co-producers Overby and Don Was. Williams builds the title track on various iterations of the line ""We were blessed by..."" but the song becomes increasingly hackneyed in its spirituality
column5: speaking in broad platitudes rather than concrete examples. ""We were blessed by the battered woman who didn't seek revenge
column6: she sings plaintively
column7: but vaguely. ""We were blessed by the warrior who didn't need to win."" When she tries to reach outside herself and address the wars in the Middle East-- a first for her-- Williams comes up with a great idea that allows her to alternate between the battlefield and the home front
column8: but the persistent couplets deliver only dully acoustic melodrama
column9: culminating in the lines
column10: ""Today I took a bullet through the heart/ Baby's gonna have to make a brand-new start.""

column1: This being a Lucinda Williams album
column2: death looms ominously even over her contentment. Blessed includes not just one but two songs about deceased friends-- a genre she has historically excelled in. But even as ""Copenhagen"" tries to evoke the shock of helplessness that comes with learning of a friend's sudden passing
column3: Williams sets the scene with an astoundingly awkward metaphor about taking a snowball to the face
column4: the melting ice mixing with her tears. Rather than poignant
column5: it sounds forced and arbitrary
column6: even campy. ""Seeing Black"" was allegedly written in the wake of Vic Chesnutt's death and continues the long line of worried artist laments like ""Drunken Angel"" and ""Real Live Bleeding Fingers and Broken Guitar Strings"". It's an emotionally forensic investigation
column7: but instead of trying to understand his suicidal impulses
column8: Williams just sounds like a scold.

column1: Ultimately
column2: Blessed has the feel of a transitional album-- from lonely to married
column3: from troubled to contented
column4: from regretful to joyful. She's confronting the prospect of happiness and commitment but hasn't fully relinquished the hard feelings of her past few releases. It is enough
column5: however
column6: to engender a lot of good will toward the album. Listening to these songs and knowing the story she has been so careful to document
column7:
you want Williams to finally find her joy. You want this album to be good. You want these songs to be better than they really are.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16308/homepage_large.75811339.jpg|Pakistan Folk and Pop Instrumentals 1966-1976|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sublime Frequencies']|2011-03-16 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:33:06.133881|"

In Pakistan
column2: much as in neighboring India
column3: the film industry dominates popular music. From the 1920s onward
column4: Lollywood-- the affectionate term for the Lahore-based studio system-- has been the source of the huge majority of hit songs in the country
column5: even as the industry has suffered one cruel setback after another
column6: from wars to coups to changing censorship laws. One side effect of film music's grip on the subcontinent's pop consciousness has been that India and Pakistan jointly represent one of the biggest holes in the global late-1960s/early-70s beat music story-- there just aren't many recordings of rock music from the era from either country.

column1: But the music existed. Much of it has been effectively lost simply because the record companies that operated in South Asia weren't interested and the bands didn't get to record. In urban Pakistan
column2: the late 60s looked in many ways similar to the late 60s in Western Europe or the U.S.-- long-haired
column3: politicized university kids making music with whatever was available to them. Bands covered Western hits
column4: and some almost certainly wrote their own material
column5: but when it came time to go into the studio-- a privilege few ever received-- their options were limited. Most cut little more than a single or an EP
column6: and instrumental versions of old folk songs and Urdu film tunes were about all they were allowed to record.

column1: Thankfully
column2: what was put to tape is pretty distinctive. If the 22 songs gathered on Sublime Frequencies' Pakistan Folk and Pop Instrumentals don't illuminate anything that could be considered a real scene
column3: they do at least share a sort of charming weirdness
column4: highlighted by a mix of local percussion
column5: surfy guitars
column6: and blaring
column7: cheap organ
column8: with the occasional sitar or accordion. The set's compiler
column9: Stuart Ellis
column10: has an ear for non-Western beat music-- he also compiled SF's Bollywood Steel Guitar set and runs Radiodiffusion International
column11: a site that for the past few years has posted one exceptional
column12: forgotten beat gem from far off the beaten track
column13: sharing songs from Brunei
column14: Sri Lanka
column15: Iraq
column16: Iran
column17: Bangladesh
column18: Somalia
column19: and dozens of other countries. It's worth checking out the Annex's long archive.

column1: What he's put together here actually represents the lion's share of recorded non-film Pakistani beat music
column2: at least that anyone's been able to dig up. The Panthers
column3: the Mods
column4: the Aay Jayes
column5: the Abstracts
column6: the Blue Birds
column7: and the Fore Thoughts are the featured bands
column8: with a few non-soundtrack songs from film composers Sohail Rana and Nisar Bazmi included to round things out. Predictably
column9: it's the Bazmi and Rana songs that sound the most like the intentional collision of styles that lay at the heart of South Asian film music during the era. Rana's ""The Khyber Twist"" even comes from an album pointedly named Folk Tunes of Pakistan on the Latin American Beat
column10: though that particular song is much more in the surf style of American groups like the Challengers and the Chantays.

column1: The best of the bands included was probably the Panthers-- Ellis is making a point when he opens the set with their ""Malkaus""
column2: which opens with a bit of ghazal-ish singing before someone yells
column3: in English
column4: ""take over
column5: Panthers!"" and the song comes in with a startling rush of Beatlesque guitar. It's a manifesto for a musical revolution that never materialized. The other bands give it their best shot
column6: though. I love the twanging and chiming guitar tones they worked with
column7: but I'll admit that the extremely treble-heavy organ sounds favored by most of these bands might sit a little hard on some listeners' ears. The mix of Western instrumentation and Pakistani rhythms results in quite a few great songs-- the Fore Thoughts' ""Shahbaz Qalander"" is an especially effective and subtle melding of East and West.

column1: Hearing this music takes on a slightly different shade of meaning when you consider what happened in Pakistan during the time covered by the compilation. It picks up just after the inconclusive 1965 war with India over Kashmir
column2: and encompasses a time of immense change and challenge for Pakistan. The military junta that had ruled the country since 1958 came to an end in 1972
column3: less than a year after a disastrous war that led to the independence of Bangladesh from Pakistan and a humiliating defeat at the hands of India. The civilian rule of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto was a period of relative liberalization
column4: and this is the period most of these songs actually come from-- many are from 1976
column5: which is not an accidental closing date. Bhutto was overthrown in 1977
column6: and the subsequent regime of General Muhammed Zia-ul-Haq pursued an aggressive policy of Islamization
column7: which included the imposition of curfews and the banning of alcohol. The death of Pakistani nightlife led most of the musicians heard on this compilation to move abroad.

column1: So Pakistan Folk and Pop Instrumentals captures an extended moment in Pakistani music and history. It's a moment in which a segment of the country's educated youth was fleetingly swept up in the great tidal currents that helped make beat music one of the first globe-spanning cultural phenomena. It's a moment that will never be duplicated
column2: and that's part of what makes it so fascinating today. We can lament that there wasn't more documentation
column3: but what we do have is interesting
column4: unique
column5:
and just plain fun to listen to.

"|15207.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15207-pakistan-folk-and-pop-instrumentals-1966-1976/|7.8|Joe Tangari

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16313/homepage_large.3eeab5b5.jpg|One Nation|29386.0|Hype Williams|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hippos in Tanks']|2011-03-16 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:33:06.864803|"

Hype Williams are
column2: ostensibly
column3: a London-based duo comprised of one Inga Copeland and one Roy Blunt. Except Inga's name might be Karen Glass
column4: and Roy Blunt may actually be Roy Nnawuchi. It's possible neither exists; some have suggested Hype Williams may in fact be a much larger collective
column5: while others have offered the name Denna Frances Glass as a potential culprit. When they perform live
column6: they don elaborate masks
column7: and are notoriously-- albeit understandably-- interview-averse. The vinyl version of One Nation
column8: their latest
column9: is a white record
column10: tucked into a plain white sleeve in a glossy white cover. Even their name
column11: Hype Williams
column12: seems less an SEO-piggybacking attempt at easy nostalgia points than a pun on the very idea of ""hype."" There's an intentional blankness and an almost post-punky spirit of deconstruction to Hype Williams' image that does well by their stark music
column13: a spacious
column14: hazy
column15: hip-hop-influenced electronic dub.

column1: As you'd imagine
column2: Hype Williams don't exactly provide credits for One Nation
column3: but they do take the time to shout out a couple of special guests: MDMA and blueberry kush. Despite a certain stoney splay
column4: there's a weird solemnity to One Nation that belies the presence of these mood enhancers
column5: an unsettling ominousness even in its floatier moments. Snatches of smeary g-funk
column6: synth-pop
column7: and monster-movie soundtracks sneak into the mix
column8: but One Nation is sparse throughout
column9: with most tracks consisting of little more than a beat and a bit of queasy synth. There are few vocals
column10: fewer hooks; it's not quite ambient enough to slip completely into the background
column11: but nothing's quite fleshed enough to demand full attention
column12: and you're better off losing yourself in the drift of One Nation in total than attempting to settle on a highlight. In their rare interviews
column13: Hype Williams have done what they can to distance themselves from this kind of half-there hypnagogy
column14: and their aloofness sets them apart from much of the bedroom-borne haze of late. Melodies don't just waft
column15: they meander
column16: beats shuffle into unlikely grooves
column17: and any hints of prettiness are suffused with a looming dread.

column1: But there's an intentionality to every gesture on One Nation. Even when the melodies threaten to lose their shape
column2: they seem to bend just so
column3: and the notes they're not playing seem every bit as important as the few they do. The negative space envelops like a fog; whoever's making this music has a producer's ear and editor's spirit
column4: excising all unnecessary details while embellishing what little's left. At its best
column5: One Nation sounds like a beat tape left to crackle for a decade in somebody's garage
column6:
a kind of post-Chronic spin on one of those far-out late 70s dub-inflected collaborative krautrock LPs. But other times it feels like a series of conceptual curios that seems to think holding the listener at arm's length might even be too close.

"|15212.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15212-one-nation/|6.4|Paul Thompson

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16310/homepage_large.5c05829a.jpg|Shaolin vs. Wu-Tang|3634.0|Raekwon|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ice H2O']|2011-03-15 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:33:07.419012|"

At this point
column2: Wu-Tang is about nostalgia. The classic template
column3: from the kung fu samples and RZA production blueprint to the rapper's trademark styles
column4: was well-established more than a decade ago. Staying in that lane hasn't always paid creative dividends for the Clan-- there are a few post-millennial Wu records that are hardly essential-- but Raekwon has managed to avoid the obvious pitfalls. Making sequels to 1990s classics was a risky effort
column5: considering how much the rap world had shifted in the interim. But with Cuban Linx II
column6: it was apparent that Rae's rapping
column7: as flashily dense and intensely percussive as ever
column8: was one of the Clan's renewable resources.

column1: Shaolin vs. Wu Tang is neither as ambitious nor as dark as Cuban Linx II. It's leaner than both Linx records-- many of the tracks clock in under three minutes-- which also frees it from the weighty expectations game that dogged Rae since Immobilarity critically bombed. The production from a slate of lesser-known names caused some fans to balk
column2: but it's a strong choice; the beats seem selected for their function rather than the producer's reputation. It's definitely a reverent record created for Wu fans
column3: with all the requisite cinema samples and minor-key melodies. The freewheeling novelty of last year's Cocainism Vol. 2 mixtape
column4: which even included Rae spitting over the Blackbyrd's classic ode to public sex
column5: is scaled back. But there is enough variation in the production and craft-conscious rhyme construction to make it a worthwhile project

column1: The production largely sticks to the RZA's overall approach. Bronze Nazareth's turn on ""Butter Knives"" hews especially closely to the RZA's more cinematic Cuban Linx moments. But there are twists throughout to keep things interesting. The best beats build on the typical Wu track by adding some new ideas. Evidence's ""The Scroll"" and Scram Jones' ""Crane Style""
column2: for example
column3: play with some unusual drum loops
column4: which provides a good counterpoint to Rae's choppy
column5: rhythmic approach to rap. ""Crane Style"" and Selasi's ""Snake Pond"" also use some great melodic samples that expand on the Wu's co-opting of ""Oriental"" cinematic tropes.

column1: The record's biggest weakness is the unfortunate ""Rock N Roll""
column2: which is doomed by its unappealing chorus
column3: generic production courtesy the generally unimpressive DJ Khalil
column4: and a guest verse from Jim Jones. Guest verses in general are all a tier below previous Raekwon records. Although Wu alumni work well enough throughout
column5: Nas' verse on ""Rich and Black"" does nothing to help his recent artistic slide. Busta Rhymes sounds ridiculous on ""Crane Style"". Rick Ross doesn't bring much to the table on ""Molasses""
column6: and Lloyd Banks verse is well-written but his voice sounds strangely strained.

column1: Raekwon
column2: though
column3: is on point throughout
column4: and in the end it's his rapping that carries the LP. From his reinterpretation of the ""Broken Language"" rap style for the title track to the densely detailed reminiscence ""From the Hills""

column6:
interlock in interesting ways and convey moods and concepts with gripping style. Few rappers could bring such an engaging sense of energy to a project so focused on preaching to the converted.

column21:
working you over slowly and deliberately.

column29: like on Soul Clap's ""3 Wheel E-Motion""

an unlikely fusion of dusty urban sounds and lush synth trickery.

column1: Everyone loves a good comeback story
column2: and the return of Gary Higgins has been one most dramatic and unlikely in recent memory. In 1973
column3: Higgins released his debut album Red Hash
column4: and then
column5: following a stint in prison on drug charges
column6: disappeared entirely from the public eye. Over the intervening years
column7: a small but fervent group of fans came to consider Red Hash a lost psych-folk classic. Following a great deal of detective work
column8: Drag City reissued the album in 2005 and Higgins returned to play some well-received live shows. In 2009
column9: Drag City then released Seconds
column10: Higgins first album of new material in more than three decades.

column1: The only snag in the resurrection of Higgins' music career was that on Seconds
column2: the backstory largely overshadowed the actual music. Time had been surprisingly kind to Higgins' gentle voice
column3: but Seconds failed to recapture the magic glow of Red Hash
column4: with stiff songwriting that too often settled into coffeehouse folk-rock clichés. So it seems a good decision that for the next stage of Higgins' musical rejuvenation Drag City has gone back to the beginning with A Dream a While Back
column5: a short collection of songs recorded by Higgins back in 1970-71. And though these solo works are not as fleshed out nor quite as transporting as the highlights of Red Hash
column6: they provide a fascinating document of a young songwriter finding his voice
column7: and leave behind lingering questions about what might have been.

column1: Oftentimes when an obscure album comes to be considered a cult classic
column2: it can be easy to hear why it failed to find a larger audience in its own time-- it's too out-of-step
column3: too innovative or forward-thinking
column4: or just simply too personal and strange. But to me that has never seemed the case with <i>Red Hash
column5: an album that sounds resolutely of its time
column6: and nearly as accessible as the folk-rock of Neil Young
column7: Bert Jansch
column8: or Paul Simon of the same era. And it certainly doesn't sound that foreign to modern ears familiar with the work of Elliott Smith or Ben Chasny
column9: who memorably covered Red Hash's ""Thicker Than a Smokey"" on Six Organs of Admittance's School of the Flower.

column1: Many of Higgins' songs on Red Hash concentrated on that slender line that exists between peaceful solitude and melancholic loneliness. These mixed emotions about being left alone with oneself are further heightened on A Dream a While Back. Whereas Red Hash was recorded with members of Higgins' backing band Wooden Wheel
column2: on these six tracks his voice is accompanied almost solely by his own acoustic guitar. Recorded at The Old Chestnut Inn in Kent
column3: CT-- a location
column4: incidentally
column5: that will soon be used as a drug rehab facility-- these songs have an intimate
column6: fragile quality that encourages its listeners to draw their chairs in a little closer.

column1: With archival material like this
column2: it is always tempting to examine the songs for hints of foreshadowing
column3: and it's easy to have a little shiver when Higgins sings such fatalistic lines as ""Ragged edges will cut your hands
column4: do you in and change your plans"" on the opening ""Stormy Weather"". On the lovely ""Waiting for You""
column5: Higgins raises his voice to a slightly higher register
column6: his near-falsetto adding to the delicacy of his lonesome chorus. It should also be mentioned that by the time of these recordings he was already a very agile guitarist and
column7: given the lo-fi nature of the production
column8: the casual sophistication of his playing on tracks like ""Laugh a Little"" or ""Oxygen"" can catch the listener off guard.

column1: All of the songs included here feature memorable if not exactly bold melodies
column2: sounding in general like pieces that Higgins intended to come back to later and build upon with a full band. That he never quite got the opportunity to do so at the time feels like a raw deal for him and for us. Listening to this collection
column3: I can't help but think there could be some killer cover versions to be made of these songs
column4: either by younger musicians looking for top-shelf material or by Higgins himself
column5:
returned at last to the spotlight.

Mystery is a difficult illusion to maintain these days. A few artists are trying-- by providing only vague geographical information
column3: crafting webpages consisting of blurred video
column4: and other heavy-handed approaches to mystique-building. Vondelpark takes a more bold-faced approach to the lack-of-personality game; no videos
column5: no MySpace page
column6: no Bandcamp
column7: nothing. So far the only tangible information that exists is that he hails from London and has a debut EP out on R&S records.

column1: The record's vibe-- lost
column2: fuzzy sounds-- fits the lack of disclosure. ""California Analog Dream"" may sound like the king of chillwave titles but the song owes more to two-step and UK garage; the beats are crystal clear-- more digital than analog-- but the rest of the instrumentation is hazy and lo-fi
column3: from the mumbled
column4: clipping vocals to barely there synth textures that swell and drift throughout the song.

column1: There's a restless feel to all four of these tracks
column2: most obvious in the vocal chatter of ""California Analog Dream"" and its yearning for escape-- walking to San Diego is a far cry from the grey
column3: rainy London. Vondelpark combines escapist elements of dream-pop-- gauzy synth textures dripped with reverb-- with some very English two-step beats. It makes for a neat self-descriptive mesh of nostalgic sounds from two distinct places-- one imagined and one lived.

column1: While the smeared vocals
column2: woozy textures
column3: and garage-y beats work on the more clearly defined moments
column4: they come across as rough or unfinished on ""Jetpack Blue Version"". Here the busy vocals feel intrusive and the melody is difficult to pin down
column5: making the song seem like a first draft. ""Hippodrome""
column6: on the other hand
column7: is the most focused track here
column8: with its lilting guitar line and insistent vocal melody. Despite being shorter and more reigned-in than the more wide-open moments on the record
column9: it still has an effortless off-the-cuff feel thanks to its subtly shifting movements and loose drums. In the end
column10: it feels strangely voyeuristic
column11:
as Vondelpark's mumbly vocal style and mysterious persona give off the sense you're privy somebody's private feelings.

In a press release for the new album by Sin Fang (formerly known as Sin Fang Bous)
column2: Morr Music touts him as ""Iceland's new king of lo-fi layered lushness
column3: which is odd: How does this pass
column4: in our haze-besotted indie climate
column5: as lo-fi? Summer Echoes is definitely layered and lush
column6: with electronic filigree laid atop orchestrated psychedelia laid atop acoustic indie-folk. But the sound separation is generally pristine
column7: contrasting timbres are clearly proportioned
column8: and stereo space is carefully managed. It was recorded with a band that included members of Múm and Seabear
column9: in Sin Fang's own studio and in Sigur Rós' Sundlaugin.

column1: Maybe the lo-fi label is just hanging on from Sindri Már Sigfússon's debut record as Sin Fang Bous
column2: Clangour
column3: where he played every instrumental part
column4: so that it felt more like his early days as Seabear
column5: before it too swelled into a full band. It seems as if he'd like to be a spontaneous bedroom musician
column6: but is actually more professional by inclination. Morr also reports that Sigfússon tends to make music on a meticulous 9-to-5 schedule
column7: and it shows in this polished
column8: richly detailed
column9: but somewhat workmanlike album. It's consistently easy to admire and
column10: occasionally
column11: be wowed by. It's harder to go crazy for
column12: which is mostly because of the singing.

column1: Sigfússon's voice describes the right pitches
column2: but that's about all-- it's kind of blank. The lack of affect works well when the melodies have a lot of character
column3: as on the nimbly rising and dipping ""Bruises""
column4: or the gently skipping ""Fall Down Slow"". Elsewhere
column5: like on ""Rituals""
column6: the vocal lines can feel a bit directionless
column7: which Sigfússon's voice isn't atmospheric enough to compensate for. If you prefer more expressive singing
column8: this probably isn't for you. But the great thing about music below the virtuoso level is hearing people find ways to work with what they've got
column9: and for Sigfússon to place so much emphasis on the environment around his voice is a smart move. He shines in the studio

column1: There are two types of embellishments that Sigfússon emphasizes on this record. At times
column2: it recalls Fool's Gold's excellent 2009 album
column3: with bright
column4: fluid highlife-derived electric guitars (e.g. ""Easier"" and ""Slowlights""). A number of other songs
column5: especially in the back half
column6: explore a Castanets-like beat-folk
column7: with rubbery electronic bass and syncopated clicks and claps
column8: most productively on ""Sing From Dream""
column9: a Baths-like concoction of twee electronica and mulched hip-hop. But Sin Fang folds in plenty of ear-bending texture from outside of these dominant modes
column10: and hardly any dynamic moment in the many-jointed songs goes without a backmasked synthesizer or harp sweep to drive it home. This is exceptionally thought-through music
column11:
which makes it lively at the microscopic level but a bit remote overall.

In the shadow of Dodos' breakthrough LP Visiter
column2: their 2009 follow-up Time to Die was considered a minor letdown; in a vacuum
column3: it was actually more of a misstep. The addition of a third member had gummed up the works for original members Meric Long and Logan Kroeber went the party line. Instead
column4: the record's achilles heel was the usually appropriate tidy economy of Phil Ek's production. Here
column5: for perhaps the first time
column6: it worked against one of his charges
column7: turning down Dodos' raw idiosyncrasies and miscasting them as genial folk-pop á la Fleet Foxes or the Shins. But when a misstep is this obvious
column8: the flipside is that troubleshooting is incredibly easy-- back to a duo and working with previous engineer John Askew
column9: No Color isn't quite the knockout Visiter was
column10: but it's a logical step in trying to advance beyond the untamed but thrilling sprawl of the past without slamming the door on it.

column1: The difference is obvious from the first minute: On opener ""Black Night"" you're immediately reminded just how magnetic Long and Kroeber can be when they're playing like they don't have to worry about waking the neighbors. The sheer physicality with which these two interact with acoustic instruments feels positively electric
column2: a potent reminder that regardless of their unorthodox musicianship
column3: this is above all else a rock band. And most importantly
column4: one that avoids the usual trope of acoustic acts gunning to be forceful (i.e.
column5: strum harder) and plays off each other's virtuosity for whatever form of crowd-pleasing they want
column6: whether it's another chorus for a beer commercial or unplugged psych-rock with the volcanic peaks of freaky companions Akron/Family.

column1: Lyrically
column2: No Color is a step in a new direction for Dodos-- for mostly better. Catalog highlights ""Jodi"" and ""Fools"" were ultimately both driven by the same gut-level writing that also resulted in some fairly awkward woe-is-the-world accounts
column3: and Long is noticeably more impressionistic here. The upside is in how the phrasing is rhythmically and thematically more locked in than ever with the sonics-- words acts in tandem with the dizzying momentum accumulated during ""Black Night""
column4: while the odd-metered repetition of ""Sleep""'s chorus mirrors the narrator's increasing self-obsession.

column1: For the most part
column2: the autumnal glow is a good look
column3: even if they nail that feeling a bit much in the record's most sedated and less rewarding second half. ""Companions"" and ""Don't Stop"" close No Color with Long's most pyrotechnic chops and most pedestrian melodies. But in between
column4: ""When Will You Go"" and ""Don't Try and Hide It"" hit an anthemic stride whose subtle build and optimism feel like new wrinkles-- in particular
column5: the latter works in a manner similar to Jimmy Eat World's ""The Middle""
column6: claiming a pep talk about feeling normal can be every bit as effective as one that makes you wonder if you really have a freak flag to fly.

column1: In a weird way
column2: ""Don't Try And Hide It"" feels like a thematic mission statement for No Color. For one thing
column3: it's one of several tracks that feature backup vocals from tourmate Neko Case
column4: but the reason I feel comfortable waiting this long to bring up what at least sounds like a huge selling point is because she's
column5: well
column6: kinda hidden. If you wanted to hear her do the force of nature thing
column7: well
column8: that's what Neko Case albums are for
column9: and the way she fits in as a bit player drives home a line from ""Black Night"" where Long confidently sings ""it was never that I was aiming at being someone else."" Whether that's true or not
column10:
No Color is proof that Dodos are indeed at their best when they're simply being themselves.

By the time James Brown's last great band slowly collapsed in 1975
column2: it was clear that something was going terribly wrong. Once so far ahead of all of his R&B contemporaries that every new single provoked an international scramble to figure out his new groove
column3: he'd now settled into repeating himself-- ""Superbad
column4: Superslick"" was a drained
column5: brittle remake of his four-year-old single ""Super Bad""-- or
column6: worse
column7: imitating his imitators. The minor hit ""Hot (I Need to Be Loved
column8: Loved
column9: Loved
column10: Loved)"" was simply a hoarse JB lyric set to a note-for-note ripoff of David Bowie's ""Fame"".

column1: From the first seven tracks on this volume of Hip-O's mail-order series-- which also include a pair of wretched doo-wop covers and two tedious versions of a University of Georgia football fight song-- you might guess that Brown's career was crashing and burning. (The lengthy funk jam ""Everybody Wanna Get Funky One More Time""
column2: the final release on his People label
column3: sounds like a farewell for which he's rousing whatever oomph he's got left.) But Brown had long since mastered the art of throwing off his cape and rushing back to the microphone just as he was being led offstage.

column1: ""I'm back!"" he declared at the beginning of ""Get Up Offa That Thing""
column2: the first record on which he figured out how to integrate his vamp-and-stab funk into the new disco sound. He was rewarded with a substantial hit
column3: and followed it up with a few more dance records that were reasonably solid
column4: if not quite groundbreaking: ""Bodyheat""
column5: ""Give Me Some Skin""
column6: ""The Spank"". Still
column7: the old master wasn't quite at home in the new era-- compared to the freewheeling funk records he was making even a couple of years earlier
column8: they were clenched-up and uncomfortable.

column1: So the fascinating stuff on Volume Ten is
column2: for the most part
column3: perversely fascinating. A soupy ""Love Me Tender""
column4: recorded a few months after Elvis's death
column5: begins with a little first-take monologue: ""You know--oh
column6: hi
column7: this is James Brown. The Godfather of Soul?-- I wanna talk about a good friend..."" ""People Who Criticize"" (when artists come up with titles like that
column8: you know there's a problem) isn't good
column9: exactly
column10: but it's bugging out with sheer spirit
column11: including a bungled but vehement piano solo and a minute and a half of unhinged scat singing at the end. The Gershwin standard ""Summertime"" is one of the few times Brown's longtime backup singer Martha High ever got to step into the spotlight--although
column12: for Brown
column13: it's an excuse to chatter about how ""I'm just so disgusted
column14: because Mother Nature didn't intend for the things that are happenin'.""

column1: And then there's ""For Goodness Sakes
column2: Look at Those Cakes""
column3: the most joyful and most ridiculous of his disco records-- an ass-watcher's diary
column4: at a much faster tempo than ""Hot Pants"". (Brown had evidently forgotten how to pull off slow funk.) When it stiffed
column5: Polydor announced that either Brown would have to turn himself over to another producer
column6: or they were done with trying to promote his rusty funk and soggy ballads to an audience that had moved on. The result was an album called The Original Disco Man-- an appeal to nostalgia and respect--led by ""It's Too Funky in Here""
column7: his first single with staying power in a few years. Produced by Brad Shapiro
column8: it sounded like no James Brown record before it
column9: slick
column10: modern and rubbery. The voice on top of it retained its force and rasp and pouncing sense of rhythm: nothing could take those away. But the days of his old slogan
column11: ""A James Brown Production-- The Sound of Success""
column12: were gone for good.

column1: At its best
column2: and on lead single ""L.I.F.E.G.O.E.S.O.N.""

column1: Even at their best
