column6: a ramshackle 19th century end-times sermon gone folk-rock. ""The whole world's rotten to the core
column7: singer Ryan Sollee reminds us with a howl on the album's most cathartic chorus. We may already be this screwed
column8: the Builders and the Butchers seem to be suggesting throughout Dead Reckoning. High time we started shouting about it.

column1: The rivers and trains and once-fashionable women's names peppering their lyrics and the old-timey garb they don for press photos further lend the Builders' doomsaying an out-of-time quality. Often
column2: their blood-spattered
column3: Revelations feel-- matched with Sollee's nasal voice and all the rollicking arrangements-- bears an uncanny resemblance of their fellow Portlandic histrionical society
column4: the Decemberists. Like The King Is Dead and R.E.M.
column5: it's a comparison the Butchers surely could've predicted; hell
column6: the Decemberists' Chris Funk sat behind the boards on their last album. Sollee's voice is a close cousin to Meloy's
column7: less nuanced perhaps but wilder in the big moments. And the band's half-delicate
column8: half-driving acoustic pileup's got plenty in common with their citymates' earlier
column9: less fussy records. It'd be awfully easy to dismiss the Butchers as mere Decemberist-a-likes
column10: but there's a jittery
column11: paranoiac quality to their music-- and Sollee's shouts in particular-- that lends it a very different intensity than even those earlier
column12: more murderous Decemberists LPs. It's almost as though
column13: while Colin Meloy was down in Missoula studying literature
column14: Sollee and company were somewhere deep in the woods
column15:
working out the bylaws of their own sovereign nation.

All that might sound a bit bleak
column16: but it's actually fairly raucous
column17: helped along by the Butchers' fondness for big shoutalong choruses and the sweaty live-in-a-room feel of their arrangements. Using two drummers to play a single kit
column18: there's a wild clatter in the uptempo numbers well suited to Sollee's breathless proselytizing. ""We All Know the Way"" imagines devotion-as-lockstep; an ironic place for a singalong
column19: yet there it is. There's plenty of unusually rollicking moments like that all over Dead Reckoning
column20: plenty of morbid lines that feel almost celebratory in their hands. Recorded quickly
column22: Dead Reckoning has an urgency and a sense of from-the-ether evil even in its slower moments; stark
column23: swirling highlight ""Out of the Mountain"" finds Sollee moaning quite matter-of-factly about setting fire to the earth and ""keeping the rain""; this isn't just any old pyro talking
column24:
and Sollee's grim lyrical visions are left to linger in this sparse setting.

Sometimes the fervor gets to be too much for them: the grating but mercifully brief ""Blood for You"" is little more than the junkyard clang of the rhythm section and Sollee's stuck-pig shout
column25: and the verses ""Cradle on Fire"" seem to get away from Sollee
column26: who loses the melody somewhere in the back of his throat. But there's few moments when they don't seem to be throwing everything they've got into these performances
column27: and that furious intensity drives them past both rough patches and easy comparisons. A couple of these melodies seem to run together after a couple listens
column28: and at times the music could stand to be a bit more gnarled to match some of Sollee's more sinister sentiments. But even as they scream down the sky
column29: the Builders and the Butchers seem to be having a blast
column30: and it's catching. Should the end of days finds you with a bottle of whiskey and Dead Reckoning
column31:
pray you've got a way to play the thing.

Gary Wilson's first album
column2: 1977's You Think You Really Know Me
column3: hinted at a hidden world. Recorded in his parents' basement
column4: it offered the kind of skewed take on saccharine AM pop best made by one lonely
column5: sunlight-starved individual. The few who heard it at the time probably had the same feeling I did when I first heard Ariel Pink
column6: a Wilson fan whose music shares similar stylistic obsessions. When Animal Collective's Paw Tracks label unearthed Pink's The Doldrums in 2004
column7: its bulging creativity encouraged fantasies that there was much more where that came from.

column1: In Pink's case
column2: fantasy turned out to be reality-- the vault he's uncovered since The Doldrums has been richer and more interesting than expected. Things haven't turned out as well for Wilson. You Think kept a shelf life via sporadic reissues and pop-star name-drops
column3: but it took 27 years for Wilson to release another solo record
column4: 2004's Mary Had Brown Hair. It's a good album
column5: but mostly remarkable for how much it sounds like You Think without matching its predecessor's bold singularity. Now
column6: with Electric Endicott
column7: Wilson's well is beginning to run dry.

column1: Not that there aren't some good songs here. But the ratio of quality-to-disposability is not very high. About a third of the tracks play like throwaways-- either ultra-generic piano jazz (Wilson has apparently played with a lounge band for a while) or squiggly
column2: aimless ambiance. While such abstractions merged nicely with his curious tics on You Think
column3: here they're just filler
column4: devoid of tension and unable to tie the album together or give it much texture.

column1: The better songs do have their moments. ""In the Night"" and the title track both hit a loopy breathlessness that makes them work as odd earworms. And Wilson's love ballads about surname-less women like Sandy
column2: Kathy
column3: and Karen have a nicely unjaded outlook akin to paeans by Jad Fair and Daniel Johnston. But those two are better at turning phrases and adding self-aware depth to their seemingly naïve tunes. Johnston especially can convey raw emotions that seem unavailable to Wilson
column4: who often sounds like he's more in love with his melodies than the girl he's singing about.

column1: Part of my ambivalence toward Electric Endicott comes from not sharing that love. Glittery synth-pop in the Steely Dan/Todd Rundgren vein is a tough sell for me. I find it hard to break through the cheesy Casio-preset associations and the obsessions with technical craft and formal figures that aren't interesting enough to warrant such commitment. Take Wilson's ""Where Are the Flowers?""
column2: whose irritatingly rote chant listing the days of the week is more like kid's homework than compelling music. Still
column3: when this sound is done with edge and freakiness
column4: it can be a unique surprise
column5: which is exactly what You Think You Really Know Me was. Electric Endicott is too often the opposite-- predictable and numbing
column6:
even when it's good.

column3: a cataclysmic earthquake cracked through Haiti
column4: killing hundreds of thousands of people and injuring or displacing millions more; now
column5: nearly 14 months later
column6: the country is still trying to right itself (according to Oxfam reports
column7: only five percent of the rubble has been cleared and just 15 percent of the required temporary housing stock has been built-- which is to say nothing of the vast infrastructural struggles the country continues to face). Collective interests-- even humanitarian ones-- move awfully fast these days (Anderson Cooper has since been dispatched elsewhere)
column8: but it seems more important than ever to give Haiti our attention. An overwhelming amount of basic recovery work-- like providing shelter
column9: water
column10: and adequate medical care to survivors-- is still undone.

column1: Here's one way Bonnie ""Prince"" Billy fans could help: spend $10 on Island Brothers
column2: his new two-song 10"" with the Cairo Gang
column3: and your cash will be directed to Edge Outreach
column4: a faith-based Kentucky nonprofit that ""trains
column5: equips
column6: and mobilizes ordinary people in sustainable solutions for clean water
column7: health and hygiene
column8: and sanitation"" (the funds will specifically bolster the group's relief work in Haiti). The two songs you'll get in exchange-- ""Island Brothers"" and ""New Wonder
column9: both familiar to veterans of Bonnie Prince Billy's last tour-- are rich and scrappy in the spirit of his most recent work (they'd fit easily on The Wonder Show of the World or Beware).

column1: Under various guises
column2: Will Oldham has experimented with a cornucopia of backing bands-- he's teamed with Nashville session musicians (Sings Greatest Palace Music)
column3: made a fuss with his two brothers (most of the Palace Music catalogue)
column4: and collaborated with Tortoise (The Brave and the Bold)
column5: to start. But his work with the Cairo Gang-- which is to say
column6: with the guitarist
column7: singer
column8: and songwriter Emmett Kelly-- has felt like an especially fruitful era
column9: and ""Island Brothers"" embodies why: Oldham
column10: in his trademark yelp-croon
column11: sings of hard times while Kelly and the rest of the band roll out raucous country-rock riffs
column12: buoyed by swooning vocal harmonies and an occasional horn solo. Oldham might be singing about sadness
column13: but the instrumentation suggests hope
column14: and ""Island Brothers"" is more about support (and community) than unfettered despair. (Metaphor alert!)

column1: ""Island Brothers"" meanders to a boisterous conclusion (check the otherworldly howl Oldham emits about 40 seconds from the end)
column2: and segues easily into ""New Wonder""
column3: a comparably staid meditation on the perils of good fortune (""What shall we do about the fact that some things/ Some things are so good that nothing can come after
column4: Oldham sings over guitar and tiny bits of piano and percussion). It's a sparse
column5: contemplative companion piece
column6: and an interesting-- slower
column7: bleaker-- counterpoint to the record's A-side.

column1: Island Brothers includes photographs of Haiti shot by acclaimed New York Times photographer Damon Winter
column2: who documented much of the devastation from Port-au-Prince (his slide shows
column3: which ran online in the weeks following the quake
column4:
are still remarkably difficult to click through). But the pictures are an easy reminder-- much like the songs included here-- to hold what you love as close as you can.

column4: Scritti Politti opted not for a picture but instead showed a breakdown of costs-- every element of the record's production itemized. This kind of fascination with and demystification of the rock process seems like an orthodox post-punk move
column5: very of its time. But it also revealed for the first time one of the unifying threads in Scritti's career-- an idea that things become more interesting when they're broken down
column6: and that what's on the surface can reveal that stuff
column7: not obfuscate it. As breakthrough single ""The 'Sweetest Girl'"" put it
column8: ""The strongest words in each belief/ Find out what's behind them.""

column1: Of course in 1979 the idea that a motley of squat-dwelling politicos like Scritti Politti might have a breakthrough single-- let alone a three-decade career and a best of package like Absolute-- would have been preposterous. The motor for this compilation
column2: as its title and lopsided sequencing makes quite clear
column3: is Scritti's string of singles from their Cupid and Psyche 85 album
column4: produced by Arif Mardin. Most were hits in Britain
column5: and ""Perfect Way"" made them brief stars in America too. But even after a string of 80s revivals
column6: nothing sounds quite like them. It's that Scritti principle again
column7: break things up and they get more interesting. This is pop exploded
column8: fractured and rebuilt as a mosaic where almost every beat seems to have a different sound from the one before. Hi-hats
column9: triangles
column10: drum pads of every kind flicker across the mix for a second or two then never reappear. In fact the tracks hold together only thanks to Green Gartside's deceptively light voice and sweet melodic touch
column11: making songs like ""Hypnotize"" and ""Wood Beez"" into exhilarating sculptures rather than a swingers party for drum presets.

column1: Green Gartside's journey-- from post-punk ideologue to minor pop princeling
column2: then into productive obscurity-- is so interesting that a chronological overview seems an obvious choice for a best of. So
column3: perhaps inevitably
column4: Absolute is no such thing. After seducing you with mid-80s glitz
column5: it bounces forward to 1999's hip-hop influenced comeback
column6: then returns to the post-punk source before finishing with new material. This hopscotch approach can work oddly well
column7: bringing out commonalities as well as differences-- when the gossamer ""Brushed With Oil
column8: Dusted With Powder"" jumps into the similarly mazy but far starker ""Skank Bloc Bologna""
column9: for instance. But frontloading the candyfloss brings disadvantages too. ""Oh Patti (Don't Feel Sorry For Loverboy)""
column10: their slickest but also saddest song
column11: gets lost in the sugar rush.

column1: ""Oh Patti"" boasts a gorgeously ornamental Miles Davis horn solo
column2: and because Scritti Politti turns so much on Green Gartside's vision and intelligence it's easy to overlook what a fine collaborator he is
column3: with an ability to find just the right partner to make a good track special. There are song-transforming turns here from Robert Wyatt
column4: Shabba Ranks
column5: and Mos Def
column6: the latter on two tracks from 1999's Anomie And Bonhomie. Here Gartside's presence is more spectral
column7: his voice like perfume over a hip-pop fusion which has aged surprisingly well. These experiments worked because Gartside's concern for how a track's components fit also includes his knowing when to drop into the background. But it's a shame that Absolute misses the finest result of Gartside's passion for hip-hop
column8: 2006's ""The Boom Boom Bap""
column9: a love letter to the genre which is also one of Scritti's most enchanting tracks.

column1: To represent 21st century Scritti we instead get two enjoyable unreleased tracks
column2: the fruit of a recent reunion with 80s collaborator Dave Gamson. ""Day Late And A Dollar Short"" finds Green draping himself delightfully over Britney-esque mecha-pop. ""A Place We Both Belong"" matches a soul-searching Gartside vocal to an R&B slow jam bump. This grappling with modern pop could herald an intriguing new direction
column3: or it could be a dead end like 1991's brief go at pop-ragga (represented here by ""She's a Woman""). With Scritti Politti
column4: you never quite know.

column1: But no matter what Green Gartside's next step it's good to hear him still so engaged with current music. He is a publically smart
column2: well-read guy-- a rarity in pop then and now-- and it's easy to focus on a band's intellectual side when one of their most infectious and witty songs is called ""Jacques Derrida"". But Green's gift wasn't just to namedrop continental philosophy. Starting with ""The 'Sweetest Girl'"" he found an emotional translation of it within pop
column3: building catchy songs out of curiosity and doubt
column4: taking the collapse of certainties and turning it into heartbreak. For all its erratic sequencing and missing pieces
column5: Absolute is a joy: It works as a collection of often thrilling singles
column6: but it also succeeds as a history of Green Gartside's open-- minded approach to pop
column7:
and of his love of it.

column6: 000-capacity beast built for the 1998 World Cup Final outside Paris. DeVotchKa were there to open for Muse

feels less like a grouping of songs as it does an entirely different animal altogether: The film score without a film to call home.

In talking about a really good but largely forgotten record made 34 years ago by an obscure soul singer

column4: Telling the Truth

column9: untroubled style.

column5: and folk signifiers. A refusal to cleave to one particular genre hindered Wright's commercial prospects throughout his career

column10: spacious grooves of ""Nantucket Island""
column11: ""I'm So Happy Now""
column12: ""Indian Reservation""

column1: The final three tracks on this reissue actually predate the recording of Telling the Truth

column3: but the seriousness of his own compositions ""Africa"" and ""Lack of Education"" doesn't make up for their undistinguished presentation. By contrast
column4: Wright's insights on Telling the Truth proper may be mostly puddle-deep
column5:
but they're delivered with such beguiling charm that it hardly matters.

column1: Most talk of Light Asylum has been centered around Funchess

column1: Coviello's synth work and industrial beat programming is the perfect foundation for Funchess' outsized character. The drums sound formidably cold and heavy

column3: catchy synth lines. ""Dark Allies"" features a twinkling arpeggio

column1: Even though In Tension is a tense and tough kind of record-- at any moment
column2: it feels as if an extra ounce of pressure could crack it in half-- one of the record's best moments is also the most melancholic. ""A Certain Person"" isn't quite the brand of Cure-grade mope you might expect from the title; instead

column5:
but In Tension isn't ready to reveal all their secrets at once. Consider this a warning shot.

Though they've been playing stadiums for decades
column2: R.E.M. have never really traded in stadium-sized rock. From the release of the ""Radio Free Europe"" single in 1981 through 1996's New Adventures in Hi-Fi
column3: the band's most anthemic songs were always tempered by space
column4: restraint
column5: and nuance; even 1994's so-called ""big dumb rock album"" Monster was an exercise in skeletal glam and sly
column6: swaggering pastiche. When drummer Bill Berry departed the band in 1997
column7: he took with him the one facet of R.E.M.'s sound that no other band has really sought to emulate: a nervous
column8: lockstep grid that lacked the momentum to power a grandiose rock band
column9: but gave Berry's bandmates ample room to weave together the distinctive tones and melodies that have always been the heart of R.E.M.

column1: Since Berry's departure
column2: R.E.M. has struggled to retain both the consistency and the daringness of their first 10 records. After releasing the plodding Around the Sun
column3: the band attempted a ""return to rock"" with 2008's Accelerate
column4: barreling through a forceful but generic set and grasping at a raw
column5: aggressive sound that was never really R.E.M.'s to begin with. So
column6: it comes as something of a relief that Collapse Into Now sounds unmistakably like an R.E.M. album. At its best

column1: The most immediately striking moments on Collapse Into Now are those that sound like explicit retreads of previous R.E.M. songs. The minor key acoustic guitar and slapback delay-treated opening ""hey"" of ""Uberlin"" is a jarring callback to Automatic for the People opener ""Drive""
column2: distracting from one of Collapse Into Now's best choruses. ""Oh My Heart"" has all the trappings of one of R.E.M.'s haunting mid-period acoustic ballads
column3: but repeats itself into drudgery. Album closer ""Blue""
column4: with its abstract sing-spoken lyrics and Patti Smith-sung backing vocals
column5: plays out like an awkward and lifeless re-imagining of New Adventures in Hi-Fi single ""E-Bow the Letter""
column6: throwing into stark relief just how unlikely and remarkable some of the band's earlier successes were.

column1: Collapse Into Now also hosts some unlikely successes of its own; in spite of its discouraging title
column2: ""Mine Smell Like Honey"" overcomes a water-treading verse and ascends to a truly a majestic classic R.E.M. chorus
column3: complete with soaring Mike Mills backing vocals and jangling Peter Buck guitars. ""Walk It Back"" alone is worth the price of admission here
column4: a gorgeous and enveloping song that takes a step back from the album's dense arrangements and gives Michael Stipe's vocals room to resonate. It's wise
column5: mature and relaxed in a way that's subtly different from anything R.E.M. have done before
column6: and it is quite possibly the best song that the band has recorded in nearly 15 years.

column1: Bits and pieces from every great R.E.M. record are present on Collapse Into Now
column2: but the ease with which the band once combined these elements is now tenuous and hard-fought. Some of Buck and Mills's best melodic ideas simply get drowned out or rushed through
column3: and Stipe often trips over the idiosyncratic vocal phrasings he once commanded so well. A deadpanned ""20th Century collapse into now"" towards the album's end echoes the line ""20th Century
column4: go to sleep"" from ""Electrolite""
column5: the last song on the last truly great R.E.M. album. Fifteen years ago
column6: however
column7: Stipe followed that line with a self-effacing ""... really deep.""  This generous and deeply human complexity was often R.E.M.'s saving grace
column8:
even as they pursued counterintuitive and seemingly pretentious directions. This album is host to more such complexity than anything since 1998's Up-- but Collapse Into Now still sounds like the work of a band caught between old habits and new adventures.

column9: breezy folk-rock ruminations for a full band: Chasny has played it all

column1: Three more tracks on Asleep are instrumentals-- the cresting opener ""Above A Desert I've Never Seen"" the glowing ""Brilliant Blue Sea Between Us""
column2: and the curling ""Saint of Fishermen"". But Chasny turns in one of his best pop songs to date

column7: it actually works

column10: electric guitar chords drift through another harmonium haze. Chasny's winding acoustic improvisations eventually goad its slow roll forward. Majestic and lumbering
column11: the tune suggests drone wizard Tom Carter collaborating with young British guitarist James Blackshaw. Mostly
column12: though

column14: Asleep on the Floodplain is like a cohesive record not because Chasny favors any one style over another (he doesn't) but because he feels confident and comfortable with each look. column13: free folk or just plain folk? Asleep on the Floodplain triumphantly answers back none of those. Rather
column14: Chasny has distilled all of his impulses and obsessions-- slow drones and brisk picking
column15: solemn mumbles and cheery riffs

Though so much of A Hawk and a Hacksaw's Balkan folk-inspired music is tied to a particular sound from a particular place

column6: making connections between what they've heard on their vast European travels and the sounds of their New Mexico home

In their recent travels between home and abroad
column9: Barnes and Trost took note of an earlier bit of musical cross-pollination: Through Mexican soap operas

column14: with a stunning vocal turn from collaborator Stephanie Hladowski. Again
column15: you don't necessarily need to be able to suss out any of these stylistic differences or geographical vagaries to dig into Cervantine
column16: but you'll appreciate the expanded palette; their take on Balkan folk
column17: more clearly displayed on their earlier records
column18: tended towards the mournful and histrionic
column19: but their newfound influences tend to be livelier in tone
column20: and the blend results in the band's most balanced record to date
column22: boisterous and heady the next. Cervantine's 40 minutes feel far longer than they are
column23: which is to its credit; when it's over
column25:
as though you've really been taken someplace.

Recorded on a two-track I'd wager has a little dust in the works
column27: off-the-cuff feel of a field recording
column28: or a pick-up performance from a traveling band. The unadorned sound does a nice job of offsetting the turn-on-a-dime technicality of some of these performances; Barnes
column30: and their temporary ensemble knock out every one of their instrumental turns
column31: but their virtuosity never feels showy like a more sterile documentation of the same sounds might. When the central melody of hard-charging opener ""No Rest for the Wicked"" drops from a full-band romp to a lone accordion
column32: this inversion of energy proves every bit as thrilling as when they start to swarm anew. Each instrument is played with wit and tenderness alike
column33: and great care has been put into these tricky arrangements. There's strength and delicacy alike in these melodies
column34:
be they Barnes and Trost's originals or their reconfigurations of traditional songs.

But what sets A Hawk and a Hacksaw apart from so many other note-perfect revivalists is their passion
column35: which turns up in every note on Cervantine. That Barnes and Trost really love this music is clear
column36: but that they seem almost possessed by it makes for something else entirely. Just as their music goes far beyond mere imitation
column37: their performances seem to push past spirited
column38: compelled not simply to observe or replicate but to create as well
column39: driven by devotion to the sounds they've heard and the ideas they inspire. Though they'd likely be the first to tell you how much they still have to learn
column40:
Cervantine's ravishing exploration of sound is another step towards mastery.

Discos Fuentes is Colombia's pre-eminent homegrown record label. When Antonio Fuentes established the label in
column2: _Colombia"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Cartagena in 1934
column3: he also established the Colombian recording industry

column7: fandango
column8: and porro records in Colombia
column9: Fuentes that oversaw the collision of African
column10: Caribbean
column11: and Colombian styles that gave rise to champeta and some of the country's other distinctive musical exports

column13: the founder's grandchildren run the label
column14: hosting a massive collection of ringtones
column15: desktop wallpapers
column16: mp3s and CDs on their website.

column1: So building an understanding of Colombian popular music necessarily requires building an understanding of Discos Fuentes

column6: Soundway founder Miles Cleret collaborates with principle compiler Roberto Gyemant and Quantic's Will Holland (who lives in Colombia) to paint a vivid picture of the hot cumbia music stewarded into record by Curro Fuentes
column7: the youngest brother of the original Fuentes family that founded the label. Curro Fuentes produced most of these tracks
column8: and even plays on many of them.

column1: This music bears a heavy jazz influence
column2: and in particular a strong affinity with the big Cuban bands of the immediate pre-Castro era. Cartagena is one of Colombia's gateways to the Caribbean
column3: so the sounds of merengue
column4: plena
column5: and embryonic salsa all made their way there as the bands on this set developed their sounds. Group musicality is emphasized across the compilation
column6: though there are plenty of great
column7: compact solos
column8: such as the supple
column9: trad jazz-informed clarinet lead on Lucho Bermudez's ""Fiesta de Negritos""-- Bermudez was one of Colombia's first bandleaders to heavily absorb the influence of North American jazz in the 1940s
column10: and though his style wouldn't be out of place alongside Artie Shaw
column11: it works well with the chunky 60s cumbia sound.

column1: In fact
column2: listening to the whole compilation all the way through reveals a general tension between the old and what was then new-- they vacillate between using electric and standup bass
column3: accordion
column4: and organ
column5: and electric guitars make a few understated appearances
column6: too. One concession to modernity that's universally avoided is the drum kit. The beats are driven by percussion sections that are a lot of fun to listen to-- checking all the different ways the washboard-like güiro can lock in with congas
column7: timbales
column8: and claves to push a song along provides several enjoyable listens alone. On some tracks
column9: the güiro's role is filled instead by hi-hat on the upbeat
column10: which gives the songs that feature the sound
column11: such as Orlando Fortich's ""Yolanda""
column12: a funkier feel
column13: though none of these tracks strive for anything like what we'd think of as a true funk beat.

column1: That's actually one of the refreshing things about the compilation-- labels focused on 20th century tropical pop music seem to have become much more comfortable in recent years with straying from the Western funk-inspired sounds that originally sparked so much interest in the music of the middle latitudes. 1960s Colombian cumbia has its own effusive charm

column3:
and a set like this is a great next step for a listener who's ready to move past the old focus on funk and get into a different kind of groove.

Again and again

column24: utilitarian voices further than you'd expect by finding a serious harmonic chemistry in their vocals; two of these guys

column27: simple melodic idea and then layer on from there

column29: they usually extend their guitar fuzz to oceanic levels

column32: of all things. And in a different time
column33:
Parts & Labor could probably run a chance of scoring a fluke radio hit of their own.

The band has a fun
column35: and they never once move away from that sound on Constant Future. That's a formulaic approach to writing an album
column36: but it's an approach that works; every one of this band's albums is worthy of hard-drive real estate. Constant Future doesn't much build on previous albums

column10: he brought his sometime touring band
column11: the Violators
column12: into the studio to help fill out those songs that required more brawn. They also appear here.) It was a jump to the relative big leagues that
column13: despite its cleaner approach
column14: offered more in the way of promise than focus. That's not at all the case here. As hinted at by last year's Square Shells EP
column15: a ""stepping stone"" to where we are now
column16: the sonics and vocals have been spit-polished to shimmer-- every sonorous detail can now be heard in full
column17: and Vile's voice has taken on a new
column18: mountainous presence in the center of each song. The conversation's grown far more engaging.

column1: What we learn is that Kurt Vile has a lot to say. He can be quick
column2: as on the strong-jawed
column3: electric groove of ""Puppet to the Man""
column4: when he opens
column5: ""I bet by now you probably think I'm a puppet to the man. Well I'll tell you right now
column6: you best believe that I am."" And he can yank your heart out
column7: as he does a number of times here
column8: perhaps most memorably amid the celestial fingerpicking of ""Baby's Arms""
column9: when he tries convincing himself that
column10: he'll ""never ever
column11: ever be alone."" But he's actually always alone here. Vile's lonesome brand of melancholia is still communicated both plainly and unassumingly enough to be missed
column12: but its that sense that he seems to be talking only to himself that lends these songs such magnetic pull. Between the two seismic chords of ""Ghost Town"" this album's bulldozing climax
column13: Vile wonders aloud
column14: ""think I'll never leave my couch again
column15: because when I'm out
column16: I'm away in my mind. Christ was born
column17: I was there. You know me
column18: I'm around. I got friends
column19: hey wait
column22: I am trying."" Although he stretches those last two or three notes
column23: it doesn't feel like he's singing. We're eavesdropping on the most private of dialogs.

column1: Sonically and compositionally
column2: Vile allows us the space to do that. He's still cycling between strummers and fingerpicked mazework
column3: but the battery of pedal effects is mostly gone. Rather than stitch loop to loop to loop
column4: Vile's given every marvelous
column5: carefully placed layer all kinds of room to aerate. In the past
column6: ""Peeping Tomboy"" may have sunk halfway through its bridge
column7: while single ""In My Time"" probably would have lost its way mid-jam. But here
column8: Vile has acknowledged limits in length for the sake of depth. It makes for a full-blown journey. Though there isn't an earworm like ""Freeway""-- that endlessly replayable
column9: interstate love song from Vile's 2008 Constant Hitmaker LP-- Smoke Rings isn't that kind of listen. This feels like a family of songs
column10: one whose complexion and course changes as a whole with every spin. In the closing moments of ""Ghost Town""
column11: Vile leaves us with
column12: ""Raindrops might fall on my head sometimes
column13: but I don't pay 'em any mind. Then again
column14:
I guess it ain't always that way."" He knows exactly what he's trying to say.

column5: Crooked I

The musical story of Jeremiah Lockwood is almost hard to believe. It reads as though someone stuck a bunch of National Geographic articles in a blender and hit puree. His early musical development was guided by his grandfather
column3: a Jewish cantor
column4: and Carolina Slim
column5: a well-known blues guitarist. That's an interesting mix right there

column8: electronic music
column9: and Balkan brass music
column10: and during a trip to Mali to play the Festival of the Desert

column3: Tom Waits collaborator Colin Stetson

column5: and for <i>The House Of Friendly Ghosts
column6: Vol. 1

She's arguably even better on ""Hey Ha Youba""

column7: Lockwood's dry guitar

column1: On other songs
column2: Lockwood sings lead
column3: and he has a diverse style that's heavily informed by cantorial singing
column4: a melismatic style not terribly far removed from the Arabic approach that influenced Arby. On album closer ""Shalom Aleichem""
column5: he sings in Hebrew
column6: but he uses the style while singing in English on other songs
column7: which can be a little jarring-- the singing style was designed around religious songs sung in Hebrew
column8: a language that's spoken very differently from English

column1: The album is structured as a sort of combination song collection and travelogue-- nearly half of the album's 15 tracks are quick interstitials

Combining two previously released UK-only EPs with an additional five new tracks
column2: Dam Mantle's First Wave is a comprehensive introduction to the Glaswegian producer (real name Tom Marshallsay). Spread over an hour

column4: found-sound collages
column5: 8-bit-influenced electro
column6: anything that could be termed ""purple""-- sometimes all at once. There's an overwhelming amount of material

column8: though sometimes overly ambitious
column9: producer.

column1: The first third of the record collects songs from last year's Grey EP and finds Marshallsay at his most manic. Opener ""A Statue That Is Perpetually Unveiled"" contains many different samples running at different speeds-- flurrying synths
column2: errant ticks and drums

column4: forgotten Disney  score. Some insidious G-funk anchors ""Rebong""

column1: First Wave's second act focuses heavily on the ""purple"" sound that Bristol's Joker and his compatriots have been fostering. ""Theatre"" and ""Purple Arrow""
column2: in particular
column3: rely on that sound's tweaked-up synths and refined  low-end. Most of the time
column4: Marshallsay is tearing everything apart
column5: attempting to cobble  together something entirely different with the debris. Unlike Joker
column6: Marshallsay jam-packs his songs with so many  different little details that the music becomes  cluttered. There's a sense of relief when he takes the deconstructed route on a few of the brand new songs
column7: crafting two terrifically ruminative tracks (""The March of the Prince"" and ""Beaching Loom"") that stand out simply because of their ability to breathe a little.

column1: There's no denying that Dam Mantle is constantly looking for ways to shift and alter his sound
column2: often at the expense of a  reliable groove or palatable bounce. But right now
column3: it's more about  exploration and figuring out how things work than just hitting the sweet  spots. He's too busy trying to crack these songs open and shake out what's  inside. Unfortunately
column4:
the music often sounds just plain busy because of it. But First Wave suggests he's close to finding some kind of harmony. Don't be surprised if he strikes the right kind of balance sometime very soon.

Yellowbirds is the solo project of Sam Cohen
column2: who for the past decade has been a member of Apollo Sunshine
column3: a Boston-born
column4: now-scattered band that's produced three great albums of willfully chaotic and eclectic indie rock. Their story has been one of gradual maturation: starting out with a rather simple binary-- power-pop collides head-on with barely controlled outbursts of noisy jamming-- and then refining it to the point where their last album
column5: 2008's Shall Noise Upon
column6: felt like a work of real vision even as it branched out in 10 different directions at once.

column1: Cohen's solo work is a little more focused stylistically. There aren't any competing personalities here
column2: and that leads him to a more conventional but still satisfying style that colors sweepingly melodic rock with a country tinge. Some of Apollo Sunshine's chaos pops up in subtle ways

column4: but it still has an endearing raggedness that makes it feel as though Cohen invited you into his living room. Cohen's self-harmonization recalls the organic
column5: warm imprecision of the Band

column2: gorgeous pedal steel playing
column3: and a climactic mid-section that pits his steel against his soaring
column4: distorted guitar-- it's like a highly refined version of Apollo Sunshine's pop/noise approach that more directly serves the songwriting. On the title track
column5: he sings at the bottom of his register and reminds me a bit of Lee Hazlewood
column6: and the song lives at roughly the same stylistic intersection as Hazlewood's music.

column1: The Color is ultimately the sound of Cohen exploring what he can do on his own
column2: layering and trying different juxtapositions of instruments and tones while writing some of his most straightforwardly accessible songs yet. His long-time band's flair for experimentation in a pop context is even more thoroughly integrated here-- see the way the main hook of ""The Honest Ocean"" is a bizarrely queasy melody played simultaneously on a guitar and a Moog. It's a good album that manages to construct a unique world in just a half hour
column3:
and I get the sense that making it was a learning experience for Cohen. It will be interesting to see what he does with the lessons in the future.

Fake blood

column15: exactly

column1: As a studio act

column4: though

The tour behind 2008's Microcastle/Weird Era Cont. still contained a touch of tension-riddled shenanigans-- one needed only to take a look at the other band members' faces while former guitarist/actual cheerleader Whitney Petty did cartwheels on stage at one of the NYC stops to know how they felt about it. The controlled blasts of power packed within their setlists

column6: like the descending
column7: drip-drop extended intro to ""Helicopter"" and ""Don't Cry""'s dreamy dropout. There's radical reconfiguring
column8: too: witness the metamorphosis of the title track to 2009's Rainwater Cassette Exchange EP

column6: sax-led ""Coronado""

column9: he breaks into a higher non-falsetto register
column10: like in the middle melodic turn of ""Don't Cry"" or during ""Hazel St.""'s ascendant peak; the effect is thrilling and easy at the same time
column11: and hopefully it'll be replicated in the future. Bradford isn't just a persona anymore; he's a performer
column12: and here he relishes the notion wholeheartedly.

column10: serves as a reminder for fans that missed out on the last tour and are desirous for thicker sounds: Deerhunter still have plenty of meat on their bones

column12:
they're not going hungry any time soon.

Frank Ocean is a 23-year-old New Orleans-born
column3: Beverly Hills-based singer who's in the gleefully hedonistic hip-hop collective Odd Future Wolf Gang Kill Them All. Frank Ocean is also known as Christopher ""Lonny"" Breaux
column4: a songwriter who has helped pen tracks for Justin Bieber
column5: John Legend
column6: and Brandy over the last few years. He's the latest  example of why the major label system is crumbling at the knees of  Twitter and Tumblr

column11: Ultra

column1: Venting about his decision to drop the record his own way
column2: he took to Twitter on March 1: ""i. did. this. not ISLAND DEF JAM. that's why you see no label logo on the artwork that I DID. guess its my fault for trusting my dumbass lawyer and signing my career over to a failing company. fuck Def Jam & any company that goes the length of signing a kid with dreams & talent w/ no intention of following through. fuck em. now back to my day. i want some oatmeal and toast. brunch swag.""

column1: The mini-rant sums up this singer's demeanor well-- openly passionate and heartfelt

column6: MGMT's  ""Electric Feel""
column7: and
column8: most surprisingly
column9: the Eagles' ""Hotel  California"". Ocean's experience within the major-label hit machine comes  through-- his casually hook-y voice is akin to Usher or Jamie Foxx's
column10: and at least three of the album's songs could (and should) slot in  comfortably on a R&B or even Top 40 radio station near you any day now. There  are distinct elements of Drake's melancholic paranoia and The-Dream's high melodrama
column11: too. But there's also a heady surreality surrounding  <i>Nostalgia
column12: Ultra that makes it unique. The cover-- showing a bright orange 1980s BMW (Ocean's ""dream car"") hidden in plain sight amidst lush greenery-- is perfectly indicative of what's inside.

column1: The record is held together by tiny interludes named after 1990s video games in which the unmistakable sounds of a cassette player rewinding
column2: fast-forwarding
column3: and stopping are heard. The old-school touch lends <i>Nostalgia

column6: fingerprint details don't stop there. On the brief  segue ""Bitches Talkin'""

column8: what the fuck?""-- not exactly the type of sentiment you'd expect to hear on any sort of R&B album.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Nicole Kidman's adulterous bedroom soliloquy from Stanley Kubrick's Eyes Wide Shut can be heard underneath the murderous ""Lovecrimes""
column3: adding a sense of manic dread. The film is once again referenced on the nightmarish
column4: Stewart-produced ""Novacane""
column5: which has Ocean losing his senses in the company of a wannabe dentist/porn star he met at Coachella. And if that sounds kind of ridiculous
column6: that's probably the point; the atmospheric track almost reads like a knowing parody of Kid Cudi's  fame-as-drug diatribes. The shout outs to Kubrick's mysterious and  lusty final masterpiece aren't just artsy braggadocio-- they make sense  within Ocean's trickily complex world
column7: too. Like on brooding highlight ""Swim  Good""
column8: where he steers his Lincoln Town Car straight into California's  crashing waves. ""I'm about to drive in the ocean
column9: he sings
column10: heart-battered. ""I'ma try to swim from something bigger than me."" He lightens up on the self-reflexive pop winner ""Songs for Women"" and the MGMT-sampling  Garden of Eden fuck ode ""Nature Feels""

column1: At 23
column2: Ocean is a few years older than his mostly-teenage friends in Odd  Future. And his maturity is apparent not only in his vastly more  laid-back style but also in how he deals with the underlying sense of  abandonment and rejection that ignites much of Odd Future's bloody

column6: the Creator on the title track of his album Bastard. Ocean grew up fatherless too

letting his guard down completely. And the fact that Tyler and Frank are smart enough to see their thematic kinship beneath all the aesthetic disparities bodes well for both.

column1: In those terms

column5: the more negative space to pit your steps against. And in evoking other stylistic side roads that don't slot as neatly into his post-funky precedent-- the Kris Menace-simpatico electro synths in the pop-friendly ""Chrysalis Records""
column6: the straight-up tech house nod of ""Recital (A Version)""

column1: But maybe the most surprising revelation is how willing Psutka is to use disorienting
column2: inside-out melodies as a front-and-center element. Think of the current vogue for warped and faded tape-jam sonics freed from its nostalgic VHS trappings

column5: woozy chords from singles like ""Drive You Crazy"" and ""Everybody Bleeding"" are pushed just a bit further out; the shaky-kneed hook that cuts in halfway through ""Liberation Front"" has the tactile sensation of an aluminum-rubber alloy
column6: all metallic sheen and resilient elasticity. At its most extreme end
column7: you get ""Barely""

column1: And yet it all falls together in that calculated way bass music albums do when they're simultaneously engineered for headphones and dancefloors. This is an album that sounds invigoratingly abrasive when you're moving and pins you to your seat when you're not
column2:
a study in pushing the limits of distortion that works as just plain good club music. And it's eclectic enough to anticipate a half-dozen directions for Egyptrixx to go from here-- odds are he's not out of surprises yet.

column1: Give Sharron Kraus' excellent fourth album

column12: too
column13: with madrigal harmonies hanging between Kraus' quaver and the bass-drum percussion of a funeral march. Kraus' arrangements used to be a tad predictable

column4: Lykke Li's biggest exposure was her song ""Possibility"" appearing on the Twilight: New Moon soundtrack. From a producer's standpoint
column5: her inclusion was a no-brainer: Not only was her debut titled Youth Novels
column6: but it captured the intense yearning of youth
column7: which is also an aim of the Twilight series. Few indie artists seemed as well poised as Li to vocalize Stephenie Meyer's heroine's point of view. As the singer herself told Pitchfork recently
column8: ""I like that age when you feel misunderstood and still believe in the pure idea that love conquers all""-- perhaps the most concise and astute explanation of that franchise's appeal.

column1: That is
column2: however
column3: only one aspect of Li's considerable appeal. As vampire franchises go
column4: she has much more in common with Buffy Summers than the shrinking Bella Swan: Li can kick serious ass
column5: yet even at her toughest
column6: she nurses a persistent desire for a normal and secure life
column7: which-- if her second album
column8: Wounded Rhymes
column9: is any indication-- involves intense love
column10: great sex
column11: and weird dance moves. Li proves a rich and compelling character in her songs
column12: which are dark but also complex
column13: contradictory
column14: and
column15: thank goodness
column16: still rough around the edges.

column1: Like Joss Whedon's show
column2: Wounded Rhymes is an album of stark
column3: scintillating contrasts: between fantasy and reality
column4: between the powerful and the vulnerable
column5: between the brash and the quiet
column6: between the rhythmic and the melodic. Audacious anthems jostle next to heartbreak ballads like ""Unrequited Love""
column7: with its simple guitar and shoo-wop backing vocals. Dense
column8: busy numbers give way to emotionally and musically stripped tracks like ""I Know Places"". ""I'm your prostitute
column9: you gon' get some
column10: she sings on ""Get Some""
column11: a come-on so blunt that it's become the talking point for this album. As a single
column12: the song brazenly grabs your attention
column13: but in the context of this album
column14: alongside such forlorn songs
column15: it becomes a desperate statement
column16: disarmingly intimate in its role-playing implications but also uncomfortably eager to shed or adopt new identities to ensure a lover's devotion.

column1: Rather than adjust or reconcile them
column2: Li lets all those contradictions ride
column3: having grown more comfortable in her musical skin. While there are no highs here quite as high as Youth Novels' ""Little Bit"" or ""Breaking It Up"" (and no low nearly as low as ""Complaint Department""
column4: though ""Rich Kids"" comes pretty damn close)
column5: there is a sense of cohesion missing from that debut
column6: as well as an understanding that a record can be a document of a particularly tumultuous time and place. To write these songs
column7: Li spent long months in New York and Southern California
column8: spending a great deal of time alone in the desert. The result is depressive without being depressing
column9: dark without being bleak
column10: as it rejuvenates
column11: refines
column12: and redirects her eccentricities.

column1: The biggest moments on Wounded Rhymes take the form of slower ballads
column2: whether stripped down like ""I Know Places"" or grandiose like ""Sadness Is a Blessing"". But they gain their power in contrast to the more upbeat tracks like opener ""Youth Knows No Pain"". Dropping some of the coy affectations of Youth Novels
column3: Li proves a surprisingly dramatic singer with a powerful voice and strong phrasing
column4: able to render the emotional pain of ""Sadness Is a Blessing"" as somehow exultant-- a transcendent state of being.

column1: Like any good vocalist
column2: she knows when to bow out and let the music speak for her. ""I Know Places"" cuts off early to set up a long
column3: dreamy coda that acts as both a quiet promise of escape and an album intermission that sets up the penultimate ""Jerome""
column4: which seems to synthesize every single emotional and musical urge on the album. Both ballad and banger
column5: the song sheds its elements until only the thunderous heartbeat rhythm remains. That moment bleeds into the finale
column6: ""Silent My Song""
column7: a nearly a cappella closer that swells and fades dramatically. ""No fist needed when you call
column8: Li sings. ""You silent my song."" It's a devastating statement
column9: yet ultimately an untrustworthy one: She has harnessed her heartache and her happiness to amplify her voice
column10:
not to lose it.

<div>
Papercuts' Jason Quever rarely raises his voice. The Bay Area native's one-man project began as a folkier relative to friends and tourmates Grizzly Bear and Beach House
column2: bands also making smeary
column3: drifting pop music informed by psychedelic harmonies of the 1960s. But unlike Beach House's Victoria Legrand's vocal smoke or the high-wire melodicism of both Grizzly Bear's Ed Droste and Daniel Rossen
column4: Quever breathes more than he sings
column5: as though he isn't sure whether he wants you to hear him at all. So when he abandoned more earthen tones for the reverb-marinated dream pop textures of 2009's You Can Have What You Want
column6: we lost a huge part of him. By muddling his mixes and softening his vocals even further
column7: he also made it difficult to know how to position our ears. Toward those long-gone vocals already headed out the door? Or at the impossibly curvy melody that was bouncing on our doorstep? Fading Parade
column8: his Sub Pop debut
column9: finds both coming together in one place. It's his strongest outing to date.

column1: We can actually hear the difference right away. Though opener ""Do You Really Wanna Know"" chains together a marvelous set of guitar melodies
column2: it doesn't really make its move until Quever slaps his chorus square in the cheek
column3: forcing the whole to thing to jump to life in a way that’s much more immediate than his previous sets of songs. He does the exact same thing with equally impressive force in single ""Do What You Will""
column4: a doe-eyed
column5: auto-harped beauty with a whale of a hook. A small fraction of this record sounds to be free of reverb and delay
column6: major portions of songs submerged for varying amounts of time. That's a lot of Spector-ized
column7: effects-driven atmosphere But it's also an interesting manner of balancing things
column8: as those moments when Quever has a layer of melody come up for air and back into focus-- particularly by way of his vocals-- are what really distinguish this album from earlier Papercuts records. This isn't music that breezes over you anymore.

column1: In a way
column2: Papercuts' addition to the Sub Pop roster makes perfect sense. While that label will forever be linked with the wet
column3: teeth-gnashing sounds of early grunge
column4: it also experienced a renaissance in the decade just past by releasing extraordinarily gentle records
column5: career-launching debuts from bands like the Shins and Iron & Wine. (Sub Pop snatched up former/fellow freak-folker and Gnomonsong label co-founder Andy Cabic's Vetiver project not long ago as well.) Quever's songwriting and presentation have been and can be similarly non-threatening to a fault. While a song like ""White Are the Waves"" and the rest of this record's too-vanilla middle third still express ""nostalgia"" or ""haze"" or the sort of semi-familiar ache that we as listeners associate with more amorphous and inscrutable songcraft
column6: it's not easily revisited nor is it really capable of sticking.

column1: But Quever has extended his transition into dreamy territory really well. In fact
column2: there's actually a sharp
column3: almost comforting amount of sonic overlap with new labelmates Beach House here
column4: particularly in the long braids of tremolo-picked guitar that Quever weaves throughout. And lthough everything about their surfaces could be considered soft
column5: all of these songs boast remarkably strong bone structure. The lattice of organ and Fender on ""I'll See You Later I Guess"" or delay-trapped droplets of ""Charades"" aren't just narcotic
column6: they're crushing. It's the quiet ones you have to watch.

Once in a while
column2: I can convince myself that it's impossible to say anything truly new in music. There has been so much music made and documented in the last 50 years
column3: my thinking goes
column4: that the best we can hope for is an artful re-combination of elements of the past (which seems like more than enough
column5: most of the time). But then I'll come across a new record that sounds like nothing else I've heard: I can't quite place it
column6: but its appeal feels so organic and easy to understand
column7: I don't really feel a need to place it
column8: either. Such is the case with the second solo album from Michigan-born
column9: Montreal-based saxophonist Colin Stetson
column10: New History Warfare Vol. 2: Judges.

column1: A few things about this record make it highly unusual. First
column2: Stetson generally records his pieces solo
column3: live
column4: and in a single take. Some of these tracks have so much sound
column5: so many cross-crossing and overlapping elements
column6: it simply doesn't seem possible that one musician is making them in real time. ""Judges"" has clattering percussion
column7: a menacing bassline
column8: and a growling lead element that sounds like an anguished voice processed in a strange way. Well
column9: the percussion turns out to be a close-mic'd recording of the instruments' keys being manipulated
column10: the low-end comes from the fact that Stetson plays the enormous bass saxophone and has a good sense of how to underpin a tune with a deep pulse
column11: and the lead voice is indeed his voice-- Stetson vocalizing through the horn as he blows. That all of these things come together at once in a piece that is compelling and highly musical is nothing short of miraculous. The key to Stetson's approach is that he uses an array of microphones placed in strategic places-- on the horn
column12: on his neck
column13: on the other side of the room-- and then mixes everything down into a churning cauldron of sound (engineer Efrim Menuck from Godspeed/A Silver Mt Zion and producer Shahzad Ismaily had their work cut out for them
column14: and they succeed brilliantly; Ben Frost is equally great on the mix). Stetson has also mastered the technique of circular breathing-- playing continuously with his mouth while breathing through his nose-- so that the sound can unspool unencumbered by his body's need for respiration.

column1: The record does bring certain reference points to mind. When Stetson really gets the circular breathing going and unleashes a torrent of notes the climb up and down the scale
column2: fans of free improv might think of solo material by players like Peter Brotzmann and Evan Parker
column3: whose mind-boggling technique is put at the service of in-the-moment expression. But Warfare Vol. 2 doesn't sound much like improv or even jazz
column4: despite our associations of the genre term with the solo horn. These pieces sound composed and carefully ordered
column5: often closer to the precision of classical minimalism than the expressionism of fire jazz. And compared to someone like saxophonist/composer/bandleader Anthony Braxton
column6: with whom Stetson has worked (if you are a virtuoso on bass sax
column7: you're going to wind up working with Braxton
column8: who greatly expanded the context for unusual reeds in jazz)
column9: Warfare feels less cerebral
column10: almost like a ""pop"" version of some of those heady compositions.

column1: So there's no prior experience needed here. You can dive in and immerse yourself in the swirl of musical color that is ""From No Part of Me Could I Summon a Voice""
column2: in which Stetson's blast of notes
column3: many per second
column4: are recorded as though from across a vast stone space
column5: each one vanishing into the air in a cloud of natural reverberation. Or marvel at the way Stetson makes a track like ""Red Horse (Judges II)"" sound almost as if it had a breakbeat
column6: the slap of the keys on the instrument so pronounced in the mix you focus on the rhythm first and the texture of the air coming through the horn later.

column1: Reinforcing the music's connection to both minimalism and pop
column2: several tracks here feature the vocals of Laurie Anderson
column3: whose approach is a natural fit with this material. ""A Dream of Water"" features her clear and hypnotic voice articulating memorable imagery (""There were those who lived in the crawlspace/ There were people lighting candles"") over a grinding and relentless arpeggiated figure from Stetson. ""All the Colors Bleached to White (ILAIJ II)"" begins with Anderson's vocal and a swelling chorus of voices and then shifts gears to a hard
column4: noir-ish stomp whose deep tones can easily shake an entire room. Shara Worden from My Brightest Diamond joins the proceedings on a powerful and affecting cover of Blind Willie Johnson's ""Lord I Just Can't Keep From Crying Sometimes""
column5: a mutant
column6: arted-up blues that reminds me of the overlooked album of Ekkehard Ehlers
column7: A Life Without Fear
column8: the way it abstracts a folk idiom and boils it down to a central emotional idea.

column1: Like the rest of the record (and Vol. 1 is also excellent
column2: if not quite as varied or powerful)
column3: ""Lord I Just Can't Keep From Crying Sometimes"" feels like music I've been subconsciously craving without even knowing it exists. And though New Warfare Vol. 2 is easy to enjoy on a purely musical level
column4: as sound
column5: without bothering about the underlying ideas or any notions of how it's made
column6:
it's also a gratifying reminder that horizons of musical expression are so much more vast than prevailing trends would indicate.

When you write music criticism
column2: you're basically telling the world what you want and do not want to hear. No one has to listen to you
column3: of course
column4: but in the best case scenario you not only have the opportunity to make a case for or against a specific work
column5: but you also send a message to the reader-- possibly a musician
column6: if not the musician being critiqued-- about what qualities amount to good art. It's usually quite futile
column7: but if you're lucky and persuasive
column8: sometimes you can nudge the world just a little bit toward what you want. But sometimes that nudging just isn't good enough
column9: and you have to take matters into your own hands and actually make the music that you want to hear.

column1: To some extent
column2: that's exactly what the members of Mr. Dream have done on their debut album Trash Hit. The Brooklyn punk trio includes Adam Moerder and Nick Sylvester
column3: former Pitchfork contributors who have seamlessly transitioned from writing about music to actually making it. (They weren't the only Pitchfork writers involved in the record-- current contributor Matt LeMay mixed a few of the tracks.) Trash Hit sounds like the work of guys who have spent a lot of time thinking about rock music. Its balance of aggression and tunefulness is unmistakably pointed
column4: and the intense physicality of the record comes off like an indictment of modern indie rock's dazed wistfulness and polite
column5: fussy arrangements. The band's obvious reference points-- basically anything having to do with Steve Albini
column6: but most especially the Pixies
column7: Nirvana
column8: McLusky
column9: and Shellac-- seem prescriptive
column10: as if they're arguing in favor of more bands sounding like the ones that inspired them.

column1: The songs on Trash Hit mostly follow the basic template for alt-rock established by Black Francis and Kurt Cobain: Hard hitting drums by Sylvester
column2: sardonic yet highly expressive vocals by Moerder
column3: and thick
column4: rumbling bass lines by Matt Morello. Moerder's bitter sense of humor and the band's cold precision give the album a distant
column5: cerebral vibe
column6: but the sound of the music is especially brutal. At their best
column7: Mr. Dream sound like a huge
column8: incredibly smart dude who wants to beat the shit out of you. That said
column9: they can go a bit overboard with the violent intensity. The hooks in ""Walter"" and ""King Klutz"" get drowned out by the band's frenzied pace
column10: while ""Shotgun Tricks"" gets bogged down by a bass line that's just a bit too leaden.

column1: There are moments on Trash Hit when Mr. Dream's approach to 1990s rock gets weirdly academic. ""Holy Name""
column2: for example
column3: sounds as if they are deliberately fucking with their audience by seeming to mash up Nirvana's ""Lounge Act"" and ""Polly"" before going on tangents that call back to the Pixies' ""Debaser"" and Guided By Voices' ""Postal Blowfish"". The song has a bizarre effect-- it plays off of a listener's familiarity with well-known songs like a Girl Talk production
column4: but constantly disrupts expectations by shifting off into something else before settling into a groove.

column1: Mr. Dream have mastered the tricks of alt-rock enough to play these sorts of formal games
column2: but that isn't nearly as satisfying as when they push themselves outside of their wry
column3: cynical comfort zone and hit upon something more nakedly emotional. The Morello-sung track ""Scarred For Life"" evokes tragedy and regret while barreling forward with great urgency
column4: while ""Unfinished Business"" has a bouncy
column5: excited chorus that sounds more like a smile than a smirk. ""Learn the Language""
column6: the album's final track
column7: offers the most promise for the band's future. The song boils their fierce rhythmic attack down to a lumbering heavy metal thud
column8: all the while building up to the record's most powerful moment of catharsis as Moerder belts out the line
column9: ""Heaven is just a zipcode."" All three members of the band turn in their finest performance on this track
column10: but Moerder in particular is a revelation. He's hardly holding back on the other songs
column11: but in ""Learn the Language"" he cuts loose at full strength and it's a total thrill. Consider this a gentle critical nudge: More of this
column12:
please.

Modern Skirts are the platonic ideal of a certain kind of college town band. You know the type: They've been described to you as ""y'know
column2: fun... kinda pop-y
column3: odds are you know someone who made out with the drummer
column4: and they're humbly ambitious in a way that suggests local royalty is an acceptable endpoint. At least that was true of the Athens
column5: Ga.
column6: group on their Rooney-fied 2005 debut
column7: Catalogue of Generous Men
column8: a document of ""O.C.""-era indie rock frozen in amber
column9: or at least the sickly yellow of Natty Lite. But whether it was due to encroaching national attention
column10: a desire to honor the daunting musical legacy of their city
column11: or both
column12: 2009's All of Us in Our Night found them focusing on artistic heft rather than accessibility. They acted as if the two were mutually exclusive
column13: and wound up with not much of either.

column1: The band's third LP
column2: Gramahawk
column3: is pretty much a do-over in every conceivable way. But despite surface attempts to sidle up as MGMT running mates
column4: its sound and scope circles back toward the middle of last decade. It points to a time when Spoon-fed types like Tapes 'n Tapes
column5: Someone Still Loves You Boris Yeltsin
column6: and Cold War Kids were lumped into a formative blog-rock vanguard that wanted to front like a movement when it was really a retreat. So if you viewed Animal Collective
column7: lo-fi
column8: club music
column9: or hip-hop as serious threats to indie rock hegemony
column10: dive into Gramahawk's treasure trove of clunky aluminum synthesizers
column11: polite rhythms
column12: and sturdy Modest Mouse-derived melodies. If you doubt their commitment to serviceability
column13: dig how all 10 tracks forgo any sort of wild bender to clock in between 3:08 and 3:55. Or mock the drum machine clatter that underpins the endlessly spooling
column14: deadpan half-raps ""Happy 81"" or ""Under Bridges and Overpasses"" at your own risk-- Cake did have a #1 album this year.

column1: In truth
column2: ""y'know
column3: fun... kinda pop-y"" is a fairly accurate point. Since Modern Skirts are somewhat tuneful without being overly hooky and seem mostly concerned with bum romance and drinking
column4: Gramahawk at least maintains the familiarity and affability of a talkative house party guest. But as such
column5: its tolerability is inversely proportional to its extroversion. Jay Gulley begins the loosely referential ""Jane Child"" boasting ""This heart is so gargantuan
column6: which itself gives two indications we're dealing with a heavy sense of assumed cleverness. But what's otherwise a nicely arranged hook is done in by his morphing his everydude drawl into a sickly thicket of harmonized falsetto. During ""Glass of Water""'s madrigal drone
column7: Gulley declares
column8: ""It hit me like I was playing rugby with the Thanksgiving Day parade
column9: the sort of wisecrack that probably rattled around its author's head until it made sense to nobody but himself. See also ""Shipshape""
column10: which promises a first date of ""a mariachi band and me removing your top."" Still
column11:
it's all so inoffensive and eager to please anyway that it's tough to get mad at Gramahawk or anyone who might gravitate to it. You just can't put a price on local charm.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16260/homepage_large.032839a6.jpg|Synthesist|29358.0|Harald Grosskopf|['Rock'
column3: Harald Grosskopf-- a drummer who lived in Berlin and had appeared on recordings by Klaus Schulze
column4: Ash Ra Tempel
column5: Cosmic Jokers
column6: and others-- holed up in the apartment of a friend in Krefeld
column7: Germany
column8: to record his debut solo album. In the flat he had a Minimoog
column9: a primitive sequencer
column10: an 8-track reel-to-reel recorder
column11: and a lot of time alone. Over the course of several weeks
column12: Grosskopf wrote and recorded the material that wound up on Synthesist
column13: which was eventually released on the venerable Hamburg-based kosmische imprint Sky. RVNG has reissued the album
column14: which is held in high esteem among early synth enthusiasts but is not widely known
column15: along with an additional disc of re-workings by some of the record's admirers (Oneohtrix Point Never
column16: James Ferraro
column17: Arp
column18: etc.) Between the original record and the new versions
column19: Synthesist offers an endlessly listenable introduction to Grosskopf's music that also serves a fascinating window into the sound of a specific time and place.

column1: In the liner notes to the set
column2: Grosskopf writes of how maintaining the Minimoog in the apartment was a nightmare
column3: and that the pitch would go flat or sharp depending on warm and cold it was in the space. He eventually figured out that if he placed a 60-watt light bulb near the synth
column4: he could regulate the temperature enough to keep the instrument sounding good. This image-- of new breakthroughs in sound-making technology having difficulty being used because of the of their surroundings-- is a nice snapshot of where music technology was in the days of analog electronics. These were the sounds of the future
column5: but they still existed in the physical world
column6: where things like air temperature mattered. Sounds hadn't yet been broken down into 1s and 0s
column7: where they could be endlessly manipulated without degradation. So Grosskopf's future music was confronting the same problems that had vexed instrumentalists for centuries-- how to keep the damn things in tune.

column1: The music on Synthesist hovers in an intriguing middle ground between instrumental synth-pop in the vein of early Kraftwerk and more free-form space-drone explorations popularized by Schulze and Tangerine Dream. The tracks are mostly compact and tend to hum along to a pop-friendly electronic pulse
column2: but they aren't tied into any sort of verse/chorus structure. Because of this
column3: the music has a floating
column4: airy quality
column5: always in motion but untethered by song
column6: which puts even more focus on the glorious analog textures.

column1: The record is divided neatly into two distinct halves. On the first side are the more tuneful tracks. ""So Weit
column2: So Gut"" hovers in a space between Giorgio Moroder's theme from ""Midnight Express"" and a Jan Hammer interlude for a montage on ""Miami Vice""-- there's a dark undercurrent pulling the bubbly keyboard percolations into some kind of nocturnal dread. ""B. Aldrian"" in contrast twinkles with nostalgia
column3: with gently shifting keyboard drones that seem designed to soundtrack a narrative about the benevolent wonder of outer space. The title track
column4: with its ""Popcorn"" bass sequence and overlapping melodies
column5: overwhelms with its simple beauty and naive charm. There's a sense of lightness and optimism permeating the tracks on the first side
column6: which forms a sort of argument that the electronic future was going to be a wonderful place.

column1: The second side shades that outlook and delves more in the realm of dystopian sci-fi. ""1847 - Earth"" is built around a metallic drone that establishes a sense of anxiety that is furthered when percussive keyboard sequences come in signaling something tense
column2: almost frantic
column3: while ""Trauma"" sounds like something fizzing up from an underground cavern
column4: the reverb on the synths bringing to mind the dark ambient spaces Robert Rich and Steve Roach would explore a couple of years later. Between the two halves of the record
column5: Synthesist offers a complex array of feelings and settings
column6: but it flows together and feels complete. Throughout
column7: is a sense of joy
column8: wonder
column9: and playful exploration
column10: even when the music leans dark
column11: as it often does on side two.

column1: The various versions on Re-Synthesist ask a simple question-- what happens when we translate these textures and ideas into the present? The biggest differences have to do with the presence of steady 4/4 kicks and a tendency to favor his moodier material. So Brooklyn duo Blondes take ""Synthesist""
column2: give it a steady beat
column3: and add a harsh alloy to the keyboards. Oneohtrix Point Never's ""Trauma 2010"" has a dramatic drone encircled by orbiting clusters of static and noise. JD Twitch from Optimo locks the synths into tight little phrases that border on the techno that would come a few years after Synthesist's release. And James Ferraro's hypnotic ""Wishmaster (Transcendental Overdrive Zone)"" strikes an imaginative balance between repetition and small
column4: incremental change.

column1: For the most part these versions are reverent
column2: which gives the record a nice flow for a disc from various artists set. It's almost hard to imagine a more coherent and logical remix/re-work companion
column3: since nearly all of these artists are already drawing heavily from the world Grosskopf inhabited in 1979. And while I can't imagine reaching for Re-Synthesist very often when Synthesist is handy (Grosskopf's drumming is especially missed)
column4: I am glad it exists. It's a bunch of artists celebrating a fantastic record that was a direct precursor of where they are now. They should be celebrating the original record
column5: given how much their music now owes to it and work like it
column6:
and so should anyone else interested in the sound of the electronic music that ushered in the 80s.

The Rural Alberta Advantage may be a humble
column3: charming trio playing ramshackle folk-rock
column4: but on their sophomore record they face a problem more often associated with gangsta rappers and superheroes: What happens after you've covered the origin story? ""The Ballad of the RAA"" aside
column5: Hometowns wasn't entirely autobiographical
column6: but whether giving a voice to remote outposts (""Frank
column7: AB""
column8: ""The Dethbridge in Lethbridge""
column9: ""Edmonton"") or detailing quotidian domestic inertia in ""Don't Haunt This Place""
column10: the experiences felt deeply embedded within them-- the proverbial record it took a lifetime to write.

column1: While Departing can't quite match its bolt-from-the-blue predecessor
column2: it's not for the usual reasons: There are no dubious genre experiments
column3: no interference from a bigger budget
column4: no pressure of serious time constraints. Simply put
column5: the stakes feel lower here
column6: and there's an attendant lack of urgency now that they're no longer struggling to be heard.

column1: Strangely enough
column2: Departing sounds more like an augmented solo project than the work of the full-bodied band that toured tirelessly after the self-released Hometowns in 2008. Which is not to say Nils Edenloff isn't a capable quarterback: While the Jeff Mangum comparisons won't be going away any time soon
column3: he works well within the context of the band's sparely arranged acoustic rock
column4: his pointed lyrics and astringent tone hearkening to folk traditions that go back way further than In the Aeroplane Over the Sea.

column1: But for a band that relies on its stage instrumentation
column2: reducing Amy Cole and Paul Banwatt to bit players proves a disappointing and somewhat baffling under-utilization of resources. On Hometowns
column3: Cole's keyboards offered a quirky counterpoint to an otherwise handcrafted sound
column4: while her harmonies maintained a warm conversational tone with Edenloff. But on Departing
column5: her contributions frequently feel like mere cameos. Meanwhile
column6: Banwatt-- a drummer of stunning technical proficiency and inventiveness-- is far too often relegated to mere timekeeping. None of this is true on first single ""Stamp""
column7: the centerpiece that towers over Departing: The desperation of Edenloff's galloping strums matches his cry that ""the hardest thing about this love is that you're never coming back."" Cole leads the whooping holler of a chorus
column8: while Banwatt rattles off octopus-armed fills as if releasing the aggression that's pent up elsewhere.

column1: Although Hometowns felt more immediate
column2: the songs themselves tended to burrow subtly into your conscience. With a low-key charm
column3: the better moments of Departing do the same; ""Two Lovers"" and ""The Breakup"" begin Departing with deceptive titles-- the former is a spare and lovelorn shuffle in which Edenloff bays
column4: ""If I ever hold you again/ I'll hold you tight enough to crush your veins
column5: whereas ""The Breakup"" draws specificity out of seemingly mundane details (""Cut a line in the snow with our boots/ To split this city in two"").

column1: The relatively sparse and chilly tone of Departing ultimately feels less like a slump than a conscious decision to present itself as the wintertime counterpart to Hometowns' prairie summer. But in the end
column2: it's sort of like spending a bitter December night snuggling a pillow instead of a person-- if you can get over a certain sense of disappointment at what's not there
column3:
it's still quite comforting.
