A lot of Eluvium's music is really good
column4: especially the album Copia
column5: where he struck a majestic balance between his ambient and quasi-classical styles-- a mixture he'd been perfecting over nearly a decade's worth of releases. And it's not hard to sympathize with the modern musician's need to monetize everything to get by. But with such a slight amount of material to consider on these two new EPs
column6: which are really closer to what used to be called maxi singles
column7: it's natural to pause and consider what our eight dollars plus shipping (each) is actually paying for.

column1: On Leaves Eclipse the Light
column2: it's one standout track from last year's uneven Similes
column3: one lackluster instrumental on ambient autopilot
column4: one capably bloggable Four Tet remix of ""The Motion Makes Me Last"" that freshens up the original's drizzly climate
column5: and a watch-once video for the same track where buildings and overpasses scroll by slowly against a big sky. Slim pickings indeed. It is a frankly unimaginative package-- it seems like we're mainly subsidizing the pretty cardstock-with-cutouts slipcover
column6: or just financially supporting Eluvium's ongoing career. That's a perfectly valid
column7: even admirable
column8: reason to buy something! But if you come at this strictly as a consumer
column9: there's not much to recommend it.

column1: The Motion Makes Me Last EP is also slight
column2: but features more engaging music and is worth a listen for anyone. The title track was another Similes highlight where Eluvium's bleary singing was perked up by a memorable melody
column3: and Nick Zammuto's very Books-y remix/cover is the most striking thing on either disc. The vocal part gets even hookier in his clear
column4: precise voice
column5: which he places at the very center of the song
column6: breaking down the instrumentation into little whirring mechanisms around it. The two new tracks in between don't innovate
column7: but they deliver the goods. ""Crash Deconstructed"" serves up a big juicy piano theme
column8: while ""Remnant Signals"" does something similar in watercolor strokes. Together
column9: they nicely sum up the two modes covered on Copia.

column1: Still
column2: ""remnant"" seems like it might be a key word here. It's not like Eluvium is out of tricks: Similes
column3: for better and worse
column4: introduced a much poppier feel to his music
column5: and his new Static Nocturne album amplifies nature sounds into something noisier and more violent than we're accustomed to from him
column6: albeit still rooted in sweeping sentimentality. The leftovers and holdbacks on these tarted-up singles aren't charmless
column7:
but it's unclear for whom they're intended besides the most ardent supporters and strict completists.

Indie fans have been exposed to an awful lot of woozy
column2: effects-laden synths over the past couple of years
column3: almost always in the service of conjuring up some sort of hazy summer sunscape. In other words
column4: chillwave
column5: a tag that plays off of the late 1970s/early 80s French coldwave movement
column6: albeit while trading that scene's bleak seriousness for druggy innocence and relaxed contentment.

column1: The gooey
column2: out-of-focus synths that herald ""Open the Wormhole in Your Heart""
column3: the opening track on Warm Ghost's Uncut Diamond EP
column4: briefly suggest we're entering the dreamily humid terrain occupied by the likes of Neon Indian and Washed Out. Quickly enough
column5: however
column6: singer Paul Duncan breaks the spell with his sternly romantic voice
column7: and it's immediately clear there's more at stake here than Hipstamatic-tinted bliss. That's not to imply Warm Ghost are more worthwhile than most chillwavers
column8: only that Duncan and his counterpart Oliver Chapoy are taking the world (and themselves) much more seriously. The deep-rooted influence of dark synth-pop
column9: shoegaze
column10: and goth-rock will tend to do that for a group.

column1: Warm Ghost's debt to all manner of icy synth sculpters
column2: slow squallers
column3: and brooding crooners is certainly pronounced
column4: yet Duncan and Chapoy do a good job of finding ways to not sound like mere sullen reenactors. For one thing
column5: the artists they evoke are sufficiently diverse musically and vocally that Warm Ghost can touch on several similarly moody genres without sounding like an out-and-out tribute act to any one group (witness how the pro forma shoegaze feel of ""Resignation Rights"" gets undercut halfway through by Knife-ish synths).

column1: An equally important factor is the duo's general smeary
column2: indistinct aesthetic
column3: which is possibly its most alluring strength. Typically it's clear vocal tics and demonstrative melodic lines that are most likely to make a group appear distractingly derivative
column4: but Warm Ghost frequently skirt that problem

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
in blurrily lovely ways
column2: like how Duncan
column3: his words already fairly obfuscated
column4: slips into ecstatic falsetto for the chorus of ""Open the Wormhole"". Or the way drums and synths have just as much prominence in the mix as the vocals on ""Without a Dancer"" and the title track
column5: respectively. In essence
column6: they're applying shoegaze principles even to songs that don't bear any other similarities to that genre. By contrast
column7: the more straightforward pop moments here aren't failures
column8: but they do tend to feel more overtly second-hand
column9: particularly the Xiu Xiu-ish ""Claws Overhead"". ""Let My Angst Unfurl in the Water Like a Hound's Tongue"" (okay
column10: maybe these guys aren't taking themselves too seriously) splits the difference quite well
column11: delivering the structured payoff of pop while still maintaining a sense of disorientation and mystery. The same feat
column12: it should be noted
column13:
that the best chillwave also performs.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16230/homepage_large.c5c4e4e6.jpg|Laru Beya|29361.0|Aurelio|['Global'
column2: 'Pop/R&B'
column4: Andy Palacio unexpectedly passed away. He was only 48. Just a year earlier
column5: he had released an album called Wátina
column6: which brought the music of his Garifuna people to its widest-ever audience. His death left a hole-- the culture of his people had lost its most prominent ambassador
column7: as well as its most important modernizer. Palacio worked hard to bring the traditional music and stories he grew up with to a wider audience
column8: and in the process
column9: he updated the music
column10: mixing the traditional elements with modern arrangements and production. The Garifuna have no country of their own-- they're an isolated
column11: underserved minority in Belize
column12: Guatemala
column13: Honduras
column14: and Nicaragua-- and as a result
column15: their culture
column16: a mix of African and native Caribbean influences that traces back to the wreck of a slave ship off the island of St. Vincent centuries ago
column17: is always in danger of being swallowed up by the larger cultures of the nations they're scattered across.

column1: On Laru Beya
column2: Aurelio Martinez picks up Palacio's baton and runs with it. Martinez has served his people's interests in other ways in the past-- he was a congressman in the Honduran legislature for several years
column3: and the first Honduran legislator of African descent-- but Palacio's death convinced him that he should commit to music as a way to spread his people's story. He appeared twice on Wátina
column4: but here he takes the helm
column5: and if Palacio changed the scope of what Garifuna music could be
column6: Martinez seems intent on inserting it into the mainstream of global music. He has spent time in Senegal
column7: studying with Youssou N'Dour
column8: and N'Dour appears on the album along with other Senegalese musicians
column9: including members of Orchestra Baobab and hip-hop group Sen Kumpe.

column1: N'Dour sings with Martinez on album opener ""Lubara Wanwa""
column2: and the kinship in their vocal styles is striking. The modern relationship between Caribbean and West African singing styles
column3: born of centuries of complex interaction
column4: is well-known
column5: but it's interesting to hear it put so blatantly on display. Martinez himself has a weathered tenor that easily handles the rapid ups and downs of his melodies. Every song on the album has a traditional Garifuna beat as a foundation
column6: but from there
column7: the songs can go just about anywhere. Horn sections
column8: guests singers
column9: and small choirs
column10: electric guitars
column11: keyboards
column12: and bass all make appearances
column13: and the net result is an album that feels very much in the spirit of recent efforts by Manu Chao and Amadou & Mariam
column14: records that build off the music of specific places to create an overall sound that's essentially placeless.

column1: Placelessness actually becomes a theme on the album
column2: too
column3: particularly on ""Yurumei"". Yurumei is the Garifuna word for St. Vincent
column4: the island across the Caribbean from the current Garifuna homeland where their culture originally arose. That's where the slave ship wrecked and the survivors mingled with the local population-- they came to live on the east coast of Central America after they were violently expelled by the British
column5: who then colonized St. Vincent themselves. Palacio sang about it
column6: too
column7: and that melancholy
column8: nostalgic sense of loss seems to be a thread running through the music. Martinez may not be able to right the wrongs of the past
column9: but he does Palacio's legacy proud on Laru Beya. And by bringing this music to a world stage
column10:
he may also help secure his people's cultural future.

Touring last year behind Dum Dum Girls' full-length debut
column3: I Will Be
column4: Kristin ""Dee Dee"" Gundred stood stock-still in front of the microphone
column5: clad in black dresses and stark red lipstick. She strummed stoically
column6: rarely speaking between songs or addressing the audience directly. The shows were short
column7: sweet
column8: and intense
column9: even if the frontwoman came across as slightly detached. It was
column10: she said
column11: a stance born of her stage fright
column12: and it worked only because her songs were so catchy and excitably noisy. Claiming the stage for herself
column13: she conveyed a sense of calm and content
column14: which suited her tales about the thrills of monogamy and devotion.

column1: The title of that album implied a theme of transformation and realization
column2: and in 2010
column3: Dee Dee took her first steps toward becoming a more dynamic performer
column4: harnessing her stage fright into a viable stage presence. That development continues on her new EP
column5: He Gets Me High
column6: a collection of four tracks that reveal the extent of her talent and range. The band's musical palette is larger and more sophisticated than that on I Will Be
column7: and they make more dramatic and idiosyncratic use of the influences they wear on their sleeves. Just shy of 14 minutes
column8: this EP further distinguishes Dum Dum Girls from the other bands drawing from this same well of fuzz-pop influences.

column1: Produced by Dee Dee with the Raveonettes' Sune Rose Wagner and music mogul/songwriter Richard Gottehrer (co-founder of Sire Records and co-writer of 60s girl-group staples ""My Boyfriend's Back"" and ""I Want Candy"" fame)
column2: He Gets Me High runs a pretty wide range of moods and emotions considering its brief runtime. The energetic ""Wrong Feels Right"" finds guitars and drums racing exuberantly toward a finish line like dragsters down a deserted highway. Waves of staticky distortion open the title track
column3: which initially echoes ""Bhang Bhang
column4: I'm a Burnout"" before veering off in other directions. And ""Take Care of My Baby"" is an exquisitely mopey farewell to a lover that could be a tour diary.

column1: With I Will Be
column2: the talking point was the Dum Dum Girls' raw sound
column3: a combination of girl-group melodies and fuzzed-out Jesus and Mary Chain guitars
column4: but Dee Dee is a careful
column5: intuitive songwriter
column6: evoking complex emotions with an economy of words. He Gets Me High traces the arc of an intense affair
column7: starting with the shimmery excitement of a first night together and ending with the painful separation
column8: with a lusty ode to a lover's narcotic effect in between.

column1: And then there's the sped-up cover of the Smiths' ""There Is a Light That Never Goes Out""
column2: which Dee Dee sings as an epilogue to the previous tracks. It's a testament to the EP's sequencing and the band's rush of guitars that she can perform a done-to-death cover and still make it sound fresh and interesting
column3: with a barreling tempo
column4: grandiose guitars
column5: and Dee Dee delivering those super-wry lyrics. You couldn't pick a more obvious choice from Morrissey's catalog (either from his Smiths years or his solo years)
column6: and while it might have been more interesting to her take on a song like ""I Started Something I Couldn't Finish"" or ""You're Gonna Need Someone on Your Side""
column7: it's likely she chose this particular song to fit the EP's narrative.

column1: Perhaps the most noteworthy development on He Gets Me High is how Dee Dee is using her voice. Shedding the rough filter of the band's earlier material
column2: she sounds much more expressive and engaged. Whether investing a love=drug metaphor with new urgency on the title track or practically breaking down on ""Take Care of My Baby""-- she wrings so much evocative pain out of the word ""take""-- Dee Dee recalls the brassy authority of Chrissie Hynde and the sharp emotionalism of Kate Bush. She's a commanding presence on these songs
column3: showing more poise and nuance than she has in the past. Rare is the EP that sounds so crucial to an artist's catalog and narrative
column4:
but it won't be surprising to look back on this release in a few years and see it as pivotal in Dum Dum Girls' career.

Anna Calvi recently listed classical composer Claude Debussy
column2: filmmaker Wong Kar-Wai
column3: and Flamenco music as influences on her self-titled debut album. While none of these signifiers seem to directly shape her music
column4: Calvi's record feels like it has much in common with cinema and literature. She uses sonic textures to evoke feelings-- from spaghetti-western guitars to her lung-busting take on gothic melodrama. Musically she's indebted to a lineage of female songwriters from Edith Piaf and Patti Smith to PJ Harvey.

column1: The latter comparison is bolstered by the appearance of longtime Harvey collaborator Rob Ellis on production duties. His rangy
column2: atmospheric handling of the music is one of the record's standout qualities. While the sound is suitably bombastic
column3: Ellis also takes care to open up enough emptiness in the mix to allow Calvi's twisting guitar to snake with menace. On the strongest moments
column4: such as ""No More Words""
column5: Calvi pushes herself into darker territory
column6: as Ellis allows cavernous space to open up
column7: her voice and guitar sounding as if they are being played into a black hole. It's also one of the softest songs on the record
column8: crafting a coiled feeling when Calvi's voice quietens to a whisper
column9: hanging like a thread but never snapping. The restraint has an edge to it that feels provocative.

column1: Still there are moments where Calvi ratchets up the drama too readily
column2: and sometimes hams it up-- see ""I'll Be Your Man""
column3: which comes across as campy. More often than not
column4: however
column5: Calvi gets the balance right: ""Suzanne and I"" feels grand as it lurches from bare guitars underpinned by pounding drums into a skeletal breakdown. The delicacy of its second half-- ghostly
column6: yearning singing and spacey fingerpicking-- makes for a bigger payoff when the drums kick back in and her guitar doubles the vocal lines
column7: giving the ending a truly anthemic quality.

column1: On much of the record Calvi explores the pained romanticism of goth with references to the devil
column2: darkness
column3: and unrequited love. These passing allusions are reduced into something elemental on ""Desire""
column4: with its impassioned wail against loneliness
column5: as Calvi sings
column6: ""You don't have to be lost""; it's a rare moment of togetherness and empathy on an album where Calvi can sometimes seem cold. She dresses up in the same outer strength as Piaf often did
column7: but without the same sense of underlying vulnerability.

column1: Calvi's outstanding vocal tone and arrangements carry the emotional punches
column2: while her lyrics can occasionally take a backseat role. She never allows herself to sound truly exposed
column3: and this adds to a sense that
column4: for all its perceived boldness and big climaxes
column5: the record never seems unhinged or fragile. It can sometimes feel more like a series of controlled demolitions than something from the gut. But once you accept these shortcomings and give yourself over to Calvi's wall of theater
column6:
there are plenty of excellent moments to lose yourself in.

Eulogies' first two releases

column7: just after the birth of Walker's own child. And Eulogies third album

column1: The irony that a band called Eulogies has now crafted something of eulogy is likely not lost on Walker
column2: though he certainly doesn't let on. Tear Down the Fences
column3: while elegiac in its own way
column4: is by far the most varied
column5: energetic record Eulogies have made to date
column6: abandoning their mopey moves in favor of sharp
column7: densely arranged indie pop songs that shine brighter the less straightforward they are. Opening track ""Out of Style
column8: Out of Touch"" rumbles with the perky energy of a Vampire Weekend tune
column9: while the tumbling ""You Hide"" could be a lost cut from Eels' Daisies of the Galaxy. In fact
column10: Walker even sounds like Mr. E on many of the songs here

column12: as the Eels frontman is no stranger to grief. But unlike so many Eels records
column13: Tear the Fences Down is near pitiless

column15: Walker's voice hanging like a ghost over the robust
column16: almost aggressive clatter of the band underneath. ""How to Say Goodbye""
column17: probably the most beautiful
column18: affecting song here
column19: boasts a chorus of gorgeous

column1: Most of Tear the Fences Down is so lyrically ambiguous that ""How to Say Goodbye"" could easily be about a girl. But Walker doesn't seem interested in spelling things out-- this is a record made with a select few people in mind
column2: and that intimacy makes it engaging. Only on two tracks does he address the tragedy head-on

column4: with Walker singing
column5: ""I'm boxed in my happiness
column6: I'm falling down/ I want to surrender
column7: but I don't know how."" It's a weirdly helpless confession; in the face of another's tragedy
column8: he's confronting the difficulty of finding happiness in his own new parenthood. But most of the conflicted feelings
column9: fears
column10: and regrets expressed on Tear the Fences Down are calmed by closing track ""Little Else to Say""
column11: a simply stated epilogue. Clearly a children's song
column12: it's an autobiographical account of the slowed process of overcoming loss-- a big idea written for small people but
column13: like a good portion of Tear the Fences Down
column14:
one that registers across the board.

Mind Spiders-- whose self-titled debut was conceived almost entirely by frontman Mark Ryan during downtime from his gig in the Denton
column3: Tex.
column4: outfit Marked Men-- don't present themselves as a particularly careful or calculating act. Playing fast and loose

column6: where pulse-quickening legends Jay Reatard and (fellow Dirtnap Records alums) the Exploding Hearts never met their tragic ends. The songs on Mind Spiders are energetic but not in-your-face
column7: fun but not goofy
column8: sharp but not stifled
column9: wild but not boorish. In essence
column10: it's a rock record that pulls no punches
column11: and it's all the more endearing because of it.

column1: Mind Spiders define their sound right out of the gate
column2: sporting tightly-wound
column3: zoetropic riffs that sound blasted from sand-filled amps. There's also a touch of B-movie fetishism thrown in-- sci-fi sound effects are not just fillers; they carry melodies

column3: reminiscent of the kind of 1950s slow-dance moves that plenty of lo-fi dabblers have shown a weakness for recently. But like the rest of Mind Spiders
column4: there's something simple and genuine about the approach-- when Ryan is whooping it up

column6: when he slows things down or tries on a little psych-channeled blues (""Slippin' And Slidin'"")
column7: you don't get the sense he's mining for cheap nostalgia.

column1: Ultimately
column2: Mind Spiders is tailor-made for those of us who value that four-on-the-floor reverie above all else. ""Don't Let Her Go"" feels akin to Reatard's Blood Visions with a pop-smart bent
column3: and ""Neurotic Gold"" is... exactly that. ""One Step Ahead"" embodies the broken heart at punk's center
column4: taking a crestfallen turn without letting the rhythm slow-- a terrific little song
column5: but one that might have you sneaking a peek at your watch every so often. And almost right on cue
column6: in kicks ""No. 3""
column7:
a rocket-fueled Radio Birdman homage that makes you wish the record were twice as long.

""I need to get away
column2: David Dondero sang on his last album
column3: 2010's # Zero with a Bullet. ""I really need to get away from me."" As David Bevan pointed out in his review
column4: Dondero sounded like a man on his last professional leg
column5: a cowboy staggering with a bullet wound. He'd been in the music business for nearly 20 years
column6: playing in a variety of genres and bands before settling into a solo career playing dusty country folk. His warbly vocal style inspired Conor Oberst
column7: and NPR's ""All Things Considered"" called him one of the best living songwriters
column8: yet sales remained negligible over the years
column9: even after he signed to his protégé's Team Love Records. It's understandable that any artist might be discouraged with such a lousy return on his creative investment
column10: and at the risk of coming across as bitter or entitled

column1: His quick-on-the-heels follow-up

column3: is the artist getting away from Team Love
column4: from electric guitars
column5: from himself. In addition to returning to Ghostmeat Records

column7: he revisits an older sound and older songs: At distinct odds with # Zero
column8: A Pre-Existing Condition is an all-acoustic record
column9: relying on guitars
column10: upright bass
column11: and harmonica as well as shakers
column12: tambourine
column13: and caxixi. It's a rough-and-tumble sound
column14: no less sophisticated for sounding so spontaneous

The remaining nine tracks are covers ranging from Lowell George's trucker anthem ""Willin'"" to Elizabeth Cotten's ""Freight Train"" to ""Kiss an Angel Good Mornin'""
column3: a massive hit for Charley Pride. Unshouldering the songwriting burden
column4: Dondero sounds lighter and more engaged
column5: his signature vocal style lending these songs a loose interpretive touch. He even has the temerity to adapt Jimmie Rodgers' ""T for Texas"" for a cheap shot at you-know-who: ""Gonna shoot that dirty hipster that stole my voice away."" The song
column6: however
column7: can't really support the sentiment
column8: which sounds like a too-clever twist ending.

column1: By design
column2: A Pre-Existing Condition is a ramshackle affair-- not quite a covers album or a new direction. Instead
column3: it's an album as therapy
column4: Dondero's reminder to himself of why he got into this business and why he stays. For him
column5: music is a way to make sense of the world
column6: which is becoming increasingly nonsensical. Woody Guthrie's ""Pretty Boy Floyd"" sounds newly topical
column7: a Great Depression anthem that resonates during the Great Recession
column8: and he makes those final lines a very specific accusation: ""You will never see an outlaw drive a family from their home."" That's much more damning than the title track
column9: a health care blues that rhymes ""social Darwinism"" with ""capitalism."" As a protest song
column10: it overreaches
column11: but maybe it's his way of stealing back from Oberst. A Pre-Existing Condition likely won't win Dondero any new fans or convince any holdouts
column12: but that's not really the point. He's content simply to play for himself. The album may sound slight in 2011
column13:
but it has the potential to be pivotal if Dondero sounds rejuvenated on the follow-up.

column3: Mike Skinner and James Murphy both seemed like transformative figures: two charismatic producer/talkers with rhythm
column4: intelligence
column5: senses of humor
column6: and senses of gravitas. Both were innovators who existed at once inside and outside a pair of emerging genres (grime and dance-punk
column7: respectively)
column8: and both focused so fully on their own tiny corners of existence that they made those experiences tangible to people who only had the slightest idea what they were talking about. Now
column9: a decade later
column10: both are preparing to say goodbye to their signature projects.

column1: Skinner's landmark debut
column2: Original Pirate Material
column3: hit just months before LCD Soundsystem's ""Losing My Edge"" single
column4: but the follow-up
column5: A Grand Don't Come for Free
column6: arguably holds up better today. A staggering conceptual LP
column7: the record was a grounded and powerful piece of linear storytelling that found Skinner in a more challenging and ambitious mode. But in that album's wake
column8: Skinner adapated a much less relatable and charismatic persona
column9: releasing a pair of disappointing LPs that squashed his accumulated goodwill. The Hardest Way to Make an Easy Living was a near-fatal cocaine-and-tabloids tantrum
column10: an attempt to shed light on celeb-culture shallowness that simply wound up indulging in it. And Everything Is Borrowed was even stranger
column11: an amber-hued pastorale that made no sense at all. Now
column12: convinced he's got nothing left to say
column13: Skinner gives us Computers and Blues.

column1: A collection of lesser beats and hooks that somewhat returns to Original Pirate Material's sonics
column2: Computers and Blues sadly trades that record's wonderful sense of place for a foggy vagueness that leaves Skinner's insights mostly impenetrable. And yet
column3: after the last two albums
column4: it feels something like a return to form
column5: actually coming closer to the particular weird spark of Skinner's debut than anything he's released since. Even the image of the apartment building on the cover echoes the lonely tenement on his first album. And as a series of disconnected sketches with cheap bedroom beats
column6: Computers and Blues is not without its charm.

column1: But where Original Pirate Material empathetically chronicled the lives of its scabby potheads
column2: Computers and Blues mostly concerns their weed-hazed days-- including
column3: on ""Outside Inside""
column4: the frustrating inability to get off the couch. Even as Skinner toys with some truly dumb lyrical conceits
column5: it's a joy to hear him push language around: ""The fossiled remains of lots of ancient ways are buried or lost in every one of my mates' brains."" And there's also the genuinely moving ""A Blip on a Screen""
column6: a vulnerable and wonderstruck song about seeing your kid on an ultrasound screen for the first time.

column1: Musically
column2: too
column3: this is still recognizably the work of the kid who once mined rap and garage for everything he could use and threw the rest away. The beats are all endearingly awkward and homemade-- drums and horns and Bollywood samples tripping all over each other rather than combining into any sort of steamroller. A few tracks bring a nice garge-disco glide
column4: an encouraging sign that Skinner could go on to be quite good at actual dance music. The hooks may be uniformly awful
column5: but at least he's trying.

column1: Still
column2: nothing on Computers and Blues rivals even the weakest moments of Skinner's first two albums
column3: and it comes out at the same time of something much more encouraging: a mixtape called Cyberspace and Reds
column4: which Skinner claims is all music he's made since he finished this album. Cyberspace and Reds dips deeper into British rap than Skinner has ever allowed himself to go
column5: with old grime comrades like Wiley and Kano and Jammer stopping by to talk shit. It's fun
column6: for a change of pace
column7: and it offers no indication that Skinner's trying to make an important piece of work. If he can lighten up enough to make something like that
column8:
there could be hope for him yet.

column7: like a thief from the nighttime
column8: Smith sings

Of all the Krautrock pioneers
column2: Faust have made the most unpredictable
column3: contrarian
column4: and sometimes just confounding music. Their biography is pretty complicated too. Disbanded in 1975
column5: they reunited in the 1990s
column6: only to split into two groups-- both called Faust-- a decade later. One
column7: a rotating collective lead by founder Hans Joachim Irmler
column8: released an album last year called Faust Is Last that was thought to be a swan song but never officially confirmed as one. The other
column9: centered on founders Jean Hervé Peron (bass) and Werner Diermaier (drums)

column1: Given that confusing history

column4: is how solid it is. Not to say it's predictable-- looping jams shift into subdued mediations

column1: If Something Dirty has a weakness

column3: a Pink Floyd-ish psych-out

column9: which melts Swayne's echoes into crunchy feedback
column10: ending with a hard-cut to silence. That sudden stop is the only moment on Something Dirty that could be called a gimmick
column11: but it feels oddly right. A fade-out would be too easy-- better to bluntly suggest that there's more music beyond that final frame
column12:
and encourage the rumor that this version of Faust is far from finished.

Take ""Fragrant Nimbus"": Atop a wiry one-chord jam

""Why Won't You Talk About It?"" opens the set with in-the-red guitars and a drumbeat that seems to be endlessly on the verge of kicking in. Hiding behind a mask and a plethora of pseudonyms while working in collaboration as both spotlight-grabbing rapper and behind-the-scenes producer

column5: would seem to form the center of Doom's ample discography

column7: enough to rival another artist's career output-- the series is often discussed as if it were a sketchbook of Doom's production ideas that is less essential than official ""finished"" albums like Operation: Doomsday or Madvilliany.

column1: That's not particularly surprising
column2: but it is a little unfair. On the one hand
column3: the Herbs line mostly act as a compendium of instrumentals Doom produced for both himself and other rappers over the course of his career
column4: from his early 1990s days with Native Tongues satellites KMD to his 21st-century rebirth as monster-loving underground polymath. Casual fans might wonder why
column5: especially if they own the original rap albums these tracks spring from
column6: they need to grapple with this much previously released material in instrumental form. But these releases are far from just being DJ tools or freestyle fodder for amateur MCs. They offer a chance for anyone to revel in Doom's breadth and inventiveness
column7: to appreciate his head-spinning stylistic shifts as a producer by bringing the beats to the foreground. Make no mistake-- most of these tracks sound plenty ""finished"" even in rhyme-less form. And as a document of an underground producer's life's work (so far)
column8: the Herbs series is rivaled only Doom's friend and fellow manic archivist Madlib in both scope and completeness.

column1: The box slaps all previous Herbs installments onto 10 slabs of DJ-friendly vinyl
column2: while also offering a digital download of the full  series and bonus material for those rabid Doom-heads who apparently  didn't get enough with their first 10 doses (for this review
column3: I listened  to digital files). The bonus cuts include a 7"" with two slices  of lo-fi R&B nostalgia
column4: the tense trunk-rattler ""Constipated Monkey""  and the richer brass-and-organ 60s fantasia ""Project Jazz""
column5: their ""lost jukebox 45"" quality fitting the old-school vinyl single format  perfectly. There's also a whole disc of unreleased material that ranges  from the whimsical
column6: Muppet-sampling ""Humrush"" to the standup bass  showcase ""It Sounded like a Roc!""
column7: though most of the never-before-heard  tracks stick to the warm
column8: friendly
column9: jazz-tinged sound of the 90s  underground
column10:
rather than Doom's harsher psychedelic/futuristic outings.

Naturally
column11: 12 new tracks on top of 71 previously released cuts will only  be an enticement to mega-fans who decided to preorder this set the day  it was announced. But whatever the package
column12: whether this lavish vinyl  collection or the multi-disc mixed CD compilation Nature Sounds released  a few years back
column13: the Herbs are an essential buy for 21st-century beat freaks. Doom covers so much ground that it might be a little surprising for those who haven't been following his career for the last two decades
column14: with something to please both hip-hop classicists and  experimental-leaning b-boys on every disc. Do you miss the strutting  Meters-derived funk of 90s hip-hop? Find plenty of it here. Or the way  producers once shamelessly flipped classic rock/R&B chestnuts
column15: letting you revel in the original hook with the bonus of a punchy rap  beat? Well
column16: Doom does his own brand of disco editing on the Doobie Brothers' ""What A Fool Believes"" on ""Mandrake"". Are you a new-school fan of the tweaked psychedelic beatscapes of the Brainfeeder crew? Doom seems anticipate those as well
column17:
making the decade-old Herbs feel more up-to-date than you might expect.

Sure
column18: he's got his signature tricks
column19: and yes some of these tracks will  always feel like backing tracks in search of a rapper. But much of  Doom's instrumental output is varied and listenable enough all on its  own
column20: full of gorgeous (the weeping violin on ""Syrax Gum
column21: the fluttering  Spanish-tinged funk guitars of ""Chrysanthemum Flowers"") and often  untrammeled melodies courtesy of his original sample sources. He's  equally at home with lusher-than-lush symphonic soul homage and  disorienting krautrock-esque noise refashioned into neck-snapping NYC  minimalism
column22: a breadth which justifies the Herbs' status as stand-alone  product. Some tracks offer the kind of antic and hook-heavy funk-collage  that once made ""DJ records

column25: immersive background music. The  luscious detailing and wild sonic change-ups of the Herbs recall a time when people didn't necessarily need an MC to  appreciate the intricacies of a killer cut-and-paste job
column26:
when many were happy to lose themselves in the head-nodding repetition of a densely layered loop.

Now that the music on In Rainbows has had four years to outshine its launch mechanism

But we've all said that we can't possibly dive into that again. It'll kill us."" This wouldn't be the first time that a member of Radiohead publicly fantasized about disowning the album format

""Morning Mr. Magpie""  re-casts an old live acoustic ballad in a more anxious light

Techno labels earn no points for being versatile. When BPitch Control launched around the turn of the millennium
column2: it had one primary thing going for it-- a rock-solid identity. That this identity was owed almost entirely to the white-hot streak label founder Ellen Allien was riding didn't matter. BPitch was a totem for Berlin and for the pop-influenced wing of the microhouse sound. In the intervening years BPitch has forfeited its hyper-focused creative identity in favor of a friends-and-family approach. This has allowed Allien freedom to cultivate her own personal techno sphere incorporating a wide range of artists and styles-- the Boogybytes mix series has been successful
column3: for the most part-- but it has also hinted at the type of slow decay that this approach can foster. In the last few years especially it has seemed that Allien and BPitch have done everything just a little bit wrong
column4: and so it goes with Werkschau
column5: the label's latest compilation
column6: a label-spanning collection of unreleased material.

column1: Werkschau (translation: showcase) isn't a terrible idea
column2: just an odd one: The label is not marking any significant anniversary or milestone. Seventeen tracks is hardly a vault cleansing
column3: but it's also quite a bit of music
column4: and no one really thought that BPitch was sitting on techno's The Basement Tapes in the first place. Werkschau will not stoke the flames under upcoming BPitch releases. But
column5: importantly
column6: Werkschau is fun to listen to
column7: and not because it offers a lot of nostalgic kicks. It is a ragtag collection of light
column8: effervescent techno
column9: one that features deft pop flourishes
column10: if few surprises.

column1: The selections on Werkschau clock in almost uncannily between four and five minutes
column2: suggesting that BPitch had some plan here: to showcase the best album tracks (as opposed to 12"" dance singles) left in its coffers. Allien is still the bellwether; slotted second
column3: ""The Kiss"" is one of her most house-indebted moments (no micro-)
column4: and much of what follows leans on that genre's warm electric pianos and familiar bass kicks. Simple genre placeholders like Zander VT's ""Gotta Look Up to Get Down"" and Kiki & Lenz's ""Morning Maniacs"" offer a camp around which the rest of Werkschau can settle. There are some surprises: Jahcoozi show up with an especially R&B-indebted take on trip-hop; Paul Kalkbrenner's ""Plätscher"" is dewy
column5: blended kosmische. The now-defunct Telefon Tel Aviv collaborate with Robin Guthrie for gorgeous
column6: strobing techno-rock. I prefer the slight
column7: vocal-oriented tracks (Timtim's ""How We Moove"" is reminiscent of the Notwist; Dillon & Coma's ""Aiming for Destruction"" is mildly sassy) because
column8: to be quite honest
column9: BPitch has rarely had the type of athletic
column10: focused producers necessary for longform dance
column11: Sascha Funke excepted.

column1: As a collection
column2: Werkschau features no internal narrative and offers no grand perspective on BPitch. (If you were to write a one-sentence bio based solely on Werkschau it might read
column3: ""BPitch was a house-y label with some good producers and some anonymous ones
column4: and that would only be about half right.) It's only minorly indicative of ""the BPitch sound
column5: certainly less so than the Camping series
column6: which began in 2005 (by which point Mark Pytlik had already noted a dissolution in the label's identity). The title implies something utilitarian and under construction-- fine. It's hard not to want more: a truer retrospective
column7: or some sense that BPitch is doing more than treading water between Allien releases (an album comprised of remixes of her last album
column8: Dust
column9: drops in March
column10: natch). BPitch is doing more
column11: of course
column12:
but Werkschau doesn't do much to highlight it. It's the rare album that is as impossible to recommend as it is easy to enjoy.

The interface between the voice and technology is central to Juliana Barwick's art. A Louisiana-born
column2: Brooklyn-based singer who previously released the album Sanguine and the EP Florine
column3: Barwick makes music whose raw material is almost exclusively her voice. But it's hard to know what she might sound like alone in a room. When she records
column4: Barwick layers and processes and twists her utterances into figures that can alternately be described as familiar
column5: soothing
column6: alien
column7: and tense. She might bring to mind the bright harmonies of Panda Bear or the mystical invocations of Elizabeth Fraser
column8: but her approach is her own.

column1: That's partly because her music feels homemade. We know that she spent a lot of time in church as a kid
column2: so it's tempting to think of her work as a digital update on sacred hymns. The heavy reverb and layering brings to mind cathedrals
column3: light refracted through stained glass
column4: some kind of surrender to or celebration of the eternal. But while Barwick can seem to be reaching for these grand themes and overwhelming statements
column5: there's something in her music that brings it back down to earth. It feels human
column6: imperfect
column7: and intimate
column8: and the line of communication is one-to-one. Despite her music's often epic sweep
column9: it can feel like she is whispering in our ears. So the sense of the sublime
column10: which permeates every note of her material
column11: ultimately works on a humble scale.

column1: We've grown used to following along with artists from their first demo to their first self-released EP to their debut album and then their breakthrough moment courtesy of a company that specializes in caffeinated sugar water. But Barwick works slowly and carefully. She had a little bump with the issue of her debut in 2007
column2: returned with a small-scale EP two years later that received a handful of positive reviews
column3: and has presumably been spending the interim figuring out how to make something even better. The Magic Place
column4: her first album for Asthmatic Kitty
column5: stands above her earlier work in virtually every way. She sings better
column6: the structures are more patient and enveloping
column7: the layering is more precise
column8: and she makes much more effective use of instrumentation. It has the feel of a modest classic of post-millennial ambient music
column9: the kind of record that sounds gorgeous and immersive on first listen and never loses its sparkle
column10: whether playing in the background or filling a room with its swells.

column1: One of the secrets to The Magic Place's enduring appeal
column2: the way it holds up to repeated listens
column3: has to do with that aforementioned imperfection. Though Barwick's essential tool is the loop
column4: she has a way of structuring them so they never seem too locked into the grid. They tumble and unspool and break into the silence like waves
column5: but they are not easily reduced to units of sound dragged from a window onto a timeline. The imperfection gives a feeling of instability to these tracks. So ""Keep Up the Good Work"" mixes piercing high-pitched voices that a friend compared to the malevolent siren calling distant ships into the rocks and then folds in indecipherable low-pitched murmurs
column6: hints of bass
column7: and a piano line that sounds like a bag of pebbles falling onto the keys. It rolls forward but with an unstable gait
column8: so the shimmering prettiness of the layers never feels too ordered and predictable.

column1: She takes a similar approach on ""Cloak""
column2: but the effect is less creepy and leans more in the direction of awe
column3: a mini celebration of the idea of ethereality. ""Prizewinning"" combines her high/low voices in loops that spread like fractals with a marching guitar/drum figure that bores through the center of the track and makes it feel a little like two complementary songs playing at once. It's in these moments
column4: where loops dangle and collide but don't quite line up
column5: that Barwick seems most indebted to the process music of Eno. The way the units of sound in Thursday Afternoon and the reconstituted Pachelbel of Discreet Music develop bears a marked similarity to the easy unpredictability these tracks present.

column1: Is something beautiful and ethereal that feels timeless and transcendent enough? What keeps Barwick from being the ""indie rock Enya
column2: which is the phrase that popped into my head when I first heard her music in 2007? It's not an easy question to answer. I want to say that the encroaching creepiness and human blemishes elevate Barwick's music above the soothing Calgon bath of new age
column3: but I'm not quite convinced that's true. I'm also not sure that it matters. Part of it has to do with where we are living now
column4: and how music functions in our lives. Complaints about the one-dimensionality of new age feel less relevant when we have so much music easily at our disposal. The Magic Place is music for a specific constellation of feelings. They are real
column5: many people share them
column6: and this album owns them completely. So while there are few identifiable words here and the titles don't really register
column7: there's a hell of a lot being expressed. We may not need Barwick to go deep into darkness or to write words that mean something
column8: because she has tapped a vein of expression that is rich and powerful and affecting and even useful. And for the time being
column9: the vein seems to be hers alone
column10:
though we can visit any time we like.

Although he had already signed with Sun Records
column2: Johnny Cash was still struggling as a musician in 1955
column3: taking gigs around Memphis with the Tennessee Two but not yet landing a strong hit single. To make ends meet
column4: he worked at the Home Equipment Company selling venetian blinds
column5: and it was his employer that sponsored his first radio show on KWEM. In May 1955
column6: he played his first show live in the studio
column7: and those 15 minutes are the centerpiece of the latest Johnny Cash reissue
column8: the second in what will hopefully be a long bootleg series. Besides the fact that he sings only three songs and Luther Perkins plays a short instrumental
column9: what's surprising about this short set is how awkward Cash comes across: As a musician
column10: he's confident and clever with that booming voice and careful phrasing
column11: and the Tennessee Two are just as energetic and tight as ever. Reading the ad copy for the Home Equipment Company's inventory of blinds and fencing
column12: however
column13: Cash speaks haltingly and stumbles a bit over his words
column14: peppering his commendations with odd pauses and rhythms. He comes off as the exact opposite of the cool
column15: smooth-talking peddler
column16: and maybe that made him a much more trustworthy spokesman.

column1: That radio program is an intriguing time capsule from an era when radio was much more localized when Cash was young and unschooled
column2: and it's almost a winking punchline that it's followed by an announcement for a concert in which Cash gets seventh billing. It's an intriguing glimpse of the artist at his most human
column3: before he became an industry. As such it's the heart of From Memphis to Hollywood
column4: the second volume in Columbia's bootleg series-- a reminder that Cash started out humbly before he became legendary (the radio show was also included on a bonus disc in The Legend box set in 2005). Nearly eight years after his death
column5: it's difficult to get any critical distance on Cash
column6: as his music is so wrapped up in his larger-than-life persona. So hearing him in this radio setting is a good reminder that there is much about him that remains unexamined and unconsidered.

column1: However
column2: that's really the only revelatory moment on<i> From Memphis to Hollywood
column3: which collects demos and rarities and generally reinforces common perceptions of the Man in Black. There are 11 solo demos that he recorded from 1954 through 1957
column4: but the only surprise is that ""I Walk the Line"" was originally written to be a dour ballad. We get acoustic versions of hits like ""Get Rhythm"" and obscurities like ""My Treasure""
column5: most of which are performed in a necessarily stark way that seems to prefigure his American Recordings albums. Some songs sound good in this setting while others are obvious demos
column6: but the percussive wallop of the Tennessee Two is sorely missed. It's actually refreshing that they figure so prominently in the Sun Records demos produced by Sam Phillips and Cowboy Jack Clement. It's obvious why the label signed the trio: These versions of ""Leave That Junk Alone"" and ""Big River"" percolate with prickly energy
column7: and Cash exhibits fresh interpretive range. He and the Two rumble through an abortive take on Jimmie Rodgers' ""Brakeman's Blues""
column8: which sounds like it's destined to fall apart
column9: and deliver a poignant version of Leadbelly's ""Goodnight Irene"".

column1: With a sense of organizational purpose and of local music history
column2: the first disc depicts Cash an artist hungry for success and willing to sell venetian blinds to get there. When he signed with Columbia records in 1958
column3: he and his family moved out to Los Angeles
column4: where Cash continued to record and dabbled in acting. There are many fine songs and many mediocre songs on the second disc
column5: which spans 1958 through 1969. There's Cash singing a taut version of ""Five Minutes to Live"" and waxing nostalgic on ""Send a Picture of Mother"". He does story-songs about outlaws and soldiers
column6: some of which are still wrenching (""Hardin Wouldn't Run"") and some of which have aged poorly (""Johnny Reb""). And then there's ""Shifting
column7: Whispering Sands""
column8: perhaps one of the most over-the-top recordings Cash ever made
column9: complete with narration by Lorne Greene
column10: best known as Ben Cartwright on ""Bonanza"".

column1: The portrait of Cash on this second disc is
column2: unfortunately
column3: fuzzy and poorly defined. It showcases everything we know about him and very little we don't know. His voice sounds just as deep and authoritative as ever
column4: his tastes just as broad
column5: his concerns just as grave
column6: but we've heard him in these settings countless times. There are no discoveries to make among these songs
column7: no secrets to untangle-- in other words
column8: nothing that adds much detail to our understanding of the artist or his career. That's not an indictment of Columbia's bootleg series
column9: which launched in 2006 with archival recordings that Cash made primarily for himself. That collection showed the private man away from the crowds and the cameras
column10: when he had a few moments alone. Hopefully there are more volumes on the way
column11: perhaps compiling his output from the late 1970s through the early 1990s-- a lost chapter of his life when he was considered old hat among Nashville hat acts and was banished to dinner club purgatory. That's a Johnny Cash we don't know very well
column12: and a glimpse of the casual
column13: private
column14:
work-in-progress side of those years would make him all the more fascinating.

column2: however polished the end product. Not that Phoenix's Thomas Mars is Marvin Gaye in the pipes department
column3: but he can honestly get across pop ecstasy
column4: even if it's the laid-back sort. Of course when you call your second album Wallpaper For the Soul
column5: you might as well be announcing that your ambitions don't extend much beyond making incredibly slick background music for the Adult Alternative set. Same as it ever was then on <i>The Past
column6: the Present
column7: and the Possible
column8: though as indie-as-background-music goes you could do a lot worse
column9: especially these days.

column1: Like many French bands
column2: Tahiti 80 mine heartbreak and hedonism equally
column3: and while their music may sound lovesick
column4: the overall vibe is also one of sun
column5: sand
column6: and good times. It's a trip-to-the-beach soundtrack
column7: in other words
column8: at least if the beach we're talking about is in Ibiza. Perhaps rather than a pop album
column9: where it pales
column10: it's better to think of <i>The Past
column11: the Present
column12: and the Possible as one of those (often French) chill-out comps that were everywhere around the turn of the millennium
column13: where it would be a stand-out. Plus compared to the glut of (mostly American) indie bands exploring a similar beachcombing sound recently
column14: Tahiti's grasp of basic songwriting makes them sound more like pop geniuses than pop wannabes. Like most bands who list the Beach Boys as an influence
column15: Tahiti 80 are kidding themselves if they think they've even reached a Surf's Up level of quality here
column16: but compared to the bulk of the chillwave crew
column17:
they're Phil Spector and Brian Wilson rolled into one.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16239/homepage_large.04013243.jpg|Discontinued Perfume|683.0|The Caribbean|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hometapes']|2011-02-23 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:33:55.801609|"

Even when you've already written about them a few times
column2: it's still tough to figure out a clear way to explain a band like the Caribbean. They're so close to being a straightforward indie rock band that it's temping to place them as some sort of prog-pop spin on early Death Cab. But they're not a straightforward indie rock band. They're half that and half something odder. It's not just the cues they take from electronic and ambient music; they have a strange way of constructing songs
column3: from the lyrics on down. Verses have no rhyme scheme
column4: chord progressions seem drawn from a hat. It's as though the band had all the pieces for comfortable indie pop in its possession but no interest in putting them into a standard order.

column1: This is of course what makes them interesting. They are bound to confound your expectations several times on any given album
column2: and if you're into that
column3: they're good enough at putting these weird songs together that they can pull you in with surprising ease. Discontinued Perfume is the band's fifth album
column4: and on this record they've struck a nice balance between building moody
column5: memorable songs and keeping listeners off balance. Acoustic guitar plays an important role on the album as a center for most of the songs
column6: but it's often set against pounding drums or noticeably synthetic keyboard sounds. Michael Kentoff's gentle
column7: high tenor
column8: wrapped in a blanket of reverb throughout the album
column9: acts as a sort of thread tying those disparate sounds together
column10: while the electric guitars take on a variety of destabilizing roles
column11: intoning with ragged melody lines
column12: atmospheric accents
column13: and even a couple of outbursts of back-masked squirming on ""The Clock Tower"".

column1: That song is one of the album's highlights
column2: making good use of a simple piano part to keep the song's momentum building. The back-masking is a nice lead-in to the dream-like ambiance of the next song
column3: ""Collapsitarians""-- the band clearly put some thought into the sequencing of the album. The title track generates a dreamy
column4: psychedelic atmosphere
column5: mixing the acoustic instruments on top of the electric ones and bringing in a strangely funky rhythm guitar part. The hint of funk sits in uneasy harmony with lines about people being wheeled away by paramedics. The album's best song is ""Artists in Exile"". It opens with an ambient recording of a crowded place (an airport?) but progresses into some uncharacteristically tight verses
column6: which are contrasted against what amounts to an instrumental chorus.

column1: By the time the song shows up in the tracklist
column2: you've been set up by the band not to expect such open concessions to pop craft
column3: so the unusual arrival of a strong instrumental hook hits doubly hard. This is one of the reasons it's important to approach Discontinued Perfume as a full album
column4: intentionally put together in a certain order. The Caribbean have never been what you'd call a singles act anyway
column5:
but here you need to take in the whole picture the band is painting.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16189/homepage_large.f5be20c6.jpg|Songs From a Toxic Apartment|29467.0|Ethan Gold|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2011-02-23 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:33:56.284610|"

The opening sequence to Ethan Gold's Songs From a Toxic Apartment is almost too fitting: a once-empty hallway punctured by a series of sharp footsteps
column2: the rattling of house keys
column3: and the opening and shutting of a creaky door. By the time the song
column4: ""Why Don't You Sleep?""
column5: gets to its soaring chorus
column6: it paints a perfect picture of the insomnia and desire for escape that color the album. While immersed in recording demos for another project
column7: Ethan Gold's physical health quickly deteriorated. He later learned his residence had been besieged by a variety of poisons before the health department considered the apartment unlivable. The titular ""toxic apartment"" was frighteningly literal
column8: forcing Gold to move his recording setup-- and the rest of his belongings.

column1: As the title suggests
column2: the album was recorded in full in his apartment (though thankfully not in the one littered with flakes of asbestos). You wouldn't know it from listening
column3: however. Gold's production prowess first came to the fore on Elvis Perkins' debut album
column4: Ash Wednesday-- a close companion of this record in terms of emotional and existential distress. So Songs is not so much lo-fi as it is low-budget. Nothing on the record bears the mild sterility of a professional studio
column5: while snatches of white noise and sounds from outside of Gold's living room window are subtly filtered into the songs.

column1: Naturally
column2: most of the tracks that make up Songs From a Toxic Apartment deal with toxicity in the emotional sense. On ""Poison""
column3: Gold's emotions are sent into a whirlwind as he asks for salvation and tries to stay motivated as the devil stares him down and his relationships are damaged by sex. The album has a childlike emotional purity to it
column4: but that's not to say that it's immature or naïve. Instead
column5: it's rooted in the fact that children don't obscure their hurt by anger or bravado or even mock diffidence
column6: as adults often do. Occasionally
column7: the songs are bogged down by grating lyrics or unnecessary bridges (such as on the breakdown in ""I.C.U. (Toxic)"")
column8: but for the most part
column9: the emotions on Songs From a Toxic Apartment are delivered with an unfiltered
column10: glaring legibility.

column1: ""Are We Recording?"" finds Gold tangled up in nerves and hunched over his mixing board
column2: facing his self-doubt with fears like
column3: ""We don't know what we're doing yet."" The fears exists even when he thinks he locates his artistic muse: He is quietly huddled in a corner
column4: softly strumming a guitar during ""That (Reprise)""
column5: singing
column6: ""This is what I am
column7: before letting out a long sigh. During ""Royal Flush""
column8: he compares love to an intense game of poker
column9: breathing in stale air and staring across the table at someone inscrutably surveying the five cards in their hand. Songs From a Toxic Apartment is a one-act play whose scenes are cast by one bright spotlight and minimal set changes.

column1: On closer ""To Isis Sleeping""
column2: Gold tests his use of dynamics by introducing countermelodies and pulling them away after a moment's notice right up until the dramatic finish
column3: as the instruments fade out into the sprinkling drops of water falling into the shower floor and running down the drain. And just like that
column4: the curtain closes on the toxic apartment
column5:
and you're left with your own four walls staring you down.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16234/homepage_large.d5bf2bbb.jpg|We're New Here|28552.0|Gil Scott-Heron|['Rock'
column2: 'Jazz'
column5: I'm New Here
column6: was his first of original material in 16 years and best in three decades. But though it was a joyful return to the living for the once-homeless recovering addict and pivotal figure of pre-South Bronx talking blues
column7: the album is defined by pallor. It's grim stuff
column8: built around Scott-Heron's ashes-to-ashes baritone and XL founder Richard Russell's skeletal production
column9: caked in grime and rust. It's essentially a podium for Scott-Heron's remarkable voice
column10: ever-wheezing and cracking
column11: that both supports and condemns his life choices with its grippingly dark magnitude.

column1: Jamie Smith
column2: percussionist and producer of the xx
column3: has become a minor celebrity of the post-dubstep Brixton scene
column4: earning a reputation as a DJ with his MPC mastery and as an ace remixer
column5: crafting memorable
column6: expansive edits of songs by Adele and Glasser in recent months. Smith
column7: like many liners-scanning millennial sound nerds
column8: is a massive Scott-Heron fan
column9: and at Russell's suggestion has taken a stab at recontextualizing I'm New Here in service of changing sounds-- you can practically hear him cycling through subgenres track-to-track.

column1: It's too dangerous to question either the necessity or the motivation behind such a project-- 22-year-old wunderkind cinches cred with resurgent iconoclast
column2: perhaps?-- but it will come up. Do your best to ignore the impulse
column3: because the residue of death that lingers on I'm New Here is wiped clean from We're New Here. It's replaced with brightness
column4: an energy
column5: and a historical milieu. Smith samples older Scott-Heron songs and works them into these newer songs. He takes a rare moment of singing
column6: recorded for but not included on the initial album
column7: and turns it into the Kieran Hebden-indebted ""My Cloud""
column8: a gorgeous and redolent centerpiece. He turns a broken man into a recombinant diva.

column1: Smith recently cited the likes of Rjd2 as both a pillar of influence
column2: and the music of his youth-- and you can hear turn-of-the-century collagists like Rj
column3: DJ Shadow
column4: and El-P all over his constructions. Smith also samples and chops unlikely vocal sources
column5: notably a snatch from Justine ""Baby"" Washington's lone hit
column6: 1963's ""That's How Heartaches Are Made""
column7: for the intro to ""The Crutch""
column8: before it erupts into a drum'n'bass burst. Here
column9: Smith's finicky
column10: hard-charging production trumps Scott-Heron's voice
column11: overpowering it with ideas
column12: if not focus. But there's a go-for-it quality to Smith's production that suggests fearlessness over reverence. On the opener
column13: ""I'm New Here""
column14: he lifts a quickened dash of Gloria Gaynor's ""Casanova Brown""
column15: giving the voice some shape and depth
column16: and slyly nodding to a polar contemporary of Scott-Heron's. This feels like quite a distance from disco
column17: and yet Smith shortens the gap between Scott-Heron's proud missives and exuberant dance music.

column1: Each experiment is a gamble; some of these spoken-word recitations were meant to be without a speed or brightened exterior-- a reconsideration of I'm New Here standout ""Me and the Devil"" is noticeably absent here. And this isn't a simple ""Is it better?"" proposition. The sonorous
column2: Bernard Hermann-esque ""NY Is Killing Me"" is such a far cry from the hand-clapping original that there's hardly any comparison at all. Only rarely does something like ""I'll Take Care of U"" happen. That song
column3: the closer
column4: is the purest distillation of Smith's taste for spacious melodrama and cinematic sweep-- it'd have fit nicely on xx. These two men only discussed the music here
column5: briefly
column6: in handwritten letters. That much shows
column7: though putting them in the same room is the next logical step both for Smith
column8: who claims he has no interest in a solo album
column9: and Scott-Heron
column10:
who is now back in the consciousness and ready to be pushed hard. Here's to reunions.

column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thrill Jockey']|2011-02-22 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:33:57.466400|"

When Arbouretum first formed
column4: they offered dusty
column5: dimly-lit folk rock that suggested a less mysterious Califone-- muffled drums
column6: Appalachian finger-picking
column7: tape hiss
column8: dark intimations in the lyrics. As time wore on
column9: their sound sprouted psych-rock fuzz
column10: which has since spread like kudzu to overtake everything. On The Gathering
column11: their fourth full-length
column12: there is precious little evidence of their former shimmering acoustic beauty. The only signal that we are dealing with the same group comes from their undimmed
column13: aching sincerity. This quality that once led them to burden an otherwise lovely song with the lumpen title ""People Flock Not to the Good"" now has lead singer Dave Heumann delivering brutal lines like these from a Jimmy Webb cover
column14: ""I was a highwayman/ Along the coach roads I did ride
column15: with a straight face. This stiffness wasn't a problem as long as their music provided nuance and shading. On The Gathering
column16: though
column17: the sonic vista is flattened out
column18: resulting in a dreary
column19: grayscale trudge of an album.

column1: It's a shame
column2: because Arbouretum show signs that they could be a great desert-rock band if they loosened up. The churning Foghat riffs on opener ""The White Bird"" evoke the right  time period and headspace
column3: and the pleasantly noodling guitar solos induce the proper middle-distance head-nod. Heumann's voice
column4: traveling somewhere between Jim James' ""Bermuda Highway"" and Scott Weiland's ""Interstate Love Song""
column5: enters high and hearty in the mix
column6: and the song cruises weightlessly along its proscribed path for seven minutes. Everything is
column7: momentarily
column8: in its right place.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: things quickly plummet off a cliff from there.  The fuzz-rock trance Arbouretum are aiming to induce needs groove to sustain it; groove
column3: in turn
column4: demands flexibility. And
column5: well
column6: you don't get much more rigidly inflexible of an on-record presence than Dave Heumann is here. With his strident vocals and leaden phrasing
column7: he lends all the swagger

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
of a Calvinist preacher to the proceedings
column2: and the effect is like Kryptonite to the groove.  ""There is a righteous band that's marching/ They're beating drums and even speaking in tongues/ They're passing plates along/ Clothed in garments of the sun
column3: he quavers on ""Destroying to Save"". Time and time again
column4: he hits his point so squarely on the nose that it hurts--  I know they're called Arbouretum and all
column5: but did he really need to sing ""Let's go inside the forest?""

column1: Sincerity
column2: by itself
column3: is no musical sin. But it makes a pretty egregious mismatch to the music Arbouretum have found themselves making. Queens of the Stone Age
column4: masters of the bleary desert-rock form
column5: found the perfect mantra to complement their sun-baked throb on ""Walking on Sidewalks""; ""I wish we could get away/ Drink wine and screw."" Sloganeering over this stuff just produces headaches and squinting. No one likes to be hectored when they're trying to bliss out. Arbouretum were once a very good folk-rock outfit; they might want to consider calming down
column6:
or unplugging.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16237/homepage_large.d392e047.jpg|Magic Trick|29099.0|Tim Cohen|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Captured Tracks']|2011-02-22 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:33:58.096935|"

As a lyricist
column2: Fresh & Onlys frontman Tim Cohen clearly evokes the early era of rock'n'roll he also explores in his music. His chord changes are simple without being rudimentary
column3: his lyrics are romantic without being cheesy
column4: and-- perhaps most notably-- his output is outrageously prolific without skirting inconsistency. Since 2009
column5: the Fresh & Onlys have released three full-lengths and handfuls of 7""s and 12""s
column6: all while touring regularly and taking a long enough ""break"" for Cohen to release his second solo set
column7: Laugh Tracks (following the limited-edition The Two Sides of Tim Cohen). After the praise for fall's Play It Strange
column8: you could expect Cohen to take a little break-- or at least wring a little more life out of a record that was released barely four months ago. But that is not Tim Cohen's way; instead
column9: we've been given the separate-but-simultaneous release of a new LP and EP from a good songwriter who can't seem to stop writing songs.

column1: The big draw here is the album
column2: <i>Magic Trick
column3: a collection that leans heavily on the well-worn themes of heartbreak and mortality. ""Love
column4: Cohen croons on acoustic ballad ""Legerdemain""
column5: ""is a trick of the heart/ A twist of the arm."" Rife with background singers
column6: a cascading bassline
column7: and subtle piano
column8: the song is reminiscent of Conway Twitty
column9: at least before the its thunderous
column10: noisy ending. Like Laugh Tracks
column11: Magic Trick is more restrained than Cohen's work with the Fresh & Onlys
column12: but the latter album is marked with a sense of nuance
column13: a likely consequence of its being his first LP since recording Play it Strange in a studio with an outside producer (Tim Green
column14: who has worked with the Fucking Champs and Comets on Fire). Spacey effects wobble throughout ""The Flower""
column15: while thudding
column16: muffled drums gallop slowly but majestically on ""Sweetheart""
column17: and the bouncy rhythm section on ""Top on Tight"" highlights Cohen's oft-unmentioned hip-hop influence.

column1: Bad Blood contains the same sort of attention to production
column2: but in smaller doses. Opener ""Delicate Creatures"" carries similar ambiance as ""The Flower""
column3: here bookended by ringing guitars. And while distant keyboards punctuate the EP's title track
column4: a little less focus was put into the sonic aspects of this shorter set of songs. Bad Blood is yet another solid set
column5: however
column6: often marrying feelings of struggle to Cohen's brightest pop numbers yet.

column1: Despite being so consistent
column2: there are clear standouts. ""I and I Will Be"" and ""Hey Little One"" are pop songs too bouncy for the driving garage of his main band
column3: but they fit perfectly into the grab-bag of styles featured in his solo work. Magic Trick closer ""I Looked Up"" is the highlight of both offerings
column4: with Cohen indulging in his gift for balladry
column5: building on top of something heartfelt and quiet with a climactic crescendo that includes a tempo change and a makeshift choir.

column1: Given the amount of Fresh & Onlys material already out there
column2: it's unlikely Magic Trick and Bad Blood will usher new fans into the fold
column3: but that's not why they exist. As Tim Cohen continues building his impressive catalog
column4: it seems he can't help but document the progress of his songwriting. Recording music
column5: collecting the most cohesive bits together
column6: and throwing it all into the either multiple times a year seems to be the only working process he knows
column7:
the magic trick that he never messes up. And fans of his work-- a number that seems to grow little by little every year-- benefit greatly by having so many of his songs at their disposal.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16225/homepage_large.a37e7691.jpg|No Witch|5467.0|The Cave Singers|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Jagjaguwar']|2011-02-22 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:33:59.557138|"

Seattle
column2: as much as any city
column3: has benefited in the past few years from a renewed interest in all things folky and pastoral. Shaggy folk traditionalists Fleet Foxes are the city's most successful band of the moment
column4: and Sub Pop is hoping to replicate that success with the more charismatic but also more conventional young outfit the Head and the Heart. Swing a banjo in that town
column5: and you're likely to hit any number of other equally rootsy bands.

column1: It's easy to see why this music could take root in Seattle
column2: surrounded as it is by fertile farmland and the natural inspiration of mountain ranges
column3: rainforests
column4: and scenic waterways. But it's worth remembering that Seattle is also a dark
column5: gray
column6: miserable puddle most of the year. Sure
column7: it's great to lay out in a field and strum your guitar
column8: but 10 months out of 12
column9: your ass is gonna get soaked right through. And it's a place not without its own (admittedly aerospace) rustbelt and daylight hatchet murders and killer cops and all the claustrophobia of city life compounded with all the isolation of the middle of nowhere.

column1: Which brings us to the Cave Singers
column2: a Rain City trio whose latest batch of rustic blues reflects a Pacific Northwest slightly less idyllic than their peers might lead you to imagine.  Cave Singers' Pete Quirk
column3: Derek Fudesco
column4: and Marty Lund came to Americana from
column5: respectively
column6: the seedy new wave of Hint Hint
column7: the grim punk rock of Murder City Devils
column8: and the opulent analog synth prog of Cobra High. No surprise then that some of those darker moods would show up in the Cave Singers' more stripped-down arrangements (and
column9: really
column10: you can only get so opulent on a floor tom).

column1: On No Witch
column2: their third album-- and first since leaving Matador for Jagjaguwar-- this dark streak is most apparent on the back-to-back songs ""Black Leaf"" and ""Falls""
column3: which together lend the album an early center of gravity. On the former
column4: Fudesco plays a circling electric guitar riff over a stomp-and-clap rhythm accented with flares of organ while Quirk rasps shaky and feverish. The latter slows the same elements down to a menacing guitar lope and backbeat then adds brass and gospel singers to Quirk's bleak muttering. The album ends with the desolate droning of ""Faze Wave"" and the relatively overdriven blues of ""No Prosecution If We Bail"".

column1: Not that No Witch is without sunshine. ""Gifts and the Raft"" opens the album with some untroubled harmonies and a fiddle jig muted enough to not sound corny. ""All Land Crabs and Divinity Ghosts"" is one long uplift
column2: floating Quirk's declarations of consequence (""it matters what you do"") on a light galloping rhythm
column3: sprightly finger-picking
column4: and a bright
column5: rising harmonica tone. And then there's the shorthand mystic drone and bongos of ""Outer Realms"". But even when their songs are at their most hopeful
column6: it feels as if it's in the face of some vague distress. The verses of ""Swim Club"" have a kind of easy
column7: ambling feel familiar from previous Cave Singers songs such as ""Seeds of Night""
column8: but then the choruses swerve into a worrying refrain (""the streets
column9: watch out"") set to a similarly downcast woodwind.

column1: Quirk has grown into his voice
column2: retaining his nasal sting while opening up a fuller and more flexible tenor
column3: while Fudesco's finger-picking and Lund's drumming are complemented by some of the most generous production the band has had. Like their revivalist peers
column4: Cave Singers aren't reinventing a genre here
column5: but they lend their local folkie scene a welcome dark side
column6:
and No Witch is their strongest album yet.
