column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16227/homepage_large.6ed20673.jpg|Fish Touch|29481.0|Pixelord|['Rap'
column3: Moscow producer Alexey Devyanin
column4: who records as Pixelord
column5: mixes 8-bit Nintendo snippets into quivering dubstep beats. That's where he is on this record. But as we learned when we spoke to him for a piece last year on the current Moscow beat scene
column6: Devyanin's output is wildly diverse and prolific. He has generated a substantial body of work in a short period of time as Pixelord
column7: and his previous work as Gultskra explores a much different musical landscape. Under that alias
column8: his sound was closer to early Fennesz or Gastr del Sol
column9: heavy on field recordings and abstraction. So he's fairly steeped in experimentation.

column1: On Fish Touch
column2: which puts four original tracks alongside three remixes from other artists
column3: Devyanin displays meticulous arrangement skills
column4: without which these familiar rhythms could be easily brushed off as mere copycatting. The stutter of UK garage artists like El-B and the ghosted vocal samples of Burial have been explored thoroughly in the past several years
column5: with varying degrees of success. What Devyanin brings to the table is restraint combined with an eagerness to blur the trappings of all these genres; his use of video game sounds adds a childlike sensibility that allows these songs to be at once ominous and mischievous. But there's a certain amount of coldness that is inevitable in his music
column6: which is so heavy on cultural references both literal and figurative. And that chill can be a bit confusing
column7: because even when there is harmonic movement and melodic development
column8: it's not clear what sort of emotion is being channeled beyond giddy thrill.

column1: With its maddening hi-hat/kick drum interplay
column2: ""Kiss Your TV"" throws down the gauntlet: Listeners have to make their way through noisy shards of glitch that cradle vocal samples from Lady Gaga and snippets of Russian dialogue about houseguests
column3: while the bass gets buried in echo. The hyperactive arpeggios of ""Cybernator"" give way to an 8-bit blip solo bookended by G-funk synths and decaying reverb
column4: and when a surprisingly bright bridge emerges
column5: it's only for a few bars. The drums here knock as tightly as a good hip-hop track should
column6: and without vocals
column7: something needs to speak. But what's being said is not always clear.

column1: The schizophrenia inherent in the four originals gets cleared on some of the remixes. Britain's Om Unit reworks ""Cybernator"" by picking up the pace with some electro drums
column2: layering those arpeggios over a much sparer template. Instead of squelchy interjections between bars
column3: there's room for the beat to spread out
column4: making the hook from the original feel fresher. The title track gets updated in two different ways; the better of these finds KidKanevil dropping a slowed-down Rick Ross vocal over a simpler beat that fixes Devyanin's bassline into a more traditional pattern. Here the squelchy descending pattern becomes more ""put your hands up"" and less ""stroke your chin
column5: and in this context that's a good thing. Pixelord has obviously spent some time sharpening these tools
column6: but at times
column7: this is a frustrating release
column8: hovering between house-party bangers and introspective bass worship. Still
column9: as the limits of quantized beats get continuously stretched and mutated
column10:
it's fascinating to enter the mind of a producer who doesn't hear the usual limitations and is willing to let his music travel in any number of directions.

When Sonic Youth established their SYR imprint 14 years ago
column2: the gesture symbolized something more than just a veteran act indulging their whims with a vanity label. It represented the point where the idea of Sonic Youth (as boundary-pushing
column3: confrontational guitarrerorists) diverged sharply from their reality (as a steady recording and touring act performing their ""120 Minutes""-minted ""hits"" for the alt-rock kids). And perhaps not coincidentally
column4: the decision to launch SYR as a outlet through which to explore their more abstract ideas came shortly after Sonic Youth's first flirtation with Hollywood
column5: having penned a handful of songs for the Richard Linklater/Eric Bogosian teen-angst document subUrbia.

column1: But while both their subUrbia contributions and their early SYR issue Slaapkamers Met Slagroom yielded material eventually reworked on the band's 1998 Geffen release
column2: A Thousand Leaves
column3: in the decade-plus since
column4: the SYR experiments have turned more imposing and impenetrable (live collaborations with Merzbow; improvised tributes to Stan Brakhage) while the Sonic Youth brand ever more eagerly courts the mainstream (Starbucks-commissioned compilations; ""Gossip Girl"" cameos). However
column5: the latest SYR marks an attempt to mediate the band's pop-vs.-art dialectic and
column6: much like their subUrbia stint 15 years ago
column7: the meeting ground is a teen flick. True to the series' experimental ethos
column8: SYR9 is a collection of amorphous
column9: atmospheric instrumental song sketches
column10: but created in service to French director Fabrice Gobert's high-school-set mystery
column11: Simon Werner a Disparu (or Lights Out
column12: according to Netflix).

column1: This isn't Sonic Youth's first stab at composing a full-length score
column2: but where previous efforts accompanied low-budget indie (Made in USA) or transgressive art-house fare (Olivier Assayas' Demonlover)
column3: Simon Werner a Disparu is an accessible
column4: if elaborately structured
column5: thriller about a series of disappearances at a French high school
column6: featuring an attractive young cast that could've stepped out of any prime-time teen soap on the WB. But beyond the band's facility with ominous soundscapes
column7: there's a tactility to Sonic Youth's music-- scraped guitar strings
column8: vigorously stabbed chords
column9: ghostly amplifier hums-- that easily lends itself to cinematic applications. Though I've not seen the film beyond a few clips on YouTube
column10: the music effectively conjures the film's idyllic suburban high-school setting and the disturbing dramas playing out within in
column11: recalling the California-hippie-dream vs. Manson-family-nightmare dichotomy that informed the band's mid-80s work.

column1: The album comprises expanded and elaborated versions of incidental music crafted for the film
column2: however
column3: even in fleshed-out form
column4: SYR9 can feel frustratingly incomplete
column5: with many pieces coming off as a series of loosely linked fragments lacking an emotional center. The band is liable to shift from chilling sound-effect chicanery to full-power rock-outs to playful piano plinking within a single track
column6: with no internal logic or recurring motifs to tie them together; the most immediately captivating moments (like the motorik surges on ""Alice et Simon"" and ""Chez Yves (Alice et Claire)"") tend to dissolve into a vaporous drift just as they're taking hold.

column1: But there are certain passages that-- in keeping with the spirit of the earliest SYR releases-- carry the promise of being developed into something more substantial on the band's next proper album
column2: like the reverberating
column3: melancholic refrain that unites ""Les Anges au Piano"" and ""Theme de Simon""
column4: which evoke A Thousand Leaves' beautifully understated ballad ""Snare
column5: Girl"". (Or perhaps the soundtrack's liberal use of piano portends a new mode of musical exploration for a band that's spent the past 30 years pushing the limits of the guitar.) You can actually hear the refinement process at work in the colossal bonus track ""Theme D'Alice""
column6: which repositions the woozy
column7: surf-tinged tract first heard on ""Dans le Bois/M. Rabier"" into an electrifying jam that betrays Sonic Youth's latent Stonesy streak
column8: before an extended
column9: ominous fade-out reasserts the film's grim context. But even if this soundtrack doesn't produce any blueprints for a future Sonic Youth album
column10:
it does at least provide the band's newly acquired contingent of Starbuck's impulse purchasers and curious Gossip Girl Googlers with a convenient access point into the band's alternate SYR universe.

If there were ever a map guiding Super Furry Animals mainman Gruff Rhys' musical path
column3: he tossed it overboard long ago. He's set out on an endlessly convoluted route
column4: using his instinct rather than reason to guide him. That rudderless approach has propelled a career full of never-ending left turns
column5: including recent collaborations with De La Soul and Gorillaz (on the latter's Plastic Beach)
column6: Sparklehorse and Danger Mouse (on Dark Night of the Soul) and Brazilian TV repairman Tony Da Gatorra (on The Terror of Cosmic Loneliness). Somehow
column7: in the middle of all this activity

column9: his third solo album.

column1: It begins with ""Shark Ridden Waters""
column2: one of the tracks Rhys recorded with Twisted Nerve/Finder Keepers co-founder Andy Votel
column3: who lives up to his cratedigger reputation by shoveling in generous portions of the Cyrkle's cover of Bacharach and David's ""It Doesn't Matter Anymore"". It plays out like a vintage
column4: spy-thriller theme searching for a film
column5: with Rhys intoning lines that belie a sinister undertow despite his wide-eyed delivery. ""I don't know what's wrong with me
column6: he croons
column7: ""but lately I've been feeling like I'm truly... at the end."" Such doom-mongering is at odds with the general thrust of Hotel Shampoo-- named after his OCD-like habit of collecting shampoo bottles from hotel rooms-- which opens byways back to the songcraft Rhys expertly mastered with his main band.

column1: In fact
column2: much of this album allows Rhys to extract ideas he's worked on in the past and breathe some new life into them. As such
column3: it's hard not to play connect-the-dots. ""Take a Sentence"" is a warmhearted ballad flushed with gently parping trumpets that mirror ""Presidential Suite"" from Rings Around the World; ""Patterns of Power"" offers a measured take on the condensed guitar brawling of ""Out of Control"" from Phantom Power; and ""Sensations in the Dark"" spins around the same frenetic Tropicália/mariachi mash-up as ""Northern Lites"" from Guerilla. Like most of Rhys' projects
column4: there's no particular destination in mind here
column5: no groove that he hits on and settles into. The only thing that binds Hotel Shampoo together are his agreeable vocal tones
column6: which have a soft familiarity to them
column7: whether he's tackling the environment on ""Conservation Conversation"" or encroaching on folky love song territory with ""If We Were Words (We Would Rhyme)"".

column1: The tangible difference between this and Rhys' other band is the absence of any tightly wound electronics from keyboardist Cian Ciárán
column2: although some similar instrumentation lends an endearing sloppiness to the proceedings. The rudimentary analog keyboard loosely splodged over ""Honey All Over"" only adds to its understated grace. The album peaks two-thirds of the way in over consecutive tracks: ""Christopher Columbus""
column3: which equates a spurned lover's actions with the spread of western imperialism
column4: all set to gravelly beats and a plastic-soul sax solo that recalls Deerhunter's ""Coronado""; and ""Space Dust #2""
column5: a jazzy duet with El Perro Del Mar that's pierced with Sirk-ian melodrama and a playfulness reminiscent of Nancy Sinatra and Lee Hazlewood's duets. ""You couldn't even look me in the eye
column6: she accuses. ""You had your sunglasses on
column7: is his pithy response.

column1: Impressively
column2: Hotel Shampoo manages to strike the right balance between Rhys' desire to indulge odd whims
column3: lyrical humor
column4: outright pop
column5: and heartfelt sentiment. More importantly
column6: he always makes it sound effortless. There's no forced quirkiness shoehorned in
column7: no conceits taken so far that they topple over into self-indulgence. He's excellent at reviewing and editing his own work
column8: making sure all the small parts serve the whole but never overwhelm it. You can hear it in the out-of-tune piano runs sprinkled over a passage of ""Conservation Conversation""
column9: or in the way ""Sophie Softly"" refracts into delightfully spindly synth tones at its close. If Rhys is set to return to Super Furry Animals any time soon
column10: this album suggests that he's in rude health
column11: both lyrically and musically
column12: and that they may regain some ground lost through the uneven Dark Days/Light Years. But the man is an unreliable narrator at the helm of his own career
column13: putting up smoke and mirrors at every turn
column14:
waiting to plunge us to unfamiliar depths at any moment.

A few years ago
column2: the Baton Rouge rap label Trill Ent. was a regional powerhouse that seemed primed for some sort of pop crossover moment
column3: thanks to the outsized personalities on its roster and the springy
column4: electric bounce beats from house producer Mouse on Da Track. In 2011
column5: though
column6: that moment of impending pop crossover is a distant memory
column7: as the label's outsized personalities-- namely Lil Boosie-- can't seem to go six months without some sort of serious arrest. And yet Mouse abides
column8: cranking out one elastic throwback banger after another and developing a seriously infectious rap style all his own. And here we have the hour-long Mouse solo mixtape
column9: Swagga Fresh Freddie
column10: proof of something I've long suspected: Mouse should be just fine on his own.

column1: For years
column2: Mouse has been the production force behind his crew's biggest hits
column3: like Boosie's ""Zoom"" and Foxx's ""Wipe Me Down"". His tracks were more stripped-down
column4: functional versions of the jittery synth-bounce jackhammers fellow Louisiana production hero Mannie Fresh used to make during Cash Money's first commercial heyday. More recently
column5: Mouse has thrown scene-stealing guest verses on tracks like Lil Cali's ""Ric Flair"" and Jimi Jump's ""2 Pieces"" remix
column6: snatching the spotlight from the other rappers on the tracks just by having more fun than anyone else. This isn't a Kanye situation
column7: where a producer transcends his way to rap-star status by introducing an original persona that rap hasn't seen before. There's nothing all that compelling about Mouse's persona; he's a club clown who loves rapping about cars and money and girls. But he loves rapping about that stuff-- takes obvious joy in it-- which makes him stand out on a label where Boosie's helium-voiced gangsta paranoia is the dominant voice. And he's got a bit of Juvenile or Nelly or D4L's Fabo in his delivery-- a melodic snap that makes throwaway moments sound thrilling just because he turns every last line into a hook.

column1: Swagga Fresh Freddie is exactly what you'd hope for from a Mouse full-length-- all those great hooks and guest verses drawn out to an hour
column2: without much in the way of filler or bullshit or anything that could distract from the party. It could stand to be a little shorter than it is
column3: and you could straight-up delete the final quarter of it from your iTunes without missing much. (The world didn't need another ""Black and Yellow"" freestyle
column4: and it's pretty jarring when Mouse half-assedly sings War's ""Why Can't We Be Friends"" on one chorus after delivering so many great choruses of his own.) But when it's on
column5: holy shit: The two-minute ""Turn Da Beat Up"" is everything you need to know about this tape-- a ridiculously propulsive bounce track that recalls hundreds of forgotten early-90s New Orleans bounce hits and never pauses for anything as pedestrian as an actual rap verse.

column1: ""Cartoon""
column2: which originally appeared on Boosie's 2010 behind-bars album Incarcerated
column3: is even better. The whole track has a deliriously
column4: irresistibly dumb concept-- Mouse feels like he's living in a cartoon-- and he commits to it with the gusto of someone who loves what he's doing. The complete chorus: ""Going Spongebob on em! Going Ninja Turtle on em! Going Bart Simpson on em! I'ma transform on em! Going Bugs Bunny on em! Going Mickey Mouse on em! Going Blues Clues on em! In a cartoooon."" It's so fun
column5: and even Boosie gets in on the ridiculousness. ""I'm always in trouble
column6: call me Garfield the cat!""-- that's one way to talk about your ongoing murder trial.

column1: The whole tape plays out like that. Mouse impersonates Bill Cosby on one track and Shredder on the next. And you won't find any reference to his label's legal woes
column2: beyond this line: ""I ain't thuggin'
column3: I ain't dealin'
column4: I ain't tryna go to prison."" That sentiment separates him from a whole lot of the rap universe
column5: even if he is delivering it on a track about how he's not afraid to beat your ass. But Mouse's music isn't about tension; it's about the physical euphoria of relief. And in that
column6:
it excels.

Banjo or Freakout's harmony-kissed bedroom music languishes in negative space. The songs that Banjo principal Alessio Natalizia lets peek out above the grey float along somewhere between the haunted bygone pop of Bradford Cox's Atlas Sound and the ponderous swirl of Panda Bear
column3: their tempos and hooks decidedly impressionistic. In his review of Banjo or Freakout's Way Slow odds and sods compilation last year
column4: Pitchfork's Zach Kelly pegged Natalizia's songs as ""ghosted"": You can make out their vague outlines and maybe a sense of their spirit
column5: but what's missing often seems more striking than what's actually there. The music's wave machine textures and gently lulling half-songs wash over you
column6: and your thoughts will inevitably wander. Sometimes it's bliss; others
column7: boredom.

column1: Natalizia recorded Banjo or Freakout with Nic Vernhes at the Rare Book Room in Brooklyn
column2: and Vernhes' naturalistic production style deepens the expanses in Natalizia's sound while maintaining its clean lines and immersive chill. What seems at first like a steely
column3: almost surgical minimalism reveals rippling textural undercurrents throughout
column4: lots for the ear to work out. But once you've wandered out into Natalizia's haze a few times and grown accustomed to the fog
column5: you start to realize there's not always much behind it.

column1: Natalizia sings in a sustain-laden
column2: slightly otherworldly pitch not unlike Brad Cox or Noah Lennox
column3: but he's got little of the former's slippery delivery and only a touch of the latter's bell-like clarity
column4: with a nasty habit of swallowing syllables all his own. His self-harmonizing can be lovely and semi-narcotic
column5: but Natalizia's voice doesn't have quite enough character to drive his ineffectual songs. ""Go Ahead"" and ""Move Out"" fare well enough and the throaty ""Can't Be Mad For Nothing"" feels like ""My Girls"" in greyscale. But save a few darker flutters that cop a move or two from Amnesiac-era Radiohead and the gorgeous up-from-underneath gurgle of closer ""I Don't Want to Start All Over Again""
column6: the rest of the songs feel meek
column7: unwilling to assert themselves over the music's delicate swirl. Beyond a tricky turnaround here and a nice little vocal double-up there
column8: these tracks feel frail
column9: mostly just sort of whisking by
column10: as though they'd float away were they not weighed down by the translucent synth film.

column1: But if you take Banjo or Freakout as an ambient record first and a pop album second
column2: the balance starts to shift in its favor. Natalizia's got a ways to go as a songwriter
column3: but with the help of Vernhes
column4: he's quite a sensualist
column5: his snowdrift sonics capable of both delicacy and heft. There's a lot of territory covered between the shimmering shuffle of ""Idiot Rain"" and the epic Jesu-like crunch of ""Black Scratches""
column6: and even if the hooks of either won't exactly knock you out-- and chances are they won't-- the luxuriant production does help push along the more melodically wanting material. Once Natalizia writes some songs better flattered by his sonic sense
column7:
I suspect he'll really have something here.

There are plenty of synth and drone artists that make epic
column3: transportive music
column4: but one of the unique things about Tim Hecker is his conceptual ability. Each of his records
column5: from the cinematic rush of Harmony in Ultraviolet to the dreamed-up cartography of An Imaginary Country
column6: explores a specific theme
column7: often in great detail. When he talked to us last month about the artwork for his latest LP
column8: <i>Ravedeath
column10: Hecker mentioned that he'd been consumed with the idea of sonic decay. ""I became obsessed with digital garbage
column11: he said. ""Like when the Kazakstan government cracks down on piracy and there's pictures of 10 million DVDs and CDRs being pushed by bulldozers.""

column1: That idea
column2: the notion of music as a cheapened
column3: battered object
column4: touches nearly every aspect of <i>Ravedeath
column6: a dark and often claustrophobic record that is arguably Hecker's finest work to date. The album is based on a single day's worth of recordings in a church in Reykjavik
column7: Iceland
column8: where Hecker used a groaning pipe organ to lay down the foundation for its tracks. (Throughout
column9: you can hear the vastness of this place
column10: as sounds ricochet around
column11: bounce off the rafters.) With help from Iceland-based producer Ben Frost-- whose ominous By the Throat is a touchstone here-- Hecker then finished the record in studio
column12: digitally adding synth wash and wailing shoegaze crunch to his live recordings.

column1: The result is a strange hybrid that lives somewhere between the digital and material realms
column2: and it's remarkable how seamlessly the two are combined. For example
column3: in a track like ""In the Fog II""
column4: it's difficult to distinguish between the organic church sounds and the processed ones that came after. But while there is harmony between the source material
column5: <i>Ravedeath
column6: 1972 is by no means about prettiness or tranquility. Hecker pits noises against one another in such a way that creates a constant push and pull between discord and beauty. It's a bit like William Basinski's Disintegration Loops
column7: but instead of music aging over time
column8: this is far more combative-- like these songs are being attacked from the inside out.

column1: It's an unusual concept but relevant given the rate at which music is consumed and discarded these days. More important than the record's ideology
column2: though
column3: is what Hecker does with it-- the weight
column4: atmosphere
column5: and contrast he builds into these songs. Take for example the ""In the Fog"" suite
column6: where over three tracks
column7: Hecker lets dissonant squall threaten an undulating organ drone until it's taken over by wailing guitar noise in third passage. Or the two-part ""Hatred of Music""
column8: which recalls an Oneohtrix Point Never synth shimmer before it disintegrates into distant industrial creaks. In each case it's not just about the wild
column9: unearthly sounds he creates but the force with which they move around the mix.

column1: Hecker is also smart with pacing and knows when to dial things back or add in softer
column2: interstitial numbers when things start to become overwhelming. That's the case in the record's back half where he uses open-ended pieces to achieve the same foreboding effect. ""Studio Suicide
column3: 1980"" is almost dreamy but has a sinister undercurrent
column4: sounding something like the more punishing moments of My Bloody Valentine's ""Only Shallow"" heard through the walls of a neighbor's apartment. I wouldn't go so far as to call songs like this and ""Analog Paralysis
column6: which has a similar celestial vibe
column7: ""ambient
column8: but they are subtler than those in the first half and give the album a sense of balance and a natural arc.

column1: If you buy into the concept of Ravedeath
column2: 1972 as an examination of music threatened by technology
column3: there are pretty clear threads that pop up over the course of the record to support that. For one
column4: it seems that the organ sounds Hecker captured back in that Rejkjavik church represent a certain purity of sound and that the digital noise battering it throughout act as the enemy
column5: the corrosive effect. There's an ongoing struggle between the two that's mirrored in the menacing song titles and gripping cover art. It's important
column6: then
column7: that the album closes with ""In the Air III""
column8: a track that features almost no interference whatsoever
column9: just the plinking organ by itself. If I'm reading it right
column10: it feels like Hecker's point is that music
column11: in its purest form
column12:
survives no matter what you throw at it.

column3: who is a preacher. These two songs are the inverse of the true-crime saga ""The Wig He Made Her Wear""

column5: The Big To-Do
column6: about a woman in a small Tennessee town who shoots her allegedly abusive husband
column7: a Church of Christ pastor
column8: in the back with a shotgun.

column1: ""Go-Go Boots"" is the better of the two new songs
column2: not only because it's shorter but because songwriter Patterson Hood is more interested in the aftermath than the murder itself. The pastor's ne'er-do-well son
column3: with a pregnant teenage girlfriend and a job pumping gas
column4: can't confront his father for fear of losing his temper
column5: so his anger just sizzles and fizzles inside him
column6: with no outlet. Hood intimates a sad arc to his life in a single verse
column7: an impressive lyrical trick that lends the song its considerable gravity. By comparison
column8: ""The Fireplace Poker""
column9: with its curious guitar curlicue wrapping around Brad Morgan's stoic drumbeat
column10: just recounts the details of the crime and sits aghast at a man's capacity for cruelty.

column1: Enthralled by small-town violence (he's reportedly working on a film about a southern crime syndicate)
column2: Hood has explored this material before
column3: documenting crime scenes in song and relating blood splatter and gunshot residue in verse while the band draw the chalk outlines on the floor. As always
column4: it's the carefully chosen details that give these songs heft and personality and keep them from becoming redundant. Hood is telling stories that are rare in rock music
column5: if not altogether nonexistent
column6: and the Truckers boast two other songwriters with similarly distinctive styles and subject matter. Mike Cooley writes in a cursory first-person
column7: emphasizing aw-shucks wordplay and wry self-deprecation: ""The Weakest Man"" is classic AM country at its wryest
column8: while ""Cartoon Gold"" is his Zevon anthem
column9: set in a dark L.A. bar seen through even darker sunglasses. ""I think about you when I can
column10: he laments
column11: ""and sometimes when I do I still get caught.""

column1: Over three albums (she's been playing for five but only writing songs for three)
column2: bass player Shonna Tucker has grown into a sharp
column3: imaginative lyricist
column4: and her one track on Go-Go Boots shows she's absorbed Hood and Cooley's knack for character sketches. ""Dancin' Ricky"" depicts a dancer out on the floor with a tight shirt and ""freedom out in the open
column5: which I read as ""tight pants."" Rather than depict this person as a fool
column6: she paints a sort of antihero: ""Hey Ricky
column7: don't let the Diabetes get you!"" Tucker cheers. Tucker may not have written ""Where's Eddie""
column8: but she sings it like she did
column9: in a performance that's restrained and soulful-- a bit of feminine guile to offset so much masculine songwriting.

column1: Eddie Hinton wrote ""Where's Eddie""
column2: and the Muscle Shoals Sounds singer and friend of the Hood family figures prominently on Go-Go Boots-- just as prominently as murderous preachers. The band recently recorded two covers of Hinton's songs for Shake It Records' singles series (Afghan Whigs' Greg Dulli has also contributed)
column3: and both sides appear on the album
column4: forming a mini-tribute to the troubled artist
column5: whose success never equaled his talents and who died in 1995 largely unknown. Hood doesn't quite have the vocal chops to put across ""Everybody Needs Love"" as confidently as Tucker sells ""Where's Eddie""
column6: but thanks to the band's exuberant take
column7: it proves a potent block of southern soul that reveals the Truckers' range and sensitivity beyond the Crazy Horse guitar attack of recent albums.

column1: In fact
column2: Go-Go Boots sounds like a slight retreat from that rock noise
column3: indulging Cooley's country jones as well as the band's more acoustic tendencies. It's a more dynamic record than The Big To-Do
column4: recalling the ramshackle vibe of their first two albums. There's a greater textural range
column5: from the noir ramble of ""Ray's Automatic Weapon"" to the spidery tension of ""Used to Be a Cop""
column6: one of Hood's best character sketches. On the heels of Go-Go Boots comes the DVD release of the documentary The Secret to a Happy Ending
column7: which chronicles the period in the mid-2000s when the Drive-By Truckers almost broke up. There's a telling moment when former guitar player/songwriter Jason Isbell asserts that that line-up was the most solid and the most creative in the band's long history of turnovers. It's no reflection on him
column8: but Go-Go Boots goes a long way to proving him wrong
column9:
suggesting a band that knows where all the bodies are buried.

Not every new bass-music record has to be a huge sea change. At some point
column3: it's good to recognize when music from an advancement-heavy scene actually succeeds as a workaday yet appealing synthesis of things that've already worked before. And when that synthesis is as broad-minded as Salva's debut
column4: Complex Housing-- which reaches toward a unique fingerprint while still letting the seams of influence show-- that it clicks at all is an achievement in itself. Paul Salva
column5: head of SF-area label Frite Nite
column6: operates like the end product of cross-genre overload
column7: the end result being an album that shows both the creative freedom and the unpredictability of someone who isn't in a big hurry to find a niche yet.

column1: The trick to Salva's music is how it shrugs off attempts to pin down its elusive origin point. There's a noticeable stylistic affinity with the Low End Theory scene a ways down the California coast in the future-funk hip hop insinuations. But the threads that run through it touch on a checklist of important club music movements from the last decade-- neo-electro
column2: Southern bounce
column3: filter house
column4: ghettotech
column5: ""purple"" dubstep
column6: turn-of-the-decade Dilla breaks
column7: UK funky
column8: pop grime
column9: and boogie funk revival. It's less the affected accent of the kid who comes back from a year in England talking like a Guy Ritchie bit player
column10: and more like the voice of a constantly moving Army brat who's let the dialects of five different regions shape his speech as he grows up.

column1: The reason this succeeds hangs largely on Salva's ear for retrofitting familiar sonic tropes. Probably the easiest example to point to would be his cover of Robert Owens' ""I'll Be Your Friend"". Stripped to the chassis and rebuilt as a sparse
column2: spacious yet evocative minimal-skewing revamp
column3: the remake builds on a recognition of what made the original work rhythmically
column4: shuffling roles around in its thorough modernization of an early-90s house anthem. The bassline becomes a minimoog melody
column5: the 4/4 gains a slippery
column6: skip-rhythm pulse
column7: and the vocal is drawn out into hypnotic
column8: delayed-payoff repetition mid-sentence (""I'll be your
column9: I'll be your
column10: I'll be your""). It's a good way to nod back to old heads
column11: and it gives Salva's music a bit of grounding in a historical context that goes deeper than the past 10 years.

column1: But the stuff that sticks to variants of more recent developments falls into place just as well
column2: aided by a crowdpleasing notion of how a good melodic hook can be the same thing as a good rhythmic hook. It's most appealing
column3: and most characteristic of an actual game plan
column4: when there's at least a couple of those hooks jostling for space until they finally intersect. ""Beached"" pits buzzing
column5: choppy synths against elastic digital space-funk bass and lets them work in tandem as a sort of dueling riff-break. And the dubstep-leaning ""Blue"" pulls off a similar trick with a rapid
column6: hyperactive succession of shuddering throbs and warbles strung together and given a unifying structure by an intricate
column7: Swiss-precise stagger-step backbeat.

column1: The simpler and less frantic things get
column2: the more pedestrian a track can feel-- the glimmering electro-house/UK funky fusion of ""Keys Open Doors"" and the shamelessly (yet effectively) Joker-aping ""Icey"" are catchy
column3: but nothing earth-shaking-- yet even those moments still carry the weight of music that sounds like it comes from a place of genuine adventurousness. As much of a polyglot parade of signifiers as it sometimes threatens to become
column4: Complex Housing coheres enough to make the quartet of other producers' remixes tacked on at the end feel like a distracting afterthought (even if they'd be good enough for a high-grade EP on their own). Underneath all the familiar sounds is the imprint of someone who knows how to make the pieces actually fit
column5: and if it's still an issue of working out the difference between distillation and construction
column6:
at least this first step of progress has some engaging energy to it. Salva's clearly been listening to all the right records-- and learning all the right lessons.

A photograph of Sean McBride-- the Brooklyn-based composer who sets sound to tape here under the alias Martial Canterel-- in the booklet of his new LP
column2: You Today
column3: depicts him surrounded by vintage synths and vast snake-like deposits of wires. The photograph frames McBride as a custodian staring pensively at his collected wares. But his curatorial role doesn't stop short at his hardware collection. His work here
column4: and as one-half of Xeno and Oaklander
column5: pays slavish homage to the anti-rock artifice of the coldwave scene from the early 1980s
column6: much of which has been revived
column7: reissued
column8: and subsequently regurgitated via the Minimal Wave label. You Today is an attempt by McBride to feed through another oblique Xerox of that era
column9: where austere vocals are stiffly reinforced by frigid layers of synths
column10: all set in rigid motion by the brutal clop of a vintage step sequencer.

column1: There's a skill at work that's undoubtedly impressive. The world may have stopped turning for McBride with the spread of glasnost across the former Soviet Union in the late 1980s
column2: but he's probably spent most of his time between then and now finely honing his craft. Opener ""Occupy These Terms"" is layered with synth rhythms that interlock and break apart at just the right moments. The alacrity of the tinny drum machine pulls this work in line with the Futurists' love of speed and motion
column3: while lyrics about the decaying of ""aging walls"" that highlight ""a need to change"" mirror that movement's fetishization of the industrial city and a desire for humankind to rise up against the natural world. Those concepts are strung throughout You Today
column4: with McBride often finding himself in perpetual motion
column5: singing about ""a strategy for moving around"" (on ""Sidestreets"") and ""moving back along lost tracks"" (on ""Secret Stores""). He twins those speed/anti-nature slants on ""The Empty Sand""
column6: although his bloodless delivery never hints at any emotion felt by the events he sings about.

column1: Deadpan vocals are a basic facet of coldwave
column2: of course
column3: but the colorless utterances here cause a sense of ennui to seep through the cracks after a while. Sadly
column4: the sole attempt to break with protocol
column5: in the minutely higher range flexed on ""Still a Part""
column6: only serves to further highlight his shortcomings as a singer. Despite such deficiencies
column7: the album occasionally bristles with invention
column8: mainly when the urge to stray into overt pop territory is quashed. ""Some Days"" skillfully circles downward by matching contrasting light/dark synth inflections; ""Don't Let Me Go"" is built around a stubborn wall of spidery white noise that all but obliterates McBride's distant vocal passages.

column1: Aside from those fleeting moments of inspiration
column2: there's not much here that pushes this beyond pastiche. The playing is impeccable
column3: but it feels like the work of an archivist. It explains why McBride's vocals lack conviction-- it's the one part of his arsenal that can't be studiously labored over until it's shorn of anything that's recognizably ""him."" It's possible that You Today would have worked better as a series of instrumentals
column4: but even that wouldn't dispel the feeling that this is a journey that reaches deep into the past and remains trenchantly stuck there. It's a shame
column5: because other minimal synth revivalists (Cold Cave
column6: Led Er Est) have shown a way forward for this music
column7: by skillfully extracting pertinent signifiers from their record collections and giving them a chance to breathe in a 21st century context. For McBride
column8:
that vision of the future remains frustratingly out of reach.

column6: VWETO

column8: which is unfortunate. Muldrow's prime appeal is the way she tackles even the most rudderless instrumentals with her silken rasp
column9: briefly attempting to keep a track in lockstep before faltering into spaced out bliss. It's this loss of control that makes her someone worth paying attention to

column1: There are promising moments
column2: though. The slap bass on ""Strike"" paired with an upper register balloon squeak is hypnotic in the most blunted way possible
column3: while album opener ""The No-No Chords"" sits dead center in California smog
column4: relying on texture and loose
column5: squelching bass to propel it forward. Meanwhile
column6: ""fOnkRocker"" rolls so smoothly over its own g-funk bounce that it's insane that she doesn't attempt to at least throw a chorus in there. VWETO might flow beautifully from beginning to end
column7: but it also rambles. Outside of those highlights

column9: modern funk.

column1: VWETO might be just another step in what is sure to be a long and storied career for Muldrow
column2: but it's not the one that will match audience expectations. When she finally gets it completely right-- and it seems ridiculous to assume she won't
column3:
based on the glimpses of brilliance she's shown in the past-- she'll elevate Nag Champa and Bead Curtain soul into something worth paying attention to again.

Strange can exist anywhere

column4: R. Kelly-- are truly weird. How bizarre can the music of Philip Glass or Wolfgang Voigt really be? It seems contained
column5: planned; the curio is the choice to be so on-keel in the first place. One of my favorite aspects of Nicolas Jaar's debut full-length
column6: Space Is Only Noise
column7: is how thoroughly it scatters this misconception. Space is leftfield electro-pop
column8: far-flung and without reserve
column9: but it is also patient
column10: quiet
column11: and small.

column1: Jaar is a Providence via New York via Chile producer. He is 21
column2: he attends Brown University
column3: and he already has several well regarded singles and EPs to his name in addition to running the Clown & Sunset imprint. Requisite hot remixes: check. He exhibits all of the earmarks of a rising techno star: He remixes dance music
column4: and his early singles were released as 12""s on dance labels. He counts Chilean techno giant Ricardo Villalobos as a prime inspiration. Little with Jaar is straightforward
column5: however. His father is an acclaimed visual artist. His mixes play like outsider pastiche. There are conflicting reports about whether his downtempo beats-- usually clocking between 90 - 110 bpm-- actually move dancefloors (Jaar himself is skeptical).

column1: Here is an alternate theory as to why Jaar occasionally fails to shuffle Nikes: He makes weird
column2: self-contained music that only lands a glancing blow on house or any other particular dance subgenre. Jaar's music incorporates lounge pop
column3: African jazz
column4: hip-hop
column5: and sound collage in addition to house and pinches of dubstep. The type of soundsystem most appropriate for Space isn't a sleek club hi

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
-fi but a Victrola in a stop-motion film (""steampunk house""-- let's please not go there).
The textures and ingredients of Jaar's music exist in the context of techno-- rhythm and repetition are clearly important to him-- but Space is not dance music. It's too slow
column2: sure
column3: but it's also too diffuse in its methods and results. Pianos
column4: organs
column5: guitar strings
column6: and
column7: most surprisingly
column8: Jaar's voice all fall under Space's sepia-toned veil. This sounds like a lot to take in
column9: but Jaar goes to great lengths to ensure that Space settles lightly. The tracks are short
column10: funny
column11: and always hitched to a melody. He sidesteps impulses-- during the quivering ""Almost Fell""
column12: for instance
column13: or during ""Specters of the Future""
column14: during which actual techno threatens-- to drift into full-on ambience
column15: skronk
column16: or extended beat passages. The goofy bass bumbling of ""Problems With the Sun"" is as likely to stick with you as the elegiac ""Colomb"". Functionally I keep thinking of my first listens to The Books' Thought for Food: familiar styles and influences are wafted under my nose. There is a lot of teasing recognition but very little realization. The record passes easily and quickly.

column1: Just as Jaar's treated instruments blur the line between digital and acoustic
column2: his voice-- calm and husky
column3: somewhat affected-- saddles up to the soul samples and film dialogue that pepper the album and confidently blends. He hums earworms-- ""Replace the word 'space' with a drink and forget it""; ""Too many kids finding rain in the dust""-- that ripple across his productions. These voices-- Jaar's own or samples-- are more than melodic placeholders. The gentle house balladry of ""I Got a Woman"" uses a looped Ray Charles refrain and French film dialogue to evoke something more specific than the electric pianos and breakbeat can. Jaar is akin to labelmates DJ Koze and Dave Aju
column4: who weave voices among beats in counterintuitive ways.

column1: Space never feels like a showcase for Nicolas Jaar; it's just a modest and well-decorated gathering place for some things he loves
column2: a place for them to interact. This teetering restraint masks the true weirdness of Space Is Only Noise. I could understand someone finding the intensely self-contained Space a bit claustrophobic
column3: but the album is most rewarding when you just grab a seat at the table. Because when Jaar chants ""Grab a calculator and fix yourself"" I don't sit there and think
column4: ""Gosh
column5:
why am I listening to electro-acoustic downtempo future-jazz?""; I go look for my calculator.

If they haven't been already

column8: or
column9: if you prefer
column10: ""hipster"")
column11: Headbangers in Ecstasy won't do anything to get in your way.

column1: Despite the chorused guitars and laggard dream-pop tempos

It's pointless to argue whether or not the wafer-thin sound was the best production Puro Instinct could afford at the time considering similarly minded documents like Real Estate or even Beach House cunningly flipped their shoestring budgets

column7: begging for more harmonies or reverb for support; and you can hear a bass at points

column4:
vacant.

column2: 'Salvo'
column4: the British record label Zang Tuum Tumb was
column5: if not the coolest thing on the planet
column6: at least a major nexus of pop coolness. A collaboration between perfectionist superproducer Trevor Horn and theoretician/publicist/ex-journalist Paul Morley
column7: ZTT released many fewer songs than records: In the label's early period
column8: every single from the likes of Propaganda
column9: Frankie Goes to Hollywood
column10: and the Art of Noise arrived as a torrent of remixes
column11: extensions
column12: edits
column13: and utter reworkings. ZTT was
column14: at first
column15: essentially an experimental label--which is an odd thing to say
column16: given that it promptly scored a handful of massive hit singles in the U.K. But its central experiment (a successful one) was foregrounding the principles that the essence of a pop hit had at least as much to do with its presentation as with its composition or recording

column1: The Art of the 12"" is a collection of various remixes from the ZTT archives

(It's not quite a greatest-hits-- Grace Jones's ""Slave to the Rhythm"" and the Art of Noise's ""Beat Box"" are conspicuous by their absence; it's also not a greatest-mixes: The version of Frankie's ""Welcome to the Pleasuredome"" here is a rare one rather than a particularly good one.) ""Move with me inside the strange world of the 12-inch

column2: though

column5: notably on Act's ""Snobbery & Decay""
column6: a song about decadence given one of the ZTT team's most decadently lush productions

The Art of Noise's slowly throbbing instrumental ""Moments in Love"" was famously played as Madonna and Sean Penn's wedding march. And Frankie's ""Relax"" went through endless permutations
column9: including the ""Sex Mix Edit"" featured here

F.M. Cornog has it pretty good. He's got a good 9-to-5 in a recession economy
column2: working the tiling department at a Home Depot somewhere in New Jersey
column3: and he comes home to his wife and an eight-year-old daughter. When he gets the itch
column4: he writes and records in his simple home studio. When he wants to put out a record-- something that is happening with less frequency thanks to that day job-- he has a sweet deal with one of the biggest indie labels around

column6: Cornog thrives behind the orange apron.

column1: His imagination
column2: however
column3: is out there treading dingy sidewalks and haunting abandoned strip malls
column4: taking in the saddest vistas of the Garden State. His seventh album
column5: the gently elegaic We Live in Rented Rooms
column6: is populated with junkies and clock-punchers

column8: others in Internet porn or philosophy. ""Conman"" ends with the threat of murder

column10: as if it's an everyday occurrence. Closer ""Three Ships"" intimates a big-box apocalypse
column11: embraced by the narrator rather than feared. Cornog sympathizes with them all
column12: inhabiting his characters as if they were simply different aspects of himself-- or different outcomes to his own story. Never straining for credibility

column8: it's simply more vivid
column9: adding a sense of keen majesty to ""Cold Ground"" and a long
column10: sad fade-out to ""The Flames Are Coming Back"". His songs remain epics in miniature
column11: yet the details are finer and more varied

Mogwai never seemed like a particularly good bet to age well. They came out of the gate as a band that Meant Something to many people
column4: namely fans of heavy guitar music and rock critics. They established a clear
column5: identifiable
column6: and exciting new sound
column7: but their latest LP-- <i>Hardcore Will Never Die
column8: But You Will-- doesn't change the pattern Mogwai have set for themselves on recent
column9: often middling
column10: releases: There are some anthemic guitar blasts
column11: some prettily drifting comedowns
column12: and one or two vocal tracks.

column1: The band has regained none of its prior fierceness
column2: but Hardcore is
column3: importantly
column4: the band's least self-conscious album in ages. There are no attempts to be <i>really heavy
column5: man. There are no stale electronics. The songs that wander out of the band's comfort zone-- most notably the Neu!-indebted ""Mexican Grand Prix""-- are the types of genre exercises a veteran rock band of Mogwai's stature should probably undertake. Hardcore feels comfy and lived-in
column6: backhanded compliments only to those who didn't slog through The Hawk Is Howling and Happy Songs For Happy People.

column1: The price for all this hominess is basically any lingering sense of mystery. Mogwai can chime away pleasantly during ""Death Rays""-- featuring the band's best guitar lick in years-- but it can't turn ""Rano Pano"" into ""Stanley Kubrick"". This is fine
column2: as long as we're willing to admit that we get different things out of Mogwai albums these days. This is a record of savvy rock vets kicking at distortion pedals until something frothy emerges. I'm on board if the results are going to be as page-turning-ly melodic as ""How to Be a Werewolf"" or as playful as the pitch-shifted ""George Square Thatcher Death Party"". The mistakes are easy to forgive: ""White Noise"" is the band's most vanilla opening track ever. The slide-guitar panorama of ""Letters to the Metro"" will still your blood just as surely as ""Like Herod"" once boiled it
column3: but it's merely the type of innocuous doodling the band has long padded its albums with.

column1: Mogwai's prior output and general demeanor has made it difficult for them to be a group that fans simply enjoy. The band built its reputation on sonic extremes
column2:
and that purview has infected their reputation: deliver a masterpiece-- I don't think they have it in them-- or suffer indifference. On Hardcore Mogwai sound like they're enjoying being Mogwai again. I'm ready to enjoy them being Mogwai again too.

column7: illicit

column11: the off-key croon that other singers might AutoTune

column1: While Dulli's palette is limited
column2: he manages to ma

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
ke these familiar elements sound fresh and vital on Dynamite Steps

column1: Dynamite Steps is Dulli's best collection since Blackberry Belle

column6:
he leers on ""Waves"". ""Cut your losses and I'll meet you there."" Dulli hasn't stood us up yet.

During the 1970s
column2: Ebo Taylor was one of the leading lights of Ghana's guitar highlife and Afrobeat scenes. He had a productive solo career and was one of the stars of the Apagya Show Band supergroup-- his contributions as guitarist and bandleader helped define the sound that we associate with 70s Ghana today. But it wasn't until this past decade that Taylor gained any kind of notoriety outside of West Africa. Soundway Records included his songs
column3: both on his own and with Apagya
column4: on its groundbreaking Ghana Soundz compilations
column5: and he stood out as a guy with his own sound. ""Atwer Abroba"" and ""Heaven""
column6: the two solo songs the label compiled
column7: had a distinctive rhythm
column8: a cousin of the Fela Kuti/Tony Allen backbeat that gave the songs a feeling of unstoppable momentum but felt much heavier than its Nigerian counterpart.

column1: One of the best side effects of the surge of interest in West African popular music has been the revival of many careers and groups that had long been idle or working in the margins-- Mulatu Astatke
column2: Bembeya Jazz
column3: Orchestra Baobab
column4: and Poly-Rythmo have all come back
column5: and now Taylor joins them with his first-ever international release. He's joined by musicians from Berlin's Afrobeat Academy
column6: which is comprised of members of Poets of Rhythm
column7: Kabu Kabu
column8: and Marijata
column9: the last of which was active in Ghana around the same time as Taylor in the 70s. The band is important
column10: because it's key to achieving a sound that makes it feel like Taylor never went away-- the material is fresh
column11: but it has a thick
column12: vintage sound that ties back to Taylor's old work nicely.

column1: It must be said that it also generalizes his sound a little bit; many Afrobeat Academy members cut their teeth on Fela
column2: after all
column3: and that's clear especially in the rhythm guitar and bass playing of J. Whitefield and Patrick Frankowski
column4: respectively. That should
column5: however
column6: be taken as an observation of style and not quality
column7: as there's not really anything you could call a wrong note on the whole album. Taylor's songs are mostly newly written for the project
column8: though the phenomenal title track is a new version of a song he originally recorded in 1980 after his first wife left him-- in the song
column9: he compares her kiss at their wedding to a kiss of death as his guitar rolls calmly along beside his vocal. Taylor has made what appears to be a strategic decision to open the album with ""Nga Nga""
column10: an adaptation of a Ghanaian children's rhyme that many people interested in highlife and Afrobeat will already recognize from a version by the Sweet Talks. Taylor's take is less frantic and takes a sort of slow-burn approach
column11: his guitar slashing ominously against the heavy horns and spacey
column12: snaking sax lead.

column1: That flash of the familiar isn't necessarily a fleeting one-- if you're a fan of Ghana Soundz or
column2: really
column3: funky old West African music in general
column4: you will feel right at home on this album. Taylor hasn't lost a bit of the spark that made his old records good (and we'll get a chance to compare more directly later this year when Strut releases a compilation of his old songs)
column5:
and the new songs honor the spirit of that music without rehashing it. There's no need for an artist like Taylor to reinvent himself at this stage-- Love and Death gives us exactly what we want and does it exceedingly well.

column3: PJ Harvey declares  on the first line of her new album

column1: On Let England Shake

column3: though

column5: she paints vivid portraits of war

column9: massive loss of life of the Great War. If it doesn't resonate as much in America as it does in Europe-- and it doesn't-- that's more our fortune than our shame.

column1: The Great War remains a rich and resonant subject for art because it briefly caused the world to step back
column2: aghast and afraid to look at what it had done. The collective trauma of World War I did indeed shake England
column3: specifically
column4: out of the end of its imperialistic Victorian stupor. The rest of the world gasped as well: WWI hastened the Russian  Revolution

column7: the result was modernism

column10: it redrew European borders
column11: creating roughly a dozen new  nations; diplomatically

column1: On ""The Words That Maketh Murder""

column3: she and her cohorts-- frequent collaborators John Parish and Mick Harvey-- break into the jaunty closing refrain from ""Summertime Blues"": ""What if I take my problems to the United Nations?"" It's a hilariously depressing coda; her song's character has experienced the unimaginable and is looking to an international peacekeeping body for help.

column8: and ""The Last Living Rose"".) As much of a piece as this record is

column11: Harvey and  co. locate a wide range of approaches to their central subject;  alongside the singles

column13: the delicate ""Hanging in the Wire""

column1: Even a cursory glance at the album-- its title
column2: song titles
column3: lyrics-- marks this as a very English record. Its pastoralism befits  Harvey's West Country background and recording setting (as well as the  fields in Europe in which most of WWI was fought
column4: and where most of the dead are  now laid to rest). But it's less about the experience of one nation with  war
column5: so much as one people. That those people are English  is Harvey soaking her music in her own surroundings and experiences. Swap out the place names with others
column6: though
column7: and  the message remains the same. It's universal and it's  necessary-- and it's powerfully and clearly stated. That it's also a joy  to hear is perhaps the most confounding juxtaposition of all
column8:
turning a record you'll respect into one you'll also love.

A revival of the 1990s
column2: a decade unusually obsessed with postmodern revivals in fashion and culture
column3: was always inevitable. But it isn't exactly overdue. In fact
column4: over the past few years
column5: the return of bands and styles from the Clinton administration has almost become cliché. Pavement
column6: Dinosaur Jr.
column7: the Dismemberment Plan
column8: Jawbox
column9: and even Blink-182 have reunited. Guided By Voices reassembled their 'classic lineup.' And Weezer recently reprised their beloved mid-90s albums in their entirety at live shows. Among younger artists

column11: whether in the Slumberland-streaked indie pop of the Pains of Being Pure at Heart or Best Coast
column12: the artful squall of No Age
column13: the achingly nostalgic paeans of Deerhunter
column14: the ambling guitar epics of Real Estate
column15: or the slacker punk-pop of Wavves.

column1: There's no escaping it: If you've heard anything about Yuck
column2: it's that this London four-piece loves the 90s. The band's members are very clearly products of the web rather than any particular geography; their self-titled debut evinces tastes that run toward fuzzy indie bands from both sides of the pond. Yes
column3: there's a bit of the wah-pedal guitar violence of Dinosaur Jr.
column4: and a little of the lackadaisical detachment of Pavement
column5: but there's also the rich tunefulness of Teenage Fanclub and Velocity Girl
column6: and at times the unadorned resignation of Red House Painters or Elliott Smith. However
column7: like so many artists saddled (fairly or not) with the ""revival"" tag
column8: from post-punk and garage-rock to nu-disco or neo-soul
column9: Yuck are worth hearing not so much because of who they sound like
column10: but what they've done with those sounds: in this case
column11: make a deeply melodic
column12: casually thrilling coming-of-age album for a generation that never saw Nirvana on ""120 Minutes"".

column1: As with their best peers in the Fat Possum stable
column2: Yuck distinguish themselves by knowing their way around around a catchy
column3: emotionally evocative song. Sometimes these can be bright and optimistic
column4: almost twee
column5: as in the peppy boy-girl endearments of ""Georgia""
column6: or the midtempo acoustic yearning of ""Shook Down"". Elsewhere
column7: they can be gritty and urgent: Screeches of feedback occasionally drown out drowsy vocals on ""Holing Out""
column8: nicely suiting lyrics about communication problems; likewise
column9: the distortion-blistered repetitions of ""The Wall"" suggest the Sisyphean efforts they describe. Then there are the heartfelt mopers: the stripped-down comfort offer ""Suicide Policeman""
column10: the Galaxie 500-meets-""Nightswimming"" ""Stutter""
column11: or the lonely post-breakup jangler ""Sunday"". Seven-minute closer ""Rubber"" is the type of gorgeously incantatory slow burner veterans like Yo La Tengo stlll make (see ""More Stars Than There Are in Heaven""
column12: from 2009's underrated Popular Songs)-- not to mention Mogwai
column13: who've remixed it-- but too few bands successfully emulate. Add up these different types of tracks
column14: and you have an unusually coherent album-length experience.

column1: If you've heard anything else about Yuck
column2: it might be that two of the band members
column3: singer/guitarist Daniel Blumberg and guitarist Max Bloom
column4: used to play in Cajun Dance Party: ambitious and typically spazzy post-Arctic Monkeys NME faves who issued a Bernard Butler-produced debut album
column5: The Colourful Life
column6: in 2008 on XL. As with that former band
column7: Yuck are occasionally guilty of some awkward lyrics-- the seemingly gratuitous ""crucifixion""/""benediction""/""addiction"" rhymes on note-bending love ballad ""Suck"" come to mind-- and it's hard to guess how long they can keep this particular sound going (a Yu[c]k side project offers intriguing hints). But together Blumberg
column8: Bloom
column9: drummer Jonny Rogoff
column10: and bass player Mariko Doi
column11: joined on certain tracks by part-time backing singer Ilana Blumberg
column12: have taken a giant step forward. As Blumberg sang with his old band
column13: the one he started as a 15-year-old
column14: ""This is now and that was then."" Or as he sings now
column15: on instantly searing album opener
column16: ""Get Away"": ""I can't get this feeling off my mind."" Whether they remember the 90s or not
column17:
more than a few people could end up saying something similar about Yuck.

Surf City's self-titled debut EP arrived in 2008

column1: On their new full-length

column5: and Bailter Space. Album opener ""Crazy Rulers of the World"" buzzes along on an endlessly repeating two-note bass riff. ""Icy Lakes"" goes one better

column3: frequently letting the background vocals carry the melodic weight. He's a front man who benefits from splicing extended adolescence with punky naiveté-- part Avey Tare
column4: part Steve Malkmus. On their debut EP
column5: Surf City had a manic edge--the band rushed through its songs with a jittery energy. Kudos is considerably more laid back and vibe-heavy. The guitars still jingle-jangle
column6:
just with a little more economy.

column1: Well over a decade after its inception
column2: it's easy to forget that before Oberst's lyrical abracadabra on 2002's Lifted garnered ""New Dylan!"" hosannas
column3: the Bright Eyes brand got its first bit of traction amongst emo kids. Leagues of them. Oberst was a pin-up-- his hair always swept perfectly across his sad
column4: massive
column5: Milk-Dud eyes-- fit to erupt in small rooms like those in which he first recorded. In the years that followed Lifted's release
column6: he left behind his handcrafted
column7: attic-pop leanings to fully embrace American roots music. It was a path he hit all the harder as his audience and profile grew. From pure folk to ham-fisted honky tonky to the classic rock of his Mystic Valley band
column8: each subsequent release employed a recording method to match the ambition of Oberst's increasingly dystopian lyricbook. That trajectory reached a pivotal point in 2007's Cassadaga

column10: string-embossed epic that found Oberst in all those modes at once
column11: engaging even further with themes both mystic and apocalyptic. Despite its flaws
column12: that record seemed the loudest expression of what Bright Eyes had seemingly always been about: articulating the world's many weights
column13: as he meant to carry them around. The People's Key

column15: breaks from the narrative. It doesn't articulate much at all.

column1: While a few traces of pedal steel remain

column3: Mogis
column4: and recently anointed permanent member/keyboardist Nate Walcott (with few exceptions Bright Eyes' cast tended to revolve) have given the former's songwriting a new sonic skin. Gone is the ""rootsy Americana shit"" he recently told Billboard he was burnt out on. In its place

Walcott's contributions in particular--  like on the hiccupping ""Haile Selassie""-- digitize a lot of the pop elements that distinguish Bright Eyes from Oberst's work elsewhere. It's as well-assembled and produced a set of songs as you'd expect from pros like these guys

column1: So Gucci's Appeal material has plenty to gain from recontextualization; the further you can get a deliriously great twofer like ""standing on the sofa spilling liquor on the speaker/ Call the paralegal 'cuz this shit should be illegal"" away from the awkwardly undulating Justice sample in ""Gucci Time""

column4: dubstep
column5: purple

column7: a lot of gurgling glo-fi and off-kilter electroid shuffle that neither bettered their origin tracks or did much to flatter Gucci's tricky rhymes. Sinden's careful not to replicate the Diplo tape's missteps on Free Gucci II: The Burrrtish Edition

column1: From ""Wonderful"" to ""Lemonade""

column3: his lively slur weaving itself around the sneaky syncopations in the music. It's not that a good Gucci remix is some kind of impossibility-- Flying Lotus and a few others proved that on the last tape-- but to really succeed it'd have to preserve both Gucci's word-drunk
column4: expectation-tweaking cadences and the grim cacophony to which Gucci is accustomed. With its tottering brainwipe bass hits and stilted-staccato rhythms

column6: everyone

column1: The trouble

Jonathan Richman's big affectation
column3: if that's even the right word
column4: is the idea that we can escape our affectations. And not just the ones we use to fit in. The things we affect to stand out
column5: too. So as frontman for legendary proto-punks the Modern Lovers
column6: sure
column7: Richman took the nihilistic clang of the Velvet Underground. But he applied it to songs about sobriety (""I'm Straight"")
column8: hometown Americana (""Roadrunner"")
column9: and old-fashioned courtship (""Girl Friend""). As a cult-beloved solo artist
column10: he has praised his heroes for the same simple reasons a child-- or a wise old man-- might: a crazy sound (""Velvet Underground"")
column11: all those pretty colors (""Vincent Van Gogh"")
column12: nice dreams (""Salvador Dali""). His live performances
column13: at once puritanically austere and shamelessly entertaining
column14: suggest an especially gifted street musician.

column1: Released last November without much fanfare
column2: the 59-year-old New England native's latest extends an increasingly remarkable series of low-key
column3: mostly acoustic albums for Neil Young's Vapor imprint over the decade-plus since Richman's closest brush with fame (as the twee singer guy in 1998 Farrelly Brothers slapstick There's Something About Mary). This fruitful phase has brought a mature gravity that translates
column4: improbably
column5: as lightness-- Richman takes his fun pretty seriously. On 2004's Not So Much to Be Loved as to Love
column6: a late-career highlight
column7: he reminded us not to spoil the good things in life by talking them to death. On 2008's sporadically sublime Because Her Beauty Is Raw and Wild
column8: he showed how to experience the bad things in life to their fullest
column9: too. Though a little less thematically unified
column10: <i>O Moon
column11: Queen of Night on Earth continues Richman's doomed but noble attempt to dig beneath the surfaces of modern existence
column12: flaunting its relatively few imperfections-- mic sounds
column13: a rushed phrase or two-- as signs of life.

column1: Like its recent predecessors
column2: Richman's new album is a pretty faithful representation of his live show. With little distracting studio gloss
column3: it captures Richman's warbling
column4: Boston-accented croon; his nylon-string
column5: flamenco-tinged acoustic guitar; and longtime drummer Tommy Larkins' stripped-down kit
column6: which he plays with jazzy panache. There are backing vocals from a handful of guests
column7: including wife Nicole Montalbano and singer/songwriter Ólöf Arnalds (of Icelandic band Múm)
column8: but these all blend comfortably enough to add to the album's feeling of shared intimacy
column9: rather than subtract from it. Foreign-language lyrics
column10: a staple of Richman's Vapor records
column11: crop up now and then
column12: but the songs are evocative enough to work as interludes if
column13: say
column14: your knowledge of French is limited to ""Lady Marmalade""-- and anyway on the reprise of ""Sa Voix M'Atisse"" JoJo helps you with the words. There's even one of those half-spoken Massachusetts geography songs Richman does from time to time
column15: ""Winter Afternoon by B.U. in Boston""
column16: though this one's percussive repetitions pale beside the wonderfully vivid ""Twilight in Boston""
column17: from 1992's essential <i>I
column18: Jonathan.

column1: Billed as a ""wee small hours"" record
column2: O Moon isn't so much melancholy as it is soaked in a sort of implacable longing. There's the quasi-title track's plaintive appeal against light pollution. Or the two takes of ""The Sea Was Calling Me Home""
column3: a mournful song that sees in the human fear of conformity little more than our standard fear of death. These songs aren't sad
column4: exactly; they're ambivalent
column5: as any honest look at the world probably ought to be. Even the love songs give both sides of the coin: ""I Was the One She Came For"" is so sweet and pure that you may find yourself wanting to believe the title isn't meant as a pun (in which case it's hilarious); ""It Was Time for Me to Be With Her"" depicts an otherworldly encounter
column6: like the Modern Lovers' ""Astral Plane"" with another three or four decades' worth of perspective.

column1: There are breezy moments
column2: too: ""These Bodies That Came to Cavort""
column3: an uptempo comment on the absurdity of making our bodies sit down all day
column4: or ignoring them when they tell us to drink less wine; ""If You Want to Leave Our Party Just Go""
column5: a simple rock'n'roll clap-along that promises
column6: ""There's no need to be polite and just stay just for appearances""; and most of all ""My Affected Accent""
column7: a self-effacing romp that isn't far removed from 2008 non-album single ""You Can Have a Cell Phone That's OK But Not Me"" and contains an immortal lyric
column8: ""I should have been bullied more than I was."" In apologizing for his 40-years-ago affectations
column9: Richman raises the question whether he-- or any of us-- can truly avoid other affectations
column10: other things ""just for appearances
column11: now or ever. We probably can't; as the philosophers say
column12: it's turtles all the way down. Then again
column13: Richman's career is a testament to the beauty of a lost but noble cause. In one of O Moon's last lines
column14: he asks
column15: ""What's life without the search for the darkened
column16: the shadowed
column17: the obscure?"" If anyone can find it
column18:
it's this guy. It's still a thrill listening to him look.

column3: the seventh LP from embattled hardcore-prog studio junkies ...And You Will Know Us by the Trail of Dead
column4: is something of a double-concept album
column5: running the thematic gamut from the death of rock radio to the work of comparative mythologist Joseph Campbell. It is split into two sections-- well
column6: suites-- divided by key. There's a limited edition that comes complete with an extra half hour of music and a graphic novel. There's that cover. Considering

column1: Trail of Dead pared down to a four-piece for the 10-day Tao sessions

column3: Tao of the Dead seems to chop its recent predecessors' average per-song runtime roughly in half. Worlds Apart and especially So Divided-- the nadir of the Trail of Dead catalog-- dragged on with excessive runtimes and twice-too-many choruses and elaborate instrumental scaffolding that
column4: tarp removed
column5: revealed a house of cards.

column1: Rather than blowing out the back end of every song with such a movement
column2: Tao of the Dead maps its grand ambitions over its full length; songs slip by quickly but not without notice
column3: and certain motifs reappear throughout
column4: lending the disc a somewhat hallucinogenic disorientation. Mostly
column5: though
column6: they move; the clipped construction helps

column8: easy on the extraneous racket
column9: alternately lovely and bruising-- are among the most delicate and memorable the band have unleashed. And
column10: smartly
column11: in shifting the focus back to the tunes themselves
column12: they've pushed the grand payoff to the end
column13: once they've really earned it.

column1: Opener ""Let's Experiment"" gives way to ""Pure Radio Cosplay""
column2: a sweaty rocker with an almost Stonesy underpinning that laments the death of rock radio
column3: a clever inversion considering it's the band's most radio-ready track in years. Conrad Keely's rough-hewn
column4: gun-to-the-head howl is
column5: like almost everything
column6: pitched down somewhat here on Tao
column7: evincing notes of near-prettiness at times
column8: but he spits out ""Cosplay"" like he really can't believe something like Nickelback exists while he languishes in semi-obscurity. Yet the sour
column9: why-not-us vibe of World's Apart couldn't be farther from the fantastical worlds Keely touches on here; his lyrics
column10: as they often do
column11: seem dwarfed by the music
column12: but the few he dangles out in front seem to emerge from Keely's full immersion in Tao's mythos. He didn't just namedrop Yes' Relayer and Rush's Hemispheres in pre-interviews because there's little or no pause between songs; each conjures a fully-formed universe between your ears
column13: a quality Tao not only aspires to but frequently achieves.

column1: As ""Cosplay"" winds down
column2: Keely jumps in with ""Wanna do another?
column3: and off they go to ""Summer of All Dead Souls""
column4: elegantly oscillating between space battle to acoustic plea without overselling either. ""Cover the Days Like a Tidal Wave"" lays a spoken-word missive over some undulating chords. Despite its title
column5: ""The Wasteland"" is a lovely
column6: sinewy psych-grunge number
column7: gliding nimbly from mellotron to megawatts. And ""Spiral Jetty"" feels like a the start of something overcooked that
column8: in the past
column9: Keely and company might’ve drawn out. Here it doesn't hit the two-minute mark
column10: closing out with a bit of dazzling feedback
column11: then easing into the sumptuous ""Weight of the Sun (Or the Post-Modern Prometheus)"". These aren't epics in miniature
column12: exactly; they move through sections and shift tone gracefully
column13: but individual tracks rarely overstay their welcome
column14: instrumental passages rarely getting more than a few seconds to themselves. When the reprise of ""Cosplay"" swings around again two-thirds of the way through the record
column15: it's a surprise every time: shouldn't that've felt longer?

column1: Tao
column2: smartly
column3: farms out most of its monolithic hugeness to the record's last two-- well
column4: six-- tracks. But not before ""Ebb Away""
column5: the loveliest track Trail of Dead have made since ""Crowning of a Heart"" from The Secret of Elena's Tomb EP nearly a decade ago. A little guitar tumble
column6: remarkable in its understatement

column12: the five-part
column13: key-of-F
column14: half-a-""Family Guy"" closing suite. ""Strange News"" is a bit like the last three Trail of Dead records in microcosm
column15: lots of movement
column16: with a tendency to drift. The track goes from a lurching alt-rock swirl to sampling a documentary about teenage homelessness in Seattle to a Source Tags-style hardcore pummel and back around again. Some will find the grandiose ""Strange News"" the most thrilling bit of Tao; others may take it as a separate piece entirely
column17: saving it for later or skipping it outright.

column1: So much of Trail of Dead's post-Source Tags & Codes output has felt desperate to recapture that now-classic set’s bluster and heart
column2: only to favor one over the other to the detriment of both. That album’s teetering-on-the-brim mix of beauty and furor seems now like lightning in a bottle
column3: the sort of thing you’d spend your life trying (and failing) to replicate. Tao of the Dead does feel
column4: in its songs and structure alike
column5: like the first post-Source Tags record not cooled in the giant shadow of their decade-old triumph; more patient
column6: more potent
column7: more dynamic
column8: less overloaded
column9: the band deftly charting out their ""Flight of the Navigator"" death trip
column10:
the skewed alt-prog fantasia between their ears come hurtling to life. Set your controls for the heart of your bong.
