About four years ago
column2: the Jamaican label Greensleeves released a double-disc greatest-hits set called From Dubplate to Download: The Best of Greensleeves Records. The label's been releasing music for decades now
column3: and listening to the set felt like taking a crash course in 30 years of Jamaican anthems
column4: from the the Wailing Souls' slow
column5: organic roots music to the fired-up high-BPM digital dancehall of recent years. And as compulsively listenable as From Dubplate to Download was
column6: there was enough variety in that long arc that the stuff at the end really didn't belong to the same genre as the stuff at the beginning. When you look back at Greensleeves' catalog
column7: you're looking at a truly varied landscape.

column1: As a DJ
column2: Diplo's greatest asset has always been his versatility
column3: his willingness to pull from any and all possible sources in order to keep a party moving. Never Scared
column4: the landmark 2003 mix from Diplo and Low Budget's Hollertronix project
column5: introduced many of us to Diplo's flailing style by finding room for the Bangles and Baltimore club and the Clash and random-ass Southern rap micro-hits; it felt like they were chewing up the whole of popular music and puking it back out in danceable form. In recent years
column6: that DJ style has hardened into something of a shtick as lesser DJs have taken it and run. But Diplo
column7: at his best
column8: still has a rare sense of rule-blurring vision; he managed
column9: for instance
column10: to get an entire festival crowd dumbing out to Ace of Base's ""All That She Wants"" during Major Lazer's set at last year's Pitchfork Music Festival. The whole Major Lazer project is a testament to how much Diplo and partner Switch love Jamaican music in all its stylistic variety
column11: so you'd think that
column12: given Greensleeves' massive back catalog to play with
column13: Diplo would take the opportunity to just go nuts. Not the case.

column1: Riddimentary: Diplo Selects Greensleeves
column2: his DJ mix of music from the label's past
column3: turns out to be a love letter to a very specific period in the genre's evolution: The early-80s moment when deep one-drop roots reggae was just starting to transform into dancehall. It was a time when all these older stars started to integrate digital drum-triggers and echoey synthesizer lines into their tracks
column4: and when the Barrington Levy/Yellowman style of nonsensical stutter-scatting was blowing up. Riddimentary isn't a wide-ranging dance party; it's a mix that maintains a single mood and a single tempo throughout. You could dance to it
column5: if you wanted
column6: but you could also wash dishes or read a book or drive down a highway in the middle of the night.

column1: In focusing on this one instant in the label's history
column2: Diplo shows a sharp understanding of the genre. There's only one track that appears on both the Greensleeves greatest-hits record and Riddimentary: ""Telephone Love""
column3: a 1988 crossover hit from Londoner J.C. Lodge
column4: by far the most modern-sounding track on Diplo's mix. Riddimentary does have a few big
column5: immortal anthems-- Gregory Isaacs' ""Night Nurse""
column6: for instance-- but it's just as likely to chase the genre down the bizarre rabbit holes it was digging at the time. So we get some dubby
column7: digitized instrumental experiments from lifers like Joe Gibbs and Prince Far I. We also get a few tracks very specific to their moment
column8: like ""Police in Helicopter""
column9: John Holt's threat to burn down sugarcane fields if police keep cracking down on marijuana farmers
column10: or ""Eventide Fire a Disaster""
column11: Barrington Levy and General Echo's mournful elegy about a 1980 blaze in a Kingston old folks' home.

column1: Riddimentary isn't a defining work of genre exhumation or anything; if you love reggae
column2: you might have a decent chunk of this mix in your iTunes
column3: and the more obscure material probably won't change your life. But it does work as a warm
column4: sustained mood-piece and a serious demonstration that Diplo knows what he's talking about when it comes to this reggae thing. If you happened to hear it in the background
column5: very little about the mix would signal that Diplo was the guy behind it; he barely even digs into his endless supply of airhorn effects and DJ drops. He just plays the background and lets the music do the talking. In this case
column6:
that's exactly what he needed to do.

column14: he calls someone ""more pussy than a cat paw.""

column1: The sneaky cleverness of some of these lines point to Gunplay's dirty
column2: shameful secret: He's actually a pretty great rapper. It's not immediately detectable beneath his goofy bluster
column3: but in the buried internal rhymes and piled-up assonances of lines like ""My niggas rock rags like a Saudi/ My Maserati looping round the emblems on ya Audi/ Only nigga out in Berlin blowin' Cali Maui/ Only nigga out in Par-ee spittin' out my calamaris"" (from ""Another One""
column4: a steam-rolling collaboration with Rick Ross and Diddy) you can hear the crumpled sheets of draft paper that went into them
column5: as well as a genuine love of words.

column1: This sense of craftsmanship is part of why Inglorious Bastard remains replayable after dozens of listens
column2: but it also means things never catch fire in the same way Flockaveli did. At every moment
column3: Gunplay remains firmly in control of his own unhinged joyride
column4: whereas it wasn't entirely clear if Flockaveli came equipped with brakes. Gunplay doesn't quite fit in with this new school of goon rappers
column5: in that way-- his blend of dead-serious technical chops and exaggerated class-clown posing harks back to Redman
column6: an older model
column7: and rap fans who couldn't stomach the artlessness of Waka Flocka's lyrics might find a more companionable listen in Bastard. However you take it
column8: though
column9: Inglorious remains some of the most colorful and invigorating rap of 2011. If you have a treadmill run in your future
column10: or a car you need to destroy with your bare hands
column11:
it should make a suitable accompaniment to either activity.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16198/homepage_large.7c130fac.jpg|Invariable Heartache|29326.0|KORT|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['City Slang']|2011-02-11 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:34:21.934733|"

Chart Records is a bit of obscure Nashville history
column2: notorious to those who dig through the crates at Grimey's but largely unregarded by those outside the city limits. Founded by Gary Walker in 1962 and purchased by local businessman Slim Williamson in 1964
column3: it was the temporary home of established acts like Junior Samples and Red Sovine
column4: but the emphasis was squarely on young talent with crossover potential
column5: including its biggest success story
column6: Lynn Anderson. Most of its roster might not ring a bell these days
column7: mush less a cash register
column8: but Chart was certainly a label of its moment
column9: when country was entertaining the notion of pop.

column1: One Chart artist
column2: a Miss Nashville runner-up named Connie Eaton
column3: married Williamson's son
column4: and they had a daughter named Cortney (now Tidwell)
column5: who grew up to become a country singer herself. Nearly half a century after Chart's founding
column6: she is paying tribute to the family business with an album of primarily Chart covers
column7: most of them duets with Lambchop frontman Kurt Wagner. Both represent the seedy Nashville underbelly of local artists actually paying heed to local history
column8: and fittingly
column9: the idea for this collaboration originated on stage at the Basement
column10: where the two sang an impromptu Don Williams cover together.

column1: Like the best Nashville duos
column2: their voices are very different yet suit each other well. Wagner's is an eccentric take on a cowboy croon
column3: which makes the weird psych-folk-country anthem ""Penetration"" more than simply a novelty
column4: while Tidwell's is a robust
column5: breathy version of a traditional starlet
column6: which can sell the delicate quaver of ""A Special Day"" as well as the epic hurt of weeper ""Who's Gonna Love Me Now"". Both communicate with equal ease the regret and invariable heartache of these tunes
column7: especially when they're trading verses. They  have chemistry
column8: which illuminates the rollicking ""Pickin' Wild Mountain Berries"" even as it makes solo numbers like ""April's Fool"" (him) and ""Yours Forever"" (her) a bit wan by comparison.

column1: The material is perhaps the most surprising aspect of Invariable Heartache. There's a startling wit to these songs
column2: not only in the unexpected title phrase sung in the first line of ""Incredibly Lonely"" but also in the coy wink of ""I Can't Sleep With You""
column3: which goes
column4: ""I can't sleep with you... I can't sleep with you... on my mind."" It's not hard to imagine any of these songs becoming hits in the 1960s
column5: nestling alongside Tammy Wynette's ""Stand By Your Man"" or Eddy Arnold's ""Make the World Go Away"". Recruiting a skeleton crew from Lambchop as their backing band
column6: Tidwell and Wagner don't try to re-create the classic sound of Chart Records
column7: with all their strings and bells and whistles
column8: nor do they try to update the songs to today's particular pop-country sound. Instead
column9: Invariable Heartache sounds more like one of Lambchop's more countrified records
column10: which is to say the music is both lush and minimal
column11: the sound of so many musicians giving themselves over completely to the song. It's a gateway album to Chart's back catalog
column12:
as well as to an adventurous era in Nashville history.

Ohio neo-country singer Jessica Lea Mayfield writes eloquently analytical love songs. With her languid drawl suggesting an interior monologue rather than an actual conversation-- as if she's thinking things out in her head-- she comes across as a woman torn between her heart and her brain. On her 2008 debut
column2: With Blasphemy So Heartfelt
column3: she picked apart her relationships like a scholar deconstructs a text
column4: parsing out the finer regrets and conflicts right up to the point of severing the emotional connection between herself and the ""you"" she's addressing. Mayfield sets her songs at that precipice of a break-up-- a tactic that lends her music the emotional force of the best country music and distinguishes her from other songwriters.

column1: Tell Me
column2: her second album
column3: matches and at times even surpasses her debut in terms of rueful atmosphere and unflinching songwriting
column4: and Mayfield works to break free of her country confines and showcase her vocals in new
column5: unexpected settings. Blasphemy set a mood and sustained it; by comparison
column6: the follow-up is positively kaleidoscopic
column7: both musically and emotionally. She writes pop hooks
column8: mingles pedal steel with ramshackle studio beats
column9: and incorporates new styles and influences
column10: such that each song has its own unique identity. If Tell Me lacks the rawness of her youthful debut (she wasn't even old enough to vote when she recorded Blasphemy)
column11: it sounds more adventurous and more playful
column12: taking greater risks that almost always pay off. The beat on ""Grown Man""
column13: which sounds like a factory pre-set on an old Casio re-appropriated as some sort of analog electronica
column14: should sound flippant and gimmicky
column15: yet it lends a wryness to her lyrics about a May-December romance: ""I'd give most anything to know
column16: as you're sitting there with your legs crossed and no clothes on
column17: what you are thinking of."" She is
column18: the song makes clear
column19: the more mature one.

column1: Sex remains a constant throughout these songs
column2: yet because it offers a respite from romantic bewilderment
column3: Mayfield's songwriting never becomes tawdry. ""Hate has brought me up the stairs into your house
column4: she sings on ""Our Hearts Are Wrong"". ""I'll not let hate be the one to make me naked for you."" There's a lot going on in these tough-minded tracks
column5: and the music is calibrated to reinforce her heady sentiments. Forgoing the cavernous sound of Blasphemy
column6: producer Dan Auerbach gives Tell Me a snappy immediacy that unites these disparate styles and musical experiments into a cohesive whole. His and Richie Kirkpatrick's guitars crash almost brutally against her delicate vocals on ""I'll Be the One You Want Someday"" and ""Somewhere in Your Heart""
column7: but in a way that enacts her emotional turmoil.

column1: The album peaks early with ""Blue Skies Again""
column2: whose ooh-sha-la-la's (sung by Auerbach) and simple
column3: infectious chorus make it a standout. It's Mayfield's most pop-oriented moment
column4: mixing country
column5: girl group
column6: shoegazer
column7: and indie pop into a breezy sound
column8: but it's also a sunny
column9: reassuring song that draws even more power from being the bright spot among so many dire situations. And that reveals the central and enthralling contradiction on Tell Me: Mayfield's uncertainties have inspired a proportionately confident album
column10:
as musically assured as it is romantically conflicted.

Rajko Müller's unique gift as a producer is his sense of play. His best tracks are the sonic equivalent of page-turners
column2: constantly making room for new sounds
column3: melodies
column4: and rhythmic half-thoughts
column5: constantly in motion without ever sounding like they made a radical departure. When they work
column6: it's in subtle ways: All their parts sound like they belong even when their entrances feel unexpected. Müller tends to stick to house music's basic pattern of one bass-drum thunk every beat and one snare every other
column7: which is another reason it never seems like he's up to anything overtly unusual: There's always a simple rhythm to tie you down if the other ones-- the sneaky
column8: evaporating ones-- don't. In between the beats are sweet
column9: detuned melodies
column10: computer wheezes
column11: and flashes of dissonance. That his experiments don't always work makes me like him more-- it seems like he'd rather hear a track fall short than bend to the rules.

column1: Müller's last full-length as Isolée
column2: 2005's We Are Monster
column3: sounded like a cluttered dollhouse
column4: micro in scale but overflowing with ornaments. It's still an amazing album for listeners who'd prefer a parade of tiny surprises to a few skullcrushing ones
column5: and probably my favorite piece of legitimate dance music to crossover to an indie audience in the past several years. Since then
column6: he's released a few singles and EPs
column7: and an early works collection called Western Store-- basically
column8: a total of maybe nine or 10 new tracks over the past six years.

column1: For people who've followed him-- through the ""Albacares"" single
column2: ""October""/""Nightingale""
column3: and ""The Fantastic Researches of Yushin Maru""-- the feel of Well Spent Youth will be familiar. It's less cheerful than We Are Monster
column4: still soft but more dissonant and evasive
column5: and significantly more invested in that recurring fascination of contemporary techno
column6: the squelchy noise.

column1: Its most unusual tracks--""Going Nowhere"" and ""Transmission""-- are so littered with sound that they feel almost random
column2: and while Müller manages to tie them together for a few seconds at a time
column3: the coherence is mostly exciting because of these wild
column4: slippery moments on either end where the music appears to come in and out of focus. He reprises melodic and rhythmic ideas
column5: but to my ears the tracks themselves are never cyclical-- it's flux-music
column6: and music that sounds better when you're willing to be patient with it than when you're not.

column1: In other places
column2: he lapses into moody
column3: low-key house
column4: and in a couple of instances-- ""Thirteen Times an Hour"" and ""Taktell""-- revisits the bright slow-plays that marked We Are Monster. While this record doesn't feel as spirited as his last full-length
column5: I think it's also a different album with different aims. I'd imagine Isolée fans who thought the pretty
column6: toy-like tracks on We Are Monster bordered on twee will prefer the open-ended and more mysterious sound of Well Spent Youth.

column1: The album is the first full-length on Pampa Records
column2: a new label run by the prankish and wonderful DJ Koze (about whom I have a lot of nice things to say
column3: almost all of which can be summed up in a ""commercial"" he recently made for the music tech company Native Instruments). The label that put out We Are Monster
column4: Playhouse
column5: is still around but has receded into a happy routine. At this point
column6: Müller's music isn't really part of a conversation about the future of dance music. ""Microhouse""-- what We Are Monster was classified as-- is an old-fashioned term.

column1: And I doubt Müller cares. He's a venerated producer with a style that people can probably recognize but nobody can imitate well. Hearing him come off a fairly quiet six years with something that doesn't sound at all anxious about being an Isolée album is a show of confidence-- warranted
column2:
of course.

To place them in the context of some of their UK guitar peers
column3: Seefeel neither had a singular creative presence like Kevin Shields
column4: nor did they feature the lush pop songwriting of Ride. Instead they were an ideas band
column5: trying to place techno/rave's quickening rhythms in the context of processed guitar music. Because they executed those ideas so perfectly
column6: it makes sense that they've regrouped more than a decade later in the name of new ideas.

column1: I would like to think that Seefeel principals Mark Clifford and Sarah Peacock planned this all along
column2: that they were biding their time until another potent
column3: fully formed musical thought occurred. Last fall's Faults EP made it clear this wasn't the case: The band was still chewing on sounds and fumbling with rhythms. Any hope Seefeel viewed Faults as a stepping stone instead of a new a aesthetic goes out the window on Seefeel
column4: the band's first full-length record since 1996.

column1: Seefeel is a thorny album
column2: a thicket of crackling guitars and faltering rhythms. Peacock's sparse
column3: drifting vocals-- at this point the last remaining element of the band's previous work-- navigate their way through by gingerly pulling branches aside. The rhythms-- usually live drums-- are supplied by former Boredoms drummer Iida Kazuhisa
column4: but they contain none of that band's combustible clamor. Instead they grapple with the guitars in slow motion. (I'm reminded of professional hockey fights in which the players
column5: with handfuls of each other's jerseys
column6: awkwardly tussle.) Seefeel's guitars now scrape and smolder
column7: but the foggy landscapes they evoke on tracks like ""Rip-Run"" and
column8: um
column9: ""Dead Guitars"" don't seem as rich as those molded by Fennesz or Black Dice.

column1: Seefeel have thankfully retained the ability to build an environment. If their previous albums sounded womb-like
column2: Seefeel is more like being an overgrown forest
column3: including the nagging discomfort: ""This place has a dark beauty
column4: but I wish my socks weren't damp."" That discomfort may be one of the compositional aims of Seefeel
column5: and sometimes it leads to arresting
column6: challenging anti-pop
column7: like on ""Step Down""
column8: where Peacock pines sweetly over an ominous mechanical advance.

column1: I want to admire Seefeel for its decisive move away from the band's past
column2: but I can't find the complexity and depth that allowed them to take an exhausting style-- shoegaze-- and turn it into something new and special. I don't care that Seefeel no longer chip hypnotic rhythms out of blocks if icy guitars
column3: but it bothers me a lot that the simple drum pattern on ""Rip-Run"" never evolves and that Peacock sounds strangled. The issue isn't one of an old fan pining for glory days; it's an old fan wondering if Seefeel would deserve notice if it were released by a group of 20-year-olds in New York or London. The answer is yes
column4: I think
column5:
but just barely.

It's usually unfair to evaluate a rapper based on image alone
column3: but that's exactly what New York MC Theophilus London wants. Not since Gene has an artist sought so blatantly to turn Morrissey idol worship into instant credibility: Now signed to a major
column4: his introduction was called This Charming Mixtape despite its This Year's American Apparel Model cover art
column5: and these days you can catch him rocking a Smith College hat
column6: which-- double word score-- happens to be an all-female institution of higher learning. Fine-- maybe he's not trying to be some sort of inside operative attempting to subvert hip-hop's typical ideas of masculinity
column7: intellect
column8: and proper sonic influence. But from Lovers Holiday
column9: it's plain to see why his forthright opinions are more often found in men's fashion mags than hip-hop rags: he's either unwilling or incapable of letting his music do any of the actual legwork.

column1: That said
column2: its easy to see what the draw is with London: By cutting straight rhyming with large quantities of R&B's 80s futurism and teen-friendly pop
column3: he represents the contemporary ideal for a modern MC. And unlike
column4: say
column5: B.o.B. or Kid Cudi
column6: you never get the idea A&Rs had to massage a rhyme spitter past into a Billboard-aspiring present. That's pretty much been the plan from Day One for London
column7: so there will be no protests of compromise. Problem is
column8: the smug entitlement
column9: unctuous self-satisfaction
column10: and cornball loverman raps reveal its bloodline to the drunk uncle of current radio rap: Common's Electric Circus.

column1: But that was a whole lot of momentarily misguided ambition
column2: whereas Lovers Holiday has London with his grip on the controls
column3: putting together a concept EP of sorts that attempts to capture the angles of humankind's most complex emotion but mostly just reminds me of places where I pay too much for work slacks. The coked-out couture-pop of ""Why Even Try?"" is typical of the hollowed chill preferred by London
column4: and whatever novelty could be gleaned from having Sara Quin (of Tegan and...) as a guest is spoiled by giving her the role and vocal processing of any given R&B gun for hire. If you ever needed a primer on what made ""Yamaha"" a display of The-Dream's mastery
column5: go check out the rental version of ""Little Red Corvette"" offered by ""Strange Love"". The idea of whether this is ""real hip-hop"" is moot; it simply falters as pop.

column1: But the gaping void at the center is London himself-- for all the Moz namedropping
column2: he's retained none of his poetry
column3: none of his vocal presence
column4: and certainly none of his wit. His singing voice is serviceable enough
column5: but he has pretty much one flow as a rapper
column6: a halting cadence that has him wheezing for breath at the end of every half bar and gives you plenty of time to register what you've just heard. Most often
column7: his lack of vocal engagement makes outright clunkers scarce
column8: but there are plenty of fortune cookie jewels (""You look ahead and I know you see the stop signs/ A blind man know it's not green all the time"") and squeamish come-ons (""Girl I ain't goin' nowhere sit here and cops and robbers down by the moonlight"") that are impossible to miss. References to camera phones and real-time Facebook updates act as signifiers of ""love in the modern time"" on ""Wine & Chocolates""
column9: yet 2011 still finds a place for harlequin romance details and the fumbled eroticism of a thousand college poetry classes. Competition is fierce
column10: but ""We can wear matching shoes like 'Thriller'/ And watch Godzilla"" ultimately won out for the biggest facepalm. This all comes immediately after the hook on prior track ""Girls Girls $"" becomes the most frequently heard line of Lovers Holiday-- ""She got drunk/ Showed her pussy on WorldStar.""

column1: Recently
column2: London was profiled in a feature called ""Rebel Style""
column3: but tellingly it was in GQ as opposed to any publication related to music. The piece touted him as not ""just a rapper
column4: but a ""Morrissey-obsessed songwriter
column5: who at age 22
column6: has already become a style icon."" We can have sartorial arguments until the stars burn out
column7: but truth is
column8: it's tough to tell exactly what the music is rebelling against here
column9: either sonically
column10: lyrically
column11: visually
column12: thematically
column13: or otherwise
column14: unless you've ignored My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy
column15: Drake
column16: Lil' B
column17: Odd Future
column18: Das Racist
column19: Lil' Wayne
column21: ""Day N Nite""-- in other words
column22: the last three years of cutting-edge pop music. To quote a better lyricist than him
column23: you just haven't earned it

If the highly suspicious bio behind Brooklyn cuddle-wavers Dream Diary is indeed 100% factual
column2: then at least give them credit for hitting the indie pop jackpot of creation tales. According to PR lore
column3: band founder Jacob Danish Sloan
column4: a disillusioned former child prodigy of the upright bass who had a really strong desire to be a rhythm guitarist
column5: bumped into bandmate Madison Farmer while walking along Manhattan's decidedly downtown Essex Street. Both of their iPods were playing the Smiths' The Queen Is Dead-- still unconfirmed if they were also carrying identical copies of The Perks of Being a Wallflower-- and bam
column6: a band was born. They found their drummer
column7: Alexander Iezzi
column8: in a bar
column9: less interestingly (and probably more true).

column1: If you read that tale as a piece of unintentional indie pop parody
column2: you're not to blame. The fibers of ridiculousness strengthen when putting on Dream Diary's debut LP
column3: We Are the Beat. From the opening six-stringed chimes of ""Paper Flowers""
column4: it's clear that we have our first post-Pains of Being Pure at Heart act of 2011. Granted
column5: Pains aren't exactly bastions of originality either-- which is exactly what makes Dream Diary's copy-of-a-copy shtick so hide-your-eyes embarrassing. That
column6: and Sloan's vocals; his thin-lipped
column7: super-affected delivery makes the entire Slumberland batting order look like a bunch of Pavarottis
column8: as it swallows words and obscures sentiments.  Not that the lyrical content here is particularly deserving of close analysis; selected song titles (""Something Tells Her""
column9: ""She Has a Way"") suggest that this record sort of wrote itself. Still
column10: it's hard to believe that in the process of writing and recording ""Audrey of Spirits""
column11: no one pointed out that Sloan's storybook coo makes his pre-chorus utterance sound a whole lot like ""Suckin' your penis.""

column1: The reasonable improvement that could be made to We Are the Beat
column2: then
column3: would be to ditch the singer-- because when he's imaginarily removed from the proceedings
column4: there's really nothing else that's going horribly wrong here. Parts are played
column5: the production is well-executed
column6: and there are even a few decently catchy melodies (the descending mini-fantasia of ""Something Tells Her""
column7: the clean shoegaze structure of ""Young Veronica""). Not even a single bookish hair is out of place here
column8: which in a way makes Dream Diary's place in the still-going Slumberland Revivalist arena that of Longwave's in the early-aughts Manhattan Rock Explosion: slick
column9: competent
column10:
and uncanny at turning sounds normally attached to real feelings into something as joyless and workmanlike as waking up for your job in the morning.

Chikita Violenta is a uniquely North American band. The Mexico City foursome has spent the past several years cutting its teeth in that capital's indie rock scene
column3: furnishing a catalog that's fundamentally at odds with what its local audience asks of its own: pop songs sung in Spanish. Instead
column4: Chikita Violenta sing in English like the 1990s American indie rock bands on which they were weaned-- Built to Spill
column5: Pavement
column6: Modest Mouse
column7: Tortoise. In addition
column8: they've opted to record extensively in Toronto with producer Dave Newfeld of Broken Social Scene fame. It makes for interesting moves: while the ultra-saturated tones and widescreen scale that made Newfeld synonymous with BSS play a noticeable role in Chikita Violenta's psych-pop transmissions
column9: TRE3S
column10: their third long-player (released by the Canadian supergroup's Arts & Crafts imprint)
column11: finds them continuing to home in on shapes and textures of their own.

column1: A good place to begin is the end. In the first warbled seconds of closer ""My Connection""
column2: indecipherable studio chatter is punctuated with a clear invitation: ""Hey
column3: come on in."" Light
column4: hand-woven guitar melodies sprawl in 38 directions at once. People continue to laugh and hoot and holler in the background. A sunny all-member chorus quickly comes into focus. ""My connection just fades away/ My connection just fades away/ Thanks for coming/ Now just walk away."" Its sentiment isn't at all in line with the welcoming way they sing it
column5: but that opening gesture is one with the rest of the indie rock anthemry to be found here. But deeper inside a song like ""My Connection""
column6: you can hear a sense of rapport that clearly allows them to link up in really thrilling ways at times.

column1: Opener ""Roni"" pairs polluted
column2: Ponderosa-thick riffs with gentler acoustic lines to heady effect
column3: its aired out chorus almost lofty as the ones featured in duo ""All I Need's a Little More"" and ""Tired"". Those two in particular lean heavily on Broken Social Scene-established dynamics and sonics
column4: though the schizophrenic pieces of the former glue together really nicely with the help of the sing-a-long at its center. It's a bit of a trade-off. While Chikita Violenta have no problems huddling together to fashion an outsized vocal hook
column5: much of the detail in their sometimes stunning interplay can get lost in froth of those same vocals. Though it's difficult to find a pulse in the grind of ""The Pause"" or meandering ""Siren"" for example
column6:
all of the moving acoustic parts of ""España"" can be found on full display. It's a march that gathers a lot of steam and a lot of tension without ever falling prey to its production values or weighty ambitions. They sound like themselves.

column4: Portishead founder Geoff Barrow took to Twitter to snip at James Blake. ""Will this decade be remembered as the Dubstep meets pub singer years?"" he asked
column5: not naming the 22-year-old producer who
column6: only that morning
column7: was highlighted in the BBC's Sound of 2011 poll. When dubstep boomed and shuddered from Croydon at the dawn of the last decade
column8: Blake wasn't yet a teenager. Barrow
column9: on the other hand
column10: was almost 40 and already on hiatus from one of the previous decade's most influential bands. He'd heard the rise of dubstep-- its cavernous bass
column11: quick-click rhythms
column12: bent vocal hooks-- and the tall
column13: plaid-wearing kid from Enfield must have sounded a lot like its populist fall.

column1: Barrow's dismissal of Blake is
column2: presumably
column3: a defense of dubstep-- the gesture suggests a purist
column4: an elitist
column5: or both. Reconsidered from the other artistic end
column6: however
column7: the implication is that maybe this is the decade where singer-songwriters-- longtime wastrels of pianos and six-strings with three chords-- finally get interesting

column3: on his Hemlock label in 2009; it was solid
column4: slightly spooky dubstep
column5: with drums darting around a sample that kept eroding. Since that debut
column6: though
column7: Blake has slowly focused on crafting songs-- bona fide
column8: three-to-four minute builders-- around hooks. Last year's ""CMYK""
column9: for instance

column4: for instance

column7: editing and re-shaping it into a new form that bears only the faintest resemblence to its opening source material. In the suite's second half

column9: static bursts
column10: and piano splashes become the essential motion. It's the type of track you might have heard on one of his recent EPs-- the kind Blake purists lament this album's supposed lack of.

If Blake really does cross over and become the pretty white male who introduces a broader audience to dubstep

Divining the inspirations and reasons why behind a record's sound can be tricky business
column3: but sometimes it's obvious. Young Galaxy were a mostly stagnant indie rock band out of Montreal whose dream-pop debut failed to garner any buzz on Arts & Crafts records. When 2009's Invisible Republic reduced their reliance on obfuscation and tightened their rhythms
column4: they still felt like a genre band outside the indie zeitgeist: theatric
column5: self-serious synth-pop. Shapeshifting
column6: the band's third album and first on Paper Bag Records
column7: was produced remotely by Studio's Dan Lissvik. The band retains their big-idea spaciness but sees Lissvik place his coiled rhythms and pulsing synths all over. The result is Young Galaxy's finest record
column8: and while it's impossible to say if Lissvik made the band better
column9: he definitely made them more interesting and relevant.

column1: Young Galaxy have always been good at glancing skyward
column2: but Lissvik provided them the jetpacks necessary to travel there. Lissvik received a fully recorded album from the band and was charged with producing/augmenting the material. Whatever specific contributions he did make
column3: Shapeshifting sounds like his work
column4: at least rhythmically: The songs are underpinned by short
column5: repeating circuits of disco guitar
column6: twinkling piano
column7: and disco thumps. It's impossible to hear the tropical whorls of ""Peripheral Visionaries"" or the way ""Phantom""'s jumping
column8: trebly guitars sink in and out of elongated sighs without hearing the elusive Swede. Sometimes the results are stunning. On ""We Have Everything""
column9: McCandless casts aside her celestial musings in favor of ascendant personal theater: ""I wept when we parted/ I wept when we united/ In poverty my love we have everything
column10: she sings
column11: Lissvik stretching a cityscape behind her. ""B.S.E."" recalls a more muscular version of the Eurythmics.

column1: Young Galaxy make explicit the type of evergreen romanticism mostly implied by bands like M83 and the Dears. Songs like ""We Have Everything"" will make you want to seize your inner libertine and/or power through your modest gym workout. They are not fucking around with vagaries or self-consciousness: at one point Catherine McCandless sings
column2: ""Watch as energy/ Rolls out to us on golden horns of light."" McCandless and the less operatic but less captivating Stephen Ramsay are hopelessly
column3: furiously enchanted throughout. The lyrics can be oppressively silly
column4: and even if they're no more so than some of Young Galaxy's peers (Cut Copy
column5: M83) I find it harder to suppress the snickers during their starry dramas. Shapeshifting is not an album for those repulsed by horoscopes and dreamcatchers.

column1: Dance music errs on the side of fantasy frequently
column2: though those fantasies tend to be self-contained (e.g. in the club
column3: in your heart). Shapeshifting isn't proper dance music-- let's call it dance-inflected pop-- but it is fantastic and unbound. The friction between Lissvik's meticulous spheres and the abandon with which McCandless and Ramsay push against their edges generates a heat absent on prior Young Galaxy records. And while it would seem that makes the band the big winners here
column4:
they do provide the occasionally sterile Lissvik with excesses (of melody and emotion) that he doesn't always generate on his own. Listening to him handle it-- imagine a child trying to hold a beach ball underwater-- is Shapeshifting's greatest reward.

It's hard to think of a more surprising reunion than that of instrumental trio the Notekillers. The Philadelphia-based group skated on the edges of post-punk and no wave in the late 1970s
column2: releasing just one 7"" (""The Zipper"" b/w ""Clockwise"") during a five-year career. What they didn't know when they broke up in 1981 was the single had a big effect on Thurston Moore and the band he was starting at the time
column3: Sonic Youth. 20 years later
column4: Moore cited that influence in Mojo magazine
column5: sparking a renewal that led to an archival Notekillers release on his Ecstatic Peace label
column6: and the reforming of the band
column7: whose members were now split between Philly and NYC.

column1: Flash-forward another nine years
column2: and the Notekillers have finally crafted their first album of new music since reuniting. That may seem like a long time
column3: but it's understandable given how busy the three musicians are-- especially guitarist David First
column4: who has forged a three-decade career as a minimalist composer and sound artist. Besides
column5: time seems rather irrelevant for this band. The sound of the 10 chugging tracks on We're Here to Help is as vital and distinctive as those they originally crafted the first time around.

column1: It's a sound that's accessible and welcoming
column2: but not easy to pin down. This is ostensibly structured punk rock
column3: with melodic shapes that resemble verses and choruses. The closest reference point is another underappreciated instrumental outfit
column4: Pell Mell. Some songs also recall the brain-vs-brawn math-metal of Don Caballero. But where both of those groups colored within their own designated lines
column5: a good bit of Notekillers' appeal comes from their willingness to play rough and loose
column6: and let their sounds spill around a bit. Sometimes they even stretch into feedback-drenched free jazz. And the band's melodic curves are deceptive-- often a catchy hook becomes a repetitive mantra before you know it
column7: no doubt due to First's highly-developed feel for the powers of minimalism.

column1: If that sounds too theoretical or abstract
column2: don't worry-- We're Here to Help is way more fun than educational. The Notekillers make energy and momentum their main priorities throughout
column3: and every song-- even the loosest and noisiest-- has its share of head-nodding beats and air-guitar-worthy riffs. For me
column4: the best tracks feature a wide range of twists
column5: leaps
column6: and crescendos. Take ""Papers"": opening with a snaky guitar line akin to Pete Townsend's wiry intro to the Who's version of ""Shakin' All Over""
column7: the trio swerves from rising rave-ups
column8: to hypnotic chord repetitions
column9: to fiery noise
column10: to even a bouncy middle section begging for hand-clap accompaniment. Such fresh diversity makes it seem like the Notekillers could-- and hopefully will-- keep churning out this ecstatic music for a long
column11:
long time.

Digital technology provides modern electronic producers with superhuman control over countless hyper-real sounds. In the analog 1970s

His augustly hyphenated name makes him sound like a severe German classical composer

column8: improvisations
column9: and moods. Amid Brian Eno's stillness and Kraftwerk's speed and light

column3: on a Revox reel-to-reel

column3: or the thrumming bass clusters of ""Fabelwein""-- while the others modulate thematic material around it in windy
column4: twisting lines. Sometimes

column8: minor

Roedelius preferred gambits of harmony and counterpoint-- one of his favorites is to let a clump of established intervals suddenly unclench and go wheeling across an octave or more. It's not that the music isn't brainy: The carefully patterned pitches

column1: The Selbstportraits can be monotonous; monotony is part of their charm. Roedelius' versatility with limited resources imbues the music with what can only be described as a deep humanity-- a mandatory thoughtfulness. ""Prinzregent"" has a remotely Asian cast
column2: while ""Herold"" gestures at funk. ""Halmharfe"" has a Nordic dolefulness

column4: a standout track from II
column5: introduces the pointillistic arpeggios of techno into the matrix. But it's all so blended into Roedelius' almost-subliminal style that a cursory listen makes the albums sound monolithic
column6: like one undifferentiated electronic pulse. You have to slow down and attune to both the pace and the narrow palette of Roedelius' world

column8: all in all
column9:
is the magic of this music-- it inspires the familiar nostalgia of having more appreciation for fewer options.

Digital technology provides modern electronic producers with superhuman control over countless hyper-real sounds. In the analog 1970s
column4: Hans-Joachim Roedelius made do with the merely real
column5: coaxing miles of variation from his Farfisa's limited selection of timbres
column6: which all tended to be shrill and watery. He recorded the material that would be released in a long series of Selbstportraits whenever he wasn't busy helping to define Krautrock and ambient music as a co-founder of seminal kosmische bands Cluster and Harmonia. His augustly hyphenated name makes him sound like a severe German classical composer
column7: but he brought a playfully jazzy sensibility to these solitary miniatures
column8: improvisations
column9: and moods. Amid Brian Eno's stillness and Kraftwerk's speed and light
column10: Roedelius found a middle way between the void and the Autobahn. His Selbstportraits are dreamy
column11: introspective cruises
column12: rising and falling as if over looping country lanes.

column1: Recorded over old tape at low speed
column2: in mono
column3: on a Revox reel-to-reel
column4: these albums sound really dated. That's why this happens to be an ideal moment to re-release the first two
column5: as their datedness-- they were originally issued on Sky Records in 1979 and 1980-- feels quite contemporary
column6: thanks to the modern resurgence of Roedelius' style of gently propulsive
column7: floridly minimalist keyboard music. You hear it everywhere in recent years
column8: from Oneohtrix Point Never and Arp to Ducktails and Nite Jewel
column9: burbling in woolly analog atmospheres. It seems that when modern musicians aspire to something back-to-basics with electronic music
column10: it's Roedelius' durable easy-listening/new-age aesthetic they're after. Selbstportrait I and II are similar in style and quality
column11: and casual fans may need only one in their lives. II has a couple of the best individual tracks
column12: and contains added material. I is stronger overall
column13: or at least feels that way because it came first
column14: introducing the palette and ideas Roedelius continues to explore on II.

column1: The formula is deceptively simple. There are usually two or three distinct voices
column2: one of which will be an ostinato-- the coursing piano of ""In Liebe Dein""
column3: or the thrumming bass clusters of ""Fabelwein""-- while the others modulate thematic material around it in windy
column4: twisting lines. Sometimes
column5: the ostinato is left out in favor of sheer thematic exploration
column6: as on ""Inselmoos""
column7: where Roedelius manipulates a sticky harpsichord-like motif through major
column8: minor
column9: and hints of chromatic modes. The music is usually solidly tonal
column10: eschewing dissonance to create a sense of everlasting flow. Roedelius preferred gambits of harmony and counterpoint-- one of his favorites is to let a clump of established intervals suddenly unclench and go wheeling across an octave or more. Maybe you've already got your mind made up about the Babies. This side project of two of Brooklyn lo-fi's marquee acts finds Woods bassist Kevin Morby trading songwriting duties and vocals with chief Vivian Girls songwriter Cassie Ramone
column2: whose fast-and-loose way with pitch is a source of contention in the indie rock world. Morby's Woods are a bit of a litmus test themselves
column3: their spindly
column4: bedhead country-folk too mellow and unfinished-sounding for some. The Babies recorded their self-titled debut at Brooklyn's Rear House with Woods' Jarvis Taveniere
column5: and the backroom vibe present on most of his productions turns up here as well. Point being
column6: the temptation to put The Babies together in your mind before you've even heard it can overwhelm any reservation of judgment.

column1: The reality
column2: it turns out
column3: is often more interesting than the sum of its parts. Heard here
column4: Morby's ramshackle country-folk sounds like Woods on a good night's sleep and a pot of strong coffee
column5: running dirtier and kicking a whole lot harder. Morby's voice carries a slight twang and a frequently pronounced derangement
column6: while Ramone-- when she's not left to sing these songs alone-- puts in a showing that might not change any minds
column7: but does hint at where her strengths lie. At its best
column8: The Babies conjures not the shrugged-off ease of either principal's better-known gigs
column9: but the odd-couple white lightning of Johnny and June
column10: Frank and Kim
column11: or John and Exene
column12: run through a K Records filter. Unusual as it is
column13: Ramone knows how to make her voice work for her-- see ""Tell the World"" from Vivian Girls' debut-- and here
column14: when she and Morby crash into one of their delirious top-heavy harmonic pile-ups
column15: the result is dizzying.

column1: Take ""Breakin' the Law""
column2: an outlaw's honeymoon trip with a hook so worn-in you'd think it was a cover. Ramone deadpans while Morby fills in the melody. ""Meet Me in the City"" taps the pure ripchord energy and guy-gal vocal multiplication of Wild Gift-era X
column3: while closer ""Caroline"" ends with a shout-along only a bit less rousing than the similarly-named Neil Diamond tune. Their voices
column4: each a bit spiky apart
column5: line up together with an eerie beauty
column6: like they’ve been singing together far longer than they have
column7: and the tunes they attach to their back-and-forth tend to be the Babies' most infectious.

column1: It's when Morby and Ramone put a little space between them that The Babies falters. Morby's breezy
column2: Ramone-less tunes tend to downshift somewhere between Pavement and the first couple of Frank Black and the Catholics LPs; he's got a nice and easy way with hooks and a smart aversion to overcomplication
column3: but his punker ""Personality"" only has so much
column4: and the jerky ""Sunset"" feels stale. Ramone solo doesn't fare quite as well. ""All Things Come to Pass"" bobs along on a pleasant enough melody
column5: one that she seems to take as a mere suggestion; her voice draws curlicues around the verses
column6: sounding like she'd rather be doing almost anything but singing them. Yet she manages to swing around on the choruses
column7: not exactly evincing perfect pitch but suggesting another take might have done the whole song some good. Her husky bit on ""Voice Like Thunder"" is equally nonchalant
column8: and the bridge she sings on opener ""Run Me Over"" almost destroys the good will created by its grinning lead-in until Morby swoops in. But the dirgey
column9: yearning ""Wild 1 is a lost cause
column10: as Ramone's vocal veers quickly into the painful.

column1: What's ultimately frustrating about The Babies is how much potential is floating around in there
column2: and how game they are to spike it. In throwing in his lot with Ramone
column3: Morby's big songwriting debut is now tied up with all kinds of preconceived notions about his songwriting partner. And Ramone
column4: who actually sounds as good or better here singing with Morby than she does with her breathy Vivian Girls compatriot Katy Goodman
column5: does a number on the goodwill she builds up here with her maddeningly inconsistent performances. So they've made made a spotty but occasionally quite successful record
column6: complicated considerably by Ramone's take-them-or-leave-them vocals
column7:
still the kind of thing only those with their minds already made up could truly love. You expected something else?

For me
column2: the most satisfying scene in the whole Lord of the Rings trilogy was the bit where the Ents finally mobilize and move to tear down the... what was that they were destroying? Some sort of orc factory? I don't remember
column3: honestly
column4: but as thinly veiled as the environmental allegory of the scene was
column5: the justice inherent to a bunch of trees taking out the very industrial operation that had been depleting the forest was quite satisfying. The album art for Hello Echo's debut album
column6: Hello
column7: takes that image and makes it several times more literal
column8: showing an Ent-like tree
column9: dukes up
column10: squaring off against some sort of smokestack skyscraper monster
column11: and the images continues onto the back of the digipack to reveal a nearby city about to be wiped out by a towering wave.

column1: The overt environmentalism of its cover art doesn't quite carry over into the album's music
column2: but it is reflected somewhat in the album's tension between the pastoral and the urban. The songs are full of images of moving out where people don't dominate the landscape
column3: to the desert or the seaside

column6: in this case a car's engine. The trio is lead by guitarist Sean Aylward

column8: whose drummer
column9: Jeremy Black
column10: produced Hello. He's joined by bassist Mike Sarno and drummer Mikey Silva
column11: and together they make an interesting trio-- they have a pretty normal set-up

column13: especially when he's playing electric.

column1: Aylward's style has its best showcase on ""Stone"". He layers acoustic and electric guitar into a cycling rhythm that imparts urgency to the song's unison singing
column2: but when he breaks out for a little solo near the end of the song
column3: it's very tied in to the structure of what he was already playing
column4: an embellishment of the rhythm part. It's a good style that enlivens the band's songwriting
column5: which is mostly quite strong but occasionally a little short on developed lyrics. Opener ""When Push Comes to Love"" is good to begin with
column6: but his rattling
column7: spiraling leads really blow it up into something huge. The best piece of pure songwriting is the quiet
column8: country-tinged ""Disconnect Me""
column9: which backs Aylward's nearly twangy lead vocal with spectral
column10: wordless harmonies and just a few well-placed electric guitar accents.

column1: That ""Disconnect Me"" succeeds so well without Aylward's guitar dominating it is a good sign for the band's future and potential to branch out. And I do hope they get the chance to branch out. Hello is a very solid debut by a band with plenty of talent-- it's not often I wind up spending so much of an indie rock review talking about a particular player's instrumental style
column2:
but Aylward really seems to have found his own voice on the guitar.

column3: and it's summer in Australia right now. So if  it feels a little weird listening to an album of euphoric

column1: Back when this group released 2004's Bright Like Neon Love
column2: the idea of backing dazed
column3: introverted indie pop with a utopian house thump was still relatively novel. And though that sound has since inspired legions of followers and copycats
column4: still no one does it quite like Cut Copy themselves. 2008's steamrolling In Ghost Colours was an album of anthems; tracks like ""Hearts on Fire"" and ""Lights and Music"" were transcendent pop that stuck in heads for days. But Zonoscope is something different. It's an album-album that puts serious work into movements and transitions
column5: and it works best when you hear it all in one chunk. That doesn't mean it's Cut Copy's OK Computer; it just means that the group has put more work into building a vast
column6: rolling landscape rather than a series of peaks.

column1: Zonoscope opens with a blast of woozy ecstasy in the form of ""Need You Now""
column2: the sort of track where you don't even realize how much tension the group has built up until they release it
column3: and ends with ""Sun God""
column4: a marathon 15-minute groove that slowly morphs into a tranced-out Giorgio Moroder thud. In between those two tracks
column5: Cut Copy build a long-form piece of work that moves between genres and ideas and moods without ever sacrificing its dancefloor momentum.

column1: ""Take Me Over"" works in a bouncy hook from Fleetwood Mac's mid-80s party-staple ""Everywhere"" and gives a sly nod to their countrymen Men at Work
column2: turning down-moments into playful  exercises in irresistible cheeseball melody. ""Where I'm Going"" is a twinkly
column3: faraway sigh of a song that could pass for Washed Out if it wasn't for the titanic Gary Glitter drum-stomp powering it. And ""Pharaohs & Pyramids"" may be the greatest thing here; it uses the band's melodic gifts and the sense of yearning in frontman Dan Whitford's voice and applies them to a classic Chicago house anthem
column4: deploying its keyboard blips
column5: synth-strings
column6: and programmed cowbells at the exact right moments
column7: building into a climactic cresting swoop.

column1: Compared to the last two albums
column2: Zonoscope has precious little guitar crunch
column3: which makes it hard to even call Cut Copy a dance-rock band anymore. And that's for the best-- not just because that combination seems like a less thrilling prospect in 2011 than perhaps it once did
column4: but also because Cut Copy have the architecture of dance music down perfectly and the confidence to execute the genre's moves with absolute precision. Even in the dead of winter
column5:
Zonoscope does its job beautifully. Imagine how it'll sound when you don't have to layer up to go outside.

Even his mask-- an all-purpose ""tribal"" piece fringed with what looks like dried grass-- is a well-meaning symbol: It's to say that ""who he is"" isn't as important as what he's doing. Of course

column1: My main concern about it-- or question

column1: Untold

column6: but has such an idiosyncratic way of sculpting and blending the sounds themselves that his tracks are easy to pick out-- they're stamped. The difference is between risking a smaller audience because you're headstrong about your style or risking an audience that isn't that invested in you because they're not sure who you are.

column1: One of the paradoxes here is that there's nothing that sounds even remotely bad on Step in Shadows. It's a glossy and well-assembled 18 minutes of contemporary UK dance music. But it doesn't really command my attention
column2:
and it never sticks its neck out-- which seems like an all right way to play your remixes but a confusing way to treat your own music.

Close couples often develop their own shared language
column3: a matrix of references and associations that hold unique meaning for the pair. A husband and wife who record and perform music together would seem like strong candidates for being so intuitively intertwined. It'd certainly go a long ways towards explaining the strange folk-pop made by Ben + Vesper.

column1: The world of marrieds Ben and Vesper Stamper is an appealingly odd one
column2: where mundane chores and concerns rub shoulders with snatches of allusive poetry. A typical song on Honors
column3: the duo's sophomore full-length release
column4: will fancifully sketch an image of birds that ""soar above and back and forth in woolly skirts"" and then moments later earnestly ask
column5: ""Are you getting six-plus hours?/ Is your will and testament in order?"" Actions and situations that might seem banal had they been laid out as conventional narrative get infused with wonder and intrigue when placed under the Stampers' stream-of-consciousness spell. ""Cell phone rings
column6: a mother sings/ Or shopping for a bathing suit
column7: the pair reports
column8: but before you have a chance to find the thread
column9: they've moved on to imaginatively observing
column10: ""Carpet socks and static shocks/ Children wield electron fields.""

column1: Ben + Vesper's music
column2: while superficially your standard organic-feeling indie-folk
column3: also seems solely beholden to its own internal logic
column4: with melodic passages frequently broken up by abrupt riffs or discordant tangents. Such persistent tonal shifts theoretically suit the lyrics well
column5: but they lack oomph and often set the duo's songs to meandering when sharper contrasts might've been genuinely thrilling. I look at what Ben + Vesper are doing as being conceptually similar to the Fiery Furnaces or even Pavement. The difference is that the Friedbergers and Stephen Malkmus invest their hodgepodge lyricism with abundant urgency
column6: turning nonsense or banalities into fervent mantras and giving their quixotic tales the push and pull of real drama.

column1: The Stampers
column2: meanwhile
column3: shy away from the loud-soft dynamics that could make even their most obtuse lyrical wanderings feel charged with clear-eyed significance
column4: and only occasionally grasp the importance of giving their listeners an anchor amidst all the associative leapfrogging. When they do hit on a refrain
column5: however
column6: the effect is always galvanizing
column7: and it really doesn't even matter what words they're intoning-- ""Style went to sleep tonight
column8: ""Label your junk or lose it
column9: and ""Thanks to a fireball"" all work just fine when repeated several times with obvious feeling. Those phrases all look pretty inscrutable on the page
column10:
but it's in these moments that Ben + Vesper most sound like they're speaking a language everyone can understand.

Along with the 20th anniversary reissue of Ride's debut LP
column3: Nowhere
column4: comes a thick  booklet of old photos
column5: liner notes
column6: and a Jim DeRogatis-penned look back  on the Oxford shoegazers' near-perfect debut. Flip to page 20 and you'll  find a gem: a grainy shot of the foursome sitting on a bed
column7: shoulder-to-shoulder
column8: each with their own reading material.  Vocalist/guitarist Mark Gardener is at one end
column9: nose-deep in a copy of the cornball self-help novella Jonathan Livingston Seagull. His bandmate
column10: songwriting foil
column11: and eventual  nemesis Andy Bell is left of center
column12: peeking out from behind an issue of Bunty
column13: an old British comic written for teenage girls. Bassist Steve Queralt is engrossed in now-defunct UK pop rag Number One
column14: while drummer Loz  Colbert seems rapt by the Christopher Isherwood novel perched at his  thumbs. With the exception of Gardener's book
column15: a likely reference to Nowhere opener ""Seagull""
column16: it's all very English. But at the same time
column17: there's magic more universal to unpack from this one image. The four of  them look like brothers. They look like ordinary
column18: wise-ass kids you knew or know. They look like a band.

column1: If I asked you about My Bloody Valentine
column2: the other most seminal shoegaze band
column3: chances are you'd think immediately  of Kevin Shields and the countless places you've heard his  singular guitar vision unfurl. But while Ride are often mentioned in  tandem with MBV
column4: their  footprint owes more to their songwork than their sonics
column5: and more to the way all four members clashed and combined. They weren't visionaries or  titans; they were young writers with a taste for high volumes. And they didn't situate their melodies amongst tides of effects-pedal-induced mayhem
column6: either; they did it the other way around. Howls were  there to support hooks
column7: and the psychedelic interplay between Gardener and Bell's two  guitars was far more pivotal to their mission than drapes of all-enveloping  noise. But that said
column8: Nowhere
column9: their seismic debut full-length
column10: found them playing  with elements of the shoegaze sound as much as they ever would. While  it's one of the genre's enduring moments
column11: it's Ride's for another reason: This family of songs is their most focused.

column1: The remastering on this edition makes that all the more clear. It starts with a sharpening. Nowhere was never an especially warm listen
column2: and felt a little flat at times if it wasn't played  dangerously loud. The new shine seems so necessary once you hear it.  Each jangle and contour has been shored up and made more distinct
column3: resulting in a richer listen. The first whinnies of ""Seagull"" sound even more serrated than before
column4: and the elliptical guitar figure at its core is less  muddy. Gardener and Bell's dual vocals on ""Polar Bear"" are now as  streamlined as that song's livelier coda. And those are just two spots  where you can hear again what a great all-around fit they were in the  beginning. Not a note feels errant or alone
column5: and Queralt and Colbert  sound inseparable
column6: capable of pummeling through squall and  enhancing fragile passages with ease. Colbert comes on strong enough to dole out compound fractures
column7: especially during ""Dreams Burn Down"" and ""Vapour Trail."" The latter remains immense
column8: standing tall as the most gripping  four-and-half-minutes of their career. Twenty years later
column9: it's exciting to realize there's a lot more to be relished in between all its chimes.

column1: Such is the case for much of the first disc. When Nowhere first arrived in late 1990
column2: Ride had already released three outstanding EPs (Ride
column3: Play
column4: and Fall) that year alone. The original North American release added three bonus tracks from Fall
column5: which are joined here by three additional tracks from the album sessions: the workman-like trio of ""Unfamiliar""
column6: ""Beneath""
column7: and  ""Sennen"". The new edition also includes ""Today""
column8: a beautiful
column9: acoustic-based torch song  that plumes for miles and miles. Count it up and that's 23 songs of  fantastic quality
column10: all culled from an opening stretch so fertile
column11: the band would have a much easier time crafting early setlists than they ever would replicating that initial spark.

column1: Though the booklet is nice and the remastering essential
column2: what makes this  anniversary package most intriguing is its second disc: a live set from a  Los Angeles show at the Roxy in Spring of 1991. Ride didn't come close  to making a splash in the States like they did at home
column3: but on this  night
column4: if audience noise is any indicator
column5: their reception was electric.  Through headphones
column6: it's hard to believe anyone on stage spent a moment gazing at their shoes
column7: as the legend goes. Rifling through  just half of their catalog at the time
column8: they sound like wild elephants  throwing their weight around. It's a terrific
column9: thunderous recording and you can quickly get a clear sense for why their live show garnered as much excitement as it did then.

column1: At the same time
column2: the nature of what  they were trying to accomplish as a band really comes through in full.  The more abrasive tones of MBV and Sonic Youth were clearly an influence as they first started to write and record
column3: but it's the  from-the-gut pop screech of Dinosaur Jr. that sounds like their closest  kin here. Ride's music wasn't necessarily game-changing but the songs are  the kind that last. When they close with ""Drive Blind""
column4: a cut from their self-titled debut EP
column5: they abandon the song's course just two minutes  in to catch a massive swell of guitar. It grows and grows and it grows  some more
column6: and then
column7: sure enough
column8: the volume dips
column9:
and they circle right back to where they started: a melody. They were really good at that.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16153/homepage_large.247b9671.jpg|Until the Light of Morning|5225.0|Essie Jain|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Light of Morning']|2011-02-04 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:34:37.882344|"

The Wire contributor Rob Young recently published a weighty tome on the history of British folk music titled Electric Eden (out in the U.S. in May). In it
column2: Young expertly threads together the various manifestations of the genre and takes a look at how each successive generation has drawn on strands from the previous one
column3: essentially mapping out a folk music version of Simon Reynolds' hardcore continuum. The book highlights how the root of many of those stylistic shifts stems from material aimed at children. At times this occurs through work like the traditional song ""The Derby Ram""
column4: which Young uses as an example of how lyrics with a spiritual air often end up as kids' nursery rhymes; at others it's channeled from sources such as Oliver Postgate's children's TV shows ""The Clangers"" and ""Pogles' Wood""
column5: which cast a considerable shadow over the Ghost Box/hauntology scene that emerged around the middle of the last decade.

column1: New York-based English singer-songwriter Essie Jain has intuitively wired herself into that same ethos with the release of her third album
column2: Until the Light of Morning. Jain has worked on the periphery of the contemporary folk scene since contributing to the Kill Rock Stars compilation The Sound the Hare Heard in 2006
column3: but for this album she seems to have used all her prior recorded efforts as a cipher of sorts
column4: a way of finding out what makes this music tick. In the sleeve notes Jain claims these songs were written after her friends started to have children; they all seemed to be searching for something appropriately soothing to get their little ones to sleep at night. And soothing it is-- both the vocals and arrangements produce a sense of being swaddled in a great surge of warmth
column5: with Jain adroitly cushioning the listener from the real world.

column1: So what we have here is an album of lullabies
column2: just over half an hour in length
column3: that features a mishmash of Jain's cottony voice and restful instrumental passages. The playing is sparse and tasteful
column4: with Jon Mizrachi's spare taps of glockenspiel often providing the most appropriate counterpart to the snug vocals
column5: while subtle touches of piano
column6: bass
column7: and guitar are slotted in at appropriate junctures. Jain is often compared to Sandy Denny
column8: although her vocal work is less heavily accented
column9: and there's a sense here that she is comfortably maturing into a style of her own. This she demonstrates on the first two tracks
column10: from the soft cooing of ""What a Big Wide World"" to the higher range of ""Lay Down"". The latter is dripping in calm thanks to the light crisscrossing of voice and piano
column11: in which Jain's simple invocations to sleep ultimately evolve into wordless humming as the track relaxes to a slumberous close.

column1: There's nothing studied about this music
column2: no attempt to awkwardly fit it into the freak-folk movement or anything else that could ostensibly win Jain any cool points. This creates a refreshing take on the genre
column3: a return to its base tenets
column4: via words that playfully reflect the habits of animals (""Falling Asleep"") or high-pitched moans that conjure up bewitching imagery of the night sky (""The Magic Star""). Sometimes these two worlds are combined
column5: with a few scattered words neatly conjoined to Jain's rudimentary mantras on ""O
column6: I Love You"". Producer Patrick Glynn deserves credit for creating just the right sense of intimacy by keeping the vocals high in the mix
column7:
often making it feel like she's right there in the room with you.

""When you're young... to say screw it all and chase your dreams is seen as courageous and brave
column2: Sonny Smith reminds us in his song-poem ""Broke Artist at the Turn of the Century"". ""People salute you. As you grow older
column3: they no longer think of you as heroic. They see you as something else: selfish
column4: foolish
column5: or lost."" Yeah
column6: he's singing in character-- Hank Champion
column7: descendent of Texan miners--  but surely that line in the sand between youthful ideologue to struggling something-or-other has occurred to Smith. Especially lately: The San Fran renaissance man-- artist
column8: author
column9: and bandleader-- recently completed work on his most elaborate project yet
column10: a handbuilt jukebox jammed with 100 songs written by Sonny and recorded with help from a coterie of the Bay Area's garage-pop movers and shakers.

column1: Each tune is assigned a fake band name
column2: each record its own custom sleeve with several groups even earning their own elaborate backstories; the mind reels at the scope of the project
column3: the mastery of mixed media such an undertaking would require
column4: the drive it'd take not to just say screw it and move onto something else. Here's this relatively unsung singer-songwriter crafting possibly the most complicated box set of all time
column5: in an edition of one; brave
column6: to be sure
column7: but at least on paper
column8: not too many degrees removed from foolish either. But Smith
column9: as he did with his Sunsets' still-great Tomorrow Is Alright LP
column10: makes it all seem too easy
column11: and his affably eclectic jukebox-era songcraft and the formidable crew he's assembled for backup make I Miss the Jams-- the second
column12: 10-song set culled from the original 100-- seem anything but foolhardy.

column1: With all the project's extra-musical elements
column2: Smith and company could've almost been forgiven for half-assing the songs themselves; standing in a room with that jukebox
column3: punching buttons for Earth Girl Helen Brown or Loud Fast Fools
column4: the occasional noise splatter or big dumb lark would seem almost inevitable. But the 10 tracks on I Miss the Jams would suggest that Smith put the tunes at least on par with all the trappings
column5: offering up a genial set of retro-minded rave-ups recorded in warm
column6: punchy mid-fi. Smith's sly wit and remarkably natural way with songcraft are very much in evidence here as they were on the Sunsets' LP
column7: but the songs here are simpler and
column8: accordingly
column9: more direct; the bawdy ""I Wanna Do It""
column10: featuring a brassy vocal from the Sandwitches' Heidi Alexander doesn't mince words
column11: while ""Teen Age Thugs""-- its verses in Spanish
column12: its chorus bored into your skull in English-- makes its point despite the potential language barrier. ""Broke Artist"" tells its tale of a skid row artist
column13: his similarly hard-luck benefactor
column14: and a run in on the wrong side of the tracks; Smith's best lyrics have a short-story quality about them anyway
column15: and it's nice to see him finding yet another way to marry his many passions on wax.

column1: Perhaps understandably
column2: the tunes do occasionally feel a tad like genre exercises-- ""Ain't No Turnin Back"" skiffles
column3: ""Back in the Day (I Can't Stand It)"" is straight British invasion R&B-- but Smith's such an unflappably cool songwriter than even borrowed clothes fit him like a glove. Like Tomorrow Is Alright
column4: I Miss the Jams is a remarkably blithe
column5: laid-back work
column6: the subtle charms of Smith's gently funny
column7: sneakily subversive songs occasionally taking a listen or two to sort themselves out. But there's a durability there that belies the fairly easy reference-grabbing and the slightly shrugged-off attitude on display; Smith's fairly unshowy
column8: trend-averse style may never win him the fanbase of some of his peppier
column9: more hook-forward left coasters
column10: but their clean lines and easy feel lends them a feeling of timelessness that seems like it ought to endure.

column1: For all the romantic notions of creative solitude in ""Broke Artist""
column2: Smith couldn't have made his big box happen without a good showing from the smoldering San Francisco indie rock scene
column3: who come out in droves here. Ty Segall takes it down a notch or four on the surfy ""One Way Doomsday Trip to Nowhere""
column4: Smith and the Fresh & Onlys' Tim Cohen attempt to out-deadpan each other on the otherwise rollicking ""Time to Split""
column5: and Kelley Stoltz fulfills his unspoken obligation to be on every San Fran record ever by appearing throughout. The spirit of community amongst this ragtag crew hasn't gone unremarked upon
column6: but it's definitely in full force here; although it's certainly Smith's record at the core
column7: it plays like a nice little overview of the San Francisco scene as it stands
column8: their unusually fresh and forward-looking take on shuffly mod-pop. Through it all
column9: Smith and company remain calm
column10: totally uncowed by the task at hand. With friends like those willing to help flesh out songs like these
column11:
Smith's wild-eyed devotion to this absurdly laborious project makes all the sense in the world.
